fields.headline: Captain Shearer says his goodbyes
fields.trailText: It was a night of farewells as the England team said goodbye to England with a 2-0 win over Ukraine, the captain Alan Shearer to Wembley and Kevin Keegan to the six players jettisoned from his squad after the team's penultimate warm-up game for Euro 2000.
fields.body:
It was a night of farewells as the England team said goodbye to England with a 2-0 win over Ukraine, the captain Alan Shearer to Wembley and Kevin Keegan to the six players jettisoned from his squad after the team's penultimate warm-up game for Euro 2000.

"It's a difficult time," said Shearer. "We've all shook hands with them, given them our sympathies and wished them all the best."

West Ham's defender Rio Ferdinand decided that the best way to treat the bad news was to "take it on the chin".

"Obviously I'm a bit dejected but I've just got to get on with it. I can't give you the reasons why I was dropped. You'll have to ask the gaffer.

"Luckily I've got time on my side. If I was 29 I'd have to be worried. I'll still be supporting the boys when they're away. I'll be the first one listening. And whoever is playing in my position, good luck to them."

Wembley cheered off the team as well, after a victory which hid plenty of deficiencies. However Shearer was never going to admit as much.

"I thought we played well against a technically excellent side," he said. "They gave us a few problems in the first 20 minutes, when they broke quickly. But we settled down and played some good football."

Ever loyal, Shearer is a proud leader whose decision to stand down from international football after Euro 2000 meant that this was his last England game on the hallowed turf.

"It was an emotional game from that point of view. I've had some great times here and some bad ones. The proudest moment of my career was walking out the first time as England captain. It's a memory I'll never forget."

A proud day, too, for Steven Gerrard on his debut. "I had loads of butterflies, and in the first 15 minutes Tony Adams was helping me get through that difficult stage," he said of the Arsenal captain, scorer of England's second goal. "He was just telling me where men were behind me and making sure I was in the right positions.

"But after that I thought I settled down and I enjoyed it. Now I just want more. Obviously I'm not really expecting to start games but I just want to play as big as part as I can. A year ago I could not dream of being in this position."

His Liverpool club-mate Robbie Fowler, scorer of the first goal but replaced at half-time, said: "I think that is the best I've felt for England."

And David Beckham declared himself happy if a bit tired after his outing at right wing-back. "It's hard work and requires a lot of running, but it's worth it to get this result. We're looking forward to the finals. It's going to be interesting over there." Never a truer word was spoken.

webTitle: Wednesday too poor to tempt me, says Kinnear

fields.headline: Wednesday too poor to tempt me, says Kinnear
fields.trailText: Joe Kinnear's planned return to football management with Sheffield Wednesday collapsed yesterday after a row over how much money will be required to return the Yorkshire club to the Premiership.
fields.body:
Joe Kinnear's planned return to football management with Sheffield Wednesday collapsed yesterday after a row over how much money will be required to return the Yorkshire club to the Premiership.

Wednesday immediately promoted the Preston North End manager David Moyes to the top of their short-list of candidates to succeed Danny Wilson.

Although Kinnear had promised to let the Wednesday chairman Howard Culley know by Tuesday evening whether or not he wished to accept a lucrative three-year contract, he asked for more time. Unfortunately for the former Wimbledon manager, time ran out at noon yesterday when he failed to respond to a deadline Culley had imposed.

Kinnear is believed to have told Culley he would require a budget of at least £10m to re-fashion a senior squad which underachieved on a regular basis en route to relegation this last season. But, with Wednesday £12m in debt, Culley was unable to satisfy Kinnear's demands.

Kinnear's agent, Jonathan Barnett, said: "I can confirm that Joe has rejected the chance to manage Sheffield Wednesday. The personal terms were fine but there were certain things he would need that weren't in place.

"With the problems that Sheffield Wednesday have had it would be virtually impossible to achieve what he wanted to achieve. He would only take the job if he thought he could get them back into the Premiership and he felt he could not do that with the predicament Sheffield Wednesday are in."

Kinnear suffered a heart attack 15 months ago, at Hillsborough shortly before a game between Wednesday and Wimbledon, and has been out of work since resigning as Wimbledon manager a year ago.

Although Moyes has now been offered the chance to restore a great club's pride, it is debatable whether the young Scot would be interested in taking on the task. Having led Preston to promotion from the Second Division last month, Moyes is arguably at the helm of a club with far greater potential than Wednesday, not least financially.

Moyes, who has more than two years of his contract to run at Deepdale, is widely acknowledged to be one of the brightest young managerial talents in English football and has, in the recent past, declined invitations to assume control at Nottingham Forest and Bristol City.

If Moyes declines Culley's offer and unless Kinnear swiftly alters his stance, Wednesday may make a move for the Huddersfield Town manager Steve Bruce, who began his career in management at Sheffield United.

British football's other great managerial saga, Martin O'Neill's proposed switch from Leicester City to Celtic, may be resolved later today. Having tired of O'Neill's apparent inability to make up his mind, Celtic are believed to have insisted on a decision by this afternoon.

After indicating, on Tuesday, that he wished to succeed John Barnes at Parkhead, O'Neill underwent one of his familiar changes of heart later that day and is now undecided about his future.

webTitle: My boss makes me feel bad

fields.headline: My boss makes me feel bad
fields.trailText: 1 June: I am really unhappy in my job but my boss makes me feel guilty if I take any time off to look for a new one.
fields.body:
The problem

I am really unhappy in my job. I have started looking for another job but whenever I arrange an interview the boss won't let me take time off because I am in charge and he's never there. He always makes me feel guilty if I take any time off.

The solution

Stop feeling guilty about taking time off. Stop right now! You are entitled to annual leave and the best way you could use it at the moment is by going for job interviews. Selection panels usually give a reasonable amount of notice (often up to a month) so simply inform your boss that you will be taking annual leave on that date - and go.

It could be that your boss is trying to prevent your finding another job because he can't manage without you. This is not your problem. Your problem is a job you are unhappy with and you are taking the right initial steps to overcome the problem - you just need to be assertive enough to follow it through.

I recommend you read a book on assertiveness because this will tell you your rights as well as techniques on how to assert yourself without being aggressive (or passive). My book, Psychology Goes to Work has a chapter on being assertive at work, or try Assertiveness At Work by K. Back or Assert Yourself by Gail Lindenfield.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

webTitle: Sainsbury sees no salvation in price cuts

fields.headline: Sainsbury sees no salvation in price cuts
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sir Peter Davis, Sainsbury's chief executive, yesterday identified quality as the platform on which Britain's second-biggest supermarket group intends to rebuild itself after reporting a 23.2% slide in pre-tax profits to £580m.
fields.body:
Sir Peter Davis, Sainsbury's chief executive, yesterday identified quality as the platform on which Britain's second-biggest supermarket group intends to rebuild itself after reporting a 23.2% slide in pre-tax profits to £580m.

Most of the decline was attributed to unimpressive earnings from the supermarket division. Fierce price competition from Tesco and Asda plus the squeeze on margins from lower food prices were blamed.

Added to these woes was the growing burden of Sainsbury's costs as it reorganised its store operations and streamlined management.

The company warned that profits would worsen in its supermarket division before they got better in the next year as it focused on improving the quality of service and product, and invested in improving administrative systems and replacing ageing depots.

However, Sir Peter ruled out entering a price war with Tesco and Asda to halt its slide in market share. "We are concentrating on bringing our UK supermarkets up to date to put Sainsbury back on track."

Sainsbury's shares fell 10.75% to 305p as one of its brokers, UBS Warburg, reduced its 2001 pre-tax forecast from £600m to £550m to account for increased investment in e-commerce and other costs.

Sir Peter rejected calls for financial targets by which any recovery could be measured. "I've only been here 92 days and that includes Saturdays and Sundays. Until I have a better feel on these things there's no benefit in putting my neck on the line."

Sainsbury is boosting its capital expenditure forecast this year from £803m to £900m, some of which will go on a new food and drink portal, Taste for Life. The majority, however, will be for the extension and refurbishment of 50 stores.

Sir Peter said Sainsbury was attempting to gain ground on Tesco, which has taken a lead in the race to dominate the internet shopping market, by spending more than £50m upgrading its internet services this year.

Sainsbury's group sales grew 6.3% to £17.4bn in the year to April 3. Supermarket stores revenues gained only 1.8% in the year as operating profit for that division fell 27.2% to £542m.

Homebase sales grew 10% in the year although operating profit dropped 13.4% to £64.6m and Shaw's had comparable sales growth of 3.1% as operating profits rose from £53.4m to £80m.

Contrary to recent speculation, there were no plans for the group to sell its Homebase DIY chain, US grocery business Shaw's or its banking arm, Mr Davis said.

Sainsbury's Bank returned to a £2.9m operating profit compared with a £5.1m loss in the previous year.

Expansion in the supermarket chain and e-commerce business this year would create around 5,000 jobs, Mr Davis said. The group is building 13 new supermarkets.

fields.headline: Dixons heightens Freeserve fever
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Dixons' attempts to whip up a frenzy among potential bidders for its 80% stake in Freeserve were given added urgency yesterday when it was reported that the retailer has set a 10-day deadline for offers to be lodged.
fields.body:
Dixons' attempts to whip up a frenzy among potential bidders for its 80% stake in Freeserve were given added urgency yesterday when it was reported that the retailer has set a 10-day deadline for offers to be lodged.

Goldman Sachs, the investment bank that is thought to have been appointed by Dixons to review the future of its holding, is believed to have made the move amid intense speculation that T-Online, the Deutsche Telekom-backed internet service provider, is poised to make a £6bn offer for Freeserve.

NTL, Terra Networks of Spain, British Telecommunications and Energis have all been mentioned as possible counter-bidders, although T-Online remains favourite.

Both Dixons and Freeserve refused to comment, but analysts believe that by placing a deadline for bids Dixons hopes to flush out as many interested parties as possible and create an auction process.

"It's clear Dixons is looking to generate as much interest as possible, and you can hardly blame them," said one analyst, who refused to be named.

Dixons has given a series of undertakings not to sell any of its shares in Freeserve before the latter announces its maiden full-year results on June 27.

Even then it is unable to off-load its entire holding for another year.

However, analysts believe that, given the volatility of Freeserve shares - which have fluctuated in price between 135p and 950p since they began trading last summer - any bid that offered a significant premium to the present price might be waved through by the stock exchange.

Freeserve shares were trading at 400p before news of Goldman Sachs' involvement leaked, and last night they closed up 42p at 530p, fuelled by bid speculation. Analysts believe 600p to 650p could be enough to tempt Dixons, as long as any offer contained enough cash and liquid securities in what is expected to be a paper-based deal.

fields.headline: Heartbreak House
fields.standfirst:
Chichester Festival Theatre
***
fields.trailText:
Chichester Festival Theatre
***
fields.body:
Everything is just a touch too sunny in Christopher Morahan's handsome production, which pitches George Bernard Shaw's story about a ship of fools heading for the rocks of disaster more as a Wildean comedy than a Chekhovian drama. There is no underlying anxiety or hidden foreboding.

Even at the end, as the characters face the abyss of the first world war and the bombers of retribution fly across the South Downs, these people greet oblivion with a kind of ecstasy, still totally unaware that the cultured, leisured world as they know it is about to end abruptly . John Gunter's set, with its bleached sun decks and figurehead of a blindfolded woman, makes the point very neatly.

Written in 1916 at the savage height of the Great War, but not performed until 1920, Shaw's "Fantasia in the Russian Manner on English Themes" is shot through with an anger at the complacency of people who have brains, income and all the time in the world but not the wit to save themselves and others from catastrophe.

The line-up of characters, from the vulgar capitalist, the young girl trying on different attitudes for size, the enterprising burglar, the fantasist and the siren is just a little too neat, and as ever Shaw is a windbag and always says everything twice when once would have done very nicely.

But as David Hare, who directed a memorable production of the play at the Almeida, has pointed out, this is the original state-of-the-nation play, and it is also a rare and satisfying example of a Shavian drama in which private meets public - but more unusually, in which heart and head are also joined.

It is a hell of a play to cast evenly, though, and there are highs and lows here: Joss Ackland's Captain Shotover, more cuddly seadog than mystic, is a little too winning, Anna Carteret's Lady Utterwood too arch and Susannah Wise's Ellie Dunn almost entirely without illusion. But Clare Higgins is utterly irresistible as the bewitching Hesione Hushabye, giving a big, bold and brave performance that persuades you that this is a woman who might indeed be foolish but who also lives her life like a candle lit at both ends. One that is about to be snuffed out.

 Till August 12. Box office: 023-8071 1818.

fields.headline: Look back in death
fields.standfirst:
The Waiting Room
Cottesloe Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
The Waiting Room
Cottesloe Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
Tanika Gupta's new play, developed in the National Theatre Studio, is an intriguing mix of the mystical and the mundane. At its best it reminds me of a now-forgotten 30s expressionist piece by JB Priestley, Johnson over Jordan: at its least inspired, it settles for the quick domestic fixes I associate with soaps.

Gupta's subject is death and loss in a British-based Indian family. Her heroine, Priya, has suffered a fatal stroke. While she is in transit to the other world, accompanied by an immortal in the guise of a famous Bollywood star, her soul wanders unseen among her surviving family; and what she discovers are the failures of her life. She has squandered her education to settle for the role of an academic's subordinate wife; and, while her son harbours resentment at his neglect, her high-flying daughter has kept from her a crucial secret.

As Priya's soul goes walkabout, too many skeletons come tumbling out of the cupboard: her adulterous liaison with her brother-in-law, the death of her third child, her daughter's closeted sexual life. You feel Priya's three-day period of transition is being used to clear up more unresolved plot-lines than you'll find in EastEnders.

What moves one is the basic premise of a dead woman grieving over her past life and sense of unfulfilment; also her gnaw ing feeling that "my death leaves very little behind". But Priya's pensive gloom is countered by the prospect of rebirth offered by her immortal supervisor. And one of the best things about Indhu Rubasingham's production is the constantly shifting relationship between Shabana Azmi's emotionally prying Priya and Kulvinder Ghir's celestial guide: Azmi's star-struck adoration gives way to truculent impatience and finally to resigned dependence.

The production also looks good thanks to Ruari Murchison's design in which a suburban sitting-room gives on to a smoke-filled curving staircase that seems to lead to paradise. And Nadim Sawalha as Priya's oppressive academic husband and Raad Rawi as his photographer-brother neatly suggest a lifelong sibling rivalry. Gupta, who has written extensively for the Soho Theatre and for television, still has plenty to learn about drama's need for narrative tension and orchestrated climaxes. But her play catches touchingly the sense of disappointment that runs through most lives as well as the possibility of spiritual redemption.

 In rep until June 21. Box office: 020-7452 3000. This review appeared in some editions yesterday.

fields.headline: Scapegoat wanted
fields.standfirst:
Send for Mr Plim/The Seven Deadly Sins
Peacock Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Send for Mr Plim/ The Seven Deadly Sins
Peacock Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
Mischa Spoliansky's operetta Send for Mr Plim caused something of a stir last year when a version of it - reorchestrated and with some additions - opened at London's BAC. The Covent Garden festival has now put on a new production, albeit in English (a very funny translation by Kenneth Richardson), though reverting to Spolian sky's original score. It proves a disturbing piece, for beneath its surface froth lurks chilling irony. Spoliansky, one of the greats of Weimar Republic cabaret (he put Marlene Dietrich on the map long before she was discovered by Josef von Sternberg), wrote it in 1932. It has been interpreted as anti-capitalist satire, which is only partly true, for its real subject - to which history has given a horrid resonance - is a vision of a society seeking a scapegoat for its every failing. The setting is a Berlin department store where the impoverished Plim is hired so that the management can make a show of firing him whenever one of the customers (a line-up of ghastly plutocrats) lodges a complaint. The Chaplinesque Plim screws up and is eventually sacked in earnest before the management realise that he is indispensable.

"Shopworkers can't sing of great emotion, not like at the opera," Plim comments - but Spoliansky uses the material to spoof almost every operatic convention going. The store's managers connive in Rossinian patter, Caroline von Recklitz, "president of the Women's Institute of Spandau" extols the beauty of an out-of-stock chamber pot with Wagenerian heft. Elida de Coty, a stroppy international vamp, is the coloratura soprano to end coloratura sopranos. It is a delicious score and the Covent Garden festival did it proud with a witty staging by Paul Curran that allowed a number of well-known British singers to send themselves up rotten. Harry Nicoll was a wonderfully nerdy Plim. Frances McCafferty brought the house down as Caroline. Best of the lot was Lilian Watson's Elida, camping it up in a mink coat and spangles and flinging out top Es as if it were the easiest thing in the world.

Coupling it with Weill's The Seven Deadly Sins seemed like a good idea, but here things were not so hot. Curran's staging lacked focus. The dancers, Maxine Fone and Andrew George, using their own choreography, indulged in a lot of sub-Kenneth Macmillan erotic grappling when it was not always needed. The BBC Concert Orchestra under Robert Ziegler played it to perfection, but Marie McLaughlin, got up like Joan Crawford, came unstuck in places as Anna, unaccountably so, since she has sung the role in London before and been, in the past, one of its finest interpreters.

fields.headline: B&B raises windfall hopes
fields.standfirst:
Forecasts higher than expected despite recent decline in banking share prices
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: More than 2.5m members of Bradford & Bingley building society will each receive windfalls estimated at between £647 and £815 when the society converts to a bank in December.
fields.body:
More than 2.5m members of Bradford & Bingley building society will each receive windfalls estimated at between £647 and £815 when the society converts to a bank in December.

The figures are contained in the society's transfer document, published yesterday, which puts B&B's estimated market value at between £1.75bn and £2.2bn.

The forecasts are higher than some analysts had been predicting in recent months. Since banking shares have fallen on the stock market there have been suggestions that the payouts could be worth as little as £350. But the figure is much lower than the unofficial estimate of £1,000, which was suggested last year.

B&B is turning into a bank after members defied the wishes of the board by voting overwhelmingly in favour of carpetbagging plumber Stephen Major's conversion resolution in April 1999. There will be a special meeting of members to approve the plans on July 17 at Sheffield Arena.

If all goes ahead as planned, the society will float on the stock market on December 4. For this to happen, at least 75% of savers and 51% of borrowers must vote in favour.

Little more than a year ago the society was warning members that if it converted to a bank "we would be working for the City and our new corporate shareholders instead of working for you".

But the message now is very different. "Little about Bradford & Bingley and how we deal with customers will change as a result of conversion," says the chairman, Lindsay Mackinlay, in the information pack for members.

B&B has opted for a flat-rate share distribution scheme whereby every member receives the same windfall, regardless of the size of financial relationship with the society. In all, 2.2m adult savers and 350,000 mortgage customers will benefit, plus 129,000 children and 10,000 trustee account holders. The midpoint between £647 and £815 is £731.

However, some observers say there could be a question mark over whether B&B will achieve the estimated market value quoted in the transfer document. Goldman Sachs, the society's adviser, said its estimate of the market capitalisation of the company was based on a theoretical flotation on December 31, 1999. But British banking shares are now 6% lower than at the end of last year.

The society acknowledges in the document that there has been "significant volatility" in share prices within the retail banking sector since the end of last year. But it goes on to say that nevertheless the board believes there is a "reasonable likelihood" that in late April this year, when the transfer document was being put together, B&B would have had a market value within the range given. It also discloses that the cost of flotation is likely to be £68m.

The society has been dogged by speculation that it could become the target of a predator or might decide to put itself up for sale. But it said that it had not received any takeover or merger approaches and added that the board had unanimously decided that conversion to a plc was the best way forward.

The society has set itself the objective of becoming "the leading independent national distributor of financial and property services", with an emphasis on "choice and independent advice". It has 630 independent financial advisers and in February it acquired mortgage broker John Charcol.

fields.headline: Cheques and balances
fields.standfirst: Clearing cheques only after 11 days is just one of many ways that British banks make money out of their customers without actually charging them to hold an account, writes Money Unlimited editor Marianne Curphey
fields.trailText: Clearing cheques after only 11 days is just one of many ways that British banks make money out of their customers without actually charging them to hold an account, writes Money Unlimited editor Marianne Curphey
fields.body:
Every couple of years the high street banks gently raise the prospect of bringing to an end the concept of "free banking" which we enjoy in the UK.

Perhaps one of them brings out a premium account with special add-ons like travel insurance and a theatre ticket booking facility in return for an annual or monthly fee.

Maybe another introduces an account where you pay a few pounds a month in order drastically to increase your overdraft level, so that the facility is there if you need it.

The incentive provided by the bank for the latter is usually that penalties for exceeding your authorised overdraft are likely to be hefty.

The aim in both cases is to soften us up for the end of free banking for current accounts in credit.

We've always had to pay handsomely for overdraft facilities, even when our average monthly balance is regularly well in the black.

But it irks the banks that in the US customers pay for some current accounts, in this country banks feel obliged to offer them for free.

So it comes as little surprise that , according to the Consumers' Association report, banks rip off customers by more than £20m a year by failing to clear cheques for up to 11 days.

Banks make money from the difference between the savings rate they offer you and the borrowing rate at which they will lend you money.

Some of the banks' most popular savings accounts pay measly rates of interest, while research has shown that the most competitive mortgage rates are often from small mutual building societies, rather than the high-street banks.

Slowing down the cheque clearing process is just another way to make money out of customers without actually making them pay directly for their current accounts.

The growth of internet accounts, with banks competing aggressively for new customers, has so far had little effect on the charges levied by the high street banks.

Instead of lowering charges for branch-based customers as well as internet customers, many of the banks have launched new brands instead. This allows them to offer different rates and charges from their high-street products.

But as the number of people switching to the internet grows, this anomaly is unlikely to able to continue, and that can only be good news for the consumer.

webTitle: Banks are profiting from cheque clearance delay

fields.headline: Banks are profiting from cheque clearance delay
fields.trailText: An antiquated cheque clearing system is allowing UK banks to make large profits on interest payments while customers are made to wait for up to 11 days for their cheques to clear, according to a report published today.
fields.body:
An antiquated cheque clearing system is allowing UK banks to make large profits on interest payments while customers are made to wait for up to 11 days for their cheques to clear, according to a report published today.

The Consumers' Association says that the outdated process is failing consumers, in an age of high speed electronic communications, and is calling on the government to set up an independent regulator of payment systems.

According to the report, published in Which? magazine, it takes three days for a cheque to pass through the clearing system, while some consumers have to wait as long as another eight days before they can access their money.

Which? says that not only do these delays cause frustration to customers, but banks and building societies can earn interest on their customers' money while denying them access to their cash.

A report, commissioned by the government on UK banking services, has concluded that systems for cheque clearing and electronic transfers of money are stuck in the 19th century, and the UK is falling behind other countries, mainly because the major banks control the payments systems, which stifles competition and innovation.

The Consumers' Association arranged for 22 volunteers to pay in 440 cheques to the top 11 institutions. More than a quarter of the cheques failed to clear by the time the banks claimed they would.

All the cheques paid into Barclays and NatWest cleared a day later than they should have. Half the cheques paid into Lloyds TSB cleared a day late, as did a quarter of those paid into the Co-Operative Bank, HSBC and Nationwide.

While some banks let customers withdraw the money from their current account on day four, Alliance and Leicester, Bank of Scotland, Northern Rock, the Royal Bank of Scotland, Yorkshire Bank and the Woolwich all make customers wait five days.

Bristol & West is the slowest for savings accounts, with customers having to wait 11 days. Asked for justification the bank said it used another bank to clear cheques.

Which? also found that consumers got a raw deal when transferring money electronically. An electronic payment leaves the payer's account on day one but can take until day four to arrive in the payee's account, if they bank at different institutions. In contrast, money paid by consumers to businesses by direct debit is credited to the company's account on the same day.

The report says the delay in clearing cheques is caused because the 8m cheques written each day are posted around the country, while bounced cheques are also returned by mail - so the bank has to wait for the post to arrive before it can be sure that it can pay a cheque.

Which? editor Graeme Jacobs said it was not in the banks' interest to change the system.

"Unfortunately banks benefit from this delay - in most cases they receive the money before letting you get at it, in which time they invest and earn interest on it. Given that banks are profiting in this way, it is hardly surprising that they are not pushing to bounce cheques electronically.

"This is one of the ways in which banks are short changing their customers, and it is about time they were forced to act more fairly," he added.

fields.headline: 'Star' bankers league abandoned
fields.standfirst:
Cult of the individual should be avoided, say merger specialists
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The ego has crash-landed. Plans to produce a league table naming the bankers behind London's biggest merger deals were dropped yesterday after the securities company which drew up the list caved in to pressure from the big investment banks.
fields.body:
The ego has crash-landed. Plans to produce a league table naming the bankers behind London's biggest merger deals were dropped yesterday after the securities company which drew up the list caved in to pressure from the big investment banks.

Management at the companies who put together the multibillion-pound deals protested to Thomson Financial Securities Data that the list would simply provide headhunters with a ready-made shopping list, forcing them to pay higher salaries in order to keep their top people on board.

Marketmerger.com, which already produces a league table and held an awards dinner for London's senior bankers earlier this month, said it got around hostility from the investment houses by going directly to its clients for information instead.

Charlie Welsh, director and founder of Marketmerger.com, said: "We understand that the banks are concerned about the 'star culture' - however, it is the companies who are asking us for this because they want to know who is advising on deals and on potential conflicts of interest."

A roll call of well known merger and acquisition banks, including Deutsche Bank, Goldman Sachs, Lehman Brothers, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and UBS Warburg, is believed to have scuppered Thomson Financial Securities Data's plan.

"Following consultation with a group of the leading financial advisers... Thomson Financial has decided not to compile or publish rankings of named individual financial advisers," Miranda McLean, marketing director at Thomson Financial said yesterday.

The merger and acquisition banks were worried about the development of a cult of the individual in an industry they insist depends on teamwork.

"We continue to work to ensure the emphasis remains on the team and egotism does not have a role in this," Heino Teschmacher, co-head of European M&A at Swiss-owned UBS Warburg said in a statement published yesterday by Thomson Financial.

Other objections include the security implications of bankers being named as some of the best paid people in the world, particularly those operating in countries such as Italy, which has a reputation for kidnappings, and the emerging markets of east Europe, Asia and south America.

Thomson Financial said it had not been expecting the groundswell of professional opposition to the planned statistics, and was surprised by how quickly the banks - renowned for pulling each other down a peg when possible - rallied against the plan.

fields.headline: Turner steps aside at CNN
fields.standfirst:
Merger sees helmsman surrender control

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Media mogul Ted Turner has lost control of CNN along with the other Turner cable networks as the news channel celebrates its 20th anniversary.
fields.body:
Media mogul Ted Turner has lost control of CNN along with the other Turner cable networks as the news channel celebrates its 20th anniversary.

Putting on a brave face regarding the restructuring of AOL Time Warner at CNN's anniversary celebration in Atlanta yesterday, Mr Turner said: "At the current time CNN reports to me and I'm very proud of all of our accomplishments. There's nothing I've ever been prouder of. But only the rocks last forever."

The new corporate line-up, operational once the $143bn (£96bn) AOL Time Warner merger is finalised in the autumn, leaves Mr Turner with the new title of "senior adviser". Combining this with a vice-chairmanship of the global media corporation means he surrenders all executive control of the networks he has nurtured since launching TBS, his first American cable venture, in 1976.

Taking over Mr Turner's mantle on the broadcast side of the new company is the relatively unknown Bob Pittman, president and chief operating officer of AOL. He steps up to become co-chief operating of ficer of AOL Time Warner, overseeing all the group's pay-TV channels.

Dick Parsons also becomes co-chief operating officer of the company with responsibility for AOL Time Warner's content businesses, including film and television production, music and book publishing.

Both Mr Pittman and Mr Parsons will report to AOL Time Warner chief executive Gerald Levin, while Steve Case chairs the group.

Also taking a vice-chairmanship alongside Mr Turner is Kenneth Novack, the vice-chairman of AOL.

The new structure confirms what many within the Turner-Time Warner group have suspected for a while - that Mr Turner, distracted from the day to day business of his broadcasting empire by his recent divorce from the actor Jane Fonda, is stepping back from the front line.

Famous for ruling his news empire with a rod of iron - the staff are banned from smoking because Ms Fonda won Mr Turner over to the anti-tobacco lobby during their nine-year marriage - he has inspired his team of journalists since CNN first launched on July 1, 1980.

The network, derided at launch as the "chicken noodle network", was the world's first 24-hour news channel when it began and it now reaches 150m homes in 212 countries.

Also under Turner's control before the reshuffle were US and international cable networks TBS, TNT and eight different versions of CNN.

Since Turner Broadcasting merged with Time Warner in 1996, other networks such as HBO and the Cartoon Network have bolstered the media group's empire.

At CNN's celebrations in its home town yesterday, Mr Turner was reluctant to comment on his future at AOL Time Warner. "I couldn't stay here forever anyway. You get too old or you die."

Asked what life would be like without CNN, he said: "There was a time when there was no CNN and Turner was doing OK, so I guess I could live without it again."

Speculation in Atlanta suggested that AOL Time Warner chief executive Gerald Levin had orchestrated the restructuring to sideline Mr Turner at a time when the new company is desperate to capitalise on its new power in the international media markets.

fields.headline: Brimson case exposes bunker mentality
fields.trailText: Engel on cricket Perhaps Wisden should employ a full-time penis-spotter, though for the past 137 years there has been a degree of trust between professionals that made this unnecessary.
fields.body:
It is always unpleasant returning to matters of private grief, particularly when it happens to be one's own. However, it is necessary to update you on the subject of Matthew Brimson's penis.

Brimson, you may recall, is the 29-year-old Leicestershire cricketer who apparently exposed himself in the team picture that appeared in the 2000 edition of Wisden. This was discovered, to the chagrin of Wis den's editor (myself), a week after the almanack was published. The story - and indeed the picture - was then picked up by almost every national newspaper. There was 24 hours worth of fun, then the world forgot about it.

Including, so it seemed, Leicestershire County Cricket Club. We had written very mildly to the club chairman, one Roger Goadby, to protest. There was a difficult conversation with the county's new secretary, James Whitaker, which ended - so I thought - with him promising that Brimson would apologise to us and, most particularly, to the photographer.

I sat back expecting a call, like the detective in the Lucan case the morning after the murder, who assumed that within hours Lord Lucan would turn himself in. Nothing happened. The only word was an announcement that Brimson was giving up cricket later this year to become a school teacher. Biology, perhaps.

A month later another letter went off - tetchier this time - to Goadby, asking why he had not the courtesy to reply. Last week he sent an extraordinary reply, saying that Brimson "denied any impropriety whatsoever" and that he had been ordered not to apologise. It was my fault, for publishing a photograph "capable of misinterpretation"; anyway, it could not have happened, because the picture was taken in 1999 and it was "inconceivable" that it would not have become public knowledge earlier.

Well, perhaps Wisden should employ a full-time penis-spotter, though for the past 137 years there has been a degree of trust between professionals that made this unnecessary. And it is possible, as I have said from the start, that we are all mistaken: that the object on the site of Brimson's crotch is indeed something else. The score, however, at present seems to be several million newspaper readers on one side of the argument (plus those who have seen the - forgive me - enlarged print), and Goadby on the other.

Perhaps he does have an explanation of the position of Brimson's right hand, and his silly grin. Anyway, nearly two months have passed; no explanation, credible or otherwise, has been offered - and certainly no apology.

I mention this because it seems to me to have implications way beyond both Brimson's crotch and my anger that a volume dedicated to the Five Cricketers of the Century should have been spoiled by someone like him. The apparent prank, and Leicestershire's handling of the aftermath, say quite a bit about the state of modern cricket.

Leicestershire, though successful on the field, are a very ill-supported county. Brimson, like most modern English players, will have played most of his cricket in front of tiny attendances. Maybe cricketers have been exposing them selves for years and no one has noticed. During Brimson's fairly ordinary career even the number of autograph hunters has dwindled to nothingness. He will hardly ever have been recognised on the streets: the pleasures and responsibilities that come from being a public figure have been denied to him.

County cricketers do not normally emerge from the local community either; Brimson was a Londoner. Helmeted while batting, anonymous at all times, they get their culture and their sustenance from the closed dressing room. Why else do they always raise their bat so excitedly to their team-mates, with the most perfunctory acknowledgment of anyone else?

Most of them spend their winters overseas, playing cricket. I doubt whether they meet enough potential cricket-watchers to understand why people are not watching it.

Leicestershire have even recruited the new club secretary from inside the dressing room, a move which may not open up their view of the world. In the enclosed world of county cricket it is easy to see how a private joke could spill into the public domain without anyone seeing what is wrong.

In dressing rooms far away a much nastier culture has arisen, in which the fixing of international matches has become accepted behaviour. Incomparably worse offences, of course; different places; larger crowds. But a similar bunker mentality; the same loss of touch with the public.

fields.headline: Adams fined for pushing Law
fields.trailText: Sussex's captain Chris Adams has been fined £500 by the England and Wales Cricket Board and warned as to his future conduct after being found guilty of pushing the Essex all-rounder Danny Law during a Benson & Hedges Cup match at Chelmsford last month.
fields.body:
Sussex's captain Chris Adams has been fined £500 by the England and Wales Cricket Board and warned as to his future conduct after being found guilty of pushing the Essex all-rounder Danny Law during a Benson & Hedges Cup match at Chelmsford last month.

A further charge of verbally abusing Law was dismissed. Adams was ordered to pay an additional £250 towards the cost of the hearing.

Following the incident towards the end of a qualifying match on April 24, Adams, whose century had put his side on the road to a substantial win, had been reported to the ECB by the England captain Nasser Hussain after consultation with Essex officials.

Nothing untoward had been detected by spectators, media or umpires but the Essex bowler Mark Ilott, himself fined £1,000 three years ago after a shoving match with Robert Croft during a NatWest Trophy semi-final, was apparently incensed by what he saw.

Law had hit a waist-high full toss to mid-on, where he was caught, but queried if it should not have been called a no-ball. It was while one umpire, Vanburn Holder, was consulting the other, Tony Clarkson, that the altercation took place.

"Chris did something that seriously upset my team and I had to back them up," Hussain said at the time.

Adams received the full backing of his county, whom he joined controversially from Derbyshire at the end of the 1997 season. At Hove they speak highly of his dedication to the task of improving Sussex cricket. But, while he has always been a competitive cricketer, he has occasionally displayed a capacity to cross the boundary into churlishness.

Earlier this month he disputed an lbw decision by the umpire David Constant with such vigour that it was deemed surprising no further action was taken.

 Indian detectives will be allowed to question the disgraced former South African captain Hansie Cronje as part of their match-fixing inquiry. Cronje and his team-mates, Herschelle Gibbs, Nicky Boje and Pieter Strydom, were charged in April by Indian police with criminal conspiracy, fraud and cheating in relation to the one-day series against India in March.

webTitle: Hutchison has all the answers for Scots

fields.headline: Hutchison has all the answers for Scots
fields.standfirst:
Republic of Ireland 1
Kennedy 2
Scotland 2
Hutchison 15, Ferguson 27
fields.trailText: Scotland last night recovered from a devastating opening to triumph in their first meeting with the Irish in 13 years after Everton's Don Hutchison executed and then created two goals in 12 minutes.
fields.body:
Scotland last night recovered from a devastating opening to triumph in their first meeting with the Irish in 13 years after Everton's Don Hutchison executed and then created two goals in 12 minutes.

The Republic could not have wished for a better start when their captain Niall Quinn was brought down by Christian Dailly after only two minutes.

The Manchester City winger Mark Kennedy let fly from 20-yards with the ensuing free-kick. The ball took a nasty deflection off Craig Burley, giving Tottenham's new goalkeeper Neil Sullivan no chance.

Scotland refused to be alarmed and Hutchison put his country level on 16 minutes. A probing ball from Burley found Neil McCann on the left and his low cross was steered home from close range by the alert Everton player.

Sullivan was fortunate after 20 minutes when he could only palm away a cross from Kevin Kilbane inches past Quinn when the striker looked certain to put the Irish back in front.

With Matt Elliott in outstanding form for Scotland in the centre of defence, it came as no real surprise when his side took the lead on the half-hour.

Hutchison stepped past a feeble challenge by Phil Babb and squared the ball into the crowded goalmouth. Stephen Carr and Billy Dodds fought for possession with the ball rebounding off Gary Breen. Barry Ferguson made no mistake, shooting from close range past Alan Kelly.

Hutchison, always a threat to the Irish defence, nearly added a third Scottish goal with a free-kick after a foul by Babb. But this time Kelly was down to save at the second attempt.

Scotland went close to grabbing a third goal just after the interval when Hutchison carved open the Irish defence. But his low cross was missed by McCann when the substitute Kevin Gallacher looked in a better position to score.

Five Irish corners in a row failed to unlock a resolute Scots' defence although Sullivan had two anxious moments dealing with Quinn's aerial threat.

The big Sunderland striker winning his 76th cap, almost forced an equaliser in the 65th minute. But Elliott was again back to prevent his header entering the net.

The Irish went all out for the equaliser when Kilbane made a marvellous 40-yard burst. But again Elliott came to Scotland's rescue with a timely interception.

Republic of Ireland (4-4-2): Kelly ( Blackburn); Carr (Tottenham), Breen (Coventry; Foley , Watford, 77min), Babb (Liverpool), Kilbane (Sunderland); McAteer (Blackburn), Finnan (Fulham), McPhail (Leeds; Phelan, Fulham, 62), Kennedy (Man C; Duff , Blackburn, 62); Quinn (Sunderland; Dunne , Everton, 77), Keane (Coventry).

Scotland (3-5-2): Sullivan (Tottenham); Dailly (Blackburn), Elliott (Leicester), O'Neill (Wolfsburg); Burley (Derby), Ferguson , (Rangers), Lambert (Celtic; Johnston , Bolton, 75), Naysmith (Hearts), McCann (Rangers); Dodds ((Rangers; Gallacher , Newcastle, 46), Hutchison (Everton).

Referee: V De Melo Pereira (Portugal).

webTitle: Barthez deal on hold as United play it safe

fields.headline: Barthez deal on hold as United play it safe
fields.trailText: Fabien Barthez will hold further talks with Manchester United today in the hope of concluding his transfer from Monaco after the two parties failed to reach agreement on a £9.5m move despite 12 hours of negotiations.
fields.body:
Fabien Barthez will hold further talks with Manchester United today in the hope of concluding his transfer from Monaco after the two parties failed to reach agreement on a £9.5m move despite 12 hours of negotiations.

Initially problems with medical tests seemed to be holding up the transfer but a bigger stumbling block now appears to be personal terms. Barthez and his advisers were expecting to agree a six-year contract worth around £40,000 a week yesterday, but several contract wrangles have yet to be resolved.

"We are still in discussions with both Monaco and the player on several matters," United's deputy chief executive Peter Kenyon said last night.

United's manager Sir Alex Ferguson had also been keen to complete the deal yesterday, but he is acutely aware, after the breakdown of Ruud van Nistelrooy's transfer from PSV Eindhoven last month, that Barthez suffered a number of injuries for Monaco last season.

The 28-year-old had his medical at a private hospital in Cheadle yesterday morning before further tests in the afternoon, with particular emphasis given to an area behind his left knee where he had an operation last October.

"I'm confident we will be given the go-ahead by the doctors to complete this transfer," said Ferguson, before leaving for a break to the United States.

 Leeds have appointed Manchester United's former assistant manager Brian Kidd, who was sacked as manager of Blackburn in November, as their director of youth development.

fields.headline: Arsenal snap up £7m Lauren
fields.trailText: Arsenal have completed the £7m transfer of the Cameroon international Lauren from Mallorca.
fields.body:
Arsenal have completed the £7m transfer of the Cameroon international Lauren from Mallorca.

The 23-year-old, who was the player of the tournament at the African Nations Cup earlier this year, has agreed a long-term contract and will join up with his new team-mates for pre-season training in July.

"He is a versatile player, comfortable in both defence and midfield," said Arsenal's manager Arsène Wenger. "He possesses strong, physical power as well as great stamina."

The 27-year-old Brazilian left-back Roberto Carlos will remain with the Champions League winners Real Madrid after signing a new contract worth £10m over five years.

Roy Hodgson is to take charge of the Danish side Copenhagen, while the former German international sweeper Matthias Sammer, 32, has been named as the manager of Borussia Dortmund.

Gabriel Batistuta has confirmed that he will be leaving Fiorentina for Roma in a £22m deal after nine years in Florence. The 31-year-old striker is set to earn about £3m a year. Fiorentina have though gained a new coach, Fatih Terim, who guided Galatasaray to victory in the Uefa Cup last season.

Turkey have included Tugay Kerimoglu of Rangers and Leicester's Muzzy Izzet in their squad for Euro 2000.

Turkey squad: Goalkeepers: Recber (Fenerbahce), Tuncay (Besiktas), Catkic (Gaziantepspor). Defenders: Akyel, Unsal (both Galatasaray), Ozalan , Temizkanoglu (both Fenerbahce), Ozkoylu (Trabzonspor). Midfielders: Umit, Okan, Ergun, Yalcin, Suat (all Galatasaray), Ercan (Fenerbahce), Akman , Tayfur (both Besiktas), Tugay (Rangers), Korkut (Real Sociedad), Izzet (Leicester). Strikers: Sukur, Arif (both Galatasaray), Derelioglu (Gaziantepspor).

webTitle: England tickets go on sale - but not to English

fields.headline: England tickets go on sale - but not to English
fields.trailText: The release of additional tickets for Euro 2000 descended into farce yesterday as the Belgian and Dutch governments banned English supporters from receiving the extra tickets for England's game with Romania in Charleroi.
fields.body:
The release of additional tickets for Euro 2000 descended into farce yesterday as the Belgian and Dutch governments banned English supporters from receiving the extra tickets for England's game with Romania in Charleroi.

Turkish fans have also been barred from purchasing any extra tickets for their side's games against Italy, Sweden and Belgium - a legacy of the ugly scenes at the Uefa Cup final in Copenhagen earlier this month.

The restrictive decision was taken last week but was made public only as fans, including some who had travelled from England, began queuing to buy tickets.

On a day of box-office chaos the tournament organisers struggled to cope with the massive demand for the remaining 48,000 tickets, the majority of which had been returned by foreign football associations.

They covered 17 games - including two of the quarter-finals, one of which could involve England - and were to be released from two sales points in Belgium and Holland and via special telephone lines at 9am yesterday.

Problems began when the local authority in Brussels refused permission for tickets to be sold from the allocated Belgian sales point at the Vorst-Nationaal arena.

"We found an alternative option in Liège but it would only become operational from next Monday," said Jan de Grave, a Euro 2000 spokesman. "Clearly this caused some problems but we felt it better to let sales go ahead in Holland rather than postpone things."

"It was chaos," said a local resident John Chapman, one of the fans who arrived at Vorst-Nationaal to find the gates locked. "There were people milling around not knowing what to do."

While sales at the second distribution point, in Rotterdam, went more smoothly, chaos reigned on the telephone lines which were overloaded with callers.

Only 20 lines had been set up and the few punters who made it through to the automatic answering system were thwarted by a recorded message asking them to try again later.

Richard van der Eijk, a spokesman for Euro 2000 in the Netherlands, admitted they had been taken unawares, "but we will be expanding the system tenfold so, when sales resume on Wednesday, we should be able to cope."

webTitle: O'Neill: my indecision is final for the moment

fields.headline: O'Neill: my indecision is final for the moment
fields.trailText: The managerial plot thickened last night as Celtic and Leicester City battled over the services of Martin O'Neill.
fields.body:
The managerial plot thickened last night as Celtic and Leicester City battled over the services of Martin O'Neill.

Although O'Neill was expected to be confirmed as the Scottish club's new manager yesterday lunchtime, a formal announcement - and accompanying press conference - was cancelled when the unpredictable Irishman had second thoughts about becoming Celtic's fifth manager in as many years.

Despite O'Neill's feelings of loyalty to Leicester, it is likely he will join the club he has supported since childhood, quite possibly in the next 24 hours.

Celtic faced ending yesterday with egg-covered faces after O'Neill - true to form - began to doubt the wisdom of a decision he had reached late on Monday night after all manner of soul-searching.

Celtic did not confirm reports of O'Neill's imminent installation as successor to John Barnes, even though the normally circumspect Press Association announced at 9.58am that he had definitely agreed to move north of the border.

However, inside two hours it became clear O'Neill's mind was not made up. He entered further negotiations with the persuasive Leicester chairman John Elsom.

As Celtic hinted at damage-limitation, speculation mounted that O'Neill was about to confirm he would honour the remaining years of his Leicester contract.

But it is believed O'Neill emerged from his meeting with Elsom late yesterday afternoon and headed for London to reopen talks with understandably confused Celtic officials.

This is not the first time O'Neill has moved to the brink of accepting one of football's top jobs only to have a dramatic, last-minute change of heart.

Two years ago he nearly moved to Everton after Howard Kendall's third spell in charge at the Merseyside club ended in failure. A few months later O'Neill looked certain to leave for Leeds only to reconsider at the eleventh hour.

One thing is certain. If he again snubs a major club, in this case Celtic, O'Neill risks being overlooked the next time an inviting managerial post is up for grabs.

Yesterday's developments will have been closely monitored - indeed, probably welcomed - by the former Wimbledon manager Joe Kinnear.

Kinnear had been expected to inform Sheffield Wednesday yesterday whether he would succeed Danny Wilson but, predictably, he asked for yet more time to consider.

Although anxious to return to management after a 14-month break, Kinnear has grave reservations about joining a club which has not only surrendered Premiership status but is £12m in debt.

Celtic did not confirm reports of O'Neill's imminent installation as successor to John Barnes, even though the normally circumspect Press Association announced at 9.58am that he had definitely agreed to move north of the border. However, inside two hours it became clear O'Neill's mind was not made up. He entered further negotiations with the persuasive Leicester chairman John Elsom. As Celtic hinted at damage-limitation, speculation mounted that O'Neill was about to confirm he would honour the remaining years of his Leicester contract. But it is believed O'Neill emerged from his meeting with Elsom late yesterday afternoon and headed for London to reopen talks with understandably confused Celtic officials. This is not the first time O'Neill has moved to the brink of accepting one of football's top jobs only to have a dramatic, last-minute change of heart. Two years ago he nearly moved to Everton after Howard Kendall's third spell in charge at the Merseyside club ended in failure. A few months later O'Neill looked certain to leave for Leeds only to reconsider at the eleventh hour. One thing is certain. If he again snubs a major club, in this case Celtic, O'Neill risks being overlooked the next time an inviting managerial post is up for grabs. Yesterday's developments will have been closely monitored - indeed, probably welcomed - by the former Wimbledon manager Joe Kinnear. Kinnear had been expected to inform Sheffield Wednesday yesterday whether he would succeed Danny Wilson but, predictably, he asked for yet more time to consider. Although anxious to return to management after a 14-month break, Kinnear has grave reservations about joining a club which has not only surrendered Premiership status but is £12m in debt.

webTitle: Train drivers had to sketch own route map, inquiry told

fields.headline: Train drivers had to sketch own route map, inquiry told
fields.trailText: Thames Train drivers were left to plan routes by passing handwritten sketches among themselves, the Paddington rail inquiry heard today.
fields.body:
Thames Train drivers were left to plan routes by passing handwritten sketches among themselves, the Paddington rail inquiry heard today.

Rail inspector Raymond Adams told the court how the rail company did not provide its drivers with printed route maps. Neil Garnham, representing the inquiry, said: "So Thames Train drivers plan routes by using handwritten sketch plans they pass amongst themselves and draw themselves?" The inspector confirmed.

Under questioning by counsel for Thames Trains, Antony Seys-Llewellyn, Mr Adams said drivers had "a lot of trouble with the sun" approaching and leaving Paddington in the morning and evening.

The court heard how Michael Hodder, 31, the driver of the fated train found travelling to the depot at Paddington from his home in Reading, Berkshire, "arduous and tiring", but Mr Adams added, "He was a very good driver, a very happy guy, always laughing and joking, and competent at his job."

A signal passed at danger has emerged as the primary cause of the Paddington crash, in which 31 people died when a Thames train went through a red light and collided with a Great Western express.

Mr Heinz Winters, the Railtrack manager responsible for assessing the signallers involved in the crash, said that they were "trained to wait and see" on signals passed at danger.

He talked of a number of failings in the Thames Trains driver training programme. It had been suggested that in an emergency it might be better for signallers to radio directly to drivers before changing the signals to stop trains. But Mr Winters said he would always switch the lights first, in accordance with the rules in the signalman's general Instructions.

Mr Winters, who is head of the signal control centre in Slough, said that a delay in stopping trains that overshot red lights was normal. He also told the inquiry that trains passing signals at danger usually pulled up within seconds.

Mr Adams said he had warned Mr Hodder there had been problems seeing the gantry which signal 109 - the signal passed at danger - was on. He added that the only "safe" way out of Paddington was to take each signal at a time. The inquiry was adjourned until tomorrow.

fields.headline: Tuition fees "should rise from £1,025 to £6,000"
fields.trailText: University tuition fees for some students should rise to around £6,000, according to a report which will go before vice-chancellors today.
fields.body:
University tuition fees for some students should rise to around £6,000, according to a report which will go before vice-chancellors today.

An enquiry commissioned by the Russell group of 19 top universities says fees should rise from £1,025 to £6,000 for science students and £4,000 for arts students.

The universities, encouraged by Andrew Adonis, education adviser in the Number 10 policy unit, believe so-called top-up fees would enable research to reach or maintain a world-class level and improve pay levels for academics.

Poorer studetns would not have to pay but instead recieve bursaries through a more developed scholarship system - the kind which will help pay for Tyneside sixth-former Laura Spence's place at Harvard.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, is opposed to top-up fees.

One of the contributors to the report, Andrew Oswald from Warwick, said the report would present the "strong moral case" for top-up fees. "Why exactly should Britain's plumbers and secretaries and telephone operators have to pay for you to go to Warwick?" he wrote in the university's student magazine.

"You will earn far more than them."

fields.headline: Closing the privilege gap
fields.standfirst:
Gordon Brown has flushed out the right. Now the left must attack the elitism at the heart of our culture

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: He's done it now. Gordon Brown has lit a fire under the British right, sending them into a fulminating fury on the issue that still strikes deepest in our national psyche: class.
fields.body:
He's done it now. Gordon Brown has lit a fire under the British right, sending them into a fulminating fury on the issue that still strikes deepest in our national psyche: class. They have raged across the pages of the Times, Telegraph and Daily Mail - cheered on by the B-team of British conservatism, the Conservative party - denouncing the communist heresies uttered by the chancellor. They have condemned him with a unanimity unknown since the general election: his stance on Oxbridge and its admissions policy is not just wrong on the facts, they cry, it is politically inept and morally indefensible. Even more than last year's declaration of war by Tony Blair against the "forces of conservatism", Gordon Brown has got right under their skin.

Why? The sages have paid less attention to that question, and more to Gordon Brown's motives. Was championing the case of Laura Spence, the super-bright Tyneside girl denied a place at Magdalen College, Oxford, a coordinated effort - agreed in advance with the PM, as the chancellor insists? Or was this a freelance operation initiated by Red Gordon (and followed by Blunkett, Cook and Prescott yesterday) to take advantage of the boss's paternity leave to cheer up the Labour faithful by showing them a glimpse of socialist stocking? Perhaps the Oxbridge offensive is simply Labour's response to the crowd- pleasing populism of William Hague. The Conservative leader has tapped a nerve twice in recent weeks, first on asylum seekers, then with the conviction of the vigilante farmer, Tony Martin. Now the government has decided to match Hague's rabble-rousing with some popular tunes of its own.

Labour also realises that in politics you need enemies. Every party, especially in government, benefits from a reviled opponent: they give you definition. Thatcher was Thatcher partly because she was the unScargill. New Labour has suffered from its own big-tent inclusivity: if it is not against anyone, what is it for? Blair's "forces of conservatism" speech last year sought to remedy that by demonising huntsmen, hereditary peers and Augusto Pinochet - three enemies the nation could love to hate. Brown's salvo last week was the sequel: Forces of Conservatism 2.

More deeply, this might just be an example of how politics is fought at the turn of the 21st century. In this post-Thatcher era there is less scope for old ideological clashes about economics: we're all market capitalists now. The gap that's left gets fills with cultural rows instead. That's how it has been in the United States for more than a decade, and it is fast becoming the pattern here. We argue less about policies than about episodes in the national culture, looking for the light they shed on a politician's or party's values. George Bush used the freed rapist Willie Horton to expose his opponent's weakness on crime in 1988. William Hague used Tony Martin for similar effect. And now Gordon Brown has Laura Spence.

For Labour, culture wars have an extra value: they come free of charge. Confronting, say, economic inequality head on might create a demand for old- fashioned wealth redistribution among Labour's core voters. It would also worry the party's new friends in affluent middle Britain. Attacking social inequality - like Oxbridge attitudes to state- educated kids - is much less expensive: it needn't cost money or votes. So expect new fronts in the culture wars to open up in the coming months - with the white, male, Oxbridge-educated judiciary and civil service the likeliest targets.

So much for the cold cunning of political calculation. What is it about Ms Spence that has got the rightwing so riled? Might it be because Gordon Brown has a real point - one that might reveal at last the fundamental difference between today's left and right?

Put aside the specifics of Laura's case. The key facts are these. According to a study by the Sutton Trust, state schools produce two thirds of the pupils qualified for Britain's five best universities - yet they get only half the places. Private schools turn out only one third of qualified leavers, yet they get half the places.

Those are devastating findings, for they blow a hole in the right's central argument: that if there are too few comprehensive kids at our best universities, it is because the schools they come from are not good enough. That might be plausible if state schools only managed to produce half the qualified 18-year-olds: then Oxbridge would simply be mirroring a national problem. But the trust's findings prove that the ancient universities could have a two-thirds state intake, and still maintain the same high standards, if they wanted to. What they have created instead is a gap: state schools have 93% of the pupils, 67% of the qualifications but only 48% of the best places. That can mean only one thing: a bias among interviewers towards those who whose parents paid for their education, who speak the way they do and come with the confidence of those born lucky. Call it the privilege gap.

Brown says his speech last Thursday (with a possible follow-up next week) was motivated by anger at that obvious injustice. If Britain genuinely believes in equal opportunity, he says, it cannot tolerate a system which allows such overt bias. He looks at Harvard, which transformed itself from a finishing school for the elite into a modern centre of excellence by dispatching 50 fulltime recruiters into America's poorest neighbourhoods, scouting for the brightest kids in the country. To those who say Harvard is different because it enjoys a vast, private endowment comes a swift response: the obligation to be fair is surely even greater on Oxford and Cambridge, which are spending public, not private, money.

The left critique is that Brown should spend more money on schools, make them better and boost state kids' chances. Or he could strip private schools of charitable status, all but destroying them and thereby wiping out the inequality problem at a stroke. But such radical action is inconceivable unless a majority of Britons first believe there is an inherent injustice to be remedied. That's why the centre-left must win this argument: if we cannot persuade our fellow Britons that a case of unfairness this obvious is wrong, then we have little chance of winning them over to bolder, or more expensive, action.

The rightwing seem to have understood this better than we have. They have leapt to defend not merely a specific admissions procedure but the rights of privilege itself. Shadow foreign secretary Francis Maude yesterday condemned Brown for engaging in "anti-elitist class war" as if elitism was a cause to be celebrated. The Tory former minister George Walden came clean in yesterday's London Evening Standard, penning an article headlined: "We need a non-elite Foreign Office about as much as we need a non-elite Manchester United." For that alone, Brown is to be congratulated: he has flushed out the right, forcing them to be defenders of privilege. Now it is up to the left to realise what is at stake, and to join battle.

webTitle: Prescott echoes battle cry against elitism

fields.headline: Prescott echoes battle cry against elitism
fields.standfirst:
Privilege and potential Ripples continue to spread from government's attack on Oxbridge 'old school tie' ethos

Comment: Michael White
fields.trailText: John Prescott yesterday pressed ahead with Labour's campaign to make the coming election a battle between its own commitment to social justice and Tory defence of privilege - despite growing criticism of Labour's record in spreading "opportunity for all".
fields.body:
John Prescott yesterday pressed ahead with Labour's campaign to make the coming election a battle between its own commitment to social justice and Tory defence of privilege - despite growing criticism of Labour's record in spreading "opportunity for all".

The deputy prime minister delivered his widely trailed speech in praise of "power, wealth and opportunity in the hands of the many, not the few," as the impact of chancellor Gordon Brown's attack on Oxbridge elitism continued to ricochet around the educational and political arenas.

Mr Prescott's message to voters was far wider than Mr Brown's complaint about old school ties affecting university access, and included a promise to defend all regions, north and south, as well as an attack on Mr Hague's latest attempts to woo pensioners.

"The Tories want a sort of national memory blackout of everything that happened in the 18 years before May 1997," he said.

"Do they think pensioners don't remember that the Tories stopped free eye tests for pensioners, the Tories broke the earnings link with the pension, the Tories oversaw the scandal of the mis-selling of private pensions, which cost a massive £3bn?"

Speaking in Gillingham, he said: "Let us be clear, we are governing for the whole of the UK, heartland and middle England, town and country, north, south, east and west."

The speech backed Mr Brown's attack in confirming that it was "immoral" to deny a fair share of life chances to those from less privileged backgrounds - among whom Mr Prescott numbered himself, a boy "spurred on to fight to make the most of myself" by 11-plus failure, he said. "That is what we're all about. About giving to the majority of people the life chances taken for granted by the privileged few."

The chancellor's July spending review - and the coming campaign - would reflect these priorities, he said.

The shadow education secretary, Theresa May, accused the government of trying to create a smokescreen to hide its own failings in education policy.

"This government has reduced the funding per student in higher education. We see student applicants going down as students face the considerable financial burden that the government has imposed on them by introducing tuition fees and by abolishing the maintenance grants," she said.

She did not believe that the government's rhetoric would strike a chord with the public. "This is the tired old class war rhetoric that the Labour party has used in the past, and frankly it is irrelevant to people's real concerns."

The Labour peer Lady Warwick, chief executive of the university heads lobby, told Radio 4's World at One: "More money for access will be very much welcome, but I think it's very important to say that that can't be a smokescreen to hide the general funding problems."

The Lib Dems say that Labour's tuition fees policy is a "drawbridge" against impoverished students. Some Labour MPs privately share that view and educationists also signalled quiet dismay.

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said that Oxbridge was already beginning to open up.

"I think the position is still serious and does need urgent attention. I am not sure that Gordon Brown chose the best case by any stretch of the imagination. I would urge the government just to think very carefully and very seriously before it dives in to a quick fix answer to an undoubtedly serious situation," Mr Hart said.

webTitle: 'We hope that one day we will be believed'

fields.headline: 'We hope that one day we will be believed'
fields.standfirst: Jeffrey Hackney, admissions tutor of Wadham College, Oxford, defends the university's admissions policy
fields.trailText: Jeffrey Hackney, admissions tutor of Wadham College, Oxford, defends the university's admissions policy
fields.body:
Oxford has this week taken a beating over the case of an able and well qualified young woman from a state school who was unable to secure a place here to read medicine. Sadly, this happens every year in every UK university both to students from state schools and those from the private sector. So the puzzle is what the fuss is about. You don't have to be a university teacher to see that you can't draw generalisations about a system from a single instance and it is a bit worrying that you can apparently be chancellor of the exchequer and do so.

I write as an Oxford tutor of some 40 years who came from a working class background in the north midlands and who has spent his life seeking to persuade similar children to apply here. When I came here not all my colleagues seemed to enthusiastically endorse that (though most did). Today if there are closet class warriors fighting for privilege and class, they are very closet indeed, and I don't see them. When I first came, children of average ability in the private sector applied to Oxford as a matter of course and children of blindingly wonderful brilliance stayed away because they thought we would not take them. It was a national tragedy, and all my life here Oxford has sought to counter this false impression. What is puzzling is that the government knows this as well as anyone and yet this week's events will make our shared goals the harder to achieve, unless the nonsense is rebutted. Oxford's failure has been to dispel that prejudice, just as the Labour party failed for 18 years in the middle of my life to persuade the nation of the error of its prejudices.

Choosing students with the potential to do well at university is a seriously difficult task. There is no educational level playing field in the 5-18 year age range in the UK. In this respect we are different from most other comparable nations. Some children will have attended schools where the unit of resource per child is many times that of others. Many private sector students will have been taught in schools in excellent condition, in small classes, with excellent libraries, and will have had coaching for university entrance. Many state school students will have attended schools, parts of which are in serious disrepair, in large groups and which are held together only by the dynamism and generosity of spirit of school teachers who do more for their students than anyone has a right to expect. University admissions officers are then supposed to be able to tell which are the students with the most potential. Every year we are challenged by school colleagues in both sectors who detect, in our efforts to discount the advantages of some and compensate for the disadvantages of others, a bias one way or the other. Picking a Cabinet must be child's play by comparison, but no doubt occasionally the odd former state school student still fails to get in.

Sending children to private schools is neither illegal, nor even immoral it seems, judging from the behaviour of the great and the good. The parents presumably imagine some educational benefit will follow. Attacking university admissions tutors is a good diversionary tactic and it is certainly a lot cheaper than putting the kind of money into state schools which would give all our children true equality of opportunity. Until there is a government funding or regulation to ensure that all our students have access to similar educational resources, all this fuss on the part of government looks like diversionary tactics and makes the tasks of admissions tutors unnecessarily hard. Meanwhile we cannot discriminate in favour of private school students nor favour state school: all we can do is seek to identify the factors which account for the admissions evidence before us. This is a serious equality of treatment issue and it has human rights, if not Human Rights, implications; and litigation from either group is always a possibility.

Oxford has two reasons for wanting to get that right, both, if you like, selfish. First, and in the national interest, is the need to have first class universities, of which we hope we are one. Our life blood depends on it and first class students are part of that aim. Second, the tutorial system here, involving near solitary confinement with students over prolonged periods, is a disproportionate penalty for tutors who make mistakes at admission time. Tutorials work only with good students and every tutor who admits students knows that. The consequences of failure constitute cruel and unusual punishment. We none of us claim to be infallible, but self interest alone would persuade any Oxford tutor who was not otherwise convinced by ordinary principles of justice.

We must continue to say that what we say is what we believe: we are looking to select the best students who apply to us and hope that one day we will be believed.
