fields.bodyText: Oxford has this week taken a beating over the case of an able and well qualified young woman from a state school who was unable to secure a place here to read medicine. Sadly, this happens every year in every UK university both to students from state schools and those from the private sector. So the puzzle is what the fuss is about. You don't have to be a university teacher to see that you can't draw generalisations about a system from a single instance and it is a bit worrying that you can apparently be chancellor of the exchequer and do so. I write as an Oxford tutor of some 40 years who came from a working class background in the north midlands and who has spent his life seeking to persuade similar children to apply here. When I came here not all my colleagues seemed to enthusiastically endorse that (though most did). Today if there are closet class warriors fighting for privilege and class, they are very closet indeed, and I don't see them. When I first came, children of average ability in the private sector applied to Oxford as a matter of course and children of blindingly wonderful brilliance stayed away because they thought we would not take them. It was a national tragedy, and all my life here Oxford has sought to counter this false impression. What is puzzling is that the government knows this as well as anyone and yet this week's events will make our shared goals the harder to achieve, unless the nonsense is rebutted. Oxford's failure has been to dispel that prejudice, just as the Labour party failed for 18 years in the middle of my life to persuade the nation of the error of its prejudices. Choosing students with the potential to do well at university is a seriously difficult task. There is no educational level playing field in the 5-18 year age range in the UK. In this respect we are different from most other comparable nations. Some children will have attended schools where the unit of resource per child is many times that of others. Many private sector students will have been taught in schools in excellent condition, in small classes, with excellent libraries, and will have had coaching for university entrance. Many state school students will have attended schools, parts of which are in serious disrepair, in large groups and which are held together only by the dynamism and generosity of spirit of school teachers who do more for their students than anyone has a right to expect. University admissions officers are then supposed to be able to tell which are the students with the most potential. Every year we are challenged by school colleagues in both sectors who detect, in our efforts to discount the advantages of some and compensate for the disadvantages of others, a bias one way or the other. Picking a Cabinet must be child's play by comparison, but no doubt occasionally the odd former state school student still fails to get in. Sending children to private schools is neither illegal, nor even immoral it seems, judging from the behaviour of the great and the good. The parents presumably imagine some educational benefit will follow. Attacking university admissions tutors is a good diversionary tactic and it is certainly a lot cheaper than putting the kind of money into state schools which would give all our children true equality of opportunity. Until there is a government funding or regulation to ensure that all our students have access to similar educational resources, all this fuss on the part of government looks like diversionary tactics and makes the tasks of admissions tutors unnecessarily hard. Meanwhile we cannot discriminate in favour of private school students nor favour state school: all we can do is seek to identify the factors which account for the admissions evidence before us. This is a serious equality of treatment issue and it has human rights, if not Human Rights, implications; and litigation from either group is always a possibility. Oxford has two reasons for wanting to get that right, both, if you like, selfish. First, and in the national interest, is the need to have first class universities, of which we hope we are one. Our life blood depends on it and first class students are part of that aim. Second, the tutorial system here, involving near solitary confinement with students over prolonged periods, is a disproportionate penalty for tutors who make mistakes at admission time. Tutorials work only with good students and every tutor who admits students knows that. The consequences of failure constitute cruel and unusual punishment. webTitle: Harvard tries to move with the times

fields.headline: Harvard tries to move with the times
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Even today, Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts, founded just 16 years after the landing of the Mayflower, has a standing and significance in the United States very similar to Oxford's in England.
fields.body:
Even today, Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts, founded just 16 years after the landing of the Mayflower, has a standing and significance in the United States very similar to Oxford's in England.

Both remain the universities of choice for the white, male, upper middle class elite that runs the country. If an American Gordon Brown wanted to make a populist attack on US universities, Harvard would probably be a tempting target.

But in the past few decades, Harvard and the rest of the American Ivy League universities have undergone a revolution in admissions policies, abandoning many - though not all - of the old social links in favour of the aggressive, increasingly international, meritocratic recruitment policy that has enabled Laura Spence to hit the jackpot.

Harvard's recruitment system is based on a team of more than 20 admissions officers who travel the US, and even abroad, in search of potential undergraduates from all backgrounds and experiences.

"We have consistently tried to get a more socially representative student body," Harvard spokesman Joe Wrinn said yesterday. "The whole idea is to put togather as diverse a class as possible each year".

Central to Harvard's efforts is a network of 5,000 Harvard graduates who comb the US on the lookout for likely talent, interviewing high school students as young as 13 in the hope that they might eventually find their way to the nation's oldest university, which was founded in 1636 and has been attended by six US presidents.

The massive financial endowments accumulated by Harvard mean that the university is able to operate an admission policy in which it helps to finance more than 70% of its freshmen. Without this, few students would be able to afford annual tuition and living costs of $35,400 (£23,000).

Harvard is far from alone in pursuing such policies. Anthony Canchola-Flores, an admissions officer at Brown University in Rhode Island, said: "We used to be a bastion of white, east coast privilege. Now nearly 40% of our 2,500 offers go to students of colour and first generation university families."

webTitle: New heights for black RAF officer

fields.headline: New heights for black RAF officer
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A 47-year-old born in Guyana yesterday became the highest ranking black officer ever to serve in Britain's armed forces.
fields.body:
A 47-year-old born in Guyana yesterday became the highest ranking black officer ever to serve in Britain's armed forces.

David Case was promoted to the rank of air commodore in the Royal Air Force with a salary of £70,000 a year. He will be responsible for personnel and training based at RAF Innsworth in Gloucestershire.

He came to Britain at the age of five, studied engineering at Queen's University Belfast and won the sword of honour as best cadet at the RAF college at Cranwell.

He has served in Germany and was recently head of the presentation team responsible for the RAF's relations with the public and the media.
Richard Norton-Taylor

webTitle: Keeping your place, Gaining a player and Losing one's temper

fields.headline: Keeping your place, Gaining a player and Losing one's temper
fields.trailText: UKRAINE BRAIN DRAIN
fields.body:
UKRAINE BRAIN DRAIN

No-one is more proud to wear the three lions on his shirt (or display his tactical naivety so prominently on his sleeve) than Kelvin Koogan. But on Monday, the England boss seemed to have added a new trick to his scant repertoire: Wenger-esque style mind-games. "There will definitely be changes - more than three, maybe," he cryptically told the press when asked about the Ukraine match. "But I won't announce the team like I normally do."

So imagine our surprise when we opened our newspapers this morning, and discovered that virtually every journalist alive had predicted the same England line-up for tonight's match. Now the Fiver's no Charlie Dimmock, but the words 'giant mole' do suggest themselves. Either that or Koogan, under psychological pressure from Ukraine boss Jozhef Szabo, has cracked again. Because everyone agrees that England will switch to a 3-5-2 formation, with Fowler starting alongside Shearer - in front of a midfield trio consisting of McManaman in a free role, Gerrard and either Ince or Scholes. The wing-backs will be Beckham and Phil Neville, and Martyn will replace Seaman in goal. All of which leaves Koogan to perm three from four in defence, with one of Adams, Southgate, Keown or Campbell missing out.

So with that all but settled, the Fiver spent the day trying to decipher the Enigma-like mind of Koogan to predict who will be the unlucky players to miss Euro 2000. Now that Romford Ray and Redknapp have dropped out through injury, there's just four more to leave out. David James and Rio Ferdinand look certainties for the chop, so after that it's any two from Barmby, Dyer, Barry, Cole and Phillips. Now rationally you'd expect Barmby and Cole to be disappointed, but this is Koogan we're talking about - so expect Phillips and Barry to be the players smashing up the Wembley conference centre when the Euro 2000 squad is announced tonight.

EURO 2000 FEVER? EURO 2000 FIVER!

The Euro, the Fiver's extra low-down from the lowlands, brought to you in association with breathe, starts on the morning of June 5. To make sure you get it, go to http://www.footballunlimited.co.uk/theeuro. Or send a mail to euro2000-request@footballunlimited.co.uk with "subscribe" in the subject line. Calm down, there's not long to wait.

TRANSFER BABYLON (AND ON)

Not so long ago, a transfer was a transfer. One minute Eric Cantona was sitting on the bench scowling at Howard Wilkinson, the next he was at Old Trafford playing one-twos with Brian McClair. Neither did anyone anticipate David Speedie leaving Coventry for Liverpool. Although there may have been a reason for that. But as the Fiver dutifully brings you the latest-minute developments in the proposed transfers of Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink and Fabien Barthez, we can't help but pine for the good old days.

First to Hasselbaink. Jimmy's £14m move to Chelsea's of Chelsea appears to be a goer again after Atletico Madrid's vice-president Miguel Angel Gil (he's the son of Jesus you know) claimed the deal was done and dusted this morning. "All that remains is for the clubs to exchange faxes and for the signing to be ratified by the English Premier League," he said. Which would lead you to believe that a transfer might just be in the offing. Until, that is, you realise that Chelsea have said nothing on the matter at all, and that the Dutchman has yet to set foot in this country.

At least Barthez put himself up in a charming Cheshire hotel while jumping through the Lord Imperial Ferg's many transfer hoops. Last night, sleep-inducing reports suggested that the deal had foundered over the slaphead-happy keeper's wage demands. Reports this morning caused even greater narcolepsy by suggesting the move was back on, and then United barely managed to raise an eyelid by announcing a press conference for 4pm. Probably to announce that they'll be announcing another conference some time next... what's that? United have signed the French international keeper? For £7.8m? On a six-year contract? They could at least have given us a hint.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"To be honest, I don't give a damn what he says. And neither does anybody else because he is wrong" - That'd be Ken Bates then. Villa midfielder Ian Taylor gives the Chelsea chairman a piece of his mind.

POSH PAUSE

Last night, Peterborough manager Barry Fry met up with the board of his newly-promoted club to make plans for the future. But soon after, the excitable little cockney left London Road in high dudgeon and with low spirits. "I've been booted out of Peterborough and I'm totally gutted," the red-faced little roly-pollster ranted, his voice barely audible above the jets of steam coming out of his ears. "I don't know if I will ever get over it. I've had many disappointments in football but none as bad as this."

News sad enough to stir feelings of sympathy in any man... if it wasn't for the fact that, according to Peterborough chairman Peter Boizot, Fry hasn't actually been sacked. According to Boizot, Fry "raised an issue about youth players. We wanted to see two or three youth players playing pretty regularly in the reserves. It caused him to get a little bit heated." Fry? Heated?

"I can't really say we had an argument," the Posh chairman continued unconvincingly. "I think he got worked up and he eventually decided to close his briefcase and walk out of the door." Considering Fry is not known for keeping things totally in perspective, and that this sort of thing used to happen every two minutes when he was at Barnet, the Fiver fully expects all this to be forgotten once the dust settles. And we're sure Boizot agrees. "As far as the directors are concerned, the door is open and he can still walk back." You see? "But I would expect [Fry] to come back with some sort of apology." Oh.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Chelsea have made a late attempt to sign Marseille winger Robert Pires, who has been expected to complete a £6.25m deal with Arsenal.

Spurs have begun talks with £3m Lens forward Pascal Nouma. The 27-year-old striker wants to play in the Premiership and the prospect of reuniting with David Ginola, who played with Nouma at PSG, may swing the balance.

Australian international captain Paul Okon is expected to sign a four-year deal at Middlesbrough later this week. The Fiorentina midfielder will cost nothing - the deal is dependent on a medical.

Chelsea are tracking 29-year-old Nigerian winger Finidi George, who would cost a bargain £3.5m from demoted Real Betis.

Leeds defender Michael Duberry is a target for Southampton.

Trevor Sinclair will be at the top of Martin O'Neill's shopping list should the Leicester manager leave for Celtic. The West Ham utility man is valued at £8m.

Manchester City and Bradford are both interested in signing Craig Hignett. They are willing to pay up to £2m for the Barnsley star.

Newcastle full-back Didier Domi has expressed an interest in returning to his former club Paris St Germain.

Bolton could snatch Hearts defender Paul Ritchie from under the noses of Rangers. Ritchie, who played for Bolton on loan last season and becomes a free agent at the end of June, has not yet been offered a contract by the Scottish champions. "We're speaking to his agent and, if what I've heard is true, then we're in his hands," Bolton manager Sam Allardyce said today.

Paris St Germain are interested in Davor Suker. West Ham remain favourites as the player wants to stay in London.

Reading have bid £400,000 for Henrik Lykke, centre-back for Danish champions Herfolge.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Joe Kinnear has turned down the offer to become Sheffield Wednesday manager, according to his agent.

Reports in today's press suggest that cable giant NTL have outbid BSkyB for the core package of Premiership TV rights. NTL are believed to have offered the Premier League £1.25bn for 66 live games and 40 pay-per-view games in the bidding for the new contract which begins in August 2001.

QPR have signed Wrexham striker Karl Connolly on a free transfer. The 29-year-old, who played more then 350 league games for Wrexham, has agreed to a three-year contract.

Preston are to issues shares in an attempt to raise up to £7.5m to go towards re-development of the ground and strengthening the squad.

Ayr have bought Hibernian defender Michael Renwick.

ITV: The Big Match (11.30pm)

Highlights of England's last home match before Euro 2000, compete with epilepsy-friendly theme tune.

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (6.30pm, 11.15pm)

It's a game on a globe.

Sky Sports 2: International Football - Live (7pm, 12midnight)

Live coverage of England's last home match before Euro 2000, compete with thumping bass-laden theme tune which always sounds tinny and empty when full-time depression sets in.

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm)

Commentator interviews man.

Sky Sports.Com TV: Fox Sports News (1am)

Presented by Lionel Bienvenu? Please say yes.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7.55pm)

Presented by Alan Green? Please say "this isn't football, it's rubbish".

David Mellor (10pm)

Unpleasant pockets of warm opinion seep through an uneven enamel gap.

webTitle: Note: I'm not barren or infertile. I'm  subfertile

fields.headline: Note: I'm not barren or infertile. I'm  subfertile
fields.standfirst: Trying: The diary of an IVF patient
fields.trailText: Trying: The diary of an IVF patient
fields.body:
It's good to learn that I'm at the cutting edge at last. Infertility is in. According to Ben Elton, there's nothing so hip as having blocked tubes. Mucus hostility is a must. A low sperm count is very cool. This was his pitch to convince the movie men to hand over millions for the making of Maybe Baby, a film about a couple having IVF treatment, released on Friday.

With me, the height of fashion is my ovaries, where my eggs are stored. I have a chromosomal condition called a "balanced translocation". Two of my 46 chromosomes are different to almost everyone else's. This genetic mix-up is only a problem for me when it comes to conceiving.

Only 23 of my 46 chromosomes will be present in any one of my eggs. When these 23 meet the 23 chromosomes in a sperm, three different things can happen. If I don't pass on my mixed-up chromosomes, a child is born free from any condition. This was the blissful but unlikely scenario which, seven years ago, led to the birth of my daughter.

If both my mixed-up chromo-somes are present, the resulting embryo will be, like me, jumbled but balanced, the only problem being when they in turn want to conceive. But if only one of the bad chromosomes is passed on, the embryo will be genetically "unbalanced". In that, the most common case, the embryo is so fatally flawed it will not survive past a few months.

In practice, most of my preg-nancies end in miscarriage. I've had four in a row. But with IVF, an embryologist can sort good fertilised embryos from bad at just eight cells, and reimplant any viable ones. This process is known as PGD, pre-implantation genetic diagnosis. It is controversial, cumbersome, expensive and very new. So thank God at least it's hip.

But not all the messages I'm getting confirm the desirability of my condition. This celebration of barrenness, giving it near celebrity status, is proceeding at exactly the same time as coverage of the Blair babe goes into overdrive. (Note that barrenness is a word I am not supposed to use. Nor infertility. I am, technically, "subfertile", sounding like something to spread over the tomato plants on a mild May morning. Subfertility and infertility are, of course, exactly the same thing. It's just that one offers the patient hope.)

Maybe Baby has no conclusive ending (the couple is left childless but still trying). But Ben and Sophie are now proud parents of twins Bert and Lottie, born through IVF. The high-profile couple were granted uncharacteristic privacy until the babes were well born. Even the avaricious Sun, which got hold of the story early on, refrained from breaking the news. The exposure of failure to have a family would be almost unbearable.

But there are many such sad endings, and they're far more frequent than the Eltons' fairy story. We just don't want to know about them. When I saw a small A4 sheet, headed Unfulfilled Dreams, pinned up on the notice board in the waiting room of the Assisted Conception Unit, at first I avoided it as if something obscene.

It gave details of a service, organised by women who had suffered multiple miscarriages or who had been unable to have a child, to grieve and remember what had never been. I hovered in front of the sign. I could barely bring myself to take down the phone number, as if it were already admitting defeat.

Most infertile women, like me, prefer to hear victorious reports, as if, by some mysterious osmosis, it will then happen to us, too. I remember a former TV presenter parading her "IVF twins", just toddlers, on the Gloria Hunniford show, one bawling her eyes out. Bizarrely, the manner of their conception added to their mother's star status. Although scientific breakthroughs are responsible for treating stubborn infertility, and it's nothing whatsoever to do with the infertile couples' personal endeavours, their true-life stories are presented as tales of individual heroism.

It's the unsuccessful stories we don't hear, because it's nothing to brag about. Elton insists that Inconceivable, his novel on which Maybe Baby is based, would have been published whether or not a faint blue line hadn't appeared on his wife's pregnancy test. Now that would have been a heroic tale. We can only confess to having had infertility treatment once it has a happy outcome.

I n truth, the success rate for IVF treatment is slim. One in five is putting a healthy glow on it. Put my age, 40, and condition together, and the chance of a "live birth" (a refreshing bit of straight talk amongst the evasive vocabulary of infertility) is less than 10%.

"Think positive!" said the cheery nurse who broke this statistic to me, as if thinking positively could alter the arrangement of my chromosomes. Parenthood is one of those rare phenomena that refuse to be subject to our control, however hard we try. And with modern IVF techniques, we are trying very hard indeed. I don't put my trust in positive feelings. My chromosomes don't care what kind of mood I'm in. I simply trust in the skill of the medical staff to do their very best, and in a little bit of luck.

Let's be something that is very unfashionable and not at all hip at the moment: let's be blunt. I'm as good as barren. My chances of the medical procedure being successful are minimal. It's an unpleasant and lengthy treatment that no one would choose. It's far more likely to be an unfulfilled dream than the subject of a feature film. But it is a chance. And I, an infertile woman nearing middle age who would like a child, am taking it.

Joseph Stone, who writes the Home and Away column, is away.

fields.headline: The baby bomb
fields.standfirst: It's meant to be the happiest time - so why do so many couples split within a year of a birth?  Sally Weale  reports
fields.trailText: It's meant to be the happiest time - so why do so many couples split within a year of a birth?
fields.body:
It is almost impossible to draw any useful or illuminating parallels between what happens in the lives of celebrities like Patsy Kensit and Liam Gallagher, and the rest of humanity. But the current media interest in their troubled marriage highlights a familiar pattern, not just in the world of the rich and famous, but for the rest of us, too. For Patsy and Liam's three-year marriage is reportedly on the rocks just eight months after the birth of their son, Lennon.

The whys and wherefores of any couple's marriage, or its failure, remain essentially a mystery to outsiders, but it doesn't take a Mori poll to tell us that relationships frequently founder soon after the arrival of a child. Babies, you see, can break up your marriage much more effectively than they can glue it together. Because, as most new parents will tell you, having a baby is like the explosion of a neutron bomb - it leaves buildings standing but destroys life as we know it.

Sarah, an interior designer, had been married to Paul, a lecturer, for three years when baby Daniel arrived. They were both delighted, but just months later their already fragile relationship was failing. "Your social life comes to an abrupt halt," says Sarah, who separated from her husband when Daniel was a year old. "Your routine is completely out the window. Then there are the sleepless nights - you haven't got the energy to deal with the demands of the day. Often the woman's role changes more dramatically than the man's. Men usually continue their jobs, women are at home looking after the baby. A lot of jealousy creeps in on both sides.

"That was a big factor for us. I found it difficult because he didn't change his lifestyle. He was still going out, and playing sport five nights a week. I got very angry and used to go out anyway, taking the baby. And Paul didn't cope well with the sleepless nights. It was creating arguments between us, and our relationship was pretty rocky anyway. With well-established relationships which have a firm foundation, and where you've talked things through beforehand, a new baby might test it for a while, but I don't think it's going to break it. For us, it was going to happen anyway."

You can read all the books you like, you can go to every NCT class in the area, but most couples are utterly unprepared for the impact of a baby, says author and Relate counsellor Julia Cole. "Until you've got the baby in your arms, it's very difficult to know how it's going to affect you. Babies are such hard work.

"Studies have shown that if the couple do not communicate well or have problems negotiating, the baby will reinforce those problems. Because both parents have to give so much time to the child, all that other stuff that used to support the couple - affection, sex, looking after the home, work - often goes by the board. Gradually, the couple start to say, 'Can we really sustain this?'" For even the most contented of couples, the dramatic change in dynamics is difficult to navigate. Often the baby becomes the sole focus of the mother's attention, leaving the father feeling excluded and redundant, says Denise Knowles, Relate counsellor and sex therapist.

And with the growing phenomenon of the so-called new dad, who wants to be as committed and actively involved as any mother, it gets even more complicated: "Nowadays we are seeing more babies being the focus of both mum and dad to the detriment of the relationship. They become so absorbed in the baby, they don't get out. They become inward-looking and suddenly they realise they haven't got a life together."

Throw work into the equation, and it piles on even more pressure. You're parents, you're both working and your idea of yourselves as a couple becomes remote. There's the emotional burden, the financial burden and then there's the sex. Doctors tell you it's all right six weeks after the birth - new dad will have it pencilled in the diary; new mum may have quite a different idea.

There is also interesting American research which suggests that women are much faster at getting to grips with parenting than men, which again may cause conflict. According to the 1992 study, women are often dissatisfied with themselves around six months after the birth of the child - they are wondering if they can cope, they may feel exhausted and unattractive. After that their satisfaction shoots up as they bond with their baby and their confidence in their parenting ability grows. Men's feelings of uncertainty drag on a lot longer; their lowest point of self-esteem comes 18 months after the birth of the child.

"It's about learning to be a parent," says Julia Cole. "Women tend to latch on to it more quickly and feel more confident about it more quickly. Men appear to struggle for longer." The imbalance leads to doubts about whether the relationship is right.

The baby itself may be an attempt to patch the relationship together, the so-called superglue baby which bonds mother and father. "It's that feeling - we will have to make the relationship work if we have a baby. But people factor out all the stress the child causes in the early years."

Sometimes the difficulties start even before the baby has been born. Cole has counselled couples whose relationship is teetering on the brink of collapse simply because the woman is pregnant. "Often it's about expectations and anxiety - will you be able to manage? Sometimes it's because the pregnancy was unexpected, or because of difficulties with your own past. Maybe your experience of being with your family was not very good. You're worried and ask, 'Am I going to be a good parent?'"

So how does anyone ever survive it? "The most important thing that really helps couples is to have support from family and friends," says Cole. "People who will babysit, people who will help with housework, people you can call for advice when the baby is crying at three in the morning. That network of friendship and family affection is probably the most crucial thing you can have."

fields.headline: Too many chiefs
fields.standfirst: Most teachers say they can spot the leaders of tomorrow in a class of five-year-olds. So is your child born to rule - or just plain bossy?  Emma Brockes  reports
fields.trailText: Most teachers say they can spot the leaders of tomorrow in a class of five-year-olds. So is your child born to rule - or just plain bossy?
fields.body:
There are eight people dining at the small flat in London and the child present is behaving oddly. She is dressed in an ankle-length white nightie, like the girl who plays conduit to the devil in the film Poltergeist. The similarity doesn't end there. During the course of the evening, she tries to rearrange the furniture, socially engineer the group by dragging guests across the room to talk to one another, and supervise the catering by planting herself in the kitchen and issuing orders through that well-known medium of control, petulance power: "Why are you doing that? Why? Why? Why?" By the end of the evening, the temptation to ask her if she's ever heard voices through the television or seen dead people is irresistible.

When it's exhibited in any child but one's own, such precocity is perceived to be the fruit of bad parenting. Confidence, independence and the ability to express one's opinions with force might be valued in the adult world, but when present in under-10s, they are more likely to provoke nausea, and the conclusion that the child is a spoilt brat and will come to no good.

Yet it is exactly the qualities most commonly read as obnoxiousness that have been identified, in research by the Institute of Leadership, as the signs teachers pick on as indicators of a child's aptitude for the role of leader. Out of the 100 teachers questioned, the majority believed that future leaders could be picked out from a class of five-year-old children. One in five thought that leadership skills should be fostered in children from the age of three. And the signs of a good leader were almost universally identified to be confidence and sociability, observations that have left the institute nervous about the way in which quiet children are being unfairly classified as undynamic.

The idea that one can make forecasts about a child's future based on the way they act in nursery school is a hazardous one. If you can pick out the leaders, then why not the losers and the serial killers? Why not decode Milly and Johnny's tussle in the sandpit as evidence of their suitability as rival captains of industry? Or Billy's reluctance to join in pinning the tail on the donkey as an indication that he'll grow up to be a creepy loner? After all, Harold Wilson was pictured as a child outside Downing Street with scary prescience for his future calling.

The problem is that the characteristics commonly thought to denote flair for leadership can be based upon false assumptions, first among them that children who are loud and bossy are acting with a level of self- consciousness that gives their behaviour any meaning. "Children from the ages of three to five rarely have what we would call 'theory of mind'," says Iram Siraj-Blatchford, professor of early childhood education at the Institute of Education. "This means an ability to take in other people's perspectives, which can be vital for leadership. Girls are more sociable at that age than boys and we could end up concluding that girls are going to make better leaders than boys. That is a ridiculous assertion."

She and colleagues from the universities of Cardiff and Oxford are engaged in a six-year study into the behaviour of 4,000 children between the ages of three and seven. "Naturally, if young children are confident they're going to be fairly bossy and assertive," she says. "That isn't necessarily leadership. I run a department, and a lot of it is based on staying quiet about what I think, problem-solving in the background and making other people feel good about the results we come up with."

In children, this can manifest itself in a strong disposition to learn, an ability to concentrate and persevere with a task in the face of failure, and an ability to ask questions, none of which need involve the more conventional displays of leadership. "I'm not sure the answer is about dominance," says Dr Glyn Collis, lecturer in psychology at Warwick University. "As a good leader, you need to be able to tune into the needs of the people you are going to lead, get them on your side - not to be bossy."

Dr Collis questions the value of even trying to base predictions of a child's future persuasions on their early behaviour. A five-year-old displaying what might be seen as leadership qualities can only be viewed as successful within the limited context of the nursery environment. "I suspect that what the teachers were responding to is an ability to identify children of five who are good leaders in the environment they're in at that time. It doesn't stand to reason that they'll be good leaders later on. To my knowledge, there is no evidence that you could identify leadership qualities in a five-year-old."

This is partly because the criteria for a "successful" child changes between junior and senior school. In junior school, the chatty, sociable child is frequently thought of by teachers to be the most engaged and potentially successful in the class. By the time they have reached secondary school, that has inverted: the talkative child is the potentially disruptive one; the studious child, the one who might be tipped for future glory.

"In the secondary environment, the more introspective child is able to focus better and present himself as a better independent learner," says Dr John Acklaw, chartered educational psychologist and former president of the Association of Educational Psychologists. "In primary school, the sociable child tends to stand out more. Sociability might be an aspect of leadership, but it isn't a necessary condition of it."

Lest it be read as an advert for pre-determinism, the most important factor in this research is identified as a child's environment. Psychologists agree that, while children as young as three can show dispositions towards certain personality types, they are influenced less by innate ability than parental behaviour. "We know that a child who experiences limit setting, and affection from a parent in strong doses, is someone who is well-adjusted and likely to be regarded as worth following by peers," says Dr Howard Steele, a psychologist at University College, London. "The home background makes a difference," says Prof Iram Siraj-Blatchford. "The amount of time parents spend reading, taking them to the library, is important. Children develop so rapidly that to identify something in them at the age of five is to solidify them in time."

The report concludes that the trick is to nurture the leader in every child, to approach leadership not as a showy, starry prize for the gobby kids in the class, but as a state of basic security for them all. "The people who rise to prominence within organisations are not always prominent early on," reminds Dr Steele. "Every leader needs to be mentored."

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Would you let your teenager sleep with their partner under your roof - and, if so, at what age?
fields.trailText: The Question: Would you let your teenager sleep with their partner under your roof - and, if so, at what age?
fields.body:
Carole Sturdy
Parent and worker with Brook, young people sex adviser

Like a lot of single parents, I have a close and quite intense relationship with my son, now 23. One issue for me was how letting him sleep with a girlfriend at home would affect our relationship: I thought he'd be less likely to leave home, less able to break the bond with me. It removes one incentive for leaving home. So I think you've got to have your child's long-term wellbeing in mind, as well as thinking of anyone else who might be in the home - say younger siblings - before you decide. Actually, I did let my teenage son have his girlfriend to stay, but by then he was planning to leave home anyway.

Anna Raeburn
Journalist, broadcaster and mother of a 19-year-old son

If you can bear the idea, I think it's got to be right. If you have a good relationship with your teenager, and they have a steady partner, then they're going to sleep together and might as well do it at home. If they're forced to go somewhere other than home for sex, they may make themselves vulnerable. Also, sex somewhere uncomfortable and inhospitable is unlikely to give them the best introduction to making love. They need somewhere they can be warm, comfortable, unhurried, and close afterwards. They'll learn positive things about sex, rather than just fumbling in corners.

Canon Ann Easter
Dean of Newham and mother of three, now in their 20s

My children are in their 20s now, but there were occasions when they brought their partners to stay at our house. If it was an established relationship and I knew about it, it was fine. But I'd always want to know beforehand: you need to know who's in your house. I wouldn't want an 18-year-old girl to encounter my husband naked on the landing. If you don't let them sleep together in your house, they'd do it in the car; it must be better for a relationship to have a bed. Also, if you know you'll be introducing your partner to your mum in the morning, maybe you're more careful who you have sex with.

Michele Elliott
Kidscape director and 501 Ways To Be a Good Parent author

I would not allow a teenager to sleep with a partner in my house because, as far as I'm concerned, that would be condoning sex outside of a long-term relationship. No teenager could have had a long-term relationship, could they? OK, perhaps if a 19-year-old had a partner of three or four years I'd think again, but that would be fairly unusual. I'd consider allowing one of my sons once they were at university or living independently to bring home a long-term girlfriend, but I'd never allow it if it was about casual sex, which isn't good for a teenager either physically or psychologically.

Julia Cole
Psychosexual counsellor and mother of two teenagers

Certainly not at 15 or 16, but maybe at 18 or 19. For most parents it has to come down to how they view their children's maturity. I have a lot of respect for my children's decision-making. If one wanted to bring a partner to stay, I'd know it was because the relationship was important to them. The first thing I'd do is sit down and talk to them about it, about sexual feelings and about contraception. I've already talked to them about these issues before. That's the crunch, I think - to have already raised the issues around sex long before you get to the stage where it's happening.

fields.headline: Off the shelf
fields.standfirst: Building a library for your child :   Ages 0-4 :   Ages 5-7 :   Ages 8-11 :   Ages 12 +
fields.trailText: Building a library for your child : Ages 0-4 : Ages 5-7 : Ages 8-11 : Ages 12 +
fields.body:
Book of the month

The Wind Singer

by William Nicholson (Mammoth, £12.99)

Anyone who has queried the point of baseline assessments, Sats tests and league tables will take heart from this innovative and subversive novel for the over nines.

In the cheerless world of Aramanth, a supposedly perfect society where everyone has a personal rating that they must strive to improve, the Hath family are oddballs. Hanno Hath prefers to read rather than study for the annual examination, his wife Ira is a prophetess and the twins, Bowman and Kestrel, are frustrated by living under a strict regime.

When Kestrel finally flips, the hand of authority comes down heavily, so the twins, together with smelly outcast Mumpo, set off on a dangerous journey to the mountains in order to find the Wind Singer which has the power to liberate their homeland.

Nicholson spins a cracking yarn, creating an exceptionally moving fantasy novel that is potent but never preachy as it subtly suggests that achievement without love and kindness is a prison.

How to buy the books

Off the Shelf is a monthly selection of the best new titles. It can be used in conjunction with the Guardian website (www.booksunlimited.co. uk) where you will find reviews of classic books that will form the backbone to a child's library. All the books can be bought direct from the website. The titles below can also be bought through Guardian Culture-Shop, at the discount indicated: freephone 0800 3166 102, or send a cheque payable to the Guardian cultureShop to 250 Western Ave, London W3 6EE.

I Will Not Ever Never Eat a Tomato

by Lauren Child (Orchard, £10.99; CultureShop price £8.99 + 99p&p)

From the screwy title onwards, everything is different about Lauren Child's book. Charlie plays a trick on his little sister Lola, possibly the faddiest eater in the universe. Carrots become twiglets from Jupiter, peas are green drops from Greenland and boring old mash potato is "cloud fluff from the pointiest peak of Mount Fuji".

Needless to say Lola is soon gobbling it all down, and so will you and your offspring be drawn in by the off-the-wall visuals that mix line drawings and patterns with photographs, creating a world that is absolutely grounded in reality yet also wildly imaginative.

Weslandia

by Paul Fleichman, illustrated by Kevin Hawkes (Walker, £4.99; CultureShop price £4.99 freepost)

One of the first things you notice when your child starts school is how quickly the most individual of children turn into conformists. It passes, but Paul Fleischman's tale may help the phase pass quicker.

Wesley is an outcast from the civilisation around him in suburban America, the only kid in town who doesn't like pizza and fizzy drinks. With the help of some seeds blown on the wind, he has founded his own civilisation in the back garden.

This wonderfully satirical book has a sinister twist at the end that reminds you how quickly even difference can be assimilated to become the norm.

Marianne Dreams

by Catherine Storr (Faber & Faber, £4.99; CultureShop price £4.99 free-post)

A long-overdue reissue of this extraordinary book, a densely psychological portrait of a child's anger, frustration and jealousy. Marianne, confined to bed with a long-term illness, finds a pencil with which she draws a house, a garden and a small boy at the window. At night she dreams she is transported into her drawing.

The writing is remarkable in the way it captures the anger that makes the powerless Marianne want to obliterate the world by scribbling it out.

A psychologist would have a field day, but children will recognise the truth with which it deals with the feelings of rage and fear.

Mercy's Birds

by Linda Holeman (Floris, £4.99; CultureShop price £4.99 freepost)

Mercy is 15 and coping with school, a mother who is falling apart, an evening job and the return of her aunt's sexually predatory boyfriend. This could be a depressing read, but Mercy is such a mixture of steel and frailty that you will her to survive. There is a horribly truthful scene in the hospital emergency room where Mercy tells her mother, who has just overdosed, how much she hates her.

Like the snow that falls on the town where this novel takes place, this is a convincing portrait of a life that is snowbound by circumstance, fear and misplaced independence. And eventually Mercy does find her place in the sun.

Mabel Dancing

by Amy Hest, illustrated by Christine Davenier (Walker, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99 + 99p&p)

This is the simplest of stories about a little girl, Mabel, who is put to bed on the night of her parents' shindig but who then watches what happens through the banisters. The sounds enchant, brought alive by the rhythm of the text and the swooshing physicality of the drawings.

Initially I had some resistance to this book, largely because it evokes a world of big houses and grand black-tie parties that seems so ridiculous. But after several bedtime sessions that ended in us prancing around the room, I concluded that any book that is so tactile and so makes its readers want to dance, has a lot going for it.

How the Whale Became and Other Stories

by Ted Hughes, illustrated by Jackie Morris (Faber and Faber, £17.99; CultureShop price £14.99 + 99p&p)

Did you know that tortoises always used to come first in any race, cats are great violinists, the hare believes that the moon wants to marry him and that it took a while for the elephant to learn to be itself?

Ted Hughes's inventive creation fables, sometimes sly and humorous and sometimes lyrical, were first published in 1963. But they have never been seen like this before. This exquisite new edition provides illustrations whose rich, grave, muted, almost medieval beauty are in perfect harmony with the deceptive simplicity of the words.

The Memory Prisoner

by Thomas Bloor (Hodder, £3.99; CultureShop price £3.99 freepost)

Maddie is 15. She hasn't left the house for 12 years since the day her granddad went missing after something nasty happened at the town library.

Thomas Bloor's first novel appears to begin in serious vein, but gradually spirals into a bizarrely comic account of a town where everything official from the post to medical records have been taken over by the local library, which hasn't lent a book to anyone for more than a decade.

There are some touches, such as the three librarians sold into slavery by the dad who has done a moonlight flit to Las Vegas, that make up for the inconsistency of tone.

Burger Wuss

by Matthew T Anderson (Walker, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99 + 99p&p)

When 16-year-old Anthony finds the girlfriend he's hardly yet found the courage to kiss underneath another guy at a party, he decides it's time for no more Mr Nice Guy. So he gets a job at the local burger drive-thru where his rival works, and plots a carefully planned revenge. Only his rival is almost always one step ahead of the game.

Much of the pleasure of Matthew Anderson's comic novel comes from the burger wars that ensue and the clash of values between corporate America and the dissidents like Anthony and Shunt, the vegan burger flipper, who refuse to buy into the dream. The writing is flip and cynical. Great fun.

webTitle: Barthez signs for United in £7.8m deal

fields.headline: Barthez signs for United in £7.8m deal
fields.trailText: Fabien Barthez has finally signed for Manchester United in a £7.8m deal - a British record for a goalkeeper.
fields.body:
Fabien Barthez has finally signed for Manchester United in a £7.8m deal - a British record for a goalkeeper.

The French international put pen to paper on a six-year deal worth a reported £45,000-a-week at Old Trafford this afternoon following a medical yesterday.

The 28-year-old was a member of France's World Cup-winning side in 1998, and is seen by manager Sir Alex Ferguson as the perfect replacement for Peter Schmeichel.

"Mark Bosnich and Raimond van der Gouw are both terrific keepers but neither have quite the personality which Schmeichel possessed," United boss Sir Alex Ferguson said earlier this week. "But Fabien has. He is a real character."

The signing of Barthez is expected to end the Old Trafford career of Bosnich - a £5m move to Spanish champions Leportivo La Coruna has already been mooted.

fields.headline: The match makers
fields.standfirst: Adoption panels have power to accept or refuse prospective parents.  Kate Hilpern  on how they are improving their selection procedures
fields.trailText: Adoption panels have power to accept or refuse prospective parents. Kate Hilpern on how they are improving their selection procedures
fields.body:
We've all seen the headlines. "Couple turned down by adoption panel because they're overweight." "Panel claims woman should never adopt because she smokes." In a society where there are children languishing in the care system, the media never fails to snap up the chance to reveal apparent scandalous injustice.

It is true that adoption panels have become far more meticulous in reaching their recommendations, and that these recommendations carry more weight than ever. Ten years ago, they had a reputation for rubber-stamping. Even five years ago, many were dominated by the thinking of the local social services.

Mary Romaine, head of British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering (Baaf) in Wales, says: "I know of one panel where the chair and many of the members were social workers in charge of the very cases that were presented to the panel - and so they would be criticising themselves if they said, 'Hang on a minute, this family may not be appropriate."'

Since adoption regulations were revised in 1997, however, panels are obliged to appoint at least three independent members - preferably an adopter, an adoptee and a birth mother. Not surprisingly, this makes for far more penetrating debates when making adoption plans for children. Why is this couple so adamant about not wanting a child to have any contact with the birth parents? Does this woman realise an eight-year-old is likely to have attachment problems?

"But this change should be perceived as positive," insists Jenifer Lord, author of Effective Panels. "After all, the panel's job is to meet the needs of the child, so it is right that they require evidence of the prospective parents' values and attitudes, life experiences and commitment."

This is particularly important in a climate where one in five adoptions does not work out and the child is returned to public care. "This can often feel like yet another rejection for the children involved, who may already have experienced significant trauma, " explains Felicity Collier, chief executive of Baaf.

"Children who are available for adoption today are generally not the babies whom many prospective adopters wish to adopt. As a result, adoption of children can be a tremendous challenge. The neglect and abuse that some of the children have suffered can seriously affect their ability to settle into a new home. It is vital that an accurate assessment is made of adopters' abilities to parent such children."

In fact, it is due to the increasingly detailed discussions of panels that prospective adopters are not turned down on single issues such as being overweight or being a smoker. New research shows that, between 1994 and 1998, only 6% of adopters were rejected. But because of strict confidentiality rules that all panel members rightly adhere to, they are never able to defend themselves against the few disappointed applicants who run to the tabloids with half-truths.

This is not to say there isn't room for improvement. A recent study carried out by Cardiff Law School found that the practice of adoption panels is still highly variable across the country. It is for this reason that training is gaining acclaim nationwide. Panels are now required by law to have at least one full training day per year, and increasing numbers are opting for three or four.

These incorporate issues such as to what extent your decision might be influenced by applicants having a history of smoking cannabis or being homosexual. Members are also updated on legal functions, agency policy, equal opportunities and practice issues. Some members may be in favour of nuclear families and need showing that, in some cases, single parents suit the needs of a child just as well, if not better.

A further breakthrough has been the number of panels allowing prospective adopters to appear personally before them. "This has proved to be incredibly valuable," says Romaine. "Say, for instance, there was a death of a birthchild. The parents may wish to discuss this face-to-face to assure the panel that it would not get in the way of parenting a child through adoption."

Research has shown that not all panels hold discussions on adoption disruptions. "This is something that, thankfully, is also changing," says Lord. "Where possible, the panel should receive the original documents of family histories. That way, they can use any lessons that can be learned from the breakdown in future decision making."

Lord also believes that the recruitment process of panels needs working at. "In many panels, a social worker will say, 'Ah, I know an adoptive mother who'll be interested in joining up.' But it is far better to advertise in the local press to ensure that the independent members really are independent."

Adoption panels are not perfect. There will constantly be room for betterment. But by reporting on them in a sensationalist manner, the media is discouraging more and more people from applying to care for children who desperately need families. Since there is a real shortage of adopters willing and able to do so, this has serious consequences.

 Kate Hilpern is a journalist and an independent member of an adoption panel.

fields.headline: That sinking feeling
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Milton charts the rough passage through the Commons of the utilities bill, which seeks to put consumers and the environment first
fields.trailText: Nicholas Milton charts the rough passage through the Commons of the utilities bill, which seeks to put consumers and the environment first
fields.body:
In the stormy seas which engulf the House of Commons, it will probably be dismissed as a bill blown off course by freak waves. But the maiden voyage of the utilities bill - a flagship piece of legislation designed to regulate the gas, electricity, water and telecommunications industries - has turned into Westminster's equivalent of Mutiny on the Bounty.

The bill began promisingly enough when it was launched in January. The Department of Trade and Industry proudly boasted that it would reduce our bills by 10%. This was New Labour putting consumers before shareholders and the environment before executive pay. But if the sentiment of the bill was on message, the detail left a lot to be desired. By committee stage in the Commons, MPs had put down over 900 amendments and the bill was sailing into troubled waters.

In March, the environmental movement tried to steer the bill back on course by tabling a series of amendments through the Liberal Democrats and furiously lobbying Labour backbenchers. Everything was going well for a big showdown over sustainable development until Andrew Stunnell and Norman Baker failed to appear in the Commons - an admirable example of Liberal Democrat joined up thinking. Unsurprisingly, their amendment sunk without trace.

Unbeknown to the loyal New Labour members serving on the committee, the government had been shaken by the telephone and digital companies, who threatened to open fire if telecommunications were not withdrawn from the bill.

In the ensuing battle, the telephone companies, with the support of John Prescott, won a resounding victory. This led to the farcical sight of the energy minister, Helen Liddell, having to justify to her own backbenchers why she was withdrawing half of the bill midway through the committee.

In a vain attempt to get her off the hook, DTI officials had stayed up all night desperately trying to find a similar precedent in the last 30 years of parliament history. They couldn't.

Liddell's boss, Stephen Byers, was also to feel the full wrath of the storm at DTI question time. In a face-saving exercise, he claimed that New Labour was now the party which "listened to industry". To hoots of laughter and jeering from the opposition, his shadow, Angela Browning, ceremoniously ripped her copy of the bill in two. For Byers, it was to be good practice for the far more testing waters which lay ahead over Longbridge.

The next navigational blunder was over that most benign of subjects, renewable energy. The Liberal Democrats, who had now decided to turn up for committee meetings, successfully got an amendment passed which included a reference to producing 10% of the UK's electricity from renewable sources in the next decade. Nothing remarkable about that you would think, especially as it was the government's own target. However, it turned out that the whips had been asleep - or, in sympathy with the Liberals, had jumped ship - for upon hearing the news, Liddell blew a fuse and the offending amendment was removed at the report stage.

All of which begs the question why the government bothers with environmental targets at all - or, come to that, parliamentary scrutiny.

At this point, the Conservatives decided to join in with a heavyweight contribution to the mutiny. Their spokesman, Nick Gibb, who had attended many committee meetings, excelled himself when he came out with the truly memorable line that energy efficiency targets saving £50 a year off electricity bills would be an "intolerable burden on consumers". Gibb must be a really popular constituency MP.

The bill was finally to flounder on the obscure rock of "net metering". This amendment aimed to give people a fair price for producing their own electricity - for example, by putting solar panels on their roof. While Labour backbenchers initially enthusiastically supported the idea, they soon found themselves in deep water with Liddell's second in command, Kim Howells.

However, even they were unprepared for their minister's reasoning for not throwing this lifeline to the UK's beleaguered renewables industry. Howells, a former NUM official who had previously caused uproar by saying that the Conservatives were right to privatise the coal industry, compared the case for supporting net metering to... cauliflowers. According to Howell's logic, "If you take a cauliflower to the supermarket then the retailer won't pay you as much for it as you would have to pay if you bought one there yourself."

This bizarre example left even the most erudite committee members dumb struck. Perhaps anyone who can make any sense of it should put their answers on a postcard and send it to the minister without delay.

The shipwrecked bill is now due to enter the House of Lords, the last hope for firm renewable energy targets. An amendment to promote sustainable development is expected to receive widespread support, with Lord Ezra, formerly the head of the National Coal Board, and Baroness Young known to be sympathetic.

Once it has navigated the Lords, the bill will return to the Commons. It would be a tragedy of Titanic proportions if peers were to pass desperately needed environmental amendments only for them to be removed again.

Before sailing back into the eye of the storm, Liddell would do well to remember that her green credentials - and, ultimately, those of her beleaguered boss, Stephen Byers - are riding on the bill. In the current maelstrom which surrounds the DTI, to throw the amendments overboard a second time would not be wise.

 Nicholas Milton is utilities bill co-ordinator for the Socialist Environment and Resources Association, the green wing of the Labour party.

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Although Roger Graef made his name developing the "fly on the wall" technique of film-making, nobody could accuse him of being a mere voyeur. His Academy Award winning series on the Thames Valley police and subsequent film work in prisons and courtrooms has been complemented by highly praised books such as Talking Blues and Living Dangerously, in which police and juvenile offenders talk about crime and justice in their own words.
fields.body:
Although Roger Graef made his name developing the "fly on the wall" technique of film-making, nobody could accuse him of being a mere voyeur. His Academy Award winning series on the Thames Valley police and subsequent film work in prisons and courtrooms has been complemented by highly praised books such as Talking Blues and Living Dangerously, in which police and juvenile offenders talk about crime and justice in their own words.

His contribution to criminology has now been recognised by a fellowship of the Mannheim Institute at the London School of Economics and by a visiting professorship at the University of Oxford. But he's likely to upset some of his new academic colleagues with a book to be published later this year by the Calouste Gulbenkian foundation, Why Restorative Justice? Repairing the Harm Caused by Crime.

Graef seeks to overthrow the traditional legalistic and punitive approach to crime and replace it with one based upon the concept of mediation. He insists that there is nothing exotic or obscure about such an idea. "It happens constantly in families when a parent or third party mediates between warring family members. It happens at work between friends. It happens when couples are thinking of splitting up."

His enthusiasm for bringing criminals and victims together so that they can, with the help of a professional mediator, work out how best to remedy the harm done, is based upon filming mediation in a wide variety of settings, from Northern Ontario to Northampton, from Texas to Thames Valley. "That experience has convinced me that restorative justice deserves a central place in our justice procedures."

Graef recognises that there are still many unresolved issues about how victim-offender mediation might work. Any decision to go to mediation would, of course, be voluntary, but how would a successful mediation be recognised by the criminal justice system? Offenders are hardly likely to agree to participate unless the process offered them a chance to reduce their sentence, but how would this reduction be standardised and how could one be certain that an apologetic offender had not merely learned another way to cheat the system?

It would be unfair to say Graef brushes these and other objections aside, but he passionately believes nothing could be worse than the present system. How would he characterise his attitude? In only two words: "Pragmatic impatience."

 Laurie Taylor talks to Roger Graef and the penal theorist, Andrew von Hirsch, about restorative justice on Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4pm today.

fields.headline: Society shorts
fields.trailText: Fire investigators believe that a blaze at a Chinese restaurant in Wednesfield, West Midlands, was caused by spontaneous combustion of some grease-stained overalls.
fields.body:
Overall loss: Fire investigators believe that a blaze at a Chinese restaurant in Wednesfield, West Midlands, was caused by spontaneous combustion of some grease-stained overalls.

Paw show: A sniffer dog used to detect drugs at a young offenders institution near Wallingford, Oxfordshire, has been fitted with leather boots after inmates complained it was leaving paw prints on their beds.

Loud protest: The organist at a church in Henley-on-Thames, Oxfordshire, has quit after complaining that the vicar sings too loud over a microphone and puts off the choir.

Otter nonsense: Police called to a reported burglary at a house in Wark, Northumberland, found the intruder in the toilet was a wild otter, which they apprehended and returned to the banks of the River Tweed.

Small gesture: Managers of a supermarket have had a scaled-down trolley made for a regular customer from Lincolnshire who is only 4ft tall.

Nice joint: Prospective buyers of a Southampton butcher's house are being offered a year's supply of meat as an incentive.

Losing face: After a season in which they lost every game, a pub's Sunday league football team in Leeds played a friendly against their supporters, and lost 5-4.

Moovie maker: Images from a camcorder strapped to a pedigree Holstein cow at this year's Devon county show will be transmitted live on the internet.

Snapped up: Customers at an Edinburgh fish and chip shop are being offered portions of fried crocodile at £5 a time.

Prize drawers: Matthew Rhys, star of the West End production of The Graduate, has donated a pair of white boxer shorts, which he wears in the bedroom scene with Kathleen Turner, to a Cardiff woman organising a prize draw in aid of Guide Dogs for the Blind.

Too cocky: Villagers in Walgrave, Northamptonshire, have rounded up a flock of 13 peacocks which have been digging up gardens, holding up traffic and keeping residents awake with their mating calls.

Reputation smeared: A rugby player had to be treated in hospital for hypothermia after being smeared in mayonnaise and left to spend the night in a wheelie bin after his club's annual dinner in Evesham, Hereford and Worcester.

Disc drive: Pupils at a failing school near Doncaster, South Yorkshire, are being offered more than £30,000-worth of CD vouchers if they improve their grades.

Hanging offence: A fare dodger ejected from a train in Nottingham hitched a five-mile free ride by hanging on to the rear windscreen wiper then fleeing at the next station before waiting police could nab him.

fields.headline: Keeping in touch
fields.standfirst: Trapped in a dark and silent void, deafblind people are the least capable of protesting about government disregard for their isolation. But some are still determined to stay in touch with the world around them
fields.trailText: Trapped in a dark and silent void, deafblind people are the least capable of protesting about government disregard for their isolation. But some are still determined to stay in touch with the world around them
fields.body:
At rush hour, Gaela Benn got out of the tube at the wrong station and, standing with her guide dog, called out for help. But despite being continuously surrounded by a crowd, she stood helplessly on the packed platform, unaided for 20 minutes. The problem was that not only is she blind, she is also profoundly deaf.

Gaela has no doubt that people offered help, but they were baffled as to how to communicate with her. Human contact can only come from the touch of a person in the outside world who is invisible to her and cannot be heard by her.

There are roughly 20,000 deafblind people in Britain and how to get through their almost impenetrable isolation is one of the great challenges of a civilised society - a challenge not very vigorously taken up by the authorities, it must be said. There is, for example, no automatic right to provision of a carer.

Gaela Benn is in a minority of that isolated 20,000; the majority of deafblind people are born with that condition, but she has a perfect memory of the sights and sounds of the world around her. Now in her forties, it wasn't until she was 30 that she was diagnosed as suffering from Usher syndrome, a genetic disorder which progressively attacks hearing and sight.

Her ability to appear to function as a hearing person creates additional problems. Many deaf people can only manage a distorted form of speech in hesitant rhythms. But Gaela, who also walks with an alert, unflinching air, retained perfect diction, her fluency unimpaired. It is almost impossible to believe that while Galea responds to you in perfectly natural speech no sound is reaching her.

As in many cases, neither her parents nor her GP realised she had hearing difficulties until she was in her teens. At school, she was considered to be stupid or slow, a friend says, because she laughed at the wrong time or didn't laugh at the right one. An examination in a GP's quiet surgery didn't reveal the defect, since at that stage the difficulty came only from external noises.

When the diagnosis came it was brutal. In an interview that did not last more than 10 minutes, the specialist told her the condition was irreversible, untreatable.

In a BBC2 documentary, Deafblind, Gaela tells the director, Mischa Scorer, what her reaction was. "He treated me as if I were a piece of wood with no feelings at all," she says. "Medically there was nothing more you can do, end of story and off you go".

This is characteristic of the reaction of some medical people who become indignant and almost hostile when faced with a human condition totally outside their control.

Scorer, who won an Emmy in 1984 for Heart of the Dragon, one of the first western documentaries filmed in China, took a long time to win the confidence of a person who, as Gaela describes it herself, lives in a world in which "a black box completely surrounds you, all frosty glass and all you can see through it is the light and vague movements... [hearing nothing] your world exists only in what you can actually touch with your hands. Beyond what you can touch with your hands, or someone making physical contact with you, nothing exists".

Gaela had the choice of retreating into institutionalised home life, rarely going out, as many deafblind people do, or of constructing a life of her own. She chose to create an independent life, cooking and taking care of herself in her council flat. But she rejects any talk of heroic triumph over disability. She says that deafblindness is not the whole story of her life; she also lives as a human being. She is fortunate in having a friend with whom she went to adult education classes. For many years, this friend (who does not wish to be named) has been her interpreter and helper.

There is a deafblind alphabet in which every letter is tapped out on the palm of the hand, laboriously, as in a written language. But Gaela discovered that her hands were not sensitive enough to keep track of this stream of letters. She often found that only part of a letter was conveyed through touch: the letter D, for example, came out unintelligibly as a touch at top and bottom, or there might be something missing from an R.

With her friend, she worked out a more "comfortable" language. Gaela thinks visually and the language is, curiously enough, more "visual", with an element of touch mime.

But the skills deafblind people can acquire are astonishing. In Scorer's documentary we also see Graham Hicks, registered blind from the age of three and profoundly deaf by seven, deftly operating a power saw. He is a skilled DIY worker and cook.

As he learned to speak as a child, he does not have to endure the profound isolation of those born deafblind and who are almost out of reach of any form of language. Graham can speak in a halting fashion, but is perfectly capable of expressing himself. He can also communicate through touch, using a finger alphabet. But there is a profound distance between deafblind people and those with normally functioning senses. He says it is impossible for people to understand what this disability is like.

Graham is married to Jackie Hicks, chief executive of Deafblind UK. "He is a person just like I am," she says, "but in the way he relates to the world he is very, very different from me. To make things work, I have to understand that all the time. And, to some extent, he has to understand how I relate to the world as well.

"It is very true that sight and hearing are distance senses; they give us a sense of what is happening outside ourselves. Much more of Graham's life, it seems to me, is happening within his body and what he can reach and what he can touch. He is less in touch with things that are much further outside himself. He can get access to the news, but other things that are happening around us he hasn't access to and has to be told. So you have to get quite deeply into that sort of understanding."

If deafblind people are in effect disregarded by government, the reason is obvious: they are mostly unseen and are the least capable of effective protest.

 The documentary, Deafblind, will be broadcast in the Under the Sun series on BBC2 tomorrow at 9.30pm.

 Deafblind UK is at 01733 358100

 Sense also works with the deafblind and offers support for families, carers and professionals. For details of projects and branches in the UK, contact 020-7272 7774.

fields.headline: Cutting ties
fields.standfirst: Mark Goldring on the dilemmas of deciding which countries most need volunteer support
fields.trailText: Mark Goldring on the dilemmas of deciding which countries most need volunteer support
fields.body:
I knew by the second set of traffic lights that the taxi driver didn't have a clue. I was in Bangkok to meet with government officials to announce the official closure of the VSO volunteer programme in Thailand. However, on a completely different matter, after months of calling the Foreign Office in London to arrange a meeting with Robin Cook, he was here in Bangkok on the last day of a tour to Thailand and had agreed to give me 15 minutes before he left for the airport.

At long last, after a tortuous journey, I arrived at my destination a full 15 minutes late. As I struggled into my jacket, Robin Cook courteously came to greet me and I proffered a sweaty palm.

It was important to meet Cook to emphasise that there was still an enormous amount of work for VSO to carry out in the south-east Asia region.

Our discussion led to VSO's strategic approach in defining our areas of work and expanding our programme in other areas of the world where the poverty was greatest. Rwanda and Ethiopia are examples of countries desperate to rebuild their education system and social infrastructure and where experienced volunteers can have a direct impact.

My main meeting in Bangkok was with the department of technical and economic cooperation, the government body that is crucial in enabling VSO to carry out the work requested by Thai employers.

In reality, the meeting was a formality. The closure of the VSO programme in Thailand after almost 40 years had been decided. But, in Thailand, formalities are important. The rationale behind pulling out of any country is a complex affair. There are always good reasons for VSO to remain. Development is an incremental process that is difficult to pin down, let alone measure and monitor.

Given that we do have limited resources and that we must prioritise the needs of poorer countries, continuing the programme in Thailand had to be weighed up against the possibility of expanding in countries such as Mozambique, Ethiopia or Rwanda.

The VSO Thailand programme is a successful one. Concentrating on two areas - the education of children with special needs and environmental education and management. Around 40 professional volunteers are working effectively, sharing their skills with Thai colleagues. They have achieved a lot; Thailand has achieved much more.

In some respects, these are perfect conditions to work in, but Thailand has a strong foundation for continued development and that is why we in London, far from the action, decided that we should begin the process of withdrawal. It is for our colleagues locally to plan just how to do this sensibly.

Although VSO Thailand will close, I was keen to impress on Siree Bunang, the deputy general of DTEC, that this was a sign of Thailand's success.

Recent Thai government legislation has guaranteed that all children, regardless of their background, will have the right and access to primary education and that children with special needs will be integrated into mainstream education.

I noted this was a welcome sign and one which would ease the transition, as Thai teachers would carry on much of the work VSO volunteers traditionally had tried to set in place.

"Legislation is welcome, Mr Goldring, but legislation is not the issue," replied Siree Bunang with a shrewd smile. "It is implementing the legislation. That is where VSO has been of most value."

While Thailand is clearly moving in the right direction on a policy level, a lot more work is required to make sure these changes are implemented on the ground. Therefore, while the decision for VSO to close has been made, the real issue is how do we close in a time period that allows us to build on the work we've done so far. Thailand has five years with no loss of VSO resources to maximise the impact of the work already undertaken and to reach a sensible closing point. Siree Bunang accepted this, though we were both aware that there was still an enormous amount to do.

As I stepped outside into the baking heat, I removed my jacket and tie. That had been a positive meeting, but it was not over yet. As I hailed another taxi, my final meeting awaited me. It was time to face the volunteers.

 Mark Goldring is chief executive of Voluntary Service Overseas.
