fields.headline: Carry on regardless
fields.standfirst: Ray Rowden on how self-regulation of the medical profession has destroyed public confidence
fields.trailText: Ray Rowden on how self-regulation of the medical profession has destroyed public confidence
fields.body:
In the past, the public was perhaps more inclined to accept a culture where the doctor or nurse "knew best". But recent events have powerfully challenged this perception, and a simple clause in the new NHS act could see the biggest shake-up ever in these arrangements.

The cases of the Bristol cardiac service, where two doctors were removed from the medical register, and the case of Dr Harold Shipman, the murderous Hyde GP, have shocked the public.

Nursing, in recent years, has also had its share of scandal. Beverly Allitt, the children's nurse who killed babies, did little to instil public confidence, and a recent decision to restore to the register a male nurse who had previously raped elderly women patients caused controversy.

Since late Victorian times, the health professions have been allowed the privilege of governing their own affairs. This is done through statutory instruments, approved by parliament, which created the bodies that regulate doctors, nurses and various therapists - bodies such as the General Medical Council (GMC), the United Kingdom Central Council for Nursing (UKCC) and the Council for the Professions Supplementary to Medicine (CPSM).

These august bodies are large, with between 60 and 100 members - a majority of whom get there by election from within the professions and the rest arriving by a combination of nomination by the great and good and appointment by the secretary of state for health.

In theory, the job of these bodies is quite clear: they are there to protect the public from rogue or negligent practitioners. Their ultimate power is to remove a professional from the state register, thus debarring them from practice. Historically, all these bodies have had an in-built majority of professionals sitting on their governing councils.

The problem with current self-regulation arrangements lies in the domination of these councils and their procedures by the professions themselves. In short, if you have a usurious complaint, the professional complained against is judged predominantly by his or her peers.

The public is rightly beginning to question the independence of such arrangements. These bodies are also slow and cumbersome in embracing change, often through no fault of their own. Before the 1999 NHS act, any government wanting to change the law governing these professions had to go through a laborious process of preparing and enacting complex primary legislation. Even assuming that parliamentary time could be found, the process of changing law usually took years.

The 1999 act changes all that. In future, the government can bring about rapid change by, first, consulting legitimate interested parties. Having consulted, the government can now pass changes through the privy council. And, once approved, proposed changes can be laid in the form of an order before parliament in a matter of weeks, and then pass swiftly into law.

I hope that the government will be bold in using these new provisions to alter radically the shape and scope of these regulatory arrangements. Why should bodies like the GMC or UKCC be dominated by professionals? In today's world, where health care becomes more complex and the public rightly demands more involvement in decisions about their health, should the public not have a greater say in governing these professions? The councils of important bodies should have half of the seats filled by lay representatives, nominated by a wide cross-section of public organisations and by the public themselves.

If governance of these professions was seen to be shared by a legitimate professional input, matched by an equal voice on behalf of the public, a true sense of balanced partnership could emerge. The public could draw far more confidence from such arrangements in protecting their interests when things go badly wrong. There is a perception that the current arrangements are stacked in favour of the professions, that vested self-interests might dominate at the expense of proper public protection.

The 1999 act allows for rapid and bold change. Alan Milburn, the secretary of state, has recently used these new powers in a limited way with the GMC role in governing doctors. Let's hope that, if the government wins a second term, Blair is prepared to go further and use the act to rebuild public confidence in the health professions.

 Ray Rowden is a registered nurse and visiting professor in the department of health studies at the University of York. The views expressed in this article are personal.

fields.headline: Looking for love
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair is insisting on radical action to ensure that children in care are placed quickly with families. But it just isn't that simple
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is insisting on radical action to ensure that children in care are placed quickly with families. But it just isn't that simple
fields.body:
The prime minister is unequivocal. In the latest issue of Red magazine, he talks of adoption being "too bureaucratic" and suggests it needs "a radical overhaul - I want to make it easier for children to be placed quickly".

He has already held a Downing Street seminar on the issue, a report is currently being drawn up by a cabinet office taskforce, and a consultation paper is due this autumn. The moves follow the Waterhouse report into abuse in children's homes in north Wales, published in February, which prompted Conservatives to propose an adoption plan for every child in care.

There is nothing new about adoption being used as a political football. What disturbs social care professionals is the way in which both major parties have been simplifying a complex issue and ignoring the fact that, of the 55,000 children in care, the number in children's homes has shrunk to a small minority: about 14,000, many of whom do not want to be adopted.

The politicians continue to ignore the huge change which has taken place in adoption - from a service helping infertile couples to obtain a baby, to the infinitely more difficult task of placing badly abused children into adoptive families where skilled adults can help them through their trauma and damage. Adoption is no longer a one-off transaction. Many adoptive families will require social service support for years.

Critics of the current system say social workers, driven by ideology, block decent ordinary people from adopting children and condemn those children to a lifetime of misery in the care system.

Reforms have always been billed as a means to curtail politically correct social workers and the reality of adoption, including pros and cons, has been buried under the rhetoric.

Professionals agree that there are many problems with the adoption process, including its legal framework. Outmoded adoption laws were written before The Children Act 1989 gave local authorities a duty to promote children's welfare and to do everything they could to support families.

There have been many attempts to reform adoption law. A review that began at the end of the eighties was followed by numerous discussion and consultative documents and culminated in a draft adoption bill in 1996. Although welcomed by professionals at the time, it was then shelved in the last days of the Conservatives by a government reluctant to get embroiled in such a polarised debate in the run-up to a general election. The current home secretary, Jack Straw, has suggested that teenage mothers could offer up their babies for adoption.

Thirty years ago, there were plenty of children available for adoption - 22,000 at the height in the seventies. But social change has meant the number of unmarried mothers putting their babies up for adoption has fallen and the number of babies available has dropped from 9,000 a year in the mid-1970s to 150 a year now, says Felicity Collier, chief executive of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering (Baaf).

Official figures show there are roughly 6,000 adoptions a year, and two-thirds are by step-parents or relatives. Of the thousands of children in care, only a fraction are available for adoption; most will return to live with their families. Most recent figures show that 2,162 children were adopted from care in England and the numbers are going up. Baaf estimates that there are up to 10,000 children in the UK who are looking for permanent new homes.

Childcare professionals agree that, until recently, local authorities haven't placed enough emphasis on adoption for children in care and that there are wide variations in rates between authorities. The government has set tough targets on adoption for local authorities and experts believe they are already having an impact.

The number of children appearing in Baaf's Be My Parent magazine, where children who need parents are "advertised", has doubled in recent months to 400, says Collier. As councils are making greater efforts with adoption, so preliminary evidence from a social services inspectorate study, announced in December, pointed to a vast shortage in the numbers of people willing to adopt.

Collier believes more young children than are currently placed for adoption could benefit, but like many in the field she doesn't believe it is the answer for all children.

Professionals recall with a shudder the days when young mothers felt pressured to give their babies up for adoption - even when, like Clare Short MP, who was reunited with her son four years ago, they were neither ignorant nor destitute at the time. As one professional puts it: "The pendulum may have swung too far the other way, but we don't want it to swing all the way back again."

Adoption today is altogether more complicated, says Collier. Those who argue that it provides a "clean break" for children in care are naive. "These aren't babies," she says. "You can't tell a child to clear its memory of their birth parent. In the 1960s, there was never any expectation that the birth family would be involved in the child's future. Now 30-40% of adoptions involve some form of ongoing contact."

Children awaiting adoption may have emotional or behavioural difficulties, disabilities or may come with siblings. It takes all kinds of people to cope with the range of children who need homes, says June Thoburn, professor of social work at the University of East Anglia.

The breakdown rate for adoptions shows how hard it is to match parents and children. For the over-threes, an average of one in five permanent placements of children from care break down; for those aged 10-12, it is as high as 50%. The only way to reduce the breakdown rate is to get the right families, and provide them with proper support, says Thoburn. "You can't place children who find it difficult to give love with adopters who expect to be loved as soon as the placement is made. That's why we need to find out so much about prospective adopters during the assessment process."

Moira Gibb, senior vice-president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, says that, with adoptive parents in short supply, social workers have been careful not to raise children's hopes unnecessarily. "It hasn't been a priority in the past because social workers know it can mean spending two to three years searching for the right family, and that wait is very destabilising for the children," she says.

If the numbers of people coming forward to complain about their treatment by adoption officials are to be believed, then social workers are getting this difficult task wrong. There are undoubtedly people who have been treated very badly by the current system, which is long overdue for reform, says Collier. Adoptive parents have complained that they weren't given a true account of their children's history. Others say post-adoption support is almost non-existent.

Those working in the field accept that social workers don't get it right all of the time. They say the judgments staff make are difficult in the extreme and that a handful of high-profile cases wrongfully create an impression of widespread failure.

When cases hit the headlines, local authorities are often unable to defend themselves if doing so would reveal confidential information. This was illustrated by the case of the Bramleys, the Cambridgeshire couple who absconded with their foster children. To the outside world, they appeared perfectly good parents. The local authority, on the other hand, had information that it believed at that time meant that the Bramleys might be unsuitable adopters.

Local authorities and adoption agencies believe there is much the government can do to improve the current system. Practical measures could include a campaign to recruit more parents, plus a system that would allow councils to recoup money spent on preparing couples for adoption when they pass them to another local authority.

More money is also needed for post-adoption services. Campaigners say that many more children would find permanent homes once these measures were in place.

fields.headline: Bought and paid for
fields.standfirst: Suspicions about science depend upon who is funding the research. Jonathon Porritt on how science has been corrupted by collusion with governments and big business to pervert the truth
fields.trailText: Suspicions about science depend upon who is funding the research. Jonathon Porritt on how science has been corrupted by collusion with governments and big business to pervert the truth
fields.body:
Observing the response of leading scientists to the debate sparked off by Prince Charles's contribution to the Reith lectures has been illuminating. Although one or two have sought to engage constructively, most have chosen to fire off contemptuous tirades spiked with personal insult and patronising pity for the intellectual pygmies who dare challenge their authority. They assume that any such challenge could only come from people corrupted by soapy emotionalism with a deep hostility to science itself.

For me, nothing could be further from the truth. In reviewing the contribution that science makes in meeting the challenge of sustainable development, I came to the conclusion that science is absolutely at the heart of that challenge. All our endeavours to build a genuinely sustainable way of life for 6bn people today, and around 10bn by 2050, are totally dependent on high quality scientific research, and the policies and sustainable technologies that flow from that research. It's no good bleating on about the dangers of "technological fixes"; without those fixes (in energy, transport, waste minimisation, pollution control and so on), we're quite simply stuffed.

Massive investment in research and new technology is, therefore, a necessary condition of achieving sustainable development. But it is not a sufficient condition. And that's where my concern about the inadequacies of the scientific method, and the intolerant fundamentalism of those like Richard Dawkins and Lewis Wolpert who subscribe to the religion of scientific materialism (for that is what it seems to be for them), comes to the fore. Paradoxically, nothing is more likely to reinforce a growing anti-science movement than their absolutist arrogance.

If there's one issue that exemplifies this dilemma it is the whole question of the independence of science today. To what extent does the growing commercialisation of science render it unfit (or at least, less fit) to serve the public purpose without fear or favour? Underlying all those surveys about how much trust the general public has in scientists today is the question of who they work for. Predictably, scientists working for the government are trusted less than scientists working for large companies, who in turn are trusted much, much less than scientists working for environmental organisations.

People's suspicions today are stronger than they've ever been, and with good reason, given that such a huge percentage of scientists are now paid by private or public sector employers who often have little interest in open scientific debate. Official government secrecy, commercial confidentiality, and the ever-present threat of funding being withdrawn are quite sufficient to button the lips of all but the most courageous.

This is not a new phenomenon. At several points in Silent Spring, published in 1962, Rachel Carson comments on the complicity of so many of the government scientists she came into contact with when researching the impact of pesticides on the environment and human health. She sympathised with their dilemma, but had little respect for what she saw as the dereliction of their duty as scientists, however dutiful they were as government officials. In private correspondence, she often quoted Abraham Lincoln: "To sin by silence when they should protest makes cowards of men."

One can only surmise that Carson would be distraught at what is happening today, when not just cowardice but "science for sale" has become a familiar phenomenon, and when the stranglehold of large companies has become a great deal tighter than it was when Carson was writing in the early 1960s.

Many leading scientists simply refuse to acknowledge either the extent or the significance of this phenomenon of co-option. The eminent geneticist Steve Jones often points out that "money doesn't smell" - by which he means that the source of any grant or research budget doesn't really matter, as the inherent integrity of the scientific method (and of the individual scientists themselves) will act as a sure defence against any malign influence.

One only has to look at the use of science in two critical environmental debates, climate change and genetic engineering, to see what complete tosh this is.

Research in climate change is largely government-driven, mediated through the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. This body was set up in 1998 at the behest of the UN general assembly to advise governments, and now involves more than 1,800 scientists from all around the world in elucidating the science of climate change. Through a number of working groups, these scientists move forward by consensus, with a highly active peer group review process in place.

This ensures that everyone has an opportunity to bring their views to bear on the debate, and has permitted the IPCC to see off the "wild cards" and most of the rubbish emanating from so-called "independent scientific experts" employed by front organisations working on behalf of the energy-intensive industries and right-wing political interests. "Bought science" has been an ugly and corrupt element in this debate for many years, provoking deep concern among reputable scientists, but it has been largely neutralised by the IPCC.

Compare that with the science process that underpins the debate about GM crops. Here the science is owned - literally and metaphorically - by a small number of very large companies. Much of the research is commercially confidential, never sees the light of day, and is carried out with the sole intent of generating future revenue streams. Nothing wrong with that in itself, of course, but it raises a substantial question mark over both the quality and the transparency of the research work done. UK politicians must now be ruefully reflecting on just how important a factor this has been in the collapse of the biotech industry across Europe.

Beneath all this lurks a deeper issue. Scientists invest enormous significance in their claim that they are not just independent and strictly objective, but positively "value-free" - often on the grounds that science only acquires "ethical content" when it is applied through public policy or technological development.

For years, people like Robin Grove-White and Brian Wynne, based at Lancaster University, have been trying to demonstrate just how absurd this myth really is. As is now widely recognised, science is socially constructed by all sorts of rules, peer group pressures, personal values and expectations. Even that reassuring notion of "sound science" is often shaped by prior social commitments framing the nature and boundaries of the issue under consideration.

With GM foods, for instance, if you think the key issue is a lack of food to meet the needs of starving people, then GM becomes "an ethical imperative". If you think the key issue is a lack of precaution and balance in the way we exploit the Earth's natural wealth, then GM serves as a telling symbol of unethical and unsustainable science.

The philosopher Philip Sherrard has summed this up: "There is one particular fallacy from which we must free ourselves, and this is the idea that contemporary scientific theories are somehow neutral, or value-free, and do not presuppose the submission of the human mind to a set of assumptions or dogmas in the way that is said to be demanded by adherence to a religious faith.

"Every thought, every observation, every judgment, every description, whether of the modern scientist or of anyone else, is soaked in preconceived built-in value judgments, assumptions and dogmas at least as rigid, if not more rigid (because they are so often unconsciously embraced), than those of any explicitly religious system. The very nature of human thought is such that it cannot operate independently of value judgments, assumptions and dogmas. Even the assertion that it can constitutes a value judgment, and implies a whole philosophy, whether we are aware of it or not."

Which helps to explain why secular materialists such as Richard Dawkins get so hot under the collar about their equally eminent scientific colleagues - such as Sir John Houghton, chairman of the royal commission on environmental pollution, and Sir Ghillean Prance, until recently director of the Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew - who see no clash between their work as scientists and their religious faith, explicitly espousing values and belief systems that must by definition shape the work they do as scientists.

Perish the thought that the Emperor of Objective Science should be seen to have no clothes precisely by comparison with the richly-clad apparel of scientists free of the illusion of value-free science.

webTitle: My brilliant plan: buy back the railways

fields.headline: My brilliant plan: buy back the railways
fields.standfirst:
Railtrack can't provide a decent service, so why don't we take over?

Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: This week it became apparent that Railtrack was pulling out of the planned £5bn upgrade to the west coast main line. It has effectively driven a steam train through the rail network's modernisation plans.
fields.body:
This week it became apparent that Railtrack was pulling out of the planned £5bn upgrade to the west coast main line. It has effectively driven a steam train through the rail network's modernisation plans. And the fact that it was a steam train just goes to show how little money has been spent on investment recently. No formal announcement was made, unless of course they got the station announcers to relay this embarrassing information over the tannoys so that no one would have the faintest idea what was being said. But we should not be surprised that they don't want to fork out £4bn to improve the railways; you'd have to sell several Casey Jones all-day breakfasts to recoup that sort of money. Railtrack believes that this sort of capital investment should come from the government. That's how things work on the railways since it was divided up by the Conservatives. One half, the private sector, collects the money; the other half, the taxpayer, is expected to dish it out. No wonder Railtrack's profits have increased every year. The gravy train is now leaving from Platform One.

Railtrack is like those passengers who spread their bags and coats across a double seat while you walk up and down the carriage looking for somewhere to sit. It's not illegal, it's just greedy. Last year's profits reached £428m after generous wages were paid out to the board. Presumably there were no more improvements that needed to be made to Britain's rail network, or the leftover money would have been spent on that. We all get annoyed at being ripped off, but at least when you pay £40 to watch Manchester United you know that Sir Alex Fergerson doesn't then expect the taxpayer to cough up for two new strikers and some more executive boxes. It's not as if Railtrack even had to pay the market value of the infrastructure in the first place. Luckily it had a family railcard and it was after 9.30 at a weekend, so it got the whole rail network for half price. And now just to show its commitment to an integrated transport system, it is now trying to sell off station car parks to private developers.

Given half a chance it would probably flog off those strips of land with those funny metal rail things on them as well; there'd be an attractive mews development with private pool and gymnasium stretching all the way from London to Glasgow.

This country has to have an effective train network. But while it is in the private sector the more money that is paid out to shareholders and executives then, as sure as leaves are going to land on the line in the autumn, the worse that service is going to be. There are just some national institutions that you cannot expect to run at a profit, such as the health service, the education system and Princess Margaret. The same is true with our railways; we need more investment, cheaper fares and the banning of the word "customer".

So a really bizarre and novel idea has just occurred to me. Why not have a railway system that is owned and operated by the state? I can't believe that no one has thought of this before. If it was all the property of the British people then the profit that comes from selling tickets and scalding hot tea with UHT milk could all be ploughed back in. There would be no conflict between safety and profit and the fatcats who run the rail companies wouldn't have to pretend they travel by train anymore. I know it has become politically unfashionable to defend state ownership, but if flared trousers can make a comeback then why can't nationalisation? Of course, anyone trying to sell the merits of this idea to the government could never call it nationalisation, you would have to give it a modern, business-sounding name like "Towards a Stake-Holding Community" and then you'd have to say the words "internet" and "millennium" a lot. But, call me a dangerous radical, if the taxpayer is forking out for the investment in the railways then the profits should go to the exchequer as well.

The failure of the rail companies to manage without state support should be a source of great satisfaction and encouragement to the left. Privatisation doesn't work. The private sector can't hack it. When John Major and Norman Lamont broke into the signal box and started desperately pulling levers, the rail industry was sent hurtling off in the wrong direction and eventually it will have to be brought back. Since then Railtrack has consistently dumped on the taxpayer, and hasn't even waited till the train pulled out of the station.

The railways should be brought back under state control and compensation should be as undervalued as the original sell off. Railtrack wouldn't have to provide any service or worry about safety or have anything to do with trains ever again. The trouble is they'd probably expect the government to step in and pay them huge profits anyway.

fields.headline: Pearl Harbor goes overboard
fields.trailText: The second world war-themed Disney megaproject, Pearl Harbor, looks set to exceed its already huge budget of $135m, according to a report in the New York Post.
fields.body:
The second world war-themed Disney megaproject, Pearl Harbor, looks set to exceed its already huge budget of $135m, according to a report in the New York Post.

These budgetary estimates are credited to an unnamed "on-the-set mole" who claims that the budget is "still upwards of that amount and "could go higher". Disney, who had already attracted criticism for the film's massive budget, has dismissed the article, accusing the "mole" of not having any idea of how a film's costs are added up.

Pearl Harbor, which is currently shooting in Hawaii, features an ensemble cast led by Ben Affleck and Cuba Gooding Jr. It is rumoured to have an impressive array of bombs and exploding gizmos choreographed by the blower-upper master/director Michael (Armageddon) Bay.

 If you want to see what all the money is being spent on, go to Coming Attractions, which has six exclusive, on-set pictures, taken on the day they filmed the bombing of the American destroyer fleet.

fields.headline: Mixed fortunes for Durham duo
fields.standfirst: wisden.com homes in on the players who are having a ball this season, and those who are a little embattled. If you have a candidate for this slot, email us at wisden@johnbrown.co.uk.
fields.trailText:
GOOD FORM
Simon Katich Durham
fields.body:
GOOD FORM
Simon Katich Durham

Katich, 24, an Australian Academy graduate, is filling the shoes of David Boon as Durham's overseas player this season. Unlike Boon, who played for windswept Tasmania, Katich is from Western Australia, where the pitches are hard, fast and quite unlike Chester-le-Street in a soggy spring. He duly made a terrible start to his county career, but found his feet in May, averaging over 60 in all cricket. A mystery virus kept him from making his international debut for Australia in Sri Lanka last September, but he has just been retained as one of the ACB's 25 contracted players and a prolific year at the Riverside should earn him a second chance.

8, 65, 6, 62, 45, 13, 47*, 137*, 45

In detail

First-class runs 268 at 67.00
One-day runs 160 at 53.33
Total runs 428 at 61.14

BAD FORM
Nick Speak Durham

Also filling David Boon's shoes at Durham is his successor as captain, Nick Speak. In April, he made an immediate impression with a couple of captain's innings: 72 against Yorkshire was followed the next day with 49 against Leicestershire, both in the B&H. But in May the runs dried up and he ended the month with an all-cricket average below ten. The horror story was particularly acute in the Championship: Speak managed just 11 runs in five innings.

fields.headline: Labour moving backwards on roads
fields.standfirst: The leaked news of Prescott's transport and road-building plans makes for a depressing U-turn, writes environment correspondent Paul Brown
fields.trailText: The leaked news of Prescott's transport and road-building plans makes for a depressing U-turn, writes environment correspondent  Paul Brown.
fields.body:
So the brave pledge of Labour to reduce and then reverse traffic growth is to be abandoned - and more money is to be thrown into road building.

It is a defeat for all those who hoped there was to be a return to an era when most people travelled to work on public transport, and it was possible to make a journey in relative speed and comfort in a bus.

Instead the powerful car, road transport, civil engineering lobby has turned back the tide of progress and the future looks bleak for anyone who has to travel anywhere.

For a country with more car plants than any other in the world and an economy based on making more and more cars and components for them it is perhaps surprising that John Prescott held out so long.

As it is, when the government's plans for transport are officially announced in six weeks, rather than leaked as they have been this week, it will be dressed up as an integrated transport package. In English that means there will be money for cars, trains, buses, trams, even bicycles so people can swap from one form of transport to another to continue their journey.

In theory it would work if there were not so many people trying to travel at once. Almost anyone who has to travel to work, particularly in the larger towns and cities, experiences delays and congestion almost every day.

Roads are jammed, buses hardly move, trains are overcrowded, frequently cancelled and late.

Even so there has been some progress. Passenger numbers on trains are surging, partly because the roads are so bad, but potentially providing revenue for new investment. In cities like Edinburgh in which public transport has been given priority - for example creating proper bus lanes where cars cannot intrude - passengers are coming back.

Yet we are intent on going backwards. Experience has already taught us that building a new section of road encourages more traffic, and merely moves the jam somewhere else. This is not anecdotal, this is proven and acknowledged by transport planners. This does not mean a bypass or an improved junction does not ease local congestion and make some people's life better, but the claim that more and more roads represent value for money is hard to accept.

50 cars on a city road take up a lot of space. 10 buses using less tarmac could carry 500 people to work. Yet the freedom to drive anywhere is code for the right to prevent public transport working efficiently.

Two or three hundred people travel in a train. With more money spent on signalling, improved maintenance and more rolling stock the numbers travelling by rail could be doubled without adding an inch of extra track. Labour's £140 billion boost for transport as it is billed will be an opportunity missed. A good slice of this massive sum will be wasted on roads that will make no difference to the mess. The main hope now is that the much-predicted rise in teleworking and other advances in technology will really allow half the nation to stay at home rather than grind their way to work through gridlocked Britain.

This does not mean a bypass or an improved junction does not ease local congestion and make some people's life better, but the claim that more and more roads represent value for money is hard to accept. 50 cars on a city road take up a lot of space. 10 buses using less tarmac could carry 500 people to work. Yet the freedom to drive anywhere is code for the right to prevent public transport working efficiently. Two or three hundred people travel in a train. With more money spent on signalling, improved maintenance and more rolling stock the numbers travelling by rail could be doubled without adding an inch of extra track. Labour's £140 billion boost for transport as it is billed will be an opportunity missed. A good slice of this massive sum will be wasted on roads that will make no difference to the mess. The main hope now is that the much-predicted rise in teleworking and other advances in technology will really allow half the nation to stay at home rather than grind their way to work through gridlocked Britain.

fields.headline: Top of the Pops
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the pop music programme on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the pop music programme going stateside on the net
fields.body:
1. And in at number one, it's TOP OF THE POPS!

2. And this one, folks, has been climbing the charts for - wait for it - 36 years! First broadcast in 1964 with Jimmy Savile at the helm, TOTP has finally made it stateside!

3. Impressed by the vigour of the show, US TV executives are bidding for the rights to an American version.

4. It would use the same studio design and title sequence as the British show, but the chart would come from Billboard - a rather more sober index in which Paul McCartney, Tina Turner and country music appear.

5. TOTP's rise follows a period of decline for the show, which, despite a revamp in 1991, had been losing viewers. Like Radio 1, it was regarded as out of touch and irrelevant to the burgeoning club scene.

6. Producer Chris Cowey was appointed to reverse the decline. He made the handsome Jamie Theakston a presenter and banned videos, forcing acts to turn up if they wanted airplay.

7. Apart from the trusty screaming teenagers, it was a far cry from the irony-laden days when John Peel was presenting. Now Jayne Middlemiss and lads' favourite Gail Porter are regular presenters.

8. This week's schedule includes Travis, S Club 7 and Belle and Sebastian - as well as Billie, the teenage warbler.

9. If those names are unfamiliar, you can relive the glory days of TOTP with TV Cream's treasury of Pops moments...

10. ...or grimace at the memory of some truly appalling sets.

webTitle: China jails 'number one rich man' for life

fields.headline: China jails 'number one rich man' for life
fields.trailText: One of China's most colourful businessmen, the former millionaire Mou Qizhong, was sentenced to life imprisonment for fraud in the central city of Wuhan yesterday.
fields.body:
One of China's most colourful businessmen, the former millionaire Mou Qizhong, was sentenced to life imprisonment for fraud in the central city of Wuhan yesterday.

Once described as China's richest man, Mou rose to fame by trading vanloads of surplus Chinese consumer goods for Russian passenger jets.

In 1994 he was officially hailed as an "outstanding entrepreneur" who set an example for others on how to "get rich quick".

Mou, 58, was found guilty of using falsified import documents to obtain foreign exchange credit from a Wuhan bank, though no goods were bought abroad.

His sentence seems severe compared to the lighter sentences given to government officials convicted of serious corruption. Misuse of import documents has been widespread among Chinese entrepreneurs, who find difficulty in raising loans directly from the banks.

Mou has always been a controversial figure, variously described as the "number one rich man" and the "number one cheat".

He nurtured grand political and economic ideas which may not have helped his reputation with the government.

The entrance to his Land Group headquarters was festooned with a saying of his: "There is nothing that cannot be achieved, only things that cannot be imagined."

His prosecution involved several unexplained delays, suggesting that high-level decisions were needed at each stage. He was detained in 1996 but not formally arrested until January last year

fields.headline: Labour's 'comprehensive spending review'
fields.standfirst: Gordon Brown plans to add £40 billion to public spending in the next 3-4 years but generosity at what price? Julian Glover explains who will win and lose in the government's comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown plans to add £40 billion to public spending in the next 3-4 years but generosity at what price? We explain who will win and lose in the government's comprehensive spending review.
fields.body:
Why is this issue making the news?
It's became clear that the Treasury has a massive amount of spare money to spend, around £40 billion in the next three to four years, on top of existing spending of £348bn. This extra money is being allocated through a process known as the 'comprehensive spending review' (CSR), and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, will announce the results in July. At the moment government departments are busy staking their claims to the cash hence recent media frenzy about public spending.

Where does this extra money come from?
Recently the exchequer has been showing a robust surplus - this year the government expects to raise some £17bn in taxes even after spending has been taken into account. Falling unemployment and the minimum wage mean that social security costs are lower than in the past, while the recent auction of mobile phone licences raised an unexpected £22bn. Some of this cash will be used to repay part of Britain's national debt, but there is money left over to increase public spending - or cut taxes.

Which areas will benefit?
Every government minister is convinced that his or her ministry is particularly deserving of the chancellor's generosity. In fact, the additional spending will be concentrated on only a few areas. The Department of Health is the only certain winner announced so far. In the March budget, Gordon Brown promised the NHS an extra £13bn. Education looks like another likely gainer with promises this week that the CSR would include measures to widen access to higher education. John Prescott, head of the department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions wants a £140 million cash reserve for transport programmes over the next 10 years and has every chance of succeeding in his demands. Regional development agencies, too, will gain extra funding to help in the regeneration of their areas. Finally, Gordon Brown has made the eradication of child poverty a personal cause and will use the CSR to help combat it. The government is committed to halving child poverty by 2010 and eradicating it by 2020.

Is it all good news?
Not quite. Gordon Brown set a ceiling for growth in real total spending of 2.5 percent a year in his last budget. To meet this, the CSR may actually cut spending in certain areas, the Ministry of Defence being a likely target. And his generosity comes at a price. In return for the extra cash the Treasury wants ministries to meet precise performance targets. The aim is to ensure that the additional money is used effectively - but the effect of this will be to increase the Treasury's control over everything the government does. This is naturally unpopular with ministers in all other departments. Critics claim it will make the government more presidential and less consensual leading to bureaucratic interference from the centre.

What do the other parties think?
The Tory party complain that Gordon Brown's plans will lead to a "high taxing, high spending" administration. They want the cash spent on tax cuts instead and suggest the chancellor is planning an uncontrolled spending spree to shore up the government's position at the polls. The Liberal Democrats argue that the extra money is long overdue and still omits some crucial services. But both parties will find it hard to complain about substantial cash boosts for health and education in the run up to the general election.

fields.headline: Coup leader asserts control
fields.trailText: Fiji's military bowed to the dictates of coup leader George Speight today withdrawing yesterday's nomination of interim prime minister, Ratu Epeli Nailatikau.
fields.body:
Fiji's military bowed to the dictates of coup leader George Speight today withdrawing yesterday's nomination of interim prime minister, Ratu Epeli Nailatikau.

In refusing the nomination, Commodore Frank Bainimarama, head of the armed services, comes under pressure to end the deadlock by formulating an acceptable shortlist of candidates. Fijilive.com reported that former reserve bank governor Savenaca Siwatibau is among a list of "independent" people acceptable to Mr Speight to serve in a new interim administration.

Mr Siwatibau is currently head of the UN's economic and social commission for Asia and the Pacific, ESCAP. Mr Speight is adamantly opposed to any appointments of people close to President Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara, who has been forced into exile after the military declared martial law on Monday.

Other names acceptable Mr Speight, backed by Fiji's version of the SAS, include former Fiji ambassador to the European Community Kaliopate Tavola, managing director of Merchant Bank of Fiji, a senator, Laisenia Qarase, and former permanent secretary Pita Nacuva.

Cmdr Bainimarama has said that he does not intend to name any more replacements until the hostages are freed, in an apparent attempt to prevent Mr Speight objecting to them and perpetuating the standoff.

Mr Speight and several gunmen took Fiji's first ethnic Indian minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, hostage, on May 19 and are still holding about 30 politicians in the country's parliamentary complex

Mr Speight's media adviser, Jo Nata, told the Sydney Morning Herald they want an influential role in the new interim government "in order to steer Fiji in the direction of indigenous Fijian supremacy".

Cmdr Bainimarama, who declared martial law, threw out Fiji's 1997 constitution which ethnic Fijians blame for giving Fijians of Indian descent too much power. Ethnic Indians, who make up 44% of the population, control many of the shops and businesses in Fiji, fuelling resentment among the indigenous Fijians.

Mr Speight has demanded that Fijians of Indian ancestry be barred from leading the country and has rejected Cmdr Bainimarama's authority and refused a face-to-face meeting.

Cmdr Bainimarama has said that the interim government would draw up a new constitution and prepare for fresh elections but warned that the process could take up to three years. He has also agreed that the armed militia who stormed the parliament be granted a complete amnesty.

The UN and countries such as Britain, Australia, New Zealand and the US have criticised Fijian forces for failing to clamp down on Speight. Sanctions have been threatened against Fiji if it refuses to return to democracy.

One hostage was temporarily released today to attend her sister's funeral. Assistant minister in the prime minister's office, Adi Ema Tagicakibau, left the parliamentary complex flanked by two police officers promising to return once the ceremony was over.

Fiji: the issue explained

fields.headline: Damned, but not out
fields.trailText: The Qayyum report is a landmark in the history of Pakistan cricket and heralds the end of a poisonous era. Pakistan has been in free fall since the dizzy heights of the 1992 World Cup. Corruption and mudslinging have combined to produce years of shame for players and officials.
fields.body:
The Qayyum report is a landmark in the history of Pakistan cricket and heralds the end of a poisonous era. Pakistan has been in free fall since the dizzy heights of the 1992 World Cup. Corruption and mudslinging have combined to produce years of shame for players and officials.

Why did it become so messy? One reason is that the laws of defamation in South Asia are weak and it is far too easy for a whirlwind of accusation to blow away reputations. The upside is that not much stays secret. India is now shaking under the same furore that rocked Pakistan. Qayyum's report, however, will allow Pakistan to refocus and restore credibility. The signs from the West Indies are that there is life after damnation.

Even so, this is the bitterest pill that Pakistan fans have ever swallowed: a swathe of heroes shamed at a stroke. But it is a welcome reckoning. There was a real danger that Qayyum would have his teeth drawn to protect the national image, but that has not happened. I have followed the inquiry closely for nearly two years and his final report covers all the evidence presented before him. Salim Malik's guilt was a "no-brainer" and the way Ata-ur-Rehman changed his story was always likely to land him in trouble, but the real conundrum was how Qayyum would deal with the other accused. The inquiry reports and leaks, to my mind, never threw up any clinching evidence against Wasim, Mushtaq and the rest, although there was plenty of innuendo and hearsay.

The judge was not convinced either. As such, it is only fair that those players are given the benefit of the doubt; a guilty verdict without proof is certainly a miscarriage of justice. It could be argued that if the case against Wasim and co. could not be proven, then they should have been fully exonerated, as Imran Khan has suggested. But Qayyum was within his mandate to recommend fines, censure, and further investigation. Indeed his recommendations are in line with ICC's new system of penalties.

The Pakistan Cricket Board deserves credit too. It didn't have to implement Qayyum's recommendations, but ICC's power of suspension will have nudged the Board towards discretion. Although this is the most far-reaching inquiry into match-fixing so far, senior figures in the English game remain sceptical about Qayyum's findings. They should not forget that the ECB's inquiry into Chris Lewis's allegations was too quick to be exhaustive or convincing, and is still not in the public domain. Indeed, it is ironic that Pakistan has given England and Australia "a lesson" in transparency, albeit belatedly.

Significantly, most other observers, notably the chief accusers (the Australian authorities and media, Rashid Latif, and Aamir Sohail), have welcomed Qayyum. But some pundits are demanding that Pakistan's players should face further sanction from ICC. Unless new evidence comes to light it is difficult to understand on what basis ICC could stiffen the penalties against Pakistan even if it wanted to. And why should it? Qayyum and the PCB have tackled the issue head on.

Michael Henderson fumed in the London Daily Telegraph on May 29 that the ECB should pull out of this year's tour to Pakistan because Qayyum and the PCB "have not actually shown anything except how best to cover their tracks". He criticises Pakistan's players for their reticence over match fixing, suggesting that the military regime should have known how to get them to talk. Pakistan is in enough trouble with Amnesty International without adding torture of cricketers to its list of wickedness. He forgets that the inquiry finished well before last year's coup.

He also implied that I unnecessarily played the race card in my column last month, in which I referred to an article of his as an example of the double standards pervading international cricket. My straightforward interpretation of Mr Henderson's stance was that in the wake of Cronjegate he was concluding that "England should stop playing India and Pakistan, as well as spurning invites to Sharjah". And what about Australia and South Africa? I asked.

Mr Henderson was unimpressed with my interpretation. He wrote: "An Asian View in the current edition of Wisden Cricket Monthly accuses this writer of things he hasn't written, but he can live with that." I hope this doesn't mean that he is happy to live with the same amnesia of convenience that he finds so distasteful in Wasim, Waqar et al.

To jog Mr Henderson's memory, on April 12 he wrote in the Telegraph: "Because nobody in India or Pakistan has either the will or the clout to identify and prosecute domestic offenders, the ECB should consider playing no more one-day games against either side until those who seek to corrupt players, and the guilty players themselves, have been brought to book. And they should not consider sending a side anywhere near a place like Sharjah ... If necessary England should stand alone." It is difficult to see what he has to complain about in my interpretation of his comments.

By following his advice, the ECB is likely to precipitate a schism in the game along racial lines, precisely the division Mr Henderson professes to be against. It is certainly a view that Asians find deeply offensive. Against the odds, and all expectations, Qayyum has taken the first decisive step in resurrecting Pakistan cricket and eliminating corruption from the game. His work deserves praise, not scorn.

Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore and brought up in Rotherham, is editor of the Bulletin of the World Health Organisation. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday on Cricket Unlimited and wisden.com. To read his previous column, "Stop Blubbering, Kapil", Click here. Next Wednesday Orin Gordon returns with his Anglo-Caribbean View.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Send your answers to the.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll do our best to answer them
fields.trailText: This week: Remi Moses; winning the Treble; Roy of the Rovers; Idwal Robling; Beckham at Spurs; and that 'what comes on the pitch at half-time' question - again.
fields.body:
Have you any idea what happened to the Manchester United and West Bromwich Albion midfield power-house Remi Moses, who was also partial to giving Jesper Olsen a slap once in a while? wonders Pete Leary.

Yes we do. Since retiring, Remi has settled down in the Alkrington area of Great Manchester, where he earns his money buying and selling property. In his spare time he's also a coach for the Manchester Warriors U-20 inline skating side, which (you've guessed it) have recently won the GB Inline Hockey League and every other trophy going.

According to Debbie Callaghan, a mother of one of the players: "Remi's absolutely brilliant. He's a real inspiration to the lads. In the four years he's been coaching they've won everything - much to the disgust of everyone else. He's a top bloke - he applauds skill all the time, and you don't get that from other managers. His saying is: 'Win when you can, but not at all costs.' His sons are both brilliant at in-line skating, which is how he got involved."

If you're interested, the Warriors train every Thursday at Bowlers Park in Trafford Park.

I recently read that Bayern Munich could have become the first German side to win the domestic double and European Cup in the same season this year. As everyone knows, it happened for the first time in England last season - are there any other European clubs that have completed this treble? asks Simon Tyers.

Celtic were the first team to win a domestic double and the European Cup in the same season. In 1967, Jock Stein's famous side won every single competition they entered, also bagging the Scottish League Cup and the Glasgow Cup (which in those days was a first-team tournament). Two other teams managed to land the treble before Manchester United did it last year, and both were Dutch: Ajax in 1972, PSV in 1988.

Near misses? The following domestic and European champions have lost their cup final - surely the easiest and least-important part of the treble - in the same year: Real Madrid (1958), Internazionale (1965), Ajax (1972), Liverpool (1977), Steaua Bucharest (1986) and Red Star Belgrade (1991). Marseille would also be included in this group for their 1993 exploits, but they were stripped of both European Cup and French league after a match-fixing scandal. If only they'd beaten PSG in the Cup final...

Which footballer has won 14 league titles, the European Cup, Uefa Cup, League Cup, FA Cup, European player of the year and once scored 40 goals in a season? asked Rob Jordan last week. We thought the question was fake - and we challenged you to prove us wrong.

We had loads of suggestions for the mystery man, including Kenny Daglish, Eusebio, Ian Rush and even Clive Allen! But as Pete Allen (and several others) suggest, the answer must be Roy Race, he of the Rovers and the subject of questions such as 'Who scored the wining goal in a FA Cup final and then put on the goalkeepers jersey to save a penalty?'. Thanks to everyone who put us out of our misery.

What became of Idwal Robling, the winner of the BBC's "Find a Commentator" competition before the 1970 World Cup? enquired Simon Kaplan.

"Poor Idwal Robling," sighs Craig Thomas (the only person who bothered to write in). "As a second-class citizen - ie. Welsh - he never stood a chance in the big leagues, so he spent a number of years commentating on football for BBC Wales."

I recently had an argument with a hairdresser as to the origins of David Beckham. We both agreed on his upbringing in London, but disagreed on which club he began his training with. I was sure that someone told me it was Tottenham, while he insisted that it was Arsenal. A free haircut is riding on this, so if you could enlighten me on the correct answer I would be very much obliged asked Tom H last week.

Following last week's Knowledge Unlimited, we had an email from Tobias Best. He says that David Beckham was not raised in Leytonstone, but in Chingford. 'This is a commonly made mistake because he was born in Whipps Cross hospital, Leytonstone,' he adds.

Tobias also claims: "The first team Beckham trained with (and played for) was a local team also based in Chingford called Ridgeway Rovers. He attended a number of Junior Spurs training sessions as a youth but always wore a Man Utd shirt (though he told us no-one seemed to mind too much), so theoretically the first Premiership team he trained with were Tottenham although he was never on their books.

"By the way, I am not some expert biographer but I know all of this because I went to the same school as him in Chingford."

An aeon ago we asked: 'What comes onto the pitch at half time, and doesn't leave until after the game on a Saturday, and not until the next day on a Wednesday? After a while we dismissed it as a fake question from the devious mind of the Fiver's second-favourite commentator, Fox TV's Lionel Bienvenu. However we recently received a letter from Paul Reeve which said:

"I don't know if this is genuinely a fake question with no answer, but one answer that seems to fit is fork marks: the groundsmen go round prodding the turf at half-time, and these marks aren't removed until next time they roll the pitch or whatever. On Saturdays, they do it after the game: weekdays, matches are in the evenings, so it doesn't get done until next day.'

Can you help?

Can anybody tell me when the dug-out was invented ? Was it during the famous Christmas ceasefire football game in World War I ? wonders Mario Kerssens.

Do you know why the "nutmeg" manoeuvre is so called, and if so, who coined the term? enquires Paul Stearn.

How many opposition players have scored hat-tricks at Old Trafford? And who were they? asks Marc Beauge.

Send your answers to the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to answer them.

webTitle: May 31: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: May 31: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText:
In brief and the latest casting news

Hollywood is set to make yet more money, Foster may be pregnant, Willis ditches agent, and on the casting couch Judy Dench, Bill Murray and Jonny Lee Miller
fields.body:
 It seems that this millennial year looks set to break all records in the movie industry, says E! Online. As Hollywood gets ready for its busy summer season, revenue is already up 9% on last year. Erin Brockovich and Gladiator have exceeded the $100m mark and, as reported yesterday, Mission Impossible 2 looks likely to exceed that amount within a few days of its release.

 Jodie Foster is pregnant with her second child, according to the Daily Mirror, which reckons the actress is 11 weeks gone. The newspaper also claims the baby is the result of artificial insemination. Foster already has a son, Charlie, who was born in July 1998. She has always refused to discuss the name of the father.

 Lord of the Rings conceptual artist John Howe was recently interviewed in the French magazine Mad Movies on the forthcoming trilogy and his relationship with director Peter Jackson. Read the full transcript on Cinescape.

 Bruce Willis has stopped being represented by the William Morris agency. The actor, who'll soon star in Barry Levinson's Outlaws for MGM, has entered into a business partnership with his former agent and William Morris top man, Arnold Rifkin. While Rifkin's new venture, Cheyenne, will partner with Willis on forthcoming projects, the star will in fact have neither an agent nor a manager - only heavyweight entertainment attorney Skip Brittenham who will serve as his rep on deals.

Casting couch

 After rumours that Edward Woodward was to take over the role (see our May 18 report), it was announced this weekend that Dame Judy Dench will return as M, 007's superior in the next Bond film.

 The remake of the Rat Pack movie, Ocean's Eleven, helmed by Steven Soderbergh, just keeps attracting big name after big name. It is rumoured that Bill Murray is to sign shortly while Warren Beatty, John Turturro and Michael Douglas have all been "in talks" about possible roles. The cast already includes Brad Pitt, Julia Roberts, Bruce Willis and Johnny Depp no less.

 Jonny Lee Miller has joined the cast of Wes Craven Presents: Dracula 2000. The film, to be directed by long-time Craven collaborator Patrick Lussier, will turn the classic Stoker tale into a modern version. It is rumoured that Miller is to play the part of an antiques expert who assists Dr Van Helsing, to be played by Christopher Plummer.

fields.headline: Edinburgh rejects private section 28 poll
fields.standfirst:
Tycoon celebrates as 1m Scots vote against repeal

More about section 28
fields.trailText: The Stagecoach tycoon Brian Souter yesterday secured the backing of 1m Scots in his fight against repeal of section 28, at an estimated cost to his personal fortune of £1m.
fields.body:
The Stagecoach tycoon Brian Souter yesterday secured the backing of 1m Scots in his fight against repeal of section 28, at an estimated cost to his personal fortune of £1m.

His privately funded ballot on plans to abolish the controversial clause found that 86.6% of the 1.2m valid votes cast - just over 1m people -favoured retention of section 28, which bans the promotion of homosexuality in schools.

The Scottish executive and gay rights groups were quick to dismiss the poll as an expensive publicity stunt which showed that three quarters of the electorate had rejected the Keep the Clause campaign.

But Mr Souter said it was a clear vindication of his efforts.

"This is a tremendous result for Keep the Clause. It really demonstrates the determination of people to defy the government and register a protest vote," he said.

"A denial of this result would be a denial of democracy."

The businessman is now set on a collision course with the Scottish executive, which has rejected an amendment that would have put traditional marriage at the heart of legislation repealing section 28.

Yesterday the amendment, tabled by a Labour member of the Scottish parliament, failed to win backing by a committee of MSPs.

Mr Souter had made it clear that he would back off if the amendment was adopted.

If it was not, he warned, then his battle would intensify, with individual politicians being made the target of massive advertising campaigns in their own constituencies.

The bill to repeal section 28 has passed the first stage in the Scottish assembly. It replaces the clause with a fresh clause emphasing the value of "stable family life," but ministers have resisted efforts to enshrine marriage in the legislation, saying it would stigmatise those not living in a "traditional" relationship.

Ministers have made one concession, in the form of an amendment that gives legal teeth to guidance for education authorities on how sex education is taught in schools.

The results of the ballot, the UK's biggest ever privately funded referendum, were announced at noon in an Edinburgh hotel. It was Mr Souter's first appearance before the press and his face broke into a broad smile as the returning officer, former West Lancashire council chief executive John Cowdall, detailed the findings. The results showed that out of 1,260,846 valid ballot papers returned, 1,094,440 people voted in favour of keeping the clause and 166,406 voted for repeal. The turnout was 34%.

The exercise, conducted by the Voteit company advised by pollsters ICM, was based on a 1999 voting register, and 300,000 of the 3.9m ballot slips sent out were undeliverable because people had either moved house or died. Mr Cowdall said a number of ballot papers returned contained offensive material or had been cut into pieces.

Mr Souter said Holyrood must now follow Westminster in strengthening legislation and offering reassurances such as those made by the education secretary, David Blunkett, and the prime minister. "Tony Blair has promised there will be no homosexual role-playing and has clearly defined what is appropriate so that parents know what their children are going to be taught," he said. "Holyrood is now looking isolated and extreme. Politicians are looking more like a group of student activists than a government.

"We will not stand back and allow a politically correct minority to undermine the position of marriage in society and determine morality for the majority. We did not vote for it, we're not having it."

Wendy Alexander, the communities minister who has spearheaded abolition of the clause, said they were committed to repeal, and a Scottish executive spokesman said the poll was a publity stunt.

"We have always said it was a flawed opinion poll and this just proves it," the spokesman said. "They are claiming 86% of votes cast were in favour of keeping the clause. They failed to mention 2.3m people who did not even bother to take part in the exercise. They can be put in the 'No' camp. It is a massive rejection of Mr Souter's position."

Gay rights campaigners also said the results were a snub for Mr Souter. "What is clear is that the overwhelming number of Scots told Souter to get stuffed by refusing to vote," a spokesman for Outright Scot land said. "When people are concerned they turn out to vote in legitimate elections. The conclusion here is that the people of Scotland are not concerned and/or don't view Souter's wheeze as a legitimate way of forming policy."

webTitle: Gay pride takes a knock from mayor of Rome

fields.headline: Gay pride takes a knock from mayor of Rome
fields.trailText: The mayor of Rome's decision yesterday to revoke his patronage of a World Gay Pride week to be held in July sparked fresh controversy over the compatibility of the colourful pageant with the celebrations marking the Roman Catholic church's jubilee year.
fields.body:
The mayor of Rome's decision yesterday to revoke his patronage of a World Gay Pride week to be held in July sparked fresh controversy over the compatibility of the colourful pageant with the celebrations marking the Roman Catholic church's jubilee year.

Critics said the actions of the centre-left mayor, Francesco Rutelli, violated constitutional guarantees of free assembly and free expression. "This left is looking increasingly like the guest wing of the Vatican," said the centre-right MP, Marco Taradash.

"What has happened to secular culture, from which Rutelli himself comes?" asked Grazia Francescato, the leader of the Green party, which supports Mr Rutelli's administration. "Does it face extinction, like the panda?"

The Vatican, worried at the prospect of gays dressed as priests and nuns frolicking in St Peter's Square, has called repeatedly for the festival to be postponed at least until the end of the jubilee.

The prime minister, Giuliano Amato, conceded in parliament last week that the timing was "inopportune" but said the government had no power to intervene.

The Vatican's anxiety has reportedly been heightened by a video sent by the archbishop of San Francisco purporting to show scenes from the city's Gay Pride march, showing festival goers in religious robes strip and mime sex acts.

Organisers of Rome's gay pride festival said the video was a fake, incorporating scenes from a private party and a Halloween parade into a misleading collage.

"That's disgraceful. The church has been spreading the truth for 20 centuries and does not disseminate falsehoods," Archbishop William Levada retorted.

Officials said the mayor had acted because festival organisers had refused to coordinate their plans with the city council and he was worried about a planned fashion show using a church as a backdrop.

But Ms Francescato said: "I would like to know how you can organise anything in Rome without passing in front of a church."

Mr Rutelli's administration agreed a year ago to be one of the official sponsors of World Gay Pride, a cultural event expected to attract as many as 200,000 people to the capital in the first week of July. The council also voted to finance the festival to the tune of 300m lira (£100,000). The subsidy has not been revoked.

Yesterday, after a tense meeting with festival organisers, Mr Rutelli announced that the city council would still act as patron for some festival events such as an Amnesty International conference on countries where homosexuality is still a crime, while removing its backing for the festival as a whole.

The international Catholic peace movement Pax Christi waded into the debate yesterday, saying that no one had objected to the reinstatement of a military parade to mark national armed forces day in Rome on June 4 although this was "not in tune with the climate of the jubilee, which speaks of reconciliation and peace".

It criticised the furore over the gay pride festival while no one remembered to deplore the "macabre pride in arms".

webTitle: Postino actor gave heroic final performance

fields.headline: Postino actor gave heroic final performance
fields.trailText: Fans of the late Massimo Troisi in the 1995 Oscar-nominated Il Postino (The Postman) may not realise quite how remarkable the actor's performance really was.
fields.body:
Fans of the late Massimo Troisi in the 1995 Oscar-nominated Il Postino (The Postman) may not realise quite how remarkable the actor's performance really was.

Writing in Sunday's New York Times about one of the US's most popular foreign-language films ever to be released, Peter Nichols notes that Troisi was so incapacitated by heart disease during filming that he could only stay on his feet for 30 seconds at a time.

Although that might seem an insurmountable obstacle in a film about a love-struck, bicycle-riding postman, director Michael Radford explains on a new DVD version of Il Postino that many scenes were reworked to allow Troisi to be seated, or shot using a stand-in who looked remarkably similar to the ailing actor.

The availability of such a close double for Troisi allowed the film to be completed despite the comedian's fatal illness. So close was the resemblance between Troisi and the stand-in - Gerardo - says Nichols, that "at Troisi's funeral some Neapolitans thought the stand-in was the actor's ghost walking behind the coffin."

fields.headline: Bohemian rhapsodies
fields.standfirst: Michael Ellison on: Remnants of the counter-culture * Food felony
fields.trailText: Michael Ellison on: Remnants of the counter-culture * Food felony
fields.body:
There is no getting away from bohemians right now, though that does not mean you will run into any examples of the species on the streets of its American breeding ground, Greenwich Village.

Here, where the monthly rent of the average apartment now would once have been enough to fund a lifetime of squalid enlightenment, they are said by some accounts to have run out of steam not long after the first world war.

But bookshops and public prints are full of bohemians and they contain a bewildering array of definitions of the term. For Christine Stansell in American Moderns: Bohemian New York and the Creation of a New Century, they represented a fusion of freedoms in politics, culture and personal relations. The Princeton history professor says this happened between 1890 and 1920 and has since subsided into "inspiration for renovating middle-class life".

If Anatole Broyard or Joseph Mitchell were alive today, they might disagree with this evaluation, of course. Broyard's unfinished memoir of life in the Village of the 1940s, Kafka Was the Rage, relies for its connection to bohemianism mostly on elegiac musings on his short-lived bookshop and a girlfriend who was both an artist and something of a puzzle.

Mitchell's book, Joe Gould's Secret, is an unusually irritating work putting together two very long pieces from the New Yorker, published in 1942 and 1964. Most readers should work out the secret, such as it is, more rapidly than they could ever arrive at a reason for the writer's fascination with a self-obsessed homeless person who is obviously mentally ill. The supposedly bohemian Gould's main achievements in the service of freedom seemed to involve free drinks.

Stanley Tucci has turned the Kleenex-thin story into a movie of the same name that, while it is a sensitive evocation of the Village before the century's halfway point, cannot resist tagging on a production-line cinema ending that never happened. Then, just before the credits roll, we are told that after the second piece appeared Mitchell continued to go to work until he died in 1996 but never published another word.

We are supposed to believe that the writer's hand was stilled by the recognition of something of himself in his subject, but anyone who has ever worked for a living is more likely to wonder why the magazine did not show him the door.

Ann Powers suggests in her book, Weird Like Us: My Bohemian America, that, far from being a thing of the past, there's a touch of the counter-culture in everyone because its values have entered the mainstream - which brings us back to refurbished middle-class life and a piece in the New York Times magazine by Rob Walker, who writes with some disdain that it is now possible to pass as mainstream and a hipster at the same time. He calls these people fauxhemians.

A number of lightning rods for this cultural, counter-cultural or even imaginary social grouping, which is very likely unaware of its own existence, formed the core of the New Yorker's literary and arts festival: novelists, poets, journalists, editors, artists and activists.

A sound drifted across the grass from a stage at one end of Bryant Park, the big backyard of the New York public library. "Slush, slush, slush . . . South Carolina. Slush, slush, slush . . . inspected my shirt."

This is Robert Pinsky, poet laureate of the United States, where they have the sense to limit tenure in the office to a fixed term so that the incumbent is less likely to find himself without any lead in his pencil or to have forgotten which one is the Queen Mum.

Pinsky was part of the rather muted climax to the festival and his words might have been very fine but it was a little difficult to be sure as they oscillated around the sky-rise canyon on 42nd Street.

No one seemed to mind. A polite couple of thousand lounged on the sunny lawns, the rude klaxons of emergency vehicles suggesting that poetry might be in crisis. Incidentally, there were as many black people here as you would find at the average blues gig: that is to say, not many at all.

The event had a pleasantly hazy quality that made it feel a bit optional, a bit "I wonder what I'll have for dinner tonight?"

Two nights earlier, Stephen King had appeared at the Bowery Ballroom and read a story that went on for nearly an hour. The mentions of oral sex and the swear words were greeted with particularly appreciative titters.

This was King's first public outing since his near-fatal encounter last year with a motorist who appeared to be trying to drive his van and walk his dog at the same time. "It's nice to be here," he said. "Actually, it's nice to be anywhere." Yes, the old ones are the best.

In his black denims and white T-shirt, jaw jutting as he attacked the microphone, discarding his crutch as though he were James Brown casting aside his cape, King could be an aged rocker.

Bill Buford, literary editor of the New Yorker, said that the writer's vision had been overlooked in favour of his sales of more than 300m, and the reading rated highly on the true index of respect for a live performance - only two mobile phones went off. King's work has been conspicuously consumed and the writer has a pretty cool self-image: hallmarks of fauxhemianism.

It is a strange fact that while an astonishingly popular author draws fewer than 300 to hear him read, a painter gets closer to 500 to listen to him talking about the use of optics in art. And no mobile phones ring.

David Hockney was beside himself with sly glee, slouched over the lectern at the Equitable Tower on Seventh Avenue, as he unfolded his theory of how great artists had cheated since 1430. It's all done with mirrors, apparently, a subject investigated in a New Yorker article last year and to be examined in greater detail soon in Hockney's next book.

"What changed? The art historian says suddenly everybody could draw better. I find that far-fetched when you know what can be done with a small mirror-lens." Art historians come in for a lot of stick from the deaf man with a spotted hanky in the breast pocket of his jacket. This does not fit into any notion of fauxhemianism - or indeed any cultural "ism". It is more of an "ish". British.

Not far away, Steve Earle, once recruited for the cause of New Country but really a curator of an individualistic strand of Americana, paraphrased King's paraphrase by telling a sold-out audience: "When I came out of jail, I was just glad to be anywhere."

Once Earle was addicted to drugs; now he is addicted to life. With King among those listening to him, he talked about country and bluegrass, rock and the Beatles, songwriting and performing, producing records, why he likes working in Ireland ("none of my ex-wives live there"), his short stories and poetry, and his anti-death-penalty activism. Maybe he is the last bohemian.

Ratting on the restaurant vermin

* Things just go from bad to worse for Mayor Rudy Giuliani. Now it turns out that some of his favourite restaurants are immune to his project to clean up the city, according to a new website that carries health department inspection records - 17, near City Hall, where he had lunch last week, is cited for vermin ("It was old mice droppings in a sub-basement that we don't use," said the owner).

Sabena's on Nassau Street, where Giuliani favours the Caesar salad, also made the vermin list. "I pride myself on having one of the cleanest restaurants in the city," said Matt Sabena.

"One or two small mouse droppings is not like the place that had rats running around inside."

*Finally the evidence of one's ears is confirmed. A survey shows that only 13% of New York subway announcements can be understood.

*Beggar seen on Seventh Avenue shaking a paper coffee cup containing a few coins: "Help me get my Mercedes out of the body shop, please?"
