fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's gossip let out on day release
fields.trailText: Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink will join Chelsea for £14m, according to his club Atletico Madrid. According to Atletico's vice-chairman Miguel Angel Gil, "An agreement between the clubs has been reached and all that remains is for the clubs to exchange faxes and for the signing to be ratified by the Premier League."
fields.body:
Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink will join Chelsea for £14m, according to his club Atletico Madrid. According to Atletico's vice-chairman Miguel Angel Gil, "An agreement between the clubs has been reached and all that remains is for the clubs to exchange faxes and for the signing to be ratified by the Premier League."

Teamtalk suggests that Chelsea are ready to pick up another player relegated from the Primera Liga this summer - 29-year-old Nigerian winger Finidi George would cost a bargain £3.5m from demoted Real Betis.

Leeds are on the verge of signing Rio Ferdinand for £12m, reports the Daily Mail. The paper believes the West Ham defender is attracted by the proposition of Champions League football, and that a move will completed within days if Ferdinand misses the cut for Kevin Keegan's Euro 2000 squad. If Ferdinand does sign it could hasten Michael Duberry's departure from Elland Road - Duberry is a target for Glenn Hoddle's Southampton.

Teamtalk believes that Trevor Sinclair will be at the top of Martin O'Neill's list of potential signings should he take the Celtic job. The West Ham utility man is valued at £8m.

Barnsley star Craig Hignett could play in the Premiership next season, despite his club's defeat in the First Division play-off final on Monday. Manchester City and Bradford are both interested in signing the 30-year-old according to the Daily Star, and they are willing to pay up to £2m.

Newcastle full-back Didier Domi has expressed an interest in returning to his former club Paris St Germain. Planet Football quotes the 21-year-old as saying: "PSG have made contact with me even though nothing has yet been settled." Domi also admits, however, that he would be willing to stay on in Tyneside too.

webTitle: Jobless actor hopes to make next Brit hit

fields.headline: Jobless actor hopes to make next Brit hit
fields.trailText: A struggling British actor who wrote and staged a sell-out comedy play with the help of a £50 donation is now hoping to attract funding to develop it into the next British-made box-office hit.
fields.body:
A struggling British actor who wrote and staged a sell-out comedy play with the help of a £50 donation is now hoping to attract funding to develop it into the next British-made box-office hit.

Kal Lashman, 34, is at present on the government's New Deal job scheme and hopes to raise £1.5m to begin filming a romantic comedy called That Little Something in his home city of Derby.

The script has already received high praise, with Monty Python star Michael Palin saying it had "moved [me] to tears as well as laughter" and that it was "one of the best [scripts] I've read in along time", comparing it with another successful British film, Brassed Off (pictured).

The actor was given £50 by a customer while working as a waiter in Sheffield as encouragement to continue. Three nights later, he had written a stage play which he performed with a group of out-of-work actors.

Lashman, who already has the support of both a showbiz lawyer and an accountant, will be presenting his idea to potential backers next month.

"The industry has made me cynical because of all the obstacles put in your way and the doors that are slammed in your face. That's why getting this off the ground means so much. It will realise a dream I have had since I was a child," the aspiring director said.

Lashman, who graduated from drama school in Manchester in 1989, had little joy finding work despite writing to more than 200 casting directors and agents. He hopes the film will start shooting as early as July.

webTitle: Starless Gloucester now a side to fear

fields.headline: Starless Gloucester now a side to fear
fields.trailText: The cricket season has only been going in earnest for a few weeks, but some familiar patterns have already emerged. England have won the first Test of the summer (or should that be spring?) for the fourth time in five years, the rain is keeping Duckworth and Lewis as busy as the groundsmen - and Gloucestershire have reached another one-day final, thanks to their 15-run triumph over Lancashire in the delayed semi-final of the resurrected B&H Cup on Bank Holiday Monday.
fields.body:
The cricket season has only been going in earnest for a few weeks, but some familiar patterns have already emerged. England have won the first Test of the summer (or should that be spring?) for the fourth time in five years, the rain is keeping Duckworth and Lewis as busy as the groundsmen - and Gloucestershire have reached another one-day final, thanks to their 15-run triumph over Lancashire in the delayed semi-final of the resurrected B&H Cup on Bank Holiday Monday.

So, after 36 years with only two Lord's appearances, Gloucestershire have now made it there three times in just over ten months, following victories in the finals of both the inaugural (and probably last) B&H Super Cup and the NatWest Trophy last August. And for a team whose most evocative names (WG Grace, Gilbert Jessop and Wally Hammond) were active before one-day cricket was even a twinkle in the administrators' eyes, it's about time too. True, Mike Procter and Zaheer Abbas did help Gloucestershire to two one-day pots in the 1970s (the Gillette Cup in 1973 and the B&H in 1977), but these were isolated successes, and not part of a growing trend.

Even so, "Gloster", as their vocal fans have it, have come almost from nowhere to become the one-day knockout team to avoid. It seems strange to talk about form teams in a format where anyone can beat anyone else on any given day. But the brief history of both cups is littered with examples of limited-overs experts. Sussex were the original one-day wizards, lifting the first two Gillette Cups (now the NatWest Trophy) in 1963 and 1964. Then, in the early 1970s, Lancashire took over as the team to topple, winning the Gillette three years on the trot, before Kent triumphed four times in six years (including three in the B&H). Somerset won their first four pieces of silverware between 1979 and 1983 (one Gillette, two B&Hs and one NatWest), then Lancashire returned to do the first NatWest/B&H double, in 1990 - a feat they repeated six years later. In between, Warwickshire seemed to play at Lord's more often than at Edgbaston.

But what makes Gloucestershire's glory unique is that they've shone without a star. Sussex, in those pre-overseas-player days, had England captain Ted Dexter (4502 Test runs), and Lancashire could call upon Clive Lloyd (7515). Kent boasted Asif Iqbal (3575), while Somerset got the best out of Ian Botham (5200 runs plus 383 wickets) and Viv Richards (8540 runs). The return of Lancashire coincided with the brilliance of Wasim Akram (398 wickets and counting), and Warwickshire had double world-record holder Brian Lara.

Gloucestershire? Their star is Australian allrounder Ian Harvey (169 runs and eight wickets in one-day internationals, but currently injured). On Monday, Lancashire, with their galaxy of internationals, must have felt like West Indies in 1983 when they were overwhelmed by a distinctly underwhelming Indian team in the World Cup final.

What Gloucestershire do possess is experience and youth, knowhow and enthusiasm. Flying the flag for the crumblies are Jack Russell (as valuable for the way he irritates the opposition as for his terrier-like stumpings), Mark Alleyne, Kim Barnett (now more of a genuine team player than the glowering godfather he resembled at Derby), and Mike Smith, a shorter, left-arm version of Gus Fraser. At the other end of the age spectrum are Jon Lewis, who recently took a Championship hat-trick, James Averis, whose 24 victims so far make him the leading one-day wicket-taker in the country, and Matthew Windows, opening up at long last.

It all adds up to, well, more than it probably should. Which may be part of the reason Gloucestershire have been riding high. Problems may arise when people start expecting them to win time after time. In fact, they might arise on June 10, when Gloucestershire must begin as favourites to beat Glamorgan, who haven't made it to Lord's since losing to Middlesex in the 1977 NatWest final. But if Gloucester do hold their nerve, they will become the first side ever to win three knockout trophies in a row. Then they really will have to be called the latest, greatest one-day team.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com. To read last week's County View, click here

fields.headline: Wonder Boys in rerelease ploy
fields.trailText: Paramount Pictures are taking the unusual step of rereleasing the film in October, complete with a new marketing campaign aimed at boosting its Oscar chances
fields.body:
"With a cast this terrific and a story this rich and wry, Wonder Boys really can't miss," wrote online magazine Salon back in February on the US release of Wonder Boys, directed by Curtis (LA Confidential) Hanson. But miss it did. Despite critical acclaim, and one of the hottest cast lists this year (Tobey Maguire, Katie Holmes, Frances McDormand, Robert Downey Jnr and Michael Douglas in the lead role), the movie failed to impact on the American public, and disappeared quickly from cinemas after grossing only $18.7m.

Undeterred by this poor showing, Paramount Pictures are taking the unusual step of rereleasing the film in October, complete with a new marketing campaign aimed at boosting its Oscar chances. E! Online reports that the new campaign will also emphasise the film's Oscar-powered pedigree - Douglas, McDormand and writer-director Curtis Hanson all have statuettes - and its stellar reviews.

It's a strategy that Miramax used successfully last year to push The Cider House Rules into Oscar contention and pump up that film's bottom line; in this case, Paramount's hoping lightning strikes twice.

While many films get a limited rerelease late in the year in hopes of getting an Oscar nod, it is extremely rare that they get a complete marketing makeover. One of the first things to go might well be the promotional poster (pictured), which features a bookish-looking, barely recognisable Douglas. As Los Angeles Times reviewer Kenneth Turan wrote, "The film's ad poster brings Elmer Fudd to mind."

Wonder Boys is about a college professor dealing with a bad marriage, a pregnant girlfriend, a dead dog, a stolen car and a bad case of writer's block. No UK release date has been announced. Check the official site for more information; or appraise US critical response to the movie on Rotten Tomatoes' Wonder Boys page.

fields.headline: DUP 'game-playing' provokes Stormont row
fields.trailText: The Democratic Unionists were condemned this morning for planning to hold on to its two Stormont ministries and pursue a policy of disruption in Northern Ireland's devolved assembly if Sinn Fein are not expelled.
fields.body:
The Democratic Unionists were condemned this morning for planning to hold on to its two Stormont ministries and pursue a policy of disruption in Northern Ireland's devolved assembly if Sinn Fein are not expelled.

First minister David Trimble and his deputy Seamus Mallon led the criticism of the DUP. Ian Paisley's party plan to return its two ministers to Stormont, but rotate others in their place with the aim of destroying the credibility of the Good Friday agreement.

Mr Trimble said the DUP was "playing games" when the best thing would have been for it to adopt an honest approach and do the jobs properly rather than take the office, advantages and perks while not carrying out the responsibilities.

Mr Mallon accused the DUP of playing Russian roulette with the wellbeing of their departments and the people who depended on them.

"It is a cynical exercise, absolutely cynical, and it is essential that the rest of the executive protect the interests of those two departments and the people who are dependent on them for services.

"I can assure you that is what we will do, we will not allow this political party to play Russian roulette with their departments and with the political process."

The DUP's Peter Robinson and Nigel Dodds, in charge of regional development and social development respectively, will continue to boycott executive and north/south ministerial meetings as before, but will resign if the party does not gain 60% unionist support for an assembly motion to exclude Sinn Fein from government.

The party's 90-strong ruling body has unanimously decided they will be replaced on a rotational basis by other DUP assembly members, with the aim of causing chaos in Northern Ireland's devolved administration.

Mr Robinson said his party's aim was the "defeat" of "the Republican agenda" by the electoral defeat of David Trimble and his team.

"That's what we are concentrating on, that's the way to defeat the Belfast agreement and the Democratic Unionist party will be using all it's time and energy and resources towards that goal," he said.

The two DUP posts would have been re-allocated to the Ulster Unionists and middle-ground Alliance party if the DUP had pulled out.

 The former director of America's Drug Enforcement Administration, Tom Constantine, is to take charge of implementing changes in policing arrangements in Northern Ireland, it was announced today. "I think we are very lucky to get him," said Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson.

fields.headline: Union's new president denounces Ofsted
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government's school inspection regime is like the Spanish inquisition and should be axed, the incoming president of the National Association of Head Teachers said yesterday.
fields.body:
The government's school inspection regime is like the Spanish inquisition and should be axed, the incoming president of the National Association of Head Teachers said yesterday.

Mick Brookes walked straight into a row with Chris Woodhead, chief inspector of schools.

In his president's address at the NAHT's annual conference in Jersey last night, Mr Brookes pleaded for the government to "call a halt to the Ofsted steamroller".

Ofsted was "established to ensure that change was implemented" - change which could now be regulated by heads, working with local "mentors" and school inspectors.

Mr Brookes ridiculed Mr Woodhead's claim that most schools were adequately resourced. "A system more suited to the Spanish inquisition must give way to something that more readily meets the needs of this century," he told delegates.

But Mr Woodhead told the BBC he felt an "appalling sense of deja vu". He added: "You have the teaching unions repeatedly, year after year, wanting to try to remove Ofsted. There is nowhere to hide for headteachers, and in my humble opinion, there should be nowhere to hide."

fields.headline: Don't call me My Dear
fields.standfirst: Susan Greenfield, director of the Royal Institution, thinks the problem of girls in science has been sorted. And women in science? That's another matter. She talks to  Sabine Durrant
fields.trailText: Susan Greenfield, director of the Royal Institution, thinks the problem of girls in science has been sorted. And women in science? That's another matter.
fields.body:
Susan Greenfield, Oxford professor of synaptic pharmacology, the director of the Royal Institution, is a neuroscientist, which is about as scary as you can get on the scale of scary things. On her desk is a paper entitled "Ultrastructural evidence for dendritic release of acetylcholinesterase in the rat substantia nigra ", which she would be reading in her coffee break if she hadn't already removed coffee, mindful of its deleterious effects, from her daily regime. She counts the study of consciousness as one of her hobbies, writing her books - the bestselling The Human Brain: A Guided Tour (Phoenix Press, £6.99), and her latest, The Private Life of the Brain (Penguin, £18.99) - as a form of relaxation, "on Sundays as others might do cooking or gardening". In short, she is a woman who knows her own mind, and possibly yours, too.

"My hair," she exclaims, whisking into the room, a large mouth on thin legs, somewhere between a tabloid columnist and an American intellectual. She is wearing a sexy, fitted, red jacket and high, stacked heels. She is 50 this year, and looks 40. "New short haircut and it's so hard to get short hair right." She attacks it with her fingers. "I just do not take a good picture." She points to a series of photos on the wall - "You see. Haggard." She was in Hello! recently and "to be honest I was slightly disappointed with the results. Perhaps one automatically thinks one is going to look like Naomi Campbell and, of course, I didn't. I looked like a dumpy middle-aged female scientist." As if she could ever look like a scientist, let alone a dumpy middle-aged one.

Greenfield is the television face of science, the Anne Robinson of the laboratory world. See her in a white coat and, chance as not, it's a little cream trench coat by Armani. You can find her at Chequers ("just a very nice dinner party"), or in the City (she has set up a limited company in preparation for any pharmaceutical rewards from her research), or "zapping around the capital with a mobile phone clamped to my ear". She's not afraid to tell you that Desert Island Discs was "the apotheosis of my career", or to describe arriving in a television studio (her series, Brain Story, is on BBC2 in July) as "coming home", or to confess that she wants to turn the fusty old Royal Institution into "a Groucho Club for scientists". She wants a society in which science is not Prince Charles's big, bad wolf: "I don't want to wave a magic wand and make everybody like scientists - of course not. But I would like to see a society where we are scientifically literate." It's one of her "credos". She is accessibility writ large, at large.

In her latest book, she sets out to show how pleasure necessitates a temporary abnegation of the self, that it involves the letting go of the personalised configurations of brain connections you may have spent a lifetime building up. If pure emotion and what Greenfield defines as the mind are at separate ends of the continuum, it is easy to see at which end of the continuum she lurks. She talks fantastically fast, but her eyes look at you steadily as if judging your reaction. "Yeah-yeah?" she says instead of punctuation, keeping you with her.

She knows how she might appear to the stuffier members of the scientific establishment. She has an internal Geiger counter that tells her how uncomfortable they are with the fact that she's a woman: "You can see the shutter coming down.

"If you try to do something that's different or original, it is inevitable that people are going to be critical. What I'm good at doing is seeing a broad picture and having a new way of looking at something. I do not have to be slaving away at a bench all day."

One scientist I spoke to before meeting Greenfield wondered tartly whether "she had ever really produced anything of any importance. Ask her what's happening with the Parkinson's protein." She smiles coolly. "It's going in an anticipated way at a pleasing speed."

She is sipping nettle tea as we talk. She used to drink maybe 50 cups of coffee a day. She used to smoke, too. "I have an addictive personality." She doesn't eat well - "just pre-prepared rubbish, I'm afraid" - but only drinks in moderation. Even at school in London in the 60s, or as a philosophy and psychology student at Oxford in the 70s, she steered clear of mind-altering substances: "Could never inhale." Has she never taken drugs for experimental purposes? "Like Aldous Huxley and mescaline, you mean? No, I have too much respect for my brain. This precious thing, this lovely previous thing that's evolved, and . . . splat."

Greenfield is married to the chemist Peter Atkins, a millionaire from writing textbooks, and they divide their time between their house, with pool, in Oxfordshire, the flat in Oxford and the director's apartment above the Royal Institution. "It would be silly to say we weren't comfortable." They have no children. Greenfield, who was brought up in west London, was the only child of an electrician and a chorus girl until her younger brother came along when she was 12. "There you are, the great star, and then there's this rival, so you start to associate babies possibly with all those negative feelings." Sometimes she wishes, "rather whimsically", that she knew what it was like to be pregnant, "but I've never had this broody feeling. I don't know whether it's because I have high testosterone, or I'm selfish or unnatural."

Whatever, she knows that with children she would not be where she is today. She thinks the problem of girls and science is being sorted, but that women and science is another matter altogether. "I've been pilloried for saying this, chastised by some of my colleagues, so please make it clear that it's my personal belief, that the bottleneck comes when women have babies. Unlike other professions, science is such a personal thing: you're judged on what you've published and if you've been off the scene . . . There should be far more provision grants, but only for people who have taken two years off for childcare."

Her own research group is unusual in being 50-50 male and female. "We all get on very well and, dare I say it, we don't have that testosterone high. It makes a difference having equal numbers - that's how human beings are supposed to be."

She knits her brow. She says: "I was in Australia recently waiting for a car to take me from one place to another and it didn't come. Eventually someone came up and said, 'Oh, I've been waiting for ages, but I thought you couldn't be a professor.' " She laughs, but doesn't look amused. "Another time," she says, "I was meeting someone in a bistro and a man said, 'Oh, my dear, you look rather lost' and I said, 'Please don't call me my dear.' It's subtle things like that. I've noticed sometimes on radio interviews if someone wishes to make a woman look small, they repeat her Christian name a lot, making her sound like a little girl."

We wind up with a credo or two - "I think what I am trying to do in my life is to be yourself, not mind if you're different from other people. So what if others don't cross-fertilise? It doesn't mean it's bad and that you shouldn't" - and then she escorts me down to the front of the faculty. On the way, I pop into the Ladies. When I come out of the cubicle, there she is in front of the mirror. "I wish it was more . . ." she says, manipulating her hair again before disappearing off into the building to find a neuron to manipulate instead.

webTitle: Heads angry at pressure to reduce exclusions

fields.headline: Heads angry at pressure to reduce exclusions
fields.standfirst:
Education Unlimited

Latest NAHT conference news
fields.trailText: Headteachers threatened yesterday to defy rulings to take violent pupils back into school and complained they were being undermined by "ridiculous" government targets to reduce exclusions.
fields.body:
Headteachers threatened yesterday to defy rulings to take violent pupils back into school and complained they were being undermined by "ridiculous" government targets to reduce exclusions.

The National Association of Head Teachers said it was considering advising its members to reject the orders of appeal panels to allow excluded pupils back in some cases.

It is also considering taking legal action against "perverse" appeal panel decisions.

Excluded pupils can appeal to a panel, which is independent, although constituted by the local education authority.

On the first day of the NAHT's annual conference in Jersey, David Hart, the general secretary, said panels were allowing disruptive children into school because they felt pressured by the education secretary, David Blunkett, who had demanded that the number of permanently excluded pupils be reduced from 12,000 to 9,000 by 2002.

Though Mr Blunkett recently made it clear that instant and permanent exclusion can be allowed for violence by pupils, the union believes that message has not got through to LEAs and appeal panels. Their rulings are undermining the authority of heads, it says.

Two pupils excluded from different London schools for wielding knives - in one case a carving knife - had recently been allowed to return on appeal, against the wishes of the headteachers, Mr Hart said.

Both incidents, which have been reported to Mr Blunkett, left other pupils "desperately frightened", and one teacher might refuse to teach one of the pupils involved.

Another NAHT member, Angeles Walford, said that when she had been temporarily in charge of a south London secondary school, she had wanted to exclude permanently a 12-year-old boy who punched a teacher. On the advice of governors and the council, the boy returned after three weeks and hit another teacher. One of the teachers had since left.

A spokesman for the Department for Education said: "Schools are free to exclude pupils when there is violence. The secretary of state wants to make it clear he will support heads who need to get rid of violent pupils or gang leaders."

The spokesman said it was possible appeals panels were making wrong decisions because of the way they interpreted the guidelines.

Mr Hart said drug dealing and serious bullying were not acknowledged by ministers as grounds for permanent exclusion for a first offence.

"We simply think the government ought to back off on this ridiculous target," he said. "The exclusions process is falling into disrepute.

"The reduction in the number of permanent exclusions may look superficially impressive. But it has been obtained at the expense of heads and their staff."

Exclusion issues were the single biggest source of tension between heads and council chief education officers, Mr Hart said.

He also asked for further guidance on the Human Rights Act, which he believes could lead to parents taking action against schools in bullying cases which could count as "inhumane or degrading treatment" under the European convention.

In two known cases parents have already gone to police because they did not feel bullying was being dealt with quickly enough by the school.

webTitle: The prospect of saying condom in front of a class of teenage girls does not fill me with unconfined joy

fields.headline: The prospect of saying condom in front of a class of teenage girls does not fill me with unconfined joy
fields.standfirst: Hard-bitten hack  Will Woodward  is used to doorstepping the stars and hitting hellish deadlines. But how did he handle a day teaching at a girls' comprehensive?
fields.trailText: Hard-bitten hack Will Woodward is used to doorstepping the stars and hitting hellish deadlines. But how did he handle a day teaching at a girls' comprehensive?
fields.body:
It is 9.05am and I am in front of a classroom of 14 and 15 year olds at Fulham Cross girls school, west London. "My name's Will Woodward and I work for the Guardian. You've just been reading Animal Farm, haven't you? What do you know about the character of Squealer?"

I write my name on the blackboard in shorthand and talk about that. Then I hand out newspaper cuttings about asylum seekers. This is the idea of Jim Grealy, the head of English: to get the class to write about asylum so that they have to deliberately manipulate the language, like Squealer did to create an impression. To deal with words like flood, tide, bogus and scrounger.

Taking Grealy's advice, I set them to write quite a lot - three sides each in 55 minutes - in a newspaper style about asylum seekers. Failing to act on his advice, I talk for more than five minutes about what they should do. They get the idea but some look a bit confused. A few ask for help from their normal teacher, Sophia Steele, who is in the room but trying not to get involved.

"Sir, who is the head of the police?"

"Sir, do you know what the capital of Sierra Leone is?"

"Sir, who decides if asylum seekers can stay?"

The work they produce is very strong, but then this, the top set of the second oldest year, should be the easiest lesson I have all day. In a class where many are first- or second-generation immigrants, most write provocatively about asylum seekers, against the grain of their thinking. Jessica comes up with emotive words such as "parasites"; Diana writes of refugees coming to Britain on a "luxury holiday package". There are also powerful descriptions of why asylum seekers come to this country and how they are treated when they get here.

After each girl reads out bits of their work, they clap each other. The lesson goes OK, not great. Sophia Steele says it was interesting, but that I should have got them talking a bit more at the beginning. "It would have been good to give them 10 minutes to discuss it in groups, and then get feedback, and have a kind of discussion."

As I walk into my next lesson, the chances of having any kind of discussion appears nil. The noise is somewhere between a football crowd and a pneumatic drill. This year-nine class have just started doing a topic on Aids. So, suggested Grealy, get them to write a story about someone with HIV or Aids.

The prospect of saying condom in front of a group of 13-year-old girls does not fill me with unconfined joy. They know I'm not a proper teacher. I am here because someone at the Campaign for Learning thought it would be a good idea for me to see what teaching was like for a day. And this is a 25-strong, second-from-top set in English, and they have seen me coming.

Robina is shouting and Nilofar is wrapping herself in a curtain.

"Please, don't do that," I say.

"Go away."

"Now c'mon, you need to get on with some work."

Nilofar sits under her desk with her paper on her chair.

"It's better to work like this."

In big letters she writes: "I have Aids. Poo hoo hoo."

"Look! Look! Look at what Nilofar's done!" says a girl whose surname is Attack.

Lee chews gum, takes gum out, throws gum away, moves seats. "I'm moving away from HER!" she says before singing a song which ends with the phrase "my skiddy knickers".

Robina won't turn round. "I am turned round."

Kayleigh only wants to speak to the class teacher, Letty Jackson. "No. I want miss."

"Hey c'mon, c'mon. You really have got to get on with some work now or you're in trouble. You've got 25 minutes now . . . Oh, please don't, please don't."

"Sir, have you ever interviewed anyone famous?"

"Sir, do you insinuate the truth and try and invent things that are really happening?"

Nilofar wraps herself in the curtain again.

When do I intervene, and when do I let it go? And why does this remind me of the May Day riot?

"Sir, I've finished, I can't write any more."

"Where are you going?"

Most of the aggro comes from a row of four desks by the window, where Robina, Bianca, Lee and Nilofar are. Most of the others want to work, and many produce good writing, full of informed comment about the spread of Aids. "Come on, you've only got eight minutes now."

"I'm reading HERS."

"Can you make more of an effort."

"Can you get Aids from masturbation?"

"I don't know anything about Aids. I've never even had sex."

"How long do you have to wait for the result of an Aids test?"

"Sssssh."

"What's the doctor in the Simpsons called? The crap one."

"Has anybody got any queries?"

"QUEER-ies!! Ha ha!"

"Why should I? It's not worth it."

"Can you put that money away, sorry."

"Can you turn round, Robina."

"I'll read it out for her!"

Cheneka, one of the disruptive pupils at the beginning, produces only half a page, but it's among the best. Maddening, really.

Somebody writes: "My life is a mess. Living La Vita Loca! Oui monsieur? I have Aids and I am very sad. I am a lesbian but people don't understand what I am going through. Thong Ta Tong To Tong. I am not your girlfriend anymore!" And that's about it in an hour and a half.

"We had some really good discussion last week," says Jackson. "But some of these girls are very, very attention-seeking and some of them have got very poor levels of concentration.

"You were trying in a very adult way to talk to them and reason with them, but unfortunately they are a group where sometimes I have to be extremely heavy-handed and shout at them - and I mean shout at them."

At lunch in the canteen, the head teacher, Jan Cartwright, hands out tokens for free school dinners which go to more than 50% of pupils. She gets in to work at 6.15am every day. Heather Ballantine, the head of years 10 and 11, who sits with me as I peer into shepherd's pie, gets in at 7.15am. She tells me the biggest discipline problem they have these days is with text messages being sent on mobile phones. Six hundred girls aged 11 to 16 go to school here, from Fulham, Acton, Battersea, and Ladbroke Grove. Between them they speak 50 languages. Almost all of their very best pupils speak a different language at home. The school is full and it doesn't have to take on excluded pupils, and the last time Ofsted visited it got some criticism but plenty of praise, especially for English. It is not posh but it is serious and well-organised.

Jim Grealy is with me for the last lesson. This is also year nine, doing the same topic, but the top set this time.

"Sir, your tie's all wrong," says Okite in the front row, and I could be about to get anxious again, but then something marvellous happens.

I hand out more newspaper cuttings on Aids and HIV and make some points, and I get them to talk about it. I make the instructions crystal clear. Imagine you've just been to interview someone with HIV or Aids: what would they say?

I don't bother putting my name up on the board in shorthand this time, too distracting. And I remember to let them talk between themselves for 10 minutes, to exchange ideas. They complain that I've asked them to write three pages, and occasionally they ask me questions, or get me to explain. And they connect, engage.

It's like I've caught some kind of learning "biting point".

I look up at the clock at 1.45pm and the room is completely quiet. They are all writing and I see how everyone is doing and I feel exhilarated. Good teachers must feel like this a lot. At least I hope they do.

"Are we writing for a tabloid or a broadsheet?"

"Sir, can babies get Aids?"

"That's brilliant."

"Thank you."

"How much do you get paid?"

Everyone writes a recognisable version of a newspaper interview. Some are uneven but all are laced with thought and empathy. They try out words like "facade" and "deplorably". Angie's character says: "I was curious to know why God chose me out of all humans who seem to appear on this fragile earth." Suddaf's Aids patient says: "I feel as though nearly everyone I see has an invisible dagger." And she rounds off with: "I saw a brave, courageous man who wouldn't be beaten and would live a full life and accomplish his dreams."

Grealy insists they wouldn't have been so well behaved if the lesson had been boring, but I am not sure. Some pupils stay behind to talk to me about how it went. "I think your approach was different to a teacher," says Okite. "Like when I was doing mine you said 'that starting bits all right but I would put in the middle, I would cheat a little bit'."

They are nice about the lesson too. And it was fun. That last lesson was thrilling really, but just think of the responsibility, day in, day out. And as I rush on to get the bus home I feel a small but certain pang of relief in knowing I'm not coming back tomorrow to do it all over again.

webTitle: The best practical joke scene: Man on the moon

fields.headline: The best practical joke scene: Man on the moon
fields.trailText: LA. The office of Maynard Smith (Vincent Schiavelli), ABC TV executive. A nervous assistant pokes her head through the door. "Sir, they're having a problem down on the Kaufman Special. They say he's not following the technical requirements."
fields.body:
LA. The office of Maynard Smith (Vincent Schiavelli), ABC TV executive. A nervous assistant pokes her head through the door. "Sir, they're having a problem down on the Kaufman Special. They say he's not following the technical requirements."

Smith looks baffled. "Technical?" Cut to the technician's booth of an anonymous TV set. Andy Kaufman (Jim Carrey) is arguing with a heavy-set technician. "It's my show! Now make it roll!" "No!" Smith approaches Kaufman, an emollient tone in his voice. "Andy, I hear fabulous things about the special."

He hesitates. "Ah, now I understand we've hit a teeny speedbump." The technician turns around. "Yeah, Kid Genius told me to mess with the horizontal hold! He wants the picture to roll!" Maynard doesn't understand. "Show me."

The technician pushes a button. On a monitor, Andy's image briefly appears, then begins to roll across the screen before finally disappearing in a blur of static. "It'll be great!" Kaufman enthuses.

"The viewer will think their TV is broken. They'll get out of their chair, they'll twist the knobs, they'll hit the TV, but they won't be able to fix it!" Maynard stares glumly at the monitor. He speaks as if addressing a child. "Andy... we don't want the viewer to get out of their chair. They might change channel." Kaufman looks exasperated. "But it's funny!"

See also: The Birds, Batman, Urban Legend

Don't see also: Porky's

Pointless trivia: Vincent Schiavelli made a number of appearances as the Reverend Gorky on Taxi alongside Andy Kaufman.

fields.headline: Of mice and men
fields.standfirst: Tonight, director Kevin Smith will watch the animated version of his indie hit Clerks premiere on American TV. A cause for celebration? Not when producers Disney seem determined to see it fail. He talked exclusively to  Joel Meadows
fields.trailText: Tonight, director Kevin Smith will watch the animated version of his indie hit Clerks premiere on American TV. A cause for celebration? Not when producers Disney seem determined to see it fail.
fields.body:
It's not unusual for a film to spin off into a television series. But indie luminary Kevin Smith's (pictured, centre) Clerks: The Animated Series - which premieres in the US this evening - is a programme with a difference. The project has a higher budget than the film it was based on (Clerks the film was financed via Smith's credit card, while the series has a budget of approximately $750,000 per episode), and its history is a chequered one.

"Way back in 1995," Smith explains, "when we were working on Mallrats, someone told me that they'd read for a part in a Clerks sitcom. Apparently, Touchstone or Disney TV were developing a series with Warner Brothers. So they produced a pilot, which was abysmal, and the series never got aired. But then I approached CAA and Miramax and suggested the idea of a Clerks animated series. The Simpsons was the only prime-time animation series at the time and, when we pitched it to Fox, they seemed to think that The Simpsons was a 'one of a kind' show, and they didn't think that anything else would ever work in the same slot."

Smith pauses, then laughs to himself as he continues: "A few years passed and, by 1998, you couldn't move for prime-time animated shows. So we mentioned to Bob Weinstein at Miramax that we were developing an animated series based on Clerks, and that we'd done the Jay And Silent Bob comics. It was at this point that we got Dave Mandel on board, who'd written for Seinfeld. We brought him in as one of the executive producers and we came up with a concept for the show, which was like the movie reduced, and with some new elements thrown in."

The show was then pitched to every US network (Warner Brothers, ABC, HBO, UPN), and won two offers: one to produce 12 episodes for UPN and another to make six for ABC. There were rumours that UPN wasn't going to last much longer, so it seemed the sensible thing for Smith to accept the ABC offer.

Clerks: The Animated Series is the first real mainstream work that Smith has produced - on a big US network to boot - so he was very aware that the writing had to be less smutty and more subtle than usual. But this didn't cause him and his writing partners any real problems.

"Firstly, going to TV, you immediately lose the ability over here to swear and be overly vulgar and obscene", he tells me, slightly regretfully. "You have to be a lot more clever with it to get stuff past the censor and the network. You have to be subversive without being profane, which is a first for me. We're definitely using The Simpsons as our model. There'd be no sense in using South Park as our template because that show pushes the envelope on a cable station over here."

Clerks was pushed around ABC's schedule, moved from an original broadcast date of March. And at one point View Askew, Smith's production company, were going to reclaim the copyright and re-edit the six episodes into a single animated film. Paul Dini, a producer of Batman animations, suggested they use a framing device, with Chris Rock as Uncle Remus, or make it a Tales From The Crypt-style anthology. But Smith wasn't happy with the fact that it would still look like a TV show, so he decided to leave it with ABC. After some pushing around, ABC decided on a broadcast date of May 31.

Smith is convinced that this date is the kiss of death for the series: "For me, May 31 pretty much ensures the show's failure. Essentially, it seems as if the network doesn't like the show. When they held test screenings in February in San Diego and Ohio, the audience didn't react very well to it. But the people who they used for the screenings had a key demographic missing: the 18 to 24-year-olds, who would be the people most likely to watch Clerks. It's insane."

In the USA, launching a series during the summer is suicide: "Very seldom does a show that debuts in the summer get picked up. Traditionally, the summer is when 25% of the audience is no longer watching." Ironically, ABC is owned by Disney, which makes it the second time - after the corporation effectively disowned his religious epic Dogma - that they have interfered with one of Smith's projects: "I can't believe that we got fucked hard by the mouse twice in the span of a year."

Taking a moment to compose himself, Smith calms down: "There's really no pressure on us because at this point it's not as if we have to get good ratings to stay on, as we're not going to be coming back. Having said that, however it does on TV, you have to figure that the worst night would probably reach more people than most of our films have reached theatrically. Potentially, if we let it run on TV and receive some nice feedback, then maybe we can turn it into a feature with a viable box office prospect ahead of it.

"It remains to be seen whether or not we'll do that."

fields.headline: Cult classic
fields.standfirst: Does John Travolta's Battlefield Earth contain subliminal messages recruiting Scientologists? Amid a flurry of bizarre claims and counterclaims, only one thing is certain: it is one of the worst movies ever made.  Duncan Campbell reports
fields.trailText: Does John Travolta's Battlefield Earth contain subliminal messages recruiting Scientologists? Amid a flurry of bizarre claims and counterclaims, only one thing is certain: it is one of the worst movies ever made.
fields.body:
It is the year 3000 and "man-animals" are scrabbling for survival in the lonely expanse of what the mighty Psychlos describe as "this pitiful excuse for a planet". It is also the year 2000 and a mere seven man-animals are scrabbling for their popcorn in the lonely expanse of one of the 3,307 cinemas in the US in which the sci-fi film Battlefield Earth has opened to spectacularly bad notices, many of which have suggested that the film is the worst of the year, the decade, the millennium or whatever exotic time-frame the alien Psychlos recognise.

But it is not so much the poor reviews - after all, turkeys land in Hollywood as regularly as swallows in Capistrano - that have attracted attention so much as the provenance of the film and the stories attached to its purpose. The book on which the film is based is the 1984 science-fiction bestseller by L Ron Hubbard, founder of the Church of Scientology. Since the star, John Travolta, is also a Scientologist this has led to much fevered speculation about whether the film has a mission beyond that of the aliens to tame the man-animals.

The film itself has taken the sort of critical battering that would make any galaxy implode. Mischievous technicians who worked on it have even put together a mock poster now circulating in Los Angeles bearing a selection of quotes: "May well turn out to be the worst movie of this century" (New York Times). "A bloated sci-fi monstrosity!" (Toronto Star). "A million monkeys with a million crayons would be hard-pressed in a million years to create anything as cretinous as Battlefield Earth" (Washington Post).

So bad have the reviews been that people are now planning expeditions to see the film for its sheer awfulness and they will not be disappointed in what the New Yorker called "this pitiful excuse for an entertainment, the Showgirls of sci-fi." The $75m film went into free-fall with a drop of 67% in box office receipts in its second week. Last weekend it took on average just over £200 per cinema - a tiny return.

There is much speculation on what went wrong, since Travolta and the director, Roger Christian, who won an art direction Oscar for Star Wars in 1977 and was nominated for his work on Alien, have both done such spectacularly successful work in the past. Perhaps the planets were just in the wrong place.

But the back-story had a separate life. This was a dastardly rumour started on the FACTNet website which, since 1994, has been producing anti-Scientology and anti-cult material from its home in Boulder, Colorado. FACTnet suggested that subliminal messages had been cunningly inserted by Scientologists to win over new converts to join the church, which now claims 8.5m members worldwide, around half of them in the US.

This mischievous tale was repeated and became part of the chat around the film, much to the dismay of the Church of Scientology. FACTNet also claimed that Scientologists had helped to fund the film as part of a recruiting drive and that its members are under instructions to see the film at least three times so that it becomes a hit.

Lawrence Wollersheim, who produces FACTNet with the help of volunteers is an ex-Scientologist who left the church - or was excommunicated, according to the Scientologists - in 1979. He has since been involved in many litigation battles with them.

He said this week that he could give no evidence for his claims because the stories had all come from people whose identity he had to protect. He said he anticipated that the church would sue but said he had a "bear-trap" waiting for them if they did.

He said his web-site was currently getting 200,000 hits a week and he is tickled that Hubbard's masterwork has turned out to be such a disaster on screen: "they've choked their own golden goose."

Warner Bros, the film's distributor, is familiar with the tales: "we hear the rumblings, they are silly nonsense," said a spokesman this week. (The reviews have been unwelcome, however, and the film's sequel that would have covered the second half of the 1,040-page book is now "up in the air", according to Warner Bros.)

The Church of Scientology is also very unhappy that the film based on its founder's best-seller should be the subject of such outlandish tales. It is anxious to put the record straight, saying that it did not pay for the funding of the movie nor are members under any instructions to see it.

An initial inquiry by the Guardian about the origin of the rumours prompted no fewer than five different representatives of the church to contact us with offers of information and I am grateful to them for a better knowledge of Hubbard: "Raised in the still-rugged frontier of Montana, he broke his first bronc and became the blood brother of a Blackfeet Indian medicine man by age six"; of his honours and awards: Golden Tie Award (French National Federation of Culture), Author of the Century (Grijalbo-Mondadori); and of the book on which the film is based: 430,000 words long, 6m copies sold since publication in 1984, translated into 21 languages. I also know more about Hubbard's time in Hollywood: he wrote the original story for the 1938 serial The Secret of the Treasure Island and worked on The Spider Returns, The Mysterious Pilot and The Adventures of Wild Bill Hickcock

The church is anxious to slap down the FACTNet calumnies. Spokeswoman Janet Weiland described the stories as "hogwash. This is a hate group and everything they have said is so off the wall. They'll say anything they can to get the media's attention. It's outrageous." From England, Bob Keenan of New Era Publications, which publishes the book, says FACTNet is "just one guy who sits there pumping all this bullshit out". In LA, other callers from the church told me that the book was a sci-fi classic in its own right and should not be confused with what the church is.

The battle over Battlefield Earth has not all been one-sided. The editor of Sci Fi magazine, Scott Edelman, argues that the film should be judged as a film: "Travolta first came across the fictional works of Hubbard as the result of his own religious beliefs. Is there anything wrong with that? Absolutely not. But some folks seem to want to make it so, worried that the film might be a Scientology proselytising tool. But it is nothing of the sort, any more than a film created by members of any other religious persuasion is an attempt at conversion. The lesson here? Judge movies for what they are on screen - and ignore the rest."

The book, Battlefield Earth, was sporting a "soon to be major motion picture" on its cover as long ago as 1984. So was the wait worth it? Sitting in a Los Angeles cinema along with seven others - three by the end of the movie - the feeling was of being locked inside a video game where no one can hear your screams because the combination of intergalactical bombardments and B-movie epic strings had drowned them out. With its wrecked cityscapes and doomed shopping malls it has the feel of a would-be Blade Runner that got the laces of its trainers caught in the starting blocks. And talking of laces, for some reason all the Psychlos seem to wear bootlaces attached to their nostrils. Why is this? British film-goers may get some unintentional smiles from the fact that the hub of the evil empire is called Home Office; maybe Jack Straw played by Charles Hawtrey could have saved it.

Anthony Lane in the New Yorker reported that when he saw the film the cinema was also "resounding to the howls of low-toned mockery and the ominous clap of seats flipping back up". His conclusion was "the one thing that could dent the armour-plated cause of Scientology is the sound of global derision." Indeed, the only subliminal voice I could detect came about 10 minutes into this 121-minute film and it seemed to be saying "Leeeaaave thisssss cinemmmaaa nooo"

Battlefield Earth is out on Friday.

webTitle: How a former US drugs chief will oversee the reform of the RUC

fields.headline: How a former US drugs chief will oversee the reform of the RUC
fields.standfirst: Former Northern Ireland correspondent Derek Brown on what the appointment of a new American commissioner to supervise police reform in Ulster means for the peace process
fields.trailText: Wednesday, 1.30pm: Former Northern Ireland correspondent Derek Brown on what the appointment of a new American commissioner to supervise police reform in Ulster means for the peace process
fields.body:
A controversial former head of the US Drugs Enforcement Administration (DEA) is to play a key role in supervising police reforms in Northern Ireland. The appointment of Tom Constantine is likely to raise many eyebrows in Westminster and in Dublin. In Belfast, it could raise the temperature of an already red hot debate.

Constantine, whose official title is oversight commissioner, will have to steer a delicate course politically as well as professionally, as he tries to breathe life into the government's policing bill over the next three years.

The bill is already under attack from nationalists and republicans who believe that Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson has significantly watered down some of the radical proposals in last year's Patten report on police reform.

The Ulster Unionists too are sniping at the bill. They want to retain the name and insignia of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, and fear that compromise could leave them outflanked by the anti-power sharing Democratic Unionists led by Ian Paisley.

Mandelson has opted for convoluted compromise. His bill talks of the new Police Service of Northern Ireland "incorporating the Royal Ulster Constabulary". Nationalists and republicans - and some Labour dissidents in the Commons - are now deeply concerned that such ambiguities could make a nonsense of the central thrust of the Patten report, which was to build an entirely new community-based police service.

The Patten report also proposed an independent overseer of the reform process, the role now taken on by Mr Constantine.

On the face of it, he is ideally qualified, as a former head of the DEA and, before that, the New York state police. But his glittering law enforcement career has been dogged by controversy, rising to something of a crescendo during his five and a half years at the drugs agency, from which he retired last summer.

Critics have accused him of deliberately running down the agency to comply with the Clinton administration's ambition of merging it with the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The DEA Watch website is particularly vitriolic about his record, compared with that of his predecessor Robert Bonner.

There is little doubt about Mr Constantine's loyalty to the US president, and it must be presumed that he will be Washington's eyes and ears in Belfast during the coming crucial months for the peace process.

Clinton, who played a key role in brokering the Good Friday peace deal, has emphasised his commitment to police reform. Constantine will be under pressure from Washington to implement radical changes, but he will be left in little doubt by unionists and by the London government that he should tread carefully.

webTitle: Fiji armed forces bow to rebels

fields.headline: Fiji armed forces bow to rebels
fields.trailText: The new military regime in Fiji speedily capitulated yesterday to almost all the demands of the rebel leader, George Speight, in an attempt to end the hostage crisis.
fields.body:
The new military regime in Fiji speedily capitulated yesterday to almost all the demands of the rebel leader, George Speight, in an attempt to end the hostage crisis.

The regime, which replaced the civilian government on Monday, agreed to his central demand of revoking the constitution in favour of a return to one racially biased against the ethnic Indian population.

Mr Speight leads a group fighting for the dominance of the Melanesian-Polynesians, who make up 48% of the population. A new prime minister, replacing Mahendra Chaudhry, who is from an Indian background, is expected to be announced today.

In other concessions to the rebels, the president, Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara, has been sent into exile and the military has offered an unconditional amnesty to Mr Speight if he ends the standoff.

The concessions raised expectations in the capital Suva that the crisis over the hostages held in the parliament building could soon be at an end. But western diplomats warned that the potential for a violent end remained, and that Mr Speight might be encouraged by his success to make further demands.

Mr Speight lent credence to the latter yesterday by saying he was not happy with the military regime led by Commodore Frank Bainimarama. "I think Bainimarama is a lost cause," Mr Speight said, claiming that he was too closely identified with the previous government. He added that about half the military supported the rebels.

The island group is split uneasily between the Melanesian-Polynesian population and the descendants of Indians brought to work on the sugar plantations by the British generations ago and who also make up 48% of the population. The Indians run the bulk of the businesses, a source of resentment.

Commodore Bainimarama, who took over when the elected government failed to quell the rebellion, revoked the multiracial constitution, which had allowed an ethnic Indian to become prime minister, and reverted to a 1990 constitution favouring the Melanesian-Polynesian population.

A Foreign Office spokesman in London yesterday deplored the move: "It is a regrettable and backward step for democracy in Fiji." A special meeting of Commonwealth foreign ministers is scheduled for next Tuesday to discuss what steps to take to express disapproval.

A Commonwealth spokesman stressed the situation remained fluid. The group has options ranging from sending an envoy to suspending Fiji from attendance at Commonwealth council meetings, the sanction imposed on Pakistan after its military coup last year.

The Commonwealth secretary general, Don McKinnon, said it would be hard to find an effective way of pressing Fiji to abandon the new race-based constitution. The ministers in the secretariat "will be taking a pretty hard line. But whether it will have an immediate effect on Fiji is problematic."

Commodore Bainimarama told the Australian government he did not want to run the Fijian government and spoke of a fresh constitution and possible new elections.

He is expected to name Ratu Epeli Nailatikau as interim prime minister today. His wife, Adi Nailatikau Mara, is among the 30 hostages. Mr Nailatikau was Fiji's army commander until he was overthrown in a military coup in 1987 and later became Fiji's high commissioner to Britain.

He is the son-in-law of the president who was reported by the Australian government yesterday to be safe aboard a ship off the Fijian coast.

Mr Speight and his gunmen seized control of the parliament on May 19, seizing power in the name of ethnic Fijians and taking the hostages. The deposed prime minister, Mr Chaudhry, is among the hostages. Negotiations were taking place last night between Mr Speight and the military regime.

webTitle: Blair acts to abolish NHS waiting lists

fields.headline: Blair acts to abolish NHS waiting lists
fields.standfirst:
The future of the NHS: special report
Polly Toynbee on Labour's plans
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is throwing his weight behind an audacious strategy that would in effect abolish NHS waiting lists, guaranteeing that no patient would wait more than three months for any treatment.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is throwing his weight behind an audacious strategy that would in effect abolish NHS waiting lists, guaranteeing that no patient would wait more than three months for any treatment.

The prime minister wants to unveil the goal as the centrepiece - the "big idea" - of the government's NHS Plan, to be set out in July.

The ambitious strategy would rid the health service of its albatross image of interminable queueing. It would deal a devastating blow to the private health insurance industry, which relies heavily on people's fear of long waits for relief of grave and painful conditions.

Health experts have convinced Mr Blair that the goal is achievable, given tough action to "manage" demand for hospital care and radical measures to tackle the worst queues for operations.

A key plank of the strategy would be separation of non-urgent or elective surgery from emergency work, which at present always takes precedence. This could involve creation of special "elective surgery centres", dealing only with common procedures such as hip and knee replacements or cataract removal.

Such centres could operate round the clock, seven days a week, and would employ nurse anaesthetists, operating assistants and other new types of staff to smash old established demarcations.

Advisers to the prime minister and Alan Milburn, the health secretary, believe waiting lists and times could become a non-issue by the end of a second Labour term. Maximum waits could be cut first to six months and then to three. A wait of up to three months is broadly comparable to the rest of Europe; it is considered inadvisable on clinical grounds to aim for anything less in all but life-threatening cases.

Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS confederation, which represents health authorities and trusts, last night said an historic breakthrough was within reach. "We are talking of nothing less than the end of queueing, which has been the Achilles heel that has beset the NHS since its beginning."

The strategy is disclosed on "NHS census day", with 1m health workers and 1m patients today being asked to make their contribution to thinking on the NHS Plan.

However, the public's top priority is already clear to ministers. Although people are concerned about dirty wards, inedible hospital food and lack of information about their care plans and progress, the overwhelming grievance is the wait to be treated.

All that stands in the way of Mr Blair grasping the big idea is the Treasury: notwithstanding the unprecedented commitment to a 35% increase in NHS funds over the next four years, there is acute anxiety over the potential cost of a no-wait health service.

Experience suggests that big cuts in waiting lists trigger surges in demand for treatment, as family doctors refer patients with long-term, "grumbling" conditions.

In 1995, the then Conservative government succeeded in all but eliminating hospital waits of more than 12 months. But outpatient numbers soared 600,000 in a year as GPs made record referrals and, by the end of 1996, long waits had shot up again.

According to the latest figures for England, 49,000 people have been waiting for treatment more than 12 months out of a total waiting list of just over 1m.

The NHS confederation is warning the government that strong action would be needed to avoid an upsurge in patient referrals as waiting times fell. In an unpublished submission to the NHS Plan consultation, it says the first six months should be spent developing "referral guidelines, scoring systems and structured methods of assessment" for GPs.

The confederation is backing the innovation of surgery centres and of specialist teams to be "airlifted" into areas running into problems.

Influential advisers brought into the health department by Mr Milburn are also supporting the radical approach. But they know that there will be resistance from many hospital consultants with contracts under lengthy renegotiation.

One solution would be to divide the consultants, offering surgeons and anaesthetists what the confederation calls "very significant remuneration" to work in the new surgery centres.

fields.headline: Mr Speight gets his way
fields.standfirst: But Fiji's ethnic balance must be restored
fields.trailText: It began as a hostage seizure. It turned into a constitutional crisis. Now it has become an army coup and the overthrow of a democratic government.
fields.body:
It began as a hostage seizure. It turned into a constitutional crisis. Now it has become an army coup and the overthrow of a democratic government. The drama in Fiji is novel in form, but depressingly ancient in substance. After decades of living in the same archipelago, and in spite of the apparent resolution of an earlier crisis which broke out over the same issues 13 years ago, relations between the two main ethnic groups are still no more settled than a simmering volcano.

At least the current violence has not produced widespread bloodshed or pogroms and has been confined to the capital city, Suva. It is a crisis between the leaders of the 51% of the archipelago's population of 800,000 who are descendants of indigenous Fijians and the 44% who are of Indian origin. It did not develop as a response to popular pressure, though Indians are now afraid they could be targeted if emotions remain high. The elite has shown minimal vision and it only took a group of gunmen led by a shady businessman to storm the parliament building and the whole edifice of constitutionalism collapsed. The president, the council of chiefs, and the army commander, all of whom are ethnic Fijians, have simply given in to the coup leader's demands. If this was merely a tactical ploy aimed at getting the Indian prime minister and the other hostages released, it might be defensible; but the signs are that it is more than that. With the president's support, the army commander is reimposing an old constitution which denies Indians political power. The Commonwealth is almost certain to move towards suspending Fiji when its ministers meet next week. It will be right to do so.

But the crisis has also exposed the weakness of Westminster-style winner-takes-all politics in a country where virtually every party is ethnically based and there is no cross-voting. The trigger for the latest events was the election which allowed the Indian party of the now deposed prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, to win an absolute majority after the ethnic Fijian vote split between five parties. Against the will of the tribal chiefs, Mr Chaudhry proposed a bill to give Indian sugar cane farmers long leases on their land. So the coup involves economics as well as politics. But the only sensible response must be some form of power-sharing. Fiji's leaders must look urgently for a constitutional formula which makes that possible.

webTitle: An end to waiting - that's a promise to the health service

fields.headline: An end to waiting - that's a promise to the health service
fields.standfirst:
Labour's revolutionary plan mustn't be dismissed as too good to be true

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's revolutionary plan mustn't be dismissed as too good to be true
fields.body:
An extraordinary and revolutionary plan is brewing. As the NHS "national plan" takes shape, the government is on the verge of making a pledge to abolish queueing in the NHS within the next five years. It would be a pledge as surprising and unexpected as the ones promising full employment and the abolition of child poverty. A hot debate is in progress, with the Department of Health and Number 10 determined to go for it, and the Treasury digging in its heels. Understandably, the Treasury fears such a promise would be a constant gun to its head, forcing unknown sums for health year after year if the target looked as if it might not be met. But advocates of the pledge are growing. It would become the big idea the NHS national plan has been searching for until now.

The prime minister is firmly in the driving seat of the national plan process, spending a great deal of his time each week on it. He is pushing ahead with this waiting list idea - once he's sure it can genuinely be done. What the prime minister wants he is likely to get, whatever the Treasury says. Visitors to him these days are regaled with detailed information about the myriad inefficiencies the NHS has lived with since its inception. He's inclined to say: "Did you know some surgeons only do three operations a week, while others do 30? Did you know 40% of people referred to hospital outpatients never needed a consultant at all?" The more the teams work away at the national plan, the clearer it becomes that unblocking the bottle-necks depends on doctors and nurses breaking down old professional demarcations.

Today a census inside the entire NHS will ask each of the day's 1m patients and the 1m NHS staff to write down their "top three things that would make the NHS better". The results will be collated by a private firm within two weeks and handed to the 120-strong national plan committee and its all-inclusive task forces of NHS professionals. The government already knows what patients will say. Recent private polling reveals they say it's waiting, waiting and waiting, especially for cancer treatments and GP appointments. Dirty wards and inedible hospital food rank high, but waiting comes first, second and third.

Could it be done? One of the chief promoters of the idea is Stephen Thornton, head of the NHS confederation. In five years? Easy, he says, it could take less than five years if the national plan is radical enough when it's published in July. What would it take? First, abandon the nonsensical target of cutting total waiting lists, one of Labour's worst manifesto mistakes. Who cares how many others wait, all that matters is how long they wait. Waiting time will be cut at first to a six-month maximum. After that everyone will get a guaranteed booked appointment in three months - and that effectively counts as abolition, in line with most of Europe. (So long as cancer and urgent cases are dealt with at once, others should be left a little while before operating as conditions can improve or patients change their minds.) How could it be done? It needs a radical break with the past and total restructuring of the professions.

One idea is to create new surgery units, with highly paid surgeons contracted for nothing but routine waiting list operations, with no danger of operations cancelled or beds purloined: emergency cases go to other units. New sub-consultant grades would do simpler operations, something the BMA strongly resists. The danger is that when waiting lists fall, GPs just refer more borderline cases to hospitals, sometimes with vague referral notes asking a consultant to "please advise on this case". That will have to stop. The new primary care groups into which all GPs are now grouped to purchase hospital services for their patients will have to control who they refer, conducting their own lab tests first and hiring their own specialists for minor operations, cutting down hospital referrals.

Hanging over all this, though, is the consultants' contract which has been in slow renegotiation for a year and a half. Tomorrow the BMA consultants committee meets in London for its annual conference, where the vexed question of the contract will be hotly debated. If the government is lucky there may be a new division between the surgeons (who have much private practice) and the majority who work very hard almost exclusively within the NHS. The waiting list promise will require deft handling of the doctors: no use precipitating rebellion. Yet something has to be done about the absurdity of the present contract that allows key surgeons to spend too much time on private work despite virtually full NHS pay. Can the government walk the tightrope of reforming the contract, getting more work out of the underperforming doctors and yet keep them enthused about the national plan?

The shocking survey by John Yates published in the Health Service journal will strengthen the government's arm - and may incense many other NHS consultants. It found supposedly full-time orthopaedic surgeons on average conducted only 6.4 operations a week taking just seven hours. They do fewer than 10 years ago, though the numbers of orthopaedic surgeons has nearly doubled. They control their long waiting lists: as a result hips, knees and other bones are the most sought after private operations. The report concludes no more orthopaedic surgeons be appointed until existing ones increase their NHS work to at least four sessions a week lasting three and a half hours each. Hardworking consultants without private practice are growing increasingly restive at being tarred with the same brush. Divide and rule may be the government strategy, but it could be a hard battle. Abolishing waiting lists will kill most private practice.

When the prime minister announced the largest increase the NHS has ever had, many insiders saw it as the last desperate chance for the NHS. Every newspaper (bar the Guardian and Mirror) was openly advocating privatisation in one form another. On television Tory shadow health minister Philip Hammond advocated an NHS for emergencies only, with private insurance for everything else. As average incomes rise fast, seductive brochures for private hospitals might woo too many people away, leaving the NHS a poor service for the poor. That is why Blair went for the things patients care about most, creating NHS Direct, high street clinics and booked operation appointments. If waiting is really abolished then the NHS will be saved. However, it is such an astonishing leap there's a danger that it will simply not be believed, in the same way that Labour's sceptical heartlands seem to disregard those other radical promises on child poverty and full employment. Time to abandon third way mumble and let Labour rhetoric match its most radical plans.
