The danger is that when waiting lists fall, GPs just refer more borderline cases to hospitals, sometimes with vague referral notes asking a consultant to "please advise on this case". That will have to stop. The new primary care groups into which all GPs are now grouped to purchase hospital services for their patients will have to control who they refer, conducting their own lab tests first and hiring their own specialists for minor operations, cutting down hospital referrals. Hanging over all this, though, is the consultants' contract which has been in slow renegotiation for a year and a half. Tomorrow the BMA consultants committee meets in London for its annual conference, where the vexed question of the contract will be hotly debated. If the government is lucky there may be a new division between the surgeons (who have much private practice) and the majority who work very hard almost exclusively within the NHS. The waiting list promise will require deft handling of the doctors: no use precipitating rebellion. Yet something has to be done about the absurdity of the present contract that allows key surgeons to spend too much time on private work despite virtually full NHS pay. Can the government walk the tightrope of reforming the contract, getting more work out of the underperforming doctors and yet keep them enthused about the national plan? The shocking survey by John Yates published in the Health Service journal will strengthen the government's arm - and may incense many other NHS consultants. It found supposedly full-time orthopaedic surgeons on average conducted only 6.4 operations a week taking just seven hours. They do fewer than 10 years ago, though the numbers of orthopaedic surgeons has nearly doubled. They control their long waiting lists: as a result hips, knees and other bones are the most sought after private operations. The report concludes no more orthopaedic surgeons be appointed until existing ones increase their NHS work to at least four sessions a week lasting three and a half hours each. Hardworking consultants without private practice are growing increasingly restive at being tarred with the same brush. Divide and rule may be the government strategy, but it could be a hard battle. Abolishing waiting lists will kill most private practice. When the prime minister announced the largest increase the NHS has ever had, many insiders saw it as the last desperate chance for the NHS. Every newspaper (bar the Guardian and Mirror) was openly advocating privatisation in one form another. On television Tory shadow health minister Philip Hammond advocated an NHS for emergencies only, with private insurance for everything else. As average incomes rise fast, seductive brochures for private hospitals might woo too many people away, leaving the NHS a poor service for the poor. That is why Blair went for the things patients care about most, creating NHS Direct, high street clinics and booked operation appointments. If waiting is really abolished then the NHS will be saved. However, it is such an astonishing leap there's a danger that it will simply not be believed, in the same way that Labour's sceptical heartlands seem to disregard those other radical promises on child poverty and full employment. Time to abandon third way mumble and let Labour rhetoric match its most radical plans. polly.toynbee@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Don't frighten the cows
fields.standfirst:
Tuba travails and proof that art really can be a load of old tripe

www.artscouncil.org.uk/funding/
fields.trailText: There are some confused cows this morning somewhere in a field in Leicestershire. Musician John Hodkin - who is about to cycle 1,000 miles around the East Midlands with his tuba giving impromptu concerts three times a day - has been experimenting on bovines before he subjects humans to the sound of the maligned musical instrument.
fields.body:
There are some confused cows this morning somewhere in a field in Leicestershire. Musician John Hodkin - who is about to cycle 1,000 miles around the East Midlands with his tuba giving impromptu concerts three times a day - has been experimenting on bovines before he subjects humans to the sound of the maligned musical instrument.

But the cows are not half as perplexed as the good folk of Rossendale, Lancashire, where vegetarian artist John Spedding has been toying with making sculptures from black pudding and tripe, big delicacies in Rawtenstall market.

These are two of wackier happenings during the Year of the Artist, when more than 1,000 artists, writers and musicians will bring art to the places art does not usually reach.

But the strangest project for a £5m series of residencies, partly funded by Coca-Cola, is Gavin Turk's brainwave to bring Che Guevara back from the grave to start a revolution by storming Shoreditch town hall in London's East End.

"I haven't worked out who should be in my band of merry men yet," Turk said. "But I will be Che, and we will be true to the spirit of Citizen Smith."

The Year of the Artist began yesterday with the unveiling of a nine-foot twitching head of John Humphrys, presenter of BBC Radio 4's Today, and a man prone to ask "But is it art?" with regularity. Richard Kriel, who will spend the year with Radio 1, and performance poet Attila the Stockbroker, who has been commissioned to read a new verse before every Brighton and Hove Albion home game, will probably reach the biggest audience.

Kriel hopes to perfect his "laser cannon", which picks out individuals in huge crowds and beams music straight at them.

For once spending in the regions far outstrips the capital, with nearly £500,000 being spent in the north-west alone, com pared to London's £172,000.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, said the year chimed with his aims, bringing art to places it is not normally seen.

Getting out and about

Artist Serena de la Hey will build a huge willow figure alongside the M5 in Somerset. Already nicknamed, "The Wicker Man Of The West", it will be 40 foot high and will also be clearly visible from the trains passing on the rail mainline.

A new opera using steam engines called The Landau Papers will be staged at dusk next month at Bolton Abbey station in Yorkshire. Written and composed by Rachel Feldberg and Sam Paechter it draws on their relatives experiences of surviving the Holocaust.

Writer Jackie Gay, who lost a leg in an accident herself, will work at Oak Tree Lane Hospital in Birmingham, which provides patients with prosthetic limbs, to encourage others to write about their trials and triumphs.

Thirteen artists from Globe Artists Studio will work with traders at Rawtenstall market in Lancashire, including making a tapestry of market life with Joan Whiteley who owns a haberdashery stall.

fields.headline: New kids in the block
fields.standfirst: Peabody estates, originally designed to house London's working poor, are now attracting younger tenants frozen out by the soaring price of property
fields.trailText: Peabody estates, originally designed to house London's working poor, are now attracting younger tenants frozen out by the soaring price of property
fields.body:
Nearly 140 years after it was founded to help house the poor of London, the Peabody Trust has on its books a surprising group of the new poor: young, qualified professionals who can't afford flats close to their jobs in the inner city.

The group - nurses, junior hospital doctors, teachers and computer staff - will be Peabody tenants for just a few years, till they move up the housing ladder. But so long as low starting salaries in the public sector are outpaced by rising house prices, there will be key employees needing help at the start of their careers.

The trust is devising new projects and offering new types of tenancy. Hi-tech blocks are rising in worn-out bits of London, outshining the drab barrack-like estates that once were the flagships of the Peabody empire. In Newington Green, there's a development combining flats, shops and a GP's surgery; in Hackney, 30 apartments in Murray Grove have been designed for young professionals on modest incomes who don't qualify for social housing but are struggling to rent. And the trust's biggest venture is just starting at Kensal Green: 300 homes on a mixed tenure scheme, offering social rented, cost rent, shared ownership and outright sale.

This smart new face of Peabody comes after decades when the trust kept a low profile, preoccupied with repairing and refurbishing its ageing stock of 17,000 homes, many built a century ago.

Peabody estates have been part of drab streetscapes for so long that we hardly notice them. Tidy but dull, there's rarely any litter or graffiti, just an indelible whiff of Victorian do-goodery - and the name of the eponymous founder on the side of the buildings.

George Peabody (1795-1869), the Anglophile American philanthropist, wasn't concerned with the rock-bottom destitute when he donated £500,000 to help the poor. The charity he set up was part of the enlightened impulse to combat insanitary slums and chronic disease in industrialised London by improvements in public health and model housing. Peabody chose to focus on industrious artisans who were a couple of rungs up the ladder. Tenants had to be in work and able to pay rent, which in turn was used to build yet more flats.

The first dwellings, opened in Spitalfields in 1864, were pretty basic. A family would be allocated two or three rooms, one with a range for cooking. Bathrooms, laundry and drying rooms were provided communally on the top floor of the building, and the flat roof above this was used for drying clothes in summer and as a playground - a necessity as most Peabody properties were located in crowded inner boroughs.

Expansion was always steady, with the income from the endowment and from rents gradually making Peabody one of the biggest housing charities in Britain. The schemes were always worthy rather than innovative. For instance, Peabody had been active for 50 years before it got round to erecting self-contained flats, in 1912-14. And the big rebuilding programme necessary after bomb damage in the last war followed traditional lines; no imaginative housing schemes were tried in the late 1940s and 50s.

In that same period, the rise of the welfare state overshadowed the work of the trust. The present director of development, Dickon Robinson, says that this downturn in the trust's standing was because "people were saying, 'I believe in rights, not charity'. The trust was unfashionable and out of steam."

And so it remained till a new directorate took over - Robinson was part of it - and realised that the 1998 housing act allowed charities to raise private finance to expand. The trust started to regenerate itself and decided its aims - to fight poverty - needed to be updated. Staff became involved with projects to aid rough sleepers in the 1980s. It was realised also that the recession had robbed many tenants of their jobs, so training for employment was taken on.

Economic changes in London in the 1990s created a new set of potential tenants: young, low-paid professionals - the update of George Peabody's original artisans. Nurses and junior doctors from St Bartholomew's and the Royal London hospitals are among the first to be helped. In partnership with the hospitals, Peabody's came up with a scheme in Stratford, east London, to provide 96 units, most for NHS staff.

Less visible than those who keep the capital's services pulsing along, but vital to its economy, are the one-person start-up businesses in craft, design and new media. For them, affordable space to live and work in has been conjured up at Westferry on the Isle of Dogs. All 27 units are ready, but are being let in batches, so there are neighbours with know-how to help the newer arrivals, and gradually build a community.

Just the right spot for Robin Greene, a Royal College of Art graduate who's about to launch his own fashion label. Greene reckons it would be hard to beat the package he's been offered: around 700 sq ft of space for £800 a month. That's about what he would pay for renting separate work and living quarters, he reckons.

In addition, the East London Small Business Centre (in partnership with Peabody) has approved the business plan he was required to submit, and will offer expert advice over the three years of his tenancy.

With so many different projects targeted at employed groups, or different ways of renting or sharing ownership, Peabody is rolling in debt: its managers and directors are actually delighted that it owes £300m, because it's a sign of vitality. "George Peabody wouldn't have wanted us to sit on our assets," says Robinson.

The trust generates an annual income of £57m, owns property worth £1.8bn, and its commercial portfolio is worth £13m, with the income used to further its charitable work. As well as the homes it has built, the trust is taking over more estates from London boroughs, acquring 2,000 council dwellings last year.

The profile of Peabody people is changing. On the long-established estates, most tenants come via councils, but they're strictly vetted. Robinson says: "We try not to take local authority tenants who have a history of rent arrears."

How are Peabody and council estates different? "To go back 20 years, there was a very strong thrift ethic on our estates," says Robinson. "Paying the rent would have been very important."

Fred Calcott, who has lived on the Palmer's estate in north London for 30 years with his wife, and brought up their children there, agrees. "There's something about Peabody that makes them different from council estates."

Partly, it's participation by tenants. "Tenants' liaison committees can talk directly to the Peabody governors, to the letting managers, the housing managers," he says.

The Peabody empire is not immune from the problems which dominate council housing departments; more vulnerable tenants are coming on to their books. Calcott estimates that 50% of those on the Palmer estate, which has 800 homes, are on housing benefit.

Calcott, who recently retired as a postman, realises that there are external pressures for change. A while ago, there was the suggestion that some of the homes might be offered for sale. "But with house prices rising, we don't want that," he says.

Tenants' views persuaded the trustees not to proceed. So, for the moment at least, it's still recognisably a Peabody place.

webTitle: Star's dome visit that never was

fields.headline: Star's dome visit that never was
fields.standfirst: Special report: The Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: As urban myths go, this was one that had everything ... a world famous actress being turned away from a struggling tourist attraction because no one recognised her.
fields.body:
As urban myths go, this was one that had everything ... a world famous actress being turned away from a struggling tourist attraction because no one recognised her.

In a week during which the Millennium Dome lost its chairman and admitted there was no chance of meeting its 12m visitors target, it faced further humiliation yesterday.

The troubled project announced it had been forced to turn away Michelle Pfeiffer during February when it was sold out for 11 days in succession.

A dome official was so aghast at missing a golden chance to attract a member of the glitterati that he offered a grovelling apology to the actress and the promise of free admission for her and her two children when she next attempted a visit.

But now the dome has been forced to apologise again after Ms Pfeiffer's agent insisted the actress had not gone anywhere near the dome.

The dome company had over-reacted when it seized upon a report on Heart FM radio's celebrity gossip show which told of Ms Pfeiffer's disappointment at being refused entry when she and her children turned up as ordinary members of the public.

The company then spent a frantic day trying to make up for the slight and invited her to visit the attraction to add a touch of glamour.

But by close of business last night, the New Millennium Experience Company was forced into a hasty retreat after a publicist for the 43-year-old actress flatly denied that she or her children, Claudia Rose and John Henry, had been anywhere near the building.

Ms Pfeiffer was in London to promote the film The Story of Us, but, according to her spokesman, spent less than 24 hours in the city, was not accompanied by her children, and had certainly not been in the vicinity of the dome.

Last night Heart FM, having confessed to being the source of the gossip, apologised for any inconvenience.

fields.headline: OECD attacks hi-tech hype
fields.standfirst:
Think-tank finds little evidence for computer-driven global economic revolution
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The so-called New Economy is largely a myth outside the United States, according to the world's top economic think-tank.
fields.body:
The so-called New Economy is largely a myth outside the United States, according to the world's top economic think-tank.

The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development sounded its note of caution about the hype surrounding the New Economy by arguing that there is no hard evidence for its existence outside the US.

While keeping an open mind about the potential impact of new technology in the rest of the world, the OECD said other countries could not expect to copy the US's success simply by buying more computers.

In its twice-yearly Economic Outlook, the OECD said information and communication technology had played an important part in boosting labour productivity growth in the US, especially during the mid-1990s.

This was due to an increase in productivity growth in the ICT-producing sector and other parts of the economy were buying more computers at ever-lower prices.

However, the Paris-based organisation said there was little direct evidence that firms in the economy as a whole were using computer technology to full effect, although there were signs that businesses were reorganising production and distribution.

Turning to the impact of new technology on the performance of other industrialised countries, the OECD said: "Evidence that greater use of information and communication technology has raised productivity growth rates outside the United States significantly is limited."

In the Nordic countries, where ICT use was comparable or even greater than in the United States, and more intensive than in most other countries, there was some some evidence that labour productivity growth was increasing.

But this evidence could be interpreted in two ways. It might be related to the use of new technology but it could also have been influenced by the turbulent macroeconomic environment in the early 1990s, when deep recessions forced producers to take drastic measures to increase efficiency in order to survive.

The OECD said that, to reap the potential benefits of new technology, governments needed to invest in education, encourage entrepreneurship and competition.

"Fostering such policies should ensure that the opportunities offered by new technologies are not missed or unnecessarily delayed, and should allow the current period of stronger growth to be sustained."

In the meantime, the OECD said, there was a danger that New Economy fever in financial markets could derail the outlook for global economic growth, risking a repeat of the boom/bust cycles of the 1970s and 80s.

The OECD said overall global growth, which reached 3.1% last year, would be 4.3% in 2000 and 3.8% in 2001, with the US, the world's biggest economy, slowing to 3% in 2001 from 4.9% this year.

Prospects for growth and employment in the euro zone were the brightest for 10 years, with GDP expected to expand by 3.5% this year and 3.3% in 2001, after 2.3% in 1999.

"The world economy continues to rebound strongly from the 1997-98 slowdown associated with the crises in the emerging market economies and is developing more favourably than it had for more than a decade," it said.

This was due to an increase in productivity growth in the ICT-producing sector and other parts of the economy were buying more computers at ever-lower prices. However, the Paris-based organisation said there was little direct evidence that firms in the economy as a whole were using computer technology to full effect, although there were signs that businesses were reorganising production and distribution. Turning to the impact of new technology on the performance of other industrialised countries, the OECD said: "Evidence that greater use of information and communication technology has raised productivity growth rates outside the United States significantly is limited." In the Nordic countries, where ICT use was comparable or even greater than in the United States, and more intensive than in most other countries, there was some some evidence that labour productivity growth was increasing. But this evidence could be interpreted in two ways. It might be related to the use of new technology but it could also have been influenced by the turbulent macroeconomic environment in the early 1990s, when deep recessions forced producers to take drastic measures to increase efficiency in order to survive. The OECD said that, to reap the potential benefits of new technology, governments needed to invest in education, encourage entrepreneurship and competition. "Fostering such policies should ensure that the opportunities offered by new technologies are not missed or unnecessarily delayed, and should allow the current period of stronger growth to be sustained." In the meantime, the OECD said, there was a danger that New Economy fever in financial markets could derail the outlook for global economic growth, risking a repeat of the boom/bust cycles of the 1970s and 80s. The OECD said overall global growth, which reached 3.1% last year, would be 4.3% in 2000 and 3.8% in 2001, with the US, the world's biggest economy, slowing to 3% in 2001 from 4.9% this year. Prospects for growth and employment in the euro zone were the brightest for 10 years, with GDP expected to expand by 3.5% this year and 3.3% in 2001, after 2.3% in 1999. "The world economy continues to rebound strongly from the 1997-98 slowdown associated with the crises in the emerging market economies and is developing more favourably than it had for more than a decade," it said.

webTitle: DNA clue to riddle of the real Jesse James

fields.headline: DNA clue to riddle of the real Jesse James
fields.trailText: The remains of a man some believe was the Wild West outlaw Jesse James were exhumed yesterday for genetic testing to settle claims that the robber died in Texas 69 years later than history books say.
fields.body:
The remains of a man some believe was the Wild West outlaw Jesse James were exhumed yesterday for genetic testing to settle claims that the robber died in Texas 69 years later than history books say.

The widely accepted view is that James was shot and killed by a member of his own gang on April 3, 1882, in St Joseph in his home state of Missouri. A gravemarker there bears his name.

But many people in Granbury, Texas, a small town 45 miles southwest of Fort Worth, believe James faked his death in Missouri and lived in Texas until 1951 - when he would have been 103 years old.

"After he died, several local residents did a visual post-mortem on his body and they found several old bullet holes as well as a rope burn on his neck," said Mary Salterille of the Granbury Convention and Visitors Bureau. "So a lot of the long-time residents here fervently believe he was the real Jesse James," she said.

The exhumation was sought by Jesse James researcher Bud Hardcastle and three reputed grandsons of the outlaw.

DNA samples from the bones of the Granbury remains will be compared with those of the James descendants to determine if the body is that of James. The results of a similar DNA probe in 1995 determined that James's body lies in the Missouri grave.

Dirt was removed from a burial plot whose headstone reads "Jesse Woodson James" and a death date of August 15, 1951. Below it says: "Supposedly killed in 1882."

James learned his fighting skills as a guerrilla raider for the Confederate side in the US civil war. After the Union won in 1865, James and his brother Frank launched their outlaw career by banding together with eight other men to rob a bank in Liberty, Missouri.

A botched Minnesota bank robbery in 1876 destroyed the gang, ending with all of the members but Jesse and Frank dead or captured. The brothers kept on robbing with new partners and in 1882 one of them was said to have shot Jesse James in the hope of collecting a reward.

webTitle: The RUC are not so bad

fields.headline: The RUC are not so bad
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Over the past few days, as the battle over the RUC's name hots up, politicians, experts and writers have come forward to give their view of the RUC. The image portrayed in many quarters is of a brutal, one-sided police force, reluctantly being pushed towards reform, clinging desperately to its name, culture and insignia and embittered that the sacrifices it had made seemed to be forgotten. This is not what I saw.
fields.body:
Over the past few days, as the battle over the RUC's name hots up, politicians, experts and writers have come forward to give their view of the RUC. The image portrayed in many quarters is of a brutal, one-sided police force, reluctantly being pushed towards reform, clinging desperately to its name, culture and insignia and embittered that the sacrifices it had made seemed to be forgotten. This is not what I saw.

I recently spent eight months with the RUC, making a series on the force for Channel 4. I am English, not naturally sympathetic towards the police and have been on holiday to Northern Ireland only once before. What I knew about the RUC was from newspapers and television programmes.

Now I have spent interminable hours sitting with officers in patrol cars waiting for something to happen, talking to them over a fry-up in the canteen, riding with their car crime squads as they pursue joyriders in the early hours of the morning, watching them police band parades that seemingly never end, drinking with them in the pub talking about the day's news and visiting them and their families at home.

The police in general, and the RUC even more so, have a reputation for conservatism. Yet the overwhelming impression I gained from my time with them, during which I was given unprecedented and virtually unfettered access to high-ranking as well as ordinary officers, was of a group of people desperate for change - change for Northern Ireland and change to the way they went about their policing.

They are tired of having to police from armoured Land-Rovers and tired of working in police stations surrounded by barbed wire and bomb-proof barriers. They want to be able to get out of their patrol cars without being stoned, attacked or abused. They want to feel part of the communities they serve.

Statistically, the RUC is an overwhelmingly one-sided force. Only some 8% of RUC officers are from a Catholic background. But this is not the whole story. Years of policing from behind armoured glass has taken its toll. Time and again RUC officers from both traditions spoke of themselves as a third community, abused and unwanted by Protestants and Catholics. The graffiti, "SS RUC" and "RUC OUT", is sprawled over the walls both the nationalist Ardoyne and the loyalist Shankill Road. For security reasons many RUC families live grouped together in suburban housing estates in areas where they feel safe, they go out drinking in carefully chosen pubs, keep their jobs secret from acquaintances, friends, even family. They even have to be careful not to give their job away by hanging their uniform shirts on the washing line. No RUC officer I spoke to wanted to carry on like this for another 20 or 30 years.

Of course, the RUC is not completely blameless for the situation in which it finds itself. Parts of the nationalist community have long argued that they reject the RUC because it is identified with and has colluded, often violently and murderously, with the loyalist community against them. What I saw were occasional examples of petty, but nevertheless deep-rooted and pernicious intolerance and acts of heavy handedness towards both communities. But I also saw almost saintly RUC behaviour in the face of thuggish provocation by both nationalists and loyalists. More importantly, I saw signs that the RUC both as an institution and on an individual level, was beginning to question its own actions and motives, fret over and analyse its prejudices, clamp down on its intolerance and heavy handed acts, prepare and initiate reform and change.

Both Nationalist and Unionist politicians are making a great deal of fuss over the proposed changes to the RUC's name and insignia. While there was a great deal of public anger among the force, in private most officers I spoke to, especially the younger ones, treated the name change as a minor inconvenience that was worth putting up with if it helped bring the police closer to the community. Other recommendations made in the Patten report, like more emphasis on community policing, the wider use of computers and closer ties with Northern Ireland's academic institutions to improve training were met with genuine enthusiasm.

The crucial question is not whether the RUC wants or is ready for change. The hold-up lies elsewhere. The current crises over flying the union flag and decommissioning confirm that politicians from both traditions are still reluctant to change. And unless they and the rest of society are prepared to move on, any reforms to the police will be worthless.

 The author was producer of The Force, shown on Channel 4 in April.

webTitle: Goodwood revisited Rolls revives glorious days

fields.headline: Goodwood revisited Rolls revives glorious days
fields.trailText: BMW yesterday deliberately eschewed the troubled heartlands of the British car industry and opted to build a new plant for the production of Rolls-Royce cars in the English countryside at Goodwood in west Sussex.
fields.body:
BMW yesterday deliberately eschewed the troubled heartlands of the British car industry and opted to build a new plant for the production of Rolls-Royce cars in the English countryside at Goodwood in west Sussex.

The German car group, which takes over the Rolls marque in 2003, is to invest around £60m in the hi-tech plant which will produce 1,000 cars a year and em ploy 350 staff. BMW said the plant would be located near the old Goodwood motor racing track, close to the racecourse shown above with a bevy of Rolls-Royces gracing the car park during the 1960s.The Earl of March (right), who helped broker the choice of location, holds an annual festival of speed at the old motor racing track site. It is also less than 10 miles from West Wittering, where Sir Henry Royce, one of the co-founders of the luxury brand, lived and worked.

Most of the staff will be drawn from the surrounding area which, BMW said, is rich in specialist craft skills used in the yacht and motor industries.

Still smarting from the accusations of betrayal when it abandoned its effort to rebuild Rover, BMW said the Goodwood area offered a combination of the heritage of racing and motorsport and was "quintessentially English". Karl-Heinz Kalbfell, the managing director of the project, said the region was the most suitable location, close to Heathrow and Gatwick airports as well as to London. It was chosen in preference to Cowley, Oxford, where BMW will build the new Mini; Crewe, the traditional Rolls-Royce home; and west London. The new company aimed to retain the marque in its originalstyle.

webTitle: Orange's buyer adds a bitter twist

fields.headline: Orange's buyer adds a bitter twist
fields.standfirst:
France Telecom concludes deal by vowing to push Vodafone out of Europe's top spot

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: France Telecom bit the hand it had just shaken yesterday. After confirming its £27bn purchase of Orange from Vodafone AirTouch it vowed to knock the British vendor from its dominant position in Europe.
fields.body:
France Telecom bit the hand it had just shaken yesterday. After confirming its £27bn purchase of Orange from Vodafone AirTouch it vowed to knock the British vendor from its dominant position in Europe.

The acquisition of Orange has elevated France Telecom to become Europe's second biggest mobile phone operator with 21.1m subscribers, still behind Vodafone's 38m.

Only hours after leaving the negotiating table with Vodafone, Michel Bon, chief executive of France Telecom, said that he "was not joking" about his ambitions and warned of the competitive assault he planned in Europe's mobile phone market.

Vodafone was forced to sell Orange by the European commission after gaining it through default when it bought the German company Mannesmann.

France Telecom plans to wrap its leading domestic brand, Itineris, and its other wirefree business under the Orange banner, which would be spun off into a separate operation by March 2001.

Orange management under the direction of Hans Snook as chief executive will run that business. Mr Bon will become chairman.

France Telecom intends to float 10-15% of the "New Orange", which would raise about £9bn and value the total business at a minimum of £90bn.

"We want to be the biggest competitor globally to Vodafone that they could imagine," Mr Snook said, throwing down the gauntlet to his former parent. "Through France Telecom we will become one of the biggest European quoted companies. It will grow to be a major global business."

Chris Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, welcomed the battle. "We've always been ready for the challenge of competition. Unlike France Telecom, we never had a licence as a birthright and we have won licences all over Europe and beat PPTs [state monopolies]."

Mr Gent called for a level playing field in all European markets and claimed there was "not fair competition in France".

France Telecom beat off MCI WorldCom and KPN in the contest to win Orange and gain a foothold in Europe's second-biggest mobile market, Britain.

KPN said it was happy to have lost out, claiming the price tag for Orange was too high compared with other companies in the sector.

The cost of buying Orange jumps to £31bn for France Telecom when the payment due to the British government for a third-generation UK mobile phone licence is included.

France Telecom chief financial officer Jean-Louis Vinciguerra gave some support to KPN's argument. "I wouldn't tell you that it is very cheap. [But] we think this price is reasonable."

The hefty price may prove to be well worthwhile with third-generation phone licences now seen as the prize throughout Europe.

Vodafone has predicted its annual revenue per user will jump 25% by 2004 because of the increase in data services such phones will drive as they transform handsets into mini-computers with high-speed internet connection and video services.

Orange is planning to bid for third-generation phone licences in Germany, France and Italy, as well as other countries in Europe when they become available.

Analysts speculated that France Telecom had been chosen as the winner because it was prepared to offer Vodafone the largest cash deal.

France Telecom will pay for half of the acquisition in cash, stumping up £13.8bn. The remainder will be paid in new France Telecom shares worth £11.3bn and the assumption by of £1.8bn of Orange's debt.

The French government's shareholding in France Telecom will be cut from 61% to 54% as a consequence of the share issue.

France Telecom has an option in place to buy back almost 10% of its own shares from Vodafone over a two-year period.

The funds France Telecom raises from its partial flotation of Orange will be used to finance the buyback of those shares.

While Vodafone holds the shares in France Telecom, it will not have any voting rights or board representation.

France Telecom has put bank facilities in place to finance the cash element of its offer and also has planned non-core asset sales which will raise £12.5bn.

The deal is expected to deliver pre-tax cash flow synergies of more than £500m annually by 2003 and revenues are expected to be boosted by £281m.

Mr Snook said the priority will be to create a seamless network for the two mobile businesses across Europe but then it will turn its sights towards North America.

"Obviously our initial focus is going to be on Europe, on integrating and consolidating what we've got. But to be a global operator we have to operate in at least North America as well."

Another area for strategic expansion may be with cable television operator NTL, which is 25% owned by France Telecom.

"We're both hopeful that something very positive will come out of this," Mr Bon said.

Barclay Knapp, NTL's chief executive, has an extensive background in mobile telephony. However, some analysts speculated that France Telecom might find that the forceful characters of Mr Knapp and Mr Snook hard to control.

The Orange acquisition has still to be given the green light by European regulators, although France Telecom is confident of completion by August.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: In the topsy-turvy world of telecoms and technology, a drag on the market in recent times, these same stocks led the charge upwards and onwards yesterday.
fields.body:
In the topsy-turvy world of telecoms and technology, a drag on the market in recent times, these same stocks led the charge upwards and onwards yesterday.

The FTSE 100 index closed 142.7 points higher at 6,359.6, while the Techmark gained 135.2 points at 3,143.34, with Vodafone AirTouch and Freeserve leading the way.

Confirmation that France Telecom is to take Orange off the hands of Vodafone Airtouch for £27bn gave the shares a leg up 20.75p to 302p and boosted the telecom sector as a whole. BT firmed 72p to 969p, Energis rose 225p to £26.00, Kingston Communications added 43p to 600p and Telewest Communications gained 14p to 260p.

Speculation that Freeserve will be the subject of a bid from Germany's T-Online drove technology issues higher: Freeserve rose 101.5p to 493.5p and boosted parent and majority shareholder Dixons 95p to 487p.

Psion rose 39p to 558p, with Sema Group up 90p at 910p and Sage Group 61p higher at 646p. ARM Holdings rose 25p to 570p.

Internet firms QXL.com , up 12p at 115p, and 365 Corp , 12p up to 91.5p, were in demand ahead of full-year results from both today.

Pace was up 105p to 875p after the group said it expects pre-tax profits for the year to June 3 to exceed market expectations due to the faster-than-expected roll-out of digital.

But, as if to prove the contrary nature of the stock exchange's relationship with the technology sector, profit-taking saw Logica in the top slot on the FTSE 100 fallers list, down 56p to £16.26.

Traditional media stocks were boosted by crowd-pleasing numbers from Emap , which rose 46p to £11.45. Emap revealed plans to roll out its men's mag FHM to markets as far-flung as Germany, Brazil and Taiwan.

Pearson , up 93p to £20.20, Reuters , 52p higher at 980p, and BSkyB up 34p to £12.42, got in on the act.

In the new age of the old world, the future is looking slightly rosier for the flotation of Prudential's internet offshoot, Egg. Spread-betting company IG Index believe Egg shares will fetch 178p-183p on their opening day, planned for the week beginning June 12. Goldman Sachs has suggested the offer range will be 130p-175p.

Life was not so rosy for the "old" economy. Boots was down 17.25p to 561p. Speculation that Unilever 's bid for Bestfoods could be raised to more than £70 a share hit the stock, down 7.25p to 461p.

Thistle Hotels was lifted by reports that Whitbread has tabled a 170p per share bid. Thistle closed 8p up at 129p.

fields.headline: Licence cost 'will not affect performance'
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Vodafone AirTouch chief executive Chris Gent yesterday said his group expected a "very acceptable" rate of return from its investment in a third-generation mobile network in Britain despite the high cost of the licence.
fields.body:
Vodafone AirTouch chief executive Chris Gent yesterday said his group expected a "very acceptable" rate of return from its investment in a third-generation mobile network in Britain despite the high cost of the licence.

He also promised a slowdown in the pace of corporate activity which has seen the group more than quadruple in size in the past year.

Vodafone has a string of disposals and flotations in the pipeline to help finance its ambitions to bid for third-generation mobile telephone licences and has not lost its appetite for growth.

During the past financial year Vodafone tied up its acquisition of AirTouch in the US, sold its stakeholding in E-Plus and, shortly after the year's end, concluded its alliance with Bell Atlantic to create Verizon Wireless and took over Mannesmann.

Since then it has sold parts of Mannesmann's engineering business, found a buyer for Orange and plans to sell 15% of France's Cegetel to Vivendi, and has deals pending in Germany and Italy.

The deals left Vodafone with 39.1m customers at the end of March - an increase of more than 50% - although that rises to 53m when Mannesmann's subscribers are included.

Pro forma results for the group - excluding Mannesmann but including AirTouch for the full year - showed turnover up 134% to £7.87bn while pre-tax profits rose by 37% to £2.47bn. In Britain it added 3.2m customers, taking the total to 8.8m and its market share to 32%.

fields.headline: Atlantic Telecom
fields.standfirst:
Atlantic TelecomIn July Atlantic will be opening in Frankfurt, thanks to First Telecom, and will spend a further £100m rolling out the services to small businesses in other major German cities.

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: In July Atlantic will be opening in Frankfurt, thanks to First Telecom, and will spend a further £100m rolling out the services to small businesses in other major German cities.
fields.body:
Shares in Atlantic Telecom continued their modest revival yesterday and may rise further next week when its deal with First Telecom is finalised.

Atlantic stock has been submerged since March, when investors lost faith in the media and telcoms sector.

The small but fast growing company saw its shares plunge from £12 to almost a third of that value. Last night they ended the day up 10p at 465p, moving in line with the rest of the sector.

Graham Duncan, Atlantic's executive chairman, hopes to allay sceptics' fears on June 7. He will explain how the First Telecom deal will enable it to become a leading provider of broadband data services in Germany, Europe's largest telecoms market.

Mr Duncan's entrepreneurial style has brought the Aberdeen-based company an army of supporters. But its rapid expansion makes the more cautious nervous.

The £520m takeover of First Telecom also entails increasing financial commitments and management issues which have led some analysts to recommend selling the stock.

Atlantic uses wireless technology to bypass BT's loop network and has access to Marconi's national network. Marconi holds a 27% stake in Atlantic but that will be reduced to 18.9% when the First Telecom deal goes through.

In July Atlantic will be opening in Frankfurt, thanks to First Telecom, and will spend a further £100m rolling out the services to small businesses in other major German cities.

There are also plans to open up competition against BT in the provision of asymmetric digital subscriber lines.

Jim Ross, analyst with ABN Amro, is one of the enthusiasts for Atlantic. He is impressed with Mr Duncan's drive and rates it a "buy".

Almost everyone agrees, the telecoms sell-off has been overdone with some investors linking the sector with internet start-ups. So it might take the inevitable rerating of the telecom sector for the bears to finally ride any wave in favour of Atlantic.

webTitle: Soya gene find fuels doubts on GM crops

fields.headline: Soya gene find fuels doubts on GM crops
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Monsanto, the international company that pioneered the use of genetically modified crops, has revealed that its most widely used GM product contains unexpected gene fragments, raising fresh doubts that the technology is properly understood.
fields.body:
Monsanto, the international company that pioneered the use of genetically modified crops, has revealed that its most widely used GM product contains unexpected gene fragments, raising fresh doubts that the technology is properly understood.

Two extra gene fragments have been found in modified soya beans that have been grown commercially in the US for four years and used as an important ingredient in processed foods sold in Britain for a similar period.

The company and the British government, which approved the soya's use in food and animal feed on behalf of the EU, yesterday insisted that the beans were no more risky to human health than conventional types. However, the revelation will cause further problems for ministers trying to prove they can manage and monitor the introduction of the technology.

Monsanto alerted the Department of the Environment to the results of new studies on its Roundup Ready soyabeans on May 19, two days after ministers revealed that thousands of acres of oilseed rape had been grown unwittingly from conventional seed contaminated by GM material. German research has suggested that a gene used to modify rape seed could leap the species barrier into the guts of bees.

Monsanto said the new studies used more advanced techniques to provide "updated molecular characterisation" of its beans which contain an inserted gene to ensure they are not destroyed by weedkiller. The tests found that two "inactive" pieces of genetic material were inserted at the same time as the whole gene. Dan Verakis, a spokesman for the company, said: "All this means is we are able to see genes in soya more clearly now. It is like putting a telescope in orbit allows astronomers to see stars better."

He insisted that the fragments were in the product when it passed safety assessments by US authorities in 1992 and in Britain in 1996.The company's letter to the government says that nearly 100m acres of such beans have been cultivated round the world since 1996 "without adverse impacts on the environment or human health. They have also been widely consumed in Europe in foods and animal feedstuffs without adverse effects." No GM soya is grown in Britain.

The Department of the Environment said its own preliminary study "suggests that the risk from these beans when used in food or animal feed is no different from conventional soya beans". The in formation was considered by one advisory committee, on releases of GM material into the environment, last Thursday. The government has promised to publish its final verdict which will be passed on to the European commission.

Andy Tait, GM campaigner for Greenpeace UK, said: "This shows exactly what we have been saying for years, that genetic modification is inherently unpredictable and will have all sorts of knock-on effects once released into the environment." Soya is used in a wide range of foods. About half the US harvest is now thought to be GM.

webTitle: Sierra Leone left in limbo with military help in short supply

fields.headline: Sierra Leone left in limbo with military help in short supply
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive guide
fields.trailText: President Ahmed Tejan Kabbah's ministers gathered yesterday at the presidential lodge, on a breezy ridge high above the muddy heat of Freetown, to greet the head of state on his return from a meeting of regional heads in Nigeria. The mood at the cabinet meeting was termed optimistic, but the truth is that Sierra Leone got less than it wanted in Nigeria and ministers know that the country's security remains extremely fragile.
fields.body:
President Ahmed Tejan Kabbah's ministers gathered yesterday at the presidential lodge, on a breezy ridge high above the muddy heat of Freetown, to greet the head of state on his return from a meeting of regional heads in Nigeria. The mood at the cabinet meeting was termed optimistic, but the truth is that Sierra Leone got less than it wanted in Nigeria and ministers know that the country's security remains extremely fragile.

The government remains suspended between a policy of aiming to inflict a decisive military defeat on the Revolutionary United front (RUF) and one of restoring peace with the rebels still in possession of territory and other assets.

At one stage it was hoped that there could be a revival of the old regional intervention force, dominated by Nigerians, ready to wage war on the RUF. Instead, the new west African troops for Sierra Leone decided on at the meeting are to be deployed as part of the UN force in the country, seen as prevented by its mandate from taking tough enough action.

Failing a revival of the monitoring group, the government had wanted a Nigerian to replace the present UN force commander, an Indian general, but it also failed in that objective. As a result, Mr Kabbah does not yet have a clear assurance of strong military backing for the offensive against the RUF either from Nigeria and other west African states, or from the British who are still sticking to their timetable for a withdrawal within the next few weeks.

The obvious fear is that then the government offensive could falter and the RUF push back into positions from which it has been dislodged.

The contrasting hope, as the minister for presidential affairs, Momodu Karoma, puts it, is that the RUF "will be forced to see sense... I think we can combine the two tracks of military pressure and reinstating the Lome peace agreement".

The meeting in Nigeria of the members of the Economic Community of West African States set up a committee of six countries to pursue a peaceful settlement. However, the unspoken worry of the Sierra Leone government is that a settlement might be sought before the RUF are beaten, leading to a repetition of the situation which led to last month's crisis, when rebels abducted hundreds of UN peacekeepers.

That is also why Sierra Leone is resisting the idea of ejecting the captive RUF leader Foday Sankoh from the country, lest he be revived as an actor once abroad. The pressure for an early settlement could come from certain west African states or from the UN, unconvinced that a decisive victory against the RUF is possible and concerned that UN forces might be left in a dangerous situation after a failed offensive.

The contradictions are certainly considerable. One is that, as the offensive moves on, it casts the UN forces more and more in the role of garrison troops, a role for which they are not clearly mandated or fully prepared. Another is that it will sooner or later run into the interests of President Charles Taylor of Liberia, whose unofficial writ runs into the very diamond areas which are the final objective of the government forces.

The problem of combining neutral UN forces with units, like the Nigerians, ready to be far more combative, could be solved by assigning the west Africans a sector of their own, with an effectively autonomous commander, in an area where fighting is expected.

The Sierra Leone military took a confident line yesterday in recording their first advances into RUF core territory, which have brought them the town of Lunsar on the way to Makeni, the key to a further advance into the diamond country.

Colonel AC Nelson-Williams, the director of operations, told reporters that the army wanted "to liberate the whole country. We have the capacity and we have the backing". But the problem for Sierra Leone government is that neither the capacity nor the backing is guaranteed.

South Africa yesterday declared the wife of Foday Sankoh persona non grata and asked her to leave the country within 24 hours.

The foreign ministry spokesman, Ronnie Mamoepa, said Fatou Mbaye Sankoh, who entered South Africa on a US passport, had done so despite his department's warning that her presence would not be permitted.

"She has...engaged in activities intended to promote the aims and objectives of her husband's movement," said Mr Mamoepa, adding that she issued statements in support of the RUF. She was asked to leave within 24 hours.

webTitle: Irving turns to US fans to fund his legal costs

fields.headline: Irving turns to US fans to fund his legal costs
fields.standfirst: The David Irving libel trial: special report
fields.trailText: The rightwing historian David Irving, who owes more than £1m in legal costs from his failed Holocaust libel case in London earlier this year, has arrived in California to start a three-month fundraising tour of the United States.
fields.body:
The rightwing historian David Irving, who owes more than £1m in legal costs from his failed Holocaust libel case in London earlier this year, has arrived in California to start a three-month fundraising tour of the United States.

At the weekend he met at a secret location in Orange county a group dedicated to proving that there was no mass extermination of Jews during the second world war.

The meeting of the Institute for Historical Review was attended by 140 people, including the former Republican congressman Pete McCloskey and a number of rightwing academics and supporters, and watched by 2,500 others around the world via the internet.

The head of the organisation, Mark Weber, told the Los Angeles Times: "Of the 16 or 17 speakers here this weekend, six have been punished as 'thought criminals' with imprisonment, court order fines or travel bans for publicly expressing dissident views on history.

"We are often asked why we seem obsessed with the Holocuast. The answer is very simple ... Our own political, social and intellectual leaders have made the fate of Europe's Jews during world war two a central icon to our age.

"No comparable attention is given to the tens of millions of other world war two victims, including the many millions of Chinese who perished."

Mr Weber said that because of the "Holocaust cult", it was often forgotten that millions of Russians had died, as had 12m to 14m Germans. He said that American history was told from a Jewish perspective.

Mr Irving said that he was appealing against his defeat in the libel action he brought against Professor Deborah Lipstadt, who had accused him of anti-semitism.

In his decision, Judge Charles Gray said that Prof Lipstadt had been justified in her attack on Mr Irving, and his chances in an appeal are thought to be slim.

Local Jewish groups expressed dismay at Mr Irving's presence, although one described him as "a freak at a sideshow" and said that he had been so discredited in the libel case that his views now carried little weight.

They said that under the first amendemnt he was guaranteed the right to free speech in the United States, but he would be essentially "preaching to his own choir".

Mr Irving accused his opponents of spending around $6m in their attempts to defeat him in court.

"It's sad to say in the battle between David and Goliath, David doesn't always win. But I think I can say in this particular battle David is going to win and the victory is going to be sweet when it comes."

He portrayed himself as the underdog fighting against insurmountable odds.

There is a large network of wealthy rightwing sympathisers on a well-travelled circuit who will await Irving in the next three months.

He will be portrayed as a victim of political correctness and a free speech martyr.

There is also a large network of Jewish groups in California who are likely to be unhappy to discover that Mr Irving is promoting his views in their area.

There have been a number of anti-semitic attacks in California, not least that carried out last year by a member of a neo-fascist group, who opened fire in a Jewish community centre. A Filipino postal worker was killed and several children injured.

fields.headline: Independence arrives embarrassingly early
fields.standfirst: Tax and benefit balance is elusive
fields.trailText: How embarrassing for the right-wing pundits at the Centre for Policy Studies and the Adam Smith Institute. Their hardy perennial, independence - that is, tax freedom - day, the point in the year when we stop working for the Treasury and start working for ourselves - has fallen on May 30, a day earlier than last year.
fields.body:
How embarrassing for the right-wing pundits at the Centre for Policy Studies and the Adam Smith Institute. Their hardy perennial, independence - that is, tax freedom - day, the point in the year when we stop working for the Treasury and start working for ourselves - has fallen on May 30, a day earlier than last year.

Given all the recent huff and puff surrounding the allegedly rising tax take under Labour and Alastair Campbell's obstinacy in not admitting as much, we might have expected independence day to have raced off towards deep summertime rather than sticking at the Whitsun bank holiday.

Apparently it is due to 2000 being a leap year, but even so, by the two bodies' own reasoning this means that at the very least the tax burden - which the two think tanks calculate to be 41% of net national income - has not risen over the past 12 months.

Of course this is not good enough for advertising guru Maurice Saatchi and economist Peter Warburton from the Centre for Policy Studies.

They argue that the chancellor could reduce the tax burden to 33% at a stroke by integrating tax and benefits completely so that nobody earning less than £15,000 pays any taxes. They estimate that this would save some £5bn in the costs of administering the present complicated system.

But, while their plan is superficially attractive, a second's thought reveals why Mr Saatchi should stick to collecting works of art, not redesigning the welfare system.

As the chancellor discovered when he set about integrating tax and benefits more closely with the introduction of the Working Families Tax Credit, the two do not go well together.

This is for the simple reason that while taxes are based on individual circumstances, the benefit system is designed to keep families out of poverty. A straightforward amalgamation of the two systems would cut some people's tax bills at the expense of chopping other people's benefit payments.

The winners from the CPS scheme would be young, single low earners living with their families.

The losers would be families surviving entirely on benefit because rates would have to fall in order to pay for a tax cut for the low earners.

Oddly enough, an integrated tax and benefit system is also a long-term cause for some sections of the political left. But the proponents of negative income tax, the left's version of an integrated tax and benefits system, acknowledge that in order for the scheme to be viable the minimum level of benefit a non-working individual receives has to be sufficient to support a family.

This would require much higher taxes from the rest of the working population, which is why the idea has never received serious consideration.

As for the CPS proponents, they promise they will be carrying out a detailed simulation of how their plan would work.

We look forward to an explanation of how their sleight of hand would do anything towards alleviating poverty in Britain, which still has the worst track record in Europe, even after more than three years of a Labour government.

Wake-up call

Such has been the flood of bids and deals from Vodafone AirTouch over the past two years that shareholders could be forgiven for wondering whether they had bought into a deal-churning investment bank rather than a global telecoms player.

In an industry undergoing rapid consolidation through a multibillion-pound version of musical chairs, the company has yet to miss a cue.

The game, of course, is not at an end and as the music plays Vodafone has a string of disposals to see through. These mostly consist of tidying up after acquisitions and all will help bulk out a balance sheet that needs super strength for Europe's rolling programme of third-generation licence bids. They will inevitably absorb management time, too, although Vodafone has shown commendable speed in dealing with non-core assets.

So what of the future? The prospects look good. Vodafone has built a strong position. The number of people using mobile phones continues to grow rapidly. Technology means the range of services which can be offered will increase, too - probably at an exponential rate.

Such tempting pickings arouse the fiercest of competitive instincts, however. Just look at the 3G licence auction, or the rhetoric from France Telecom yesterday after confirmation of the Orange takeover. Maintaining margins, never mind increasing them, is going to be tough in the face of competition that will maintain pressure on prices.

What Vodafone must show now is that its strategic vision and corporate finance savvy are matched by a tactical ability to make the real returns its shareholders will expect.
fields.bodyText: How embarrassing for the right-wing pundits at the Centre for Policy Studies and the Adam Smith Institute. Their hardy perennial, independence - that is, tax freedom - day, the point in the year when we stop working for the Treasury and start working for ourselves - has fallen on May 30, a day earlier than last year. Given all the recent huff and puff surrounding the allegedly rising tax take under Labour and Alastair Campbell's obstinacy in not admitting as much, we might have expected independence day to have raced off towards deep summertime rather than sticking at the Whitsun bank holiday. Apparently it is due to 2000 being a leap year, but even so, by the two bodies' own reasoning this means that at the very least the tax burden - which the two think tanks calculate to be 41% of net national income - has not risen over the past 12 months. Of course this is not good enough for advertising guru Maurice Saatchi and economist Peter Warburton from the Centre for Policy Studies. They argue that the chancellor could reduce the tax burden to 33% at a stroke by integrating tax and benefits completely so that nobody earning less than £15,000 pays any taxes. They estimate that this would save some £5bn in the costs of administering the present complicated system. But, while their plan is superficially attractive, a second's thought reveals why Mr Saatchi should stick to collecting works of art, not redesigning the welfare system. As the chancellor discovered when he set about integrating tax and benefits more closely with the introduction of the Working Families Tax Credit, the two do not go well together. This is for the simple reason that while taxes are based on individual circumstances, the benefit system is designed to keep families out of poverty. A straightforward amalgamation of the two systems would cut some people's tax bills at the expense of chopping other people's benefit payments. The winners from the CPS scheme would be young, single low earners living with their families. The losers would be families surviving entirely on benefit because rates would have to fall in order to pay for a tax cut for the low earners. Oddly enough, an integrated tax and benefit system is also a long-term cause for some sections of the political left. But the proponents of negative income tax, the left's version of an integrated tax and benefits system, acknowledge that in order for the scheme to be viable the minimum level of benefit a non-working individual receives has to be sufficient to support a family. This would require much higher taxes from the rest of the working population, which is why the idea has never received serious consideration. As for the CPS proponents, they promise they will be carrying out a detailed simulation of how their plan would work. We look forward to an explanation of how their sleight of hand would do anything towards alleviating poverty in Britain, which still has the worst track record in Europe, even after more than three years of a Labour government. Wake-up call Such has been the flood of bids and deals from Vodafone AirTouch over the past two years that shareholders could be forgiven for wondering whether they had bought into a deal-churning investment bank rather than a global telecoms player. In an industry undergoing rapid consolidation through a multibillion-pound version of musical chairs, the company has yet to miss a cue. The game, of course, is not at an end and as the music plays Vodafone has a string of disposals to see through. These mostly consist of tidying up after acquisitions and all will help bulk out a balance sheet that needs super strength for Europe's rolling programme of third-generation licence bids. They will inevitably absorb management time, too, although Vodafone has shown commendable speed in dealing with non-core assets. So what of the future? The prospects look good. Vodafone has built a strong position. The number of people using mobile phones continues to grow rapidly. Technology means the range of services which can be offered will increase, too - probably at an exponential rate. Such tempting pickings arouse the fiercest of competitive instincts, however. Just look at the 3G licence auction, or the rhetoric from France Telecom yesterday after confirmation of the Orange takeover. Maintaining margins, never mind increasing them, is going to be tough in the face of competition that will maintain pressure on prices. What Vodafone must show now is that its strategic vision and corporate finance savvy are matched by a tactical ability to make the real returns its shareholders will expect.

fields.headline: Members only
fields.standfirst:
Labour's national policy forum hoped to smooth relations between party and government. But there has been little sign of improvement

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's national policy forum hoped to smooth relations between party and government. But there has been little sign of improvement
fields.body:
The relationship between party and government was recently likened by former Labour general secretary Tom Sawyer to a rocket and a space capsule. In opposition, the rocket, with the capsule at the top, thrusts upwards. Once elected, the rocket - the party at large - is jettisoned. Ministers in the capsule head off into space. The rocket crashes back to earth. Membership (see the chart) may well tumble with it.

Labour and its governments have a tradition of falling out. In an effort to prevent this happening again in the mid-90s, Mr Sawyer and then policy director Matthew Taylor devised a "national policy forum". Policy would be assembled following consensual discussion at a twice-yearly meeting of 170 party delegates. The meeting would be held in private. Votes would be kept to a minimum.

The old ways of the big annual conference - contradictory motions, grandstanding in front of the cameras and knife-edge votes - would be relegated to the history books. Ministers would take the policy forum seriously; the forum would give them early warning of drift away from the grassroots.

This new process is now reaching its most testing moment. Six documents are being published for the policy forum taking place in Exeter this summer. They have been drawn up by commissions chaired by ministers and elected members of the national executive (NEC). They represent two years of consultation within the party, including hundreds of local forums. They should, in theory, provide the route map for a second term.

But the documents offer little insight into new directions. Instead they glowingly render the Blair government's achievements to date. The document on economic policy reiterates the March 2000 budget. Rarely have so many platitudes been gathered together in one place. If this represents the combined insights of thousands of party members then Labour is either ridiculously loyal or suffering from an excess of the culture of contentment.

One member of the policy forum is Ann Black, elected to the NEC for the first time last week. She fears the process is a device to prevent legitimate differences reaching the floor of the annual conference. Some 35 of the 170 delegates have to support a motion at the forum for it to be included as a proposition on which a separate vote can be taken at the party conference.

Last autumn she pushed for changes to the document on welfare - for example linking the basic pension with earnings rather than prices. But following a deal between the unions and the platform (in which Alistair Darling, the social security secretary promised a review), the unions withdrew their support and Ms Black found herself with fewer than 10 votes at the forum. As a result her proposition was excluded and no delegate could then table a pensions motion at the party conference. There has been little discernible sign of the promised welfare review since.

Perhaps delegates found Ms Black's arguments did not merit support. But there is a danger that the drive for consensus turns the forum into a means of filtering out disagreement from conference debate. If something is heavily defeated after being voted upon behind closed doors at the policy forum, the autumn conference is powerless to put the issue to the vote.

Conference delegates can only put forward what are described as contemporary motions but these cannot touch upon any subject discussed in the big policy documents - severely circumscribing delegates' rights.

Meanwhile at the highest echelons something entirely different is happening. Ed Richards, a bright young Downing Street policy advisor appointed last year by Tony Blair, is drawing up a "second term programme". Judging by the void in the policy documents, this badly needs doing. It is said that Mr Richards is consulting within the party, as well as pressure groups, factions, business and unions. What he hopes to do first is to assemble a vision of what Britain should be like at the end of a Labour second term in say 2005. He then plans to work backwards to establish the policies necessary to fulfil this vision. Mr Richards, a former aide to chancellor Gordon Brown and a strategist for the BBC, is as bright as they come; but a formidable amount is resting on his shoulders.

He is working in tandem with Mr Brown's second comprehensive spending review, now being conducted by the Treasury. This will be the second source of ideas for the Labour manifesto. SR 2000, as Whitehall calls it, will whittle down the 600 or so targets set Whitehall departments and reduce them to a more manageable 200. Whether a Treasury-led process can produce an eye- catching clutch of new ideas will depend heavily on Gordon Brown himself and his ability to retain political control of such a vast process. The key may lie in the 14 cross-cutting spending reviews covering areas such as crime prevention, rural affairs or Sure Start - the programme designed to make children "school ready by the age of five".

The chancellor is a remarkable political strategist, constantly aware of the big political picture, but also abreast of the micro policy detail. Given the paucity of product coming from the policy forum, Mr Brown and Mr Richards have a lot to do. Despite everyone's best intentions it seems the old elite is still really running Labour's preparation for a second term.

 Patrick Wintour is the Guardian's chief political correspondent patrick.wintour@theguardian.com

webTitle: Lifeline for Baan as Invensysgoes Dutch

fields.headline: Lifeline for Baan as Invensysgoes Dutch
fields.trailText: Struggling Dutch business software group Baan's search for a strategic solution to its problems may soon be over.
fields.body:
Struggling Dutch business software group Baan's search for a strategic solution to its problems may soon be over. Invensys, the engineering group formed by the merger of BTR and Siebe last year, is tipped to announce a cash bid for the Dutch group in the near future.

The deal could even be announced today, according to Reuter news agency, citing industry sources. Speculation that a bid could be on the way for Baan has been gaining ground after news that the group was in talks with potential buyers. Invensys was seen as a possible buyer last week but declined to comment.

Baan has been struggling for almost two years amid continuing losses. Its share price has been hit hard - falling from more than €40 two years ago to a low recently of little more than €1.50.

Pierre Everaert, who took over as a stop-gap chief following the departure of Mary Coleman in January, has been in discussions with Lazard, the investment bank, about the group's strategic options.

These include an outright takeover, the recruitment of a strategic investor or the sale of part of the business.

Aurum, which helps busi ness manage customer relationships and which has customers including Delta A irlines and AT&T, has been seen as a possible candidate for sale but Baan's management is understood to prefer a takeover of the whole group.

Invensys, which has sold close to £2bn worth of businesses in 18 months, has also shown it is prepared to spend.

At the announcement of the group's interim results chief executive Allen Yurko noted: "Acquisitions of £350m underline Invensys' commitment to acquiring complementary software and technology business which enhance our leadership position in the automation and controls market."

webTitle: IPC magazines for sale as What's on TV price cut bites

fields.headline: IPC magazines for sale as What's on TV price cut bites
fields.trailText: Fierce competition in the television listings market has done little to improve the value of magazine publisher IPC, which has discreetly been put up for sale by venture capital owner Cinven.
fields.body:
Fierce competition in the television listings market has done little to improve the value of magazine publisher IPC, which has discreetly been put up for sale by venture capital owner Cinven.

The publishing house yesterday said half-year revenues had been dragged lower by a 15p reduction in the cover price to 35p of its best-selling What's On TV, bringing circulation revenues at the group £4.2m, or 3.1% lower.

For the six months to April, IPC reported a 0.8% increase in revenues to £176.6m and pre-tax profits of £2.4m, up from just £700,000 in the same period last year.

Plans for a stock market flotation of IPC, which also owns Woman's Own, Marie Claire and Loaded, appeared to have been abandoned earlier this month in favour of a trade sale of the business.

Cinven, which bought the business two and a half years ago, has approached a number of buyers including Telewest, although the cable company is now understood to have lost enthusiasm for the deal.

Cinven is understood to be seeking around £1.5bn - a figure seen by industry analysts as optimistic, given IPC's poor performance since the venture capital business paid £860m for it.

IPC chief executive Sly Bailey said the price cut in What's On TV had been necessary to see off TV Choice, which was launched by Germany group Bauer last August. The result, she added, was only a "marginal" dent in What's On TV's 1.75m circulation.

Ms Bailey said the media landscape had changed since the business had been ac quired by Cinven, causing the company to reassess the way forward. "Since the buy-out we have been approached by various joint venture partners or strategic alliances, whatever you would like to call them, and we continue to evaluate the best option - and that still includes flotation."

IPC, whose titles also include TV Times, said advertising revenues rose 7.6% in the six months to the end of March and first half pre-tax profit before exceptional items and goodwill amortisation still jumped to £2.4m ($3.61m) from £0.7m.

The group said that strong advertising revenues were set to power solid full-year profits growth for IPC.

"Advertisement sales have remained buoyant at the start of the second half and the group continues to expect operating income in the full year to exceed last year by over 20%," it added.

Operating income rose 36% - if 1999 reorganisation costs are included - to £29.6m in the first half of the year on revenues of £176.6m, while operating margins excluding reorganisation costs improved by one point to 16.7%.

webTitle: Newsplayer starts at a healthy clip

fields.headline: Newsplayer starts at a healthy clip
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Paul Duffen and his partner Barry Llewellyn yesterday pocketed £8.5m each (on paper anyway) as their Newsplayer internet start-up cruised to a successful launch.
fields.body:
Paul Duffen and his partner Barry Llewellyn yesterday pocketed £8.5m each (on paper anyway) as their Newsplayer internet start-up cruised to a successful launch.

They showed that internet companies can still be in big demand: shares in the company, which provides historic newsreel footage over the web, rose to a healthy premium on the Alternative Investment Market.

Several technology debuts have been postponed due to stock market turbulence. But Newsplayer proceeded at a "realistic" price of 84p and ended the day at 92.5p.

Chief executive Paul Duffen said he was happy to start at a level representing good value and one which gave investors "plenty of headroom" for the future.

He accepted the price might have been twice as high had the launch happened earlier, even though Newsplayer had tangible content and aimed to break even "early in the cycle".

Mr Duffen added: "Obviously we have had to accept that this is a hostile environment for raising money so we had to be realistic [about the pricing]. We are a real company with real products and a very low burn rate."

Newsplayer placed 16m of its 66m shares with the help of broker Investec Henderson Crosthwaite. The company is now capitalised at £60.1m with Mr Duffen and Mr Llewellyn each holding a 14% stake.

The company aimed to raise £10.15m of new money from the flotation but promises this will not be blown on immediate needs. Half will be used for a marketing campaign but the rest might be spent on acquisitions and alliances as well as helping the business tick over for the next three years.

Newsplayer has agreements with companies such as ITN, Reuters television archive and French Pathé news. This gives it video material from 1896 to the present day so users can access any of the 14,000 video clips on demand.

Adolf Hitler in full flow at a Nuremburg rally, the coronation of Queen Elizabeth 2, great sporting memories and an interview with Charlie Chaplin are among its highlights.

Newsplayer says the archive is valuable for education as well as entertainment.

Newsplayer is convinced it has a healthy future as consumers download its material on to their PCs. But the real benefits should come when there is widespread use of the internet via television screens.

The company says it has no real competitors and is to roll out the service in the US. With net portals such as AOL moving into television, convergence is just round the corner. Newsplayer should be well placed to benefit.
