webTitle: London hotel rooms to cost more

fields.headline: London hotel rooms to cost more
fields.trailText: London hotel room rates are set to increase by more than double the level of inflation with average prices up from £108 in 1999 to £119 by 2001, experts predicted yesterday.
fields.body:
Around 26.5m visitors are heading for the capital city this year - an increase of 4% - and this will help boost demand according to the latest hotel industry report from TRI Hospitality Consulting.

It says: "Occupancy levels have hit a peak over the last two years, and as a result, average room rates are increasing and look set to continue their climb."

But TRI believes improved trading conditions will only really help companies "catch-up" following the significant real room rate decreases that took place in the first five years of the 1990s.

Jonathan Langston, joint managing director of TRI, also predicted that the long-awaited consolidation in the corporate hotel sector would come to fruition over the next 12 to 18 months. Although Hilton merged with Stakis and Whitbread bought Swallow, there was much less merger and acquisition than expected. Leading companies would have to acquire to grow.

fields.headline: Aitken's secret $4m Swiss bank account
fields.standfirst: Aitken's secret $4m account
fields.trailText: Bankruptcy officials have received dramatic new evidence, which they are believed to be investigating, that Jonathan Aitken - the disgraced former cabinet minister who claims to be virtually penniless - had a secret Swiss bank account into which $4m was deposited by a Saudi prince.
fields.body:
Bankruptcy officials have received dramatic new evidence, which they are believed to be investigating, that Jonathan Aitken - the disgraced former cabinet minister who claims to be virtually penniless - had a secret Swiss bank account into which $4m was deposited by a Saudi prince.

Evidence of the existence of this account, at the Lausanne branch of Credit Suisse, has led to the postponement of an agreement that Aitken had hoped to make with his credi tors to escape from bankruptcy without paying much of the debt he owes from his failed libel action.

Since he declared himself bankrupt, Aitken's affairs have been under investigation by trustees in bankruptcy, accountants responsible to the Official Receiver.

It can be a criminal offence to conceal assets.

The fresh evidence about a Swiss account reached the accountancy firm Baker Tilly last week, when the main creditors - the Guardian, Granada TV and the Inland Revenue - were considering an offer from
Aitken of £1.7m towards legal costs and other liabilities totalling more than £3m.

This followed the reported earlier discovery that Aitken has also secretly moved more than £500,000, from the proceeds of selling a house, from Britain into a bank account in Monaco.

It is now understood that detailed evidence has been obtained, from financial sources involved in the Credit Suisse transaction, that the $4m was moved out of an account belonging to the king's son Prince Mohammed at the Bank Al Saudi Al Fransi in the
Saudi town of Al-Khobar, and into an Aitken-controlled Swiss account in April 1995, shortly after the cabinet minister embarked on his ill-fated libel action.

Last night, after denials from Aitken, the prince's business manager, Said Ayas, was asked by the Guardian about the transactions. He confirmed how they had taken place in a statement through his City solicitor, Adam Greaves of Rakisons: "Prince Mohammed _ paid $4m into a bank account with the Lausanne branch of Credit Suisse _ with the intention
that they be used to pay Jonathan Aitken's legal fees in fighting his libel action."

The true ownership of the account was hidden behind the name of Fides - a small firm of Lausanne accountants that Aitken regularly used for business transactions, and which had originally acted for his wife Lolicia, who had Swiss commercial interests in Lausanne, where she grew up.

Fides set up the separate account as nominees on the Aitkens' behalf specifically to receive the money. The code name chosen to identify the account was WAVIC 332771-
02-1. The letters represented the names of the Aitkens' three children, William, Alexandra and Victoria. The money would subsequently have been moved out again into other accounts. Such elaborate procedures would enable Aitken to deny that he or his wife had any accounts in their own names at Credit Suisse, or that they currently have an interest in accounts there.

The Guardian and Granada TV were targets of the costly libel action by Aitken after they exposed his financial links with Prince Mohammed, and the fact that he had lied
about a 1993 visit to the Ritz in Paris while he was a minister in the Conservative government. He had been meeting Prince Mohammed to offer him lucrative secret arms sales commissions.

Aitken later served a seven-month jail term for perjury after his libel suit collapsed.

webTitle: Pressure mounts on Berlin over child custody

fields.headline: Pressure mounts on Berlin over child custody
fields.trailText: President Clinton is to raise the issue of child custody during talks in Berlin this week with the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, following a series of high-profile abduction cases involving German nationals.
fields.body:
President Clinton is to raise the issue of child custody during talks in Berlin this week with the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, following a series of high-profile abduction cases involving German nationals.

Pressure has been mounting on Germany to allow foreign parents involved in "tug-of-love" cases with Germans to have the kind of access rights permitted in many other European countries and the US.

Mr Schröder plans to announce a series of reforms this week in an attempt to pre-empt a diplomatic rift with Washington over the issue, the Washington Post reported yesterday. The measures were agreed at a special meeting of the German cabinet last week.

The central issue is the consistent refusal of German courts to allow foreign parents to have normal access rights to visit or receive visits from their children if the German parent opposes such a move.

Lady Catherine Meyer, wife of the British ambassador to Washington, started campaigning on the issue after her two children from her first marriage to a German doctor were abducted by their father. Since the abduction in 1994 the German courts have allowed Lady Meyer - who has lobbied Hillary Clinton and Cherie Blair for support - to see her sons for only 24 hours.

A lobby of American parents involved in similar custody battles has forced Congress to take up the issue. The parents complain that Germany, far more than any other western democracy, imposes insurmountable barriers on foreign parents in such cases. Last week, Congress voted unanimously to take up the issue.

Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, returned from Washington earlier this month warning that the controversy threatened to damage US-German relations. Since then, Berlin has been trying to defuse the row without appearing to lay down the law on individual cases.

Mr Clinton arrives in Germany tomorrow following meetings with EU leaders in Lisbon.

webTitle: Ex-RAF man survives flak from wife over photo fake

fields.headline: Ex-RAF man survives flak from wife over photo fake
fields.trailText: Bill Easterbrook's surprise at finding himself pictured in a holiday brochure dancing cheek to cheek with a glamorous stranger was matched only by that of his wife.
fields.body:
Bill Easterbrook's surprise at finding himself pictured in a holiday brochure dancing cheek to cheek with a glamorous stranger was matched only by that of his wife.

The former RAF squadron leader, who is in his eighties, found himself facing tough questioning on the home front, despite his protestations that he had never met the woman.

He was finally let off the hook when it emerged that the holiday company had doctored the photograph, removing his wife, Joan, from the picture and inserting another woman.

The couple picked up the Leisurely Days brochure of First Choice to plan a holiday abroad this year. Inside, to their amazement, was a half-page photograph of Mr Eastwood apparently dancing with the mysterious woman at a hotel in Cyprus.

He was saved from his wife's wrath only when he spotted that a flower pinned in his lapel in the picture was on the wrong side of his jacket and his female partner was leading in the dance.

"I realised the picture was back-to-front," he said. "And the only time I've ever worn that jacket with a flower pinned to the lapel was on a cruise on the Canberra years ago. I've never even been to that hotel in Cyprus."

"My wife is fairly broadminded, which is just as well because it left her questioning my fidelity. It's not something you need at our age.

"When Joan saw the brochure she said: 'Oh my God, that's you. And who are you with? Who are you dancing with?'

"She didn't know who the woman was and asked a few pertinent questions. I told her I didn't know who she was either. Then I looked at the picture a bit more closely and realised there was something very wrong.

"I was holding the woman's left hand - which meant she was leading and I was taking the female role. The flower on my lapel was in the wrong side - I would never wear a flower on that side."

Mr Eastwood, from Weston-super-Mare, Somerset, wrote to the holiday company to complain.

"I object to being used in an advertising brochure without my permission being sought," he said. "It is advertising a Cypriot hotel, which isn't even a place we would go on holiday. My wife said, 'Ît's only a three star hotel'."

A spokeswoman for First Choice holidays, based in Crawley, West Sussex, apologised unreservedly and said production of the brochure had now been stopped.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 'Mussel power' to mend bones
fields.body:
'Mussel power' to mend bones

Scientist believe the sticky gum produced by shellfish to help them cling to rocks may help doctors glue broken human bones.

Researchers at York University have found that a protein made by mussels allows them to stick to rocks under water and is twice as powerful as man-made epoxy resin adhesives. If it can be replicated in a laboratory it would enable surgeons to do away with pins and use glue to mend bone fractures.

Porritt sets green example

Jonathon Porritt, former chairman of Friends of the Earth and an adviser to the Prince of Wales, did not turn up when he was asked to open a new National Trust study centre in Studland, Dorset.

Instead, to encourage people to reduce traffic, he sent by bicycle courier a 15 minute video of himself officially opening the centre from his Cheltenham home.

Harley Street 'headache'

Doctors in prestigious Harley Street have been angered by a decision by Westminster council to give part of the London road its original title, Brunswick Place.

The crown estate proposed the switch to enhance the street's residential nature. Doctors at one practice in Upper Harley Street "strongly objected". But a council consultation saw nine in favour of the change with eight against, while the London fire and civil defence authority objected because the name Brunswick was already used in the area.

Radiohead to go touring in tent

The rock band Radiohead are to take their own venue out on tour - to avoid dealing with corporate sponsors. The group are to play European and British gigs in a 10,000 capacity hi-tech Kayam tent.

Autumn dates have been confirmed for Holland, France and Belgium with others to be lined up in the UK and Ireland between September 1 and October 13.

Police issue murder sketch

West Midlands police yesterday issued a sketch of the face of an unidentified man whose body and severed head were found in parkland. Officers hoped a relative or friend would recognise the artist's impression of the murder victim and contact detectives.

Police said the victim was between 5ft 9ins and 5ft 11ins and slim, with short, closely cropped dark hair and sideburns.

The gruesome discovery was made by an elderly man walking his dog in Rednal, south Birmingham, early on Monday.

Detective Chief Inspector Dave Unwin said: "Extensive inquiries have been made but unfortunately we are still some way from finding out who he was."

The victim was wearing jeans and trainers, but was naked from the waist up when found. A postmortem failed to establish the cause of death.

Rare London map for auction

A wall map showing just about every house in London, the first drawn up after the great fire of 1666, is to be auctioned at Sotheby's on June 12.

The 14-sheet "Accurate Plan of the Cities of London and Westminster and the Borough of Southwark" extends from Islington in the north to Lambeth and from Hyde Park in the west to Limehouse, was published in 1682 and is expected to fetch up to £5,000.

webTitle: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes

fields.headline: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: "I'd forgotten what Cherry's voice sounded like," remarks Jeff the accountant, plying a fork in the hot and spicy special in the tribunal canteen.
fields.body:
"I'd forgotten what Cherry's voice sounded like," remarks Jeff the accountant, plying a fork in the hot and spicy special in the tribunal canteen.

Cherry was a typist who used to work for Jeff's firm. She stopped talking to Jeff (and everybody else) nine months before her dismissal.

Me: "Why?"

Jeff: "Uh, well, it was a protest about having to fill in timesheets."

Me: "And you didn't do anything about it?"

Jeff: "Well, she did fill in the timesheets. And it wasn't like she didn't communicate at all, I mean she wrote things on Post-it notes."

Things might have carried on like that indefinitely, but then Cherry erected some six-foot screens around her desk.

Me: "And the reason for that?"

Jeff points to a photocopy in the bundle of documents which reproduces a long snake of Post-its:

"I am placing these / screens here to avoid / RADIATION from other / people's VDUs which is / a serious threat to my / health and safety at work."

Jeff: "Uh, she stuck that on the outside of the screens."

Me (gently): "And life carried on?"

Jeff nods forlornly. We may win this case, but Jeff's managerial self-esteem is bleeding to death before my eyes.

So there was Cherry, barricaded behind her screens, increasingly covered in ageing Post-it notes, a silent fortress in an office of fewer than 20 people. The sense I get from Jeff and the others is that this would have carried on into eternity had things not taken a further turn for the weird.

Jeff shows me the little dolls. They look like something I made when I was a little girl with pipe cleaners, some scraps of cloth and some retired American tan tights. Only Cherry is a much better seamstress than I ever was and the cunningly embroidered little faces are clearly recognisable as Jeff and various other people in the firm. They are wearing expressions of torment.

Cherry hung the dollies on the outside of her screens by chains of paperclips - and finally got a written warning. Or did she? Cherry turns out in cross-examination to be one of life's literalists:

Me: "And then they issued you with a written warning?"

Cherry: "No."

Me: "Well, what's this at page 42 of the bundle? Are you saying you didn't receive that?"

Cherry: "It's typed."

So in the end it was Cherry's refusal to accept a typed warning and take down the dolls that led to her dismissal. Which the tribunal finds was fair. Not that the news seems to cheer Jeff et al much. They still wear the blank expressions you see in photographs of people rescued from cults.

webTitle: Why Labour revels in renewed class warfare

fields.headline: Why Labour revels in renewed class warfare
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The first that Tony Blair's spin doctors heard of Laura Spence's university plans was on May 22 when sharp-eyed members of the Cabinet Office's media monitoring unit spotted an "Oxford Snubs North Talent" headline splashed over the Newcastle Journal.
fields.body:
The first that Tony Blair's spin doctors heard of Laura Spence's university plans was on May 22 when sharp-eyed members of the Cabinet Office's media monitoring unit spotted an "Oxford Snubs North Talent" headline splashed over the Newcastle Journal.

By the time they circulated the newspaper cutting to the daily media strategy meeting, 8.30am in the press secretary's office at No 10, the man who chairs the meeting, Alastair Campbell, had already spotted the story in that day's Daily Mail.

From their very different perspectives on educational opportunity, both the Mail and New Labour saw its political potential. Both have long campaigned against "snooty" Oxbridge colleges whose admission panels carelessly reject talented kids from comprehensives.

But once Gordon Brown, the chancellor, had let rip in a speech last Thursday against the "scandal" of Laura's rejection, the government was accused of engaging in class warfare.

Class warfare is very old Labour, but it lurks just below New Labour's meritocratic surface, along with the hunch - yet to be proved - that heartland voters like it too. So there was clearly opportunism in Labour's attack.

Labour meritocrats in industry and the civil service were scandalised, as were leftwing Oxbridge dons who have fought for greater access but nurse unease that the grammar and direct grant schools which nursed their own talents were purged by Labour in the past.

Ministers were ready for the reaction and did not flinch. The campaign was quickly carried forward by Robin Cook (Edinburgh University) to John Prescott (11-plus failure, Hull University and Ruskin).

Brown has campaigned for greater educational opportunity since he was a precocious student radical at Edinburgh University. But he may have had a further motive for last week's attack. Labour MPs blame him for the backlash against the 75p pension rise, "our worst mistake so far, far worse than the Dome," one said yesterday.

So the chancellor, a formidable populist when he bothers to be, had no scruple about using Laura's case to contrast his vision of "opportunity for all" - jobs, welfare, health, education - with what Labour strategists see as the Tory leader William Hague's defence of privilege and the old school tie.

Blair, who sees himself as a Fettes/Oxford rebel, contemptuous of "Old Brit" snobberies and traditions, did not reprimand Brown over his speech, contrary to weekend reports.

Labour's interest in attacking what remains of Oxbridge social exclusivity pre-dates the Laura Spence case. David Blunkett gave the Association of University Teachers' conference the same message in calmer terms on May 10.

His remarks were addressed to the 10 top universities which take only 5% under-privileged students (the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology goes out and finds 30%).

Citing the much-admired missionary work of the Sutton trust, run by self-made millionaire Peter Lampl, Mr Blunkett said "a just and prosperous" society needed to do more to get "young people from the lower socio-economic groups into higher education". Currently 17% make it, compared with 45% from non-manual groups.

Mr Blunkett mentioned Oxbridge only in his final passage. "I welcome measures taken by leading universities, including Oxford and Cambridge ... but there is much more we can do together,"| he said.

The speech garnered virtually no publicity.

Mr Blunkett is said to feel Mr Brown could have been more diplomatic too, but it was the chancellor who got the issue up and running.

Mr Brown spends summer holidays in the US, often at Harvard which he has seen transform itself in the 25 years he has known it from "a finishing school for elites" into a genuinely open home for excellence from all classes. As an exponent of a skills economy he believes Britain needs all its talents.

Rightly or wrongly, Labour believes that it can benefit from signs that Hague is finally getting the Tory act together.

Tony Blair and Brown are united in believing that Margaret Thatcher benefited from good enemies - Arthur Scargill, General Galtieri of Argentina and Michael Foot - who helped define her.

They think that the Laura Spence case makes clear their forthcoming campaign themes - "opportunity for all" and the "many not the few". They think that senior Tories look embarrassed defending Oxbridge on TV. Tory MPs believe that "aspirational" Britain agrees with them.

Polling day will show who is right.

As an exponent of a skills economy he believes Britain needs all its talents. Rightly or wrongly, Labour believes that it can benefit from signs that Hague is finally getting the Tory act together. Tony Blair and Brown are united in believing that Margaret Thatcher benefited from good enemies - Arthur Scargill, General Galtieri of Argentina and Michael Foot - who helped define her. They think that the Laura Spence case makes clear their forthcoming campaign themes - "opportunity for all" and the "many not the few". They think that senior Tories look embarrassed defending Oxbridge on TV. Tory MPs believe that "aspirational" Britain agrees with them. Polling day will show who is right.

fields.headline: Infection kills 18th heroin user
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: An unidentified infection that has been killing heroin addicts in Scotland and Ireland has claimed another victim, health officials in Glasgow said yesterday. Twenty-six drug users in Glasgow and 14 in Dublin have contracted the illness; 18 of them have died.
fields.body:
An unidentified infection that has been killing heroin addicts in Scotland and Ireland has claimed another victim, health officials in Glasgow said yesterday. Twenty-six drug users in Glasgow and 14 in Dublin have contracted the illness; 18 of them have died.

In Glasgow the illness emerged early this month, with 17 of the 26 cases affecting women and eight women being among the 12 dead.

All are believed to have injected heroin direct into muscle tissue and have suffered severe inflammation around the site of the injection.

The Dublin cases have followed a similar pattern as far as the illness is concerned, but most of the victims have been men.

Health officials in Glasgow said they had spoken to their Irish counterparts and concluded that the two outbreaks were likely to have the same cause.

Last week tests at the chemical warfare research centre in Porton Down, Wiltshire, ruled out anthrax, which scientists had suggested as the cause of the Glasgow outbreak.

American specialists have been called in to help the investigations in both cities. Tissue samples from those affected have been sent to the centre for disease control and prevention in tlanta, Georgia.
Kirsty Scott

webTitle: TV giants in US vie for Top of the Pops

fields.headline: TV giants in US vie for Top of the Pops
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Top of the Pops, once threatened with the axe as the MTV generation switched off in droves, is at the centre of a multi-million bidding war between US television networks who now regard it as the gold standard in music shows.
fields.body:
Top of the Pops, once threatened with the axe as the MTV generation switched off in droves, is at the centre of a multi-million bidding war between US television networks who now regard it as the gold standard in music shows.

Executives are competing to secure the rights to the latest TOTP format, which bears only a passing resemblance to the programme that spawned the dance troupe Pan's People and introduced the faces of DJs Jimmy Savile, Noel Edmonds and Dave Lee Travis to an undeserving public.

The US version would use the same title sequence and studio design as the British show, but would be based on the Billboard chart and fronted by American presenters. It marks a trend in British television companies selling successful formats abroad: the ITV quiz show Who Wants to be a Millionaire? has been a big hit in the US, and the children's programme Teletubbies is a similar moneyspinner for the BBC.

Chris Cowey, the flamboyant producer who has led the Top of the Pops revival in Britain, has opened negotiations with executives from the US networks, and hopes a deal will be signed later this year. "When we played them the showreel, their jaws hit the table. They couldn't believe we did this show every week, with eight bands on each show, and recorded in two hours," he said.

It is expected that the American show would have a "symbiotic relationship" with the UK one: the British version could slot in acts recorded for the US version, and vice versa.

The idea has already been a success in Germany, where a Top of the Pops magazine has just been launched to complement the television programme, which has been running there for a year. Holland and Turkey are also showing their own variations of the show, based on local charts.

Two other formats are also sold abroad: the complete show as broadcast on BBC1, and another variety where the foreign broadcaster splices in local presenters between the British chart acts. In all, Top of the Pops, first broadcast on the BBC in 1964, is shown in 87 countries on 14 channels and has made more than £10m for the corporation.

BBC Worldwide, which markets the corporation's asset abroad, is determined to capitalise on the Top of the Pops brand. Graham Samuels, music marketing director, said it had big ambitions for the show. "In terms of developing the BBC's overall brand around the world, it is very important. The marriage of the BBC's public service remit with the commercial side, working together to the benefit of the licence fee payer, is often forgotten."

The programme is enjoying renewed strength in Britain after a period of apparently inexorable decline. At one stage, the BBC considered dropping TOTP, because it was seen as increasingly irrelevant by record labels and viewers alike. Under the new regime, however, viewing figures have picked up: ratings are steady at about 5m a week.

Mr Cowey banned almost all music videos and insisted that if record companies wanted their acts to feature on the show, they would have to appear in person or not at all. The programme attracts international names such as Madonna and Whitney Houston, as well as established British acts. Instead of having a rota of Radio 1 disc jockeys presenting the programme, it is now fronted mainly by Jamie Theakston, Jayne Middlemiss and Gail Porter.

Mr Theakston said the US deal was important for the programme's profile. "I think it's a good thing, it's an established brand in this country and I think it underlines the ambition that we have for this show. There is no reason why we can't have a Top of the Pops in America, or Europe, or wherever. It's a tried and tested formula, it works."

TOTP history

First broadcast on January 1, 1964, fronted by Jimmy Savile. Revamp in 1991 failed to halt its 1980s decline and a last chance was given to Chris Cowey, veteran producer of The Tube and the White Room, who brought in Jamie Theakston and banned the showing of videos - even Madonna had to show up. Decline arrested.

Those TOTP moments

 On a live show in 1988, All About Eve missed their cue, and the music for Martha's Harbour went out on air as the band sat on stage, looking bemused.

 Status Quo's Rick Parfitt, apparently somewhat emotional, once staggered backwards into the drummer, falling off the stage and taking most of the kit with him. Ever the professionals, the rest of the band appeared not to notice.

 Fish, lead singer of Marillion, ingeniously skirted a sore throat problem by getting the audience to sing the words of Lavender Live from a giant idiot board, as he pointed at the words.

fields.headline: No: 1646 The Duke of Hamilton
fields.trailText: Angus Alan Douglas Douglas-Hamilton.
fields.body:
Aka i): Angus Alan Douglas Douglas-Hamilton.

Aka ii): Scotland's premier peer.

Aka iii): Hereditary Keeper of Holyroodhouse.

Age: 61.

One gathers that His Grace is greatly upset. He is indeed.

What's the cause of his displeasure? It's the foie gras, I'm afraid.

The cook forgot to order enough? Or the butler served a stingy portion? No. It was his grocer.

His Grace's grocer! Yes, he's decided to boycott Jenners - the Harrods of Edinburgh - a shop he's patronised for 30 years.

Is he trying to ape Prince Philip who withdrew royal warrants from Harrods in the royal family's feud with Mohamed al Fayed over Diana and Dodi? Hamilton isn't petty.

What's it all about then? He wants the store to stop selling foie gras because it's cruel to force-feed geese to produce it.

He's a reformed gourmet, who used to stuff himself with pté, truffles and caviar? Nope: he tried fois gras once, then decided it was an unacceptable "cruel delicacy".

At a blow-out lunch with Fatty Soames? That wasn't the occasion.

And Hamilton's not a huntin', shootin', maimin' and killin' aristo who's seen the error of his ways? No, he's a model landowner.

You mean he'd rather shoot poachers than pheasants: Not quite. But last summer he offered a £500 reward to capture poachers who'd used a crossbow to attack his 160-strong herd of deer.

Impeccably humane credentials for a lordly landowner: Yes, it runs in the family. His grandmother was famous for pioneering slaughterhouse reform in the 20s.

Family motto: In Tesco we trust.

Do say: " A little more Heinz sandwich spread, Your Grace?"

Don't say: "Not long till the Glorious Twelfth, eh, Dukie."

Not to be confused with: Neil Hamilton, Bertie Wooster.

webTitle: Club vows to tackle drug abuse

fields.headline: Club vows to tackle drug abuse
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The huge Liverpool nightclub Cream has been given five months to tackle drug abuse or face closure.
fields.body:
The huge Liverpool nightclub Cream has been given five months to tackle drug abuse or face closure.

Managers, who admit that the club has a serious drug problem, have promised action to clear it of pushers. All customers will be frisked for drugs; there will be undercover opertions to bar pushers; police will make regular covert sweeps for drugs; there will be closed circuit TV surveillance for drug abuse; and no one will be admitted after 1am.

Police opposed renewal of Cream's entertainments licence, but the city council granted it a reprieve until October 31 after its managing director, James Barton, agreed to stringent controls.

Last July a tourism officer, Liz Wood, died after taking ecstasy at the club, which can hold 3,100 customers.

fields.headline: On the road to nowhere
fields.standfirst: Touring theatre is in crisis, with falling audiences and cutthroat competition. It doesn't help that many venues don't believe in drama, says  Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: Touring theatre is in crisis, with falling audiences and cutthroat competition. It doesn't help that many venues don't believe in drama, says Lyn Gardner
fields.body:
In the London offices of Shared Experience, a theatre company with a worldwide reputation, general manager Rachel Tackley is trying to find venues for the company's forthcoming British tour of Ibsen's Doll's House. One theatre manager listens politely and then declines on the grounds that he has already booked a Chekhov play. He really wouldn't, he explains, want two dramas within a few weeks of each other. "But you're a theatre," responds Tackley despairingly.

A couple of hundred miles up the road, Tim Highman of English Touring Theatre is selling his show. "We have a new production starring Prunella Scales," he tells one venue manager. "Oh, I'll definitely take that." "Don't you want to know what the play is?" asks Highman. "If it's got Prunella Scales in it, that's good enough for me." Chekhov's Cherry Orchard, with Scales as Madame Ranevskaya, is duly booked.

A couple of years ago, Mike Alfreds, the veteran figure who runs the touring company Method and Madness, got together a group of venue managers to find out what they wanted. "Shakespeare?" he asked. "No, there's too much," came the reply. "New plays?" "Too hard to sell." "So," said Alfreds, despairingly, "what do you want?" "It is not our job to tell you what we want - we just know what we don't want."

For all his experience in the touring sector, Alfreds never did find out what they wanted. A year ago this month, Method and Madness ceased to tour, three years into an ambitious project to create a repertoire of work with a permanent ensemble. Alfreds admits that the company could no longer persuade enough venues to take its work.

This is not a story of villainous theatre managers unable to recognise a good thing when it is stuck under their noses, or of poor hard-done touring companies that only produce brilliant work. Anyone who saw Method and Madness's abysmal Cherry Orchard two years ago will know this is not the case. But it is the story of an often ignored, certainly underfunded and distinctly unglamorous sector of theatre that is in crisis.

It is a crisis that the Arts Council seems to be only belatedly recognising and for which it is partly responsible. In last week's response to the Boyden report on the state of British theatre, the Arts Council's Next Stage document speaks of the need for "further development of the Arts Council's national touring policy, and in particular the refinement of its approach to touring drama."

But there are many in the sector who would question whether it has had any kind of constructive approach to touring drama in recent years. The fact that Method and Madness has been mothballed for a year, producing nothing, its lottery-funded offices barely used, while its board takes a leisurely decision on its future seems at odds with The Next Stage's concern that over a six-year period funding for nationally touring companies has resulted in 24% fewer performances and 13% fewer workshops, leading to a 28% decrease in audiences.

Method and Madness is one of the three touring companies funded by the Arts Council's drama department (the others are English Touring Theatre and Oxford Stage Company). The fact that it has produced no work for a year may have played as big a part in the decline in audiences as the standstill funding that has put all these companies under intense pressure. The Arts Council, however, maintains that it is up to the board of Method and Madness to decide its future, however long that may take.

But there is something even odder going on. The Arts Council talks about a "significant reduction in the number of tours", yet ask almost any company that tours on the middle scale, and with the exception of Theatre de Complicite, which could probably book a tour of Roget's Thesaurus without any trouble, all sigh about the increasingly difficult task of getting venues to take their work.

In part this is because, as Tish Francis of Oxford Playhouse says, "We have been both expanding what we offer our audiences and trying to extend that audience itself. Diversity is the key word." That's not a problem at a venue such as the Playhouse because of its good reputation and proximity to London. It can take its pick of touring drama and is part of what Dominic Dromgoole of Oxford Stage Company calls the "Harvey Nichols touring circuit", a select bunch of well-run, upmarket venues such as Oxford and Malvern that will get good audiences and make money.

Elsewhere, as Dromgoole points out, diversity can simply mean that "you are up against shite that is more commercial than you are. It is hard to put a Robert Holman play up against Murder at the Vicarage.

It is not just companies that have been hit. As touring costs have risen, some venues, particularly in the north, are no longer able to afford decent touring productions. And so the places visited by the major companies have taken on a distinctly southern bias. The idea of tours filling the gaps in the regional rep network is a fiction.

Tim Highman also points out that while a policy of diversity may bring new audiences into the theatres, it doesn't always bring them in for drama. "If your play is the only drama programmed that season, you have to build an audience from scratch every time you turn up in that venue." English Touring Theatre's solution has been an extensive education and outreach programme.

But it is not just from the commercial sector that the touring companies have been feeling the squeeze. A few years back, seeing a gap in the market, the Almeida, the Donmar, the RSC and the National and some regional reps leapt in. The result is an overcrowded market where touring companies are squeezed out of prime venues by others whose main subsidy is for their building-based work.

The Arts Council's Next Stage recognises that there is a problem and that touring can't be looked at in isolation but must be seen in a broader context of regional theatre. It also suggests that there must be a more constructive relationship between the touring companies and the regional reps, some of which have occasionally demonstrated a "Get off my patch" mentality.

Yet before the Arts Council takes action there are signs that the companies themselves are taking the initiative. Oxford Stage Company's London residencies have attracted criticism, but the company has not shirked its commitment to touring. English Touring Company has an educational programme second to none.

Tish Francis thinks that the Arts Council must respond more quickly to the changing needs of touring, while Dominic Dromgoole argues that theatre, particularly regional touring, is mired in a culture in which "everything is impossible". He prefers to think that everything is possible. "After all, what's the point of touring unless you think it's fun? The great thing about a touring show is that it is always an event. The production never settles."

Rachel Tackley agrees: " Touring is the sexiest place to be. You can play to a bunch of 16-year-olds in one place and to greying old ladies in the next. The response is so different. And you don't have to worry about the state of the toilets or the bar profits. That's somebody else's problem."

The Cherry Orchard tours till July 1. Details: 01270 501800.

fields.headline: Staging Speer
fields.standfirst: What's the best way to represent the evils of Nazism, asks  Michael Billington
fields.trailText: What's the best way to represent the evils of Nazism
fields.body:
How do you dramatise the story of Albert Speer? How do you plausibly present a man who lied in order to live with himself? A dramatic hero can easily present two faces: one to the characters, another to the audience. But the singular fact about Speer is the masked nature of his whole existence. His confession of guilt at the Nuremberg trials in 1946 appears like a skilled tactical manoeuvre; and even when, at the end of his life, he admits in an affidavit to his "tacit acceptance of the persecution and murder of millions of Jews" he queries the precise translation of "tacit acceptance", prevaricating to the last.

In her 750-page biography of Speer, Gitta Sereny has the freedom to question his every statement, to pore over every scrap of evidence. David Edgar has no such luxury in the three-and-a-half-hour play he has fashioned from the book for the National Theatre. He can present Speer through his own and other people's eyes but he cannot deal in the minutiae of scholarship. While I broadly welcome Edgar's attempt to restore public issues and events to our increasingly privatised stage, I also think his play raises an acute aesthetic problem. How do you encompass the evils of Nazism? Through fact? Through fiction? Or through a hybrid mixture of the two?

Edgar is not alone in using Speer as a means of exploring the nature of Nazism. Only last year at the Almeida we saw Esther Vilar's two-hander, Speer, in which Klaus Maria Brandauer appeared as Hitler's former architect and armaments minister. But Vilar's play was a rigged moral debate based on a totally artificial premise: that Speer would have accepted an invitation to lecture in East Berlin in 1980 and would have agreed to be subjected to forensic interrogation by his host. Vilar's purpose was quite plain: to put Speer in the dock and expose his supposed penitence as a survival tactic.

Edgar's play strikes me as in every respect superior to Vilar's, in that it denies itself the soft option of posthumous arraignment to acknowledge Speer's masked complexity, hall-of-mirrors conscience and fatal erotic enthralment to Hitler.

But two other works have also lately put Speer on stage: one factually, the other obliquely. The former was a version of the Nuremberg war crimes trial, edited by the Guardian's Richard Norton-Taylor and staged at the Tricycle in 1996. We were able to hear, in their own words, the testimonies of Speer, Goering, Field-Marshal Keitel and the pedantic philosopher Alfred Rosenberg.

What struck me at the time was the variety of moral evasions they offered, from Goering's denial of all knowledge of liquidation policies to Rosenberg's semantic quibbles over the precise meaning of "extermination"; beside this, Speer's retrospective condemnation of Hitler and limited confession of guilt acquired a rambling sympathy. But the great virtue of the Tricycle's piece was that it presented the evidence and allowed us to form our own conclusions.

The other, more oblique work is a play in which Speer's name is never mentioned at all: Harold Pinter's Ashes to Ashes. Pinter has freely admitted that the play was triggered by reading Sereny's book. In particular, Pinter was haunted by the horrific image of an underground labour camp in the Harz mountains where the workers were hurled by the guards into their own shit. But Pinter was also clearly intrigued by Speer's late-life love affair with a young German woman. His play becomes an extremely complex exploration not just of the magnetism of evil but of the spiritual duality that enables people to exist as both agents of tyranny and functioning human beings.

What this suggests to me is that the documentary or the imaginative approach are the theatre's best weapons for addressing the subject of Nazism. If Edgar's play achieves only limited success, it is because it attempts to combine the two. On the documentary level, it is perfectly honourable. But it suffers from a structural flaw: the use of Speer in the first half as an unreliable narrator whose confessions to the Spandau pastor, Georges Casilis, have to wait until the second part for correction and re-evaluation.

It is when Edgar allows himself dramatic licence that the play takes wing: there is one extremely powerful moment at the end when the furious ghost of Hitler returns to haunt Speer's imagination and to ask why, when he talked of elimination and extermination, he was never taken literally. Edgar, you feel, has at last liberated himself from his source and you begin to see the play he might have written.

As it stands, Albert Speer is a perfectly valid examination of Speer's continued deception of himself and others. But, as an examination of Nazism, it falls somewhere between the chilling sobriety of fact and the unfettered use of the dramatist's imagination.

Albert Speer is at the National Theatre, London SE1 (020-7452 3000), till July 8.

fields.headline: Peoplesound beat goes on
fields.standfirst:
Finns help music downloader forget start-up snags

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Peoplesound.com, the free on-line music download site, yesterday shrugged off concerns surrounding the future backing for start-up internet companies by finalising a new funding round valuing it in excess of £70m.
fields.body:
Peoplesound.com, the free on-line music download site, yesterday shrugged off concerns surrounding the future backing for start-up internet companies by finalising a new funding round valuing it in excess of £70m.

Finnish wireless communications operator Sonera Corporation is taking an 8% stake in the London-based company, with internet venture capital firm Zouk Ventures taking a further 2.4%. Under the terms of the deal Peoplesound becomes exclusive free music provider for Sonera's global wireless portal, Zed.

"This deal will allow music downloads straight to mobile handsets enabling music lovers to have their favourite music wherever they go," said Ernesto Schmitt, president of Peoplesound.com.

However, many prolific internet investors remain ner vous about committing further funds to the sector, following the recent shake-up in the valuation of internet companies. Broadcaster BSkyB, which earlier this month agreed a £300m deal to buy Sports Internet and has taken minority stakes in numerous net start-ups, is understood to have pulled out of possible investments in Peoplesound and fledgling betting firm Flutter.com.

Mr Schmitt declined to comment but Flutter chief executive Josh Hannah said: "We talked and they [BSkyB] were fairly interested for a while but went away. They have betting interests of their own and I couldn't be sure that they pulled back because of the market."

BSkyB refused to comment. Flutter has subsequently closed a $38m funding round with new investment from Chase, UBS Warburg, Benchmark Capital and Europe@Web.

 Computer services firm Getronics plans to launch and later separately list an e-business enterprise relationship management unit.

Getronics said it would have teams of consultants experienced in the design of e-business solutions. The new business, G2E, would be based in Amsterdam with branches initially in Madrid, Milan and London. "Getronics is the first ICT solutions provider to make the important step towards customised e-solutions based on pre-defined, reusable components," said Getronics' chief executive officer, Cees van Luijk.

But investors took little comfort from the new venture after the firm repeated its full-year outlook. It also acknowledged asking some analysts to recalculate their earnings per share forecasts, saying estimates of more than two euros were unrealistic. Shares closed at a session low of €18.70, a loss of 5.2%.

fields.headline: Only here for the ear
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Romney:  Sculpting with sound
fields.trailText: Sculpting with sound: Sonic Boom, curated by musician and critic David Toop, aims to make us hear (and sometimes see) sound in a new way - to make us reconsider the way it shapes our everyday perceptions even when we don't notice it.
fields.body:
This weekend I went to the Hayward Gallery's exhibition Sonic Boom: the Art of Sound. I heard the rustle of a paper bag, someone's denimed knees rubbing together, the muted rattle of a slide projector, and a group of French students arguing on the stairs. A particularly nice touch highlighted the interplay between the closed exhibition space and the outside world - the mobile phone that went off the second I left the gallery.

None of these sounds were actually in the catalogue. All of them were incidental - random interference, if you like. But then incidental sounds have played a key role in modern art ever since John Cage lifted and lowered his piano lid and let the mystified mutters in between the composition.

Sonic Boom, curated by musician and critic David Toop, aims to make us hear (and sometimes see) sound in a new way - to make us reconsider the way it shapes our everyday perceptions even when we don't notice it. But sound can't be exhibited in the same way as visual art. You can't show a sound in isolation, or stick it in a glass case, although some artists try to get close. Pan Sonic's 2 X 50 Hz Thru Leslie Speaker is just what it says, the sound itself and nothing but - or as near as dammit, since the machinery that produces the sound is visually so uninteresting it is barely there.

The problem is, sounds are hard to separate. Colours from one painting don't leak into its neighbours - not literally at least - but with sound you can barely stem the flow. In Mariko Mori's video installation, the artist oohs and aahs away in her guise as purple-hued space cadet, her ethereal vocals seeping quietly from a speaker. But she is constantly drowned out by Stephan von Huene's adjacent exhibit, a wooden robot emitting boisterous clicks and burps. A few paces away, you can slip into the darkened cubicle of Max Eastley and Thomas Köner's List of Japanese Winds, 10 booming gongs cocooning you in deep bass. But even here, the robot belches force their way in.

Philip Jeck puts interference to use in his stack of some 70 Dansettes loaded with treated and defaced singles and LPs, wheezing together like an orchestra of the dead. It's a melancholy evocation of technological and aesthetic mortality, with Stravinsky reduced to two notes and a thud, crackling in endless discord against a similarly butchered Herb Albert.

Some artists attempt to protect their work's delicacy, insulating it in more or less sealed environments. Paul Schütze's elegant Site Three is its own microclimate, a glass-floored space with watery videos on three walls, and a very sculpted three-dimensional soundtrack: chill-out space as conceptual steam bath. In Brian Eno's Civic Recovery Centre (Quiet Club), a slide show mutates gently in the dark, to old-fashioned ambient rumblings; I was rather pleased to find its insular sobriety punctured by some low-level squeaking from outside.

Another dark chamber contains Christian Marclay's film Guitar Drag, in which an electric guitar is dragged along a road on the end of a rope, making a godawful feedback death-rattle. There's a peculiar delight in seeing this cruel and unusual punishment inflicted on an instrument that has itself been responsible for much torture over the last 50 years. But there was also the pleasure of finding sheer brutalist noise in this rather studious environment.

Outside on the sculpture court, Christina Kubitsch has draped a canopy of magnetic induction cables; put on headphones and you can wander around a virtual forest of birdsong and waterfalls. You still get occasional infiltration from the South Bank outside: clattering skateboards, burbles from Greyworld's walkway installation. But remove the phones and you're suddenly somewhere more interesting - outside the spectacle, watching 20 other people wandering around in silent reverie, listening to the oasis that is nowhere but in their own heads.

Visual exhibitions, come to think of it, are not so different from Sonic Boom: some works will always be "louder" and drown out the opposition because they are brighter, or bigger, or more heavily publicised. But you also realise how some quiet works make their presence felt simply by asking you to sift them out from the hubbub. With Max Eastley's kinetic sculptures, you have to refocus your ears to a barely perceptible scrape or the tinkle of a few beads on a wire. One piece is a line of bobbing stick figures tracing invisible patterns on a white surface. The subliminal scratch is just sufficiently present to stand out from the overall wash of oo-ee-oo atmospherics and electronic haze. This is the natural sound of next to nothing, but it demonstrates with Zen discretion that near-silence can sometimes drown out the surrounding noise, just for a moment - the blink of an ear?

Sonic Boom is at the Hayward Gallery, London SE1 (020-7928 3144), till June 18.

webTitle: Court circular: Who's up in front of the judge

fields.headline: Court circular: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Far be it from Court Circular to leap unthinkingly to the defence of a fellow hack, but we couldn't suppress a smile at the news that Larry Birkhead, a freelance journalist from Louisville, Kentucky had begun legal action against actress Ashley Judd for - allegedly - libelling him on the TV show Entertainment Tonight.
fields.body:
Far be it from Court Circular to leap unthinkingly to the defence of a fellow hack, but we couldn't suppress a smile at the news that Larry Birkhead, a freelance journalist from Louisville, Kentucky had begun legal action against actress Ashley Judd for - allegedly - libelling him on the TV show Entertainment Tonight.

The legalistic kick-off got under way last August, when Birkhead interviewed Judd's mother Naomi for USA Today on the thorny issue of Hollywood sex and violence, during which she remarked that "Pop and I wouldn't watch" their daughter's turn in the 1996 TV movie Norma Jean And Marilyn, and refused to comment on her role in the steamy (and very, very poor) Double Jeopardy.

Whereupon, much to Birkhead's chagrin, lil' Ashley then appeared on the tube describing the article as a "complete fabrication" - an open invitation, in the eyes of the journalist's attorney Phillip Kimball, to the punitive damages suit filed at Louisville Central Court last week. "We're very aware", observed Judd's spokesperson, "that there is a lawsuit, but we have no further information at this stage."

Meanwhile, the ever-troubled Sean "Puffy" Combs resolved at least one of his growing collection of litigious battles last week, coughing up an undisclosed settlement to a woman injured in a stampede at a charity basketball game way back in 1991.

The plaintiff, one Nicole Levy, had gone after both Puffy and fellow rapper Heavy D after their participation in the hoop game during which a crowd stampede left nine people dead and Levy suffering unspecified "physical distress".

At the time the suit was originally filed, Combs' lawyers described it as "phony" and "disrespectful", although - with firearms charges still hanging over him from last December's shooting incident at a Manhattan nightclub - not phony enough to preclude shelling out a sum widely assumed to be seven digits long to make her go away.

webTitle: Tax battle brings turmoil to millionaires' paradise

fields.headline: Tax battle brings turmoil to millionaires' paradise
fields.standfirst: Summer residents demand the vote in hideaway of the stars
fields.trailText: The Memorial Day weekend, the first big bash of summer, is barely out of the way and there are weeks to go yet before the pinnacle of the season, the Fourth of July celebrations. But all is not well in the Hamptons, a 30-mile long fork of land at the end of Long Island which is the favourite hideaway of the rich and famous.
fields.body:
The Memorial Day weekend, the first big bash of summer, is barely out of the way and there are weeks to go yet before the pinnacle of the season, the Fourth of July celebrations. But all is not well in the Hamptons, a 30-mile long fork of land at the end of Long Island which is the favourite hideaway of the rich and famous.

Money is not a problem in a place where it costs an average of $1m (£670,000) to buy a house on the 12-mile strip linking East Hampton, Southampton and Bridgehampton.

"Money has no meaning out here in the Hamptons," said Steven Gaines, the best-selling author of Philistines at the Hedgerow: Passion and Property in the Hamptons . "Once you're insanely rich, this is the place to come. It's really summertime on laughing gas."

But the part-time inhabitants of this ultra-rich enclave are still up in arms about a debate older than the United States itself - the issue of taxation without representation.

Lowell Harwood, owner of a $6m beach house, with swimming pool, tennis court and putting green in Southampton, wants to know why should he pay local taxes when he does not have a vote.

Mr Harwood, 70, who made millions through property development in Manhattan, and others like him are thought to pay about three-quarters of Southampton's property taxes but cannot take part in local elections because they are not permanent residents. He and about 100 others also pay water taxes for water they do not receive.

"Nobody is going to feel sorry for us," he said. "That is not what we are looking for. We just want justice. If I can afford a house like mine these people feel that I can afford to pay their water bill. I don't mind giving money to charity but I don't like it taken away."

No one in Southampton village has had water from the Hampton Bays district since a pipe was severed 62 years ago, yet Mr Harwood has to pay $1,800 a year for this, on top of the $700 for water he does receive from the Town of Southampton Water Authority.

The monied migrants who help to swell the village's year-round 3,900 population by another 25,000 each summer would like a referendum on the water bills - except they would not be able to take part in it.

Mr Harwood has said he may consider legal action to press his case if the tax situation does not change.

His stand divides representatives in the area, which is just three hours away from Manhattan by road. "It is a grave injustice to take the money of summer residents and not give them full mem bership in the club, said Bill Hattrick, a permanent resident who is president of the Southampton Association, most of whose 700 members are part-timers.

But Joseph Romanosky, the village mayor, said: "Permanent residents feel they can't drive around any more because of traffic and sometimes they can't even walk around because of the crowds of summer people. And now you are telling them that the summer people should have the right to vote? They don't know these people and they don't trust them."

But if the permanent residents don't know many of the summer visitors then they are they are among the few people in the US who do not.

The comedian Jerry Seinfeld is one of the most famous arrivals, having paid about $40m for a house formerly owned by Billy Joel, but others include many of America's most famous figures, including Steven Spielberg, Leonardo DiCaprio, and, just to give it a bit of edge, the rap figures Jay-Z and Sean "Puffy" Combs, both of whom have faced criminal charges relating to, respectively, assault and possession of firearms.

Each year the Hamptons becomes more popular, raising the volume of grumbles from lifers about over-crowding.

But some outsiders are prepared to make adjustments, of a sort. Jonathan Iseson, 42, a hedge fund manager, has just taken delivery of a new 48ft cruiser, docked at Sag Harbour yacht club. The last one was 55ft. "I got rid of the wife so I didn't need the space," he said.

At home with Hollywood's big hitters

Jerry Seinfeld Once the highest-paid man on television for his sitcom series, which finished two years ago. Since then he has devoted his time to getting married, buying Billy Joel's house for about $40m and hanging out, as they say

Steven Spielberg The movie director is credited with starting the trend that gives the Hamptons its cache. He made his first foray 17 years ago and the rest of Hollywood followed, so the story goes. Bill and Hillary Clinton are frequent house guests

Kelsey Grammer The Frasier star was said to have been so lonely in the house at Sagaponack that he took to walking along the beach introducing himself to people

Sean "Puffy" Combs The rapper was fined $2,000 after last year's Fourth of July party got out of hand. He has taken his revenge on East Hampton by moving west to a bigger house priced at $3.9m

Kim Basinger and her fellow actor and husband Alec Baldwin are renting a house during work on their farm

Leonardo DiCaprio The Titanic star is sharing a house with his friend and rising star Tobey Maguire

Sarah Jessica Parker is taking it easy with actor husband Matthew Broderick after completing work on the third series of Sex and the City
fields.bodyText: The Memorial Day weekend, the first big bash of summer, is barely out of the way and there are weeks to go yet before the pinnacle of the season, the Fourth of July celebrations. But all is not well in the Hamptons, a 30-mile long fork of land at the end of Long Island which is the favourite hideaway of the rich and famous. Money is not a problem in a place where it costs an average of $1m (£670,000) to buy a house on the 12-mile strip linking East Hampton, Southampton and Bridgehampton. "Money has no meaning out here in the Hamptons," said Steven Gaines, the best-selling author of Philistines at the Hedgerow: Passion and Property in the Hamptons . "Once you're insanely rich, this is the place to come. It's really summertime on laughing gas." But the part-time inhabitants of this ultra-rich enclave are still up in arms about a debate older than the United States itself - the issue of taxation without representation. Lowell Harwood, owner of a $6m beach house, with swimming pool, tennis court and putting green in Southampton, wants to know why should he pay local taxes when he does not have a vote. Mr Harwood, 70, who made millions through property development in Manhattan, and others like him are thought to pay about three-quarters of Southampton's property taxes but cannot take part in local elections because they are not permanent residents. He and about 100 others also pay water taxes for water they do not receive. "Nobody is going to feel sorry for us," he said. "That is not what we are looking for. We just want justice. If I can afford a house like mine these people feel that I can afford to pay their water bill. I don't mind giving money to charity but I don't like it taken away." No one in Southampton village has had water from the Hampton Bays district since a pipe was severed 62 years ago, yet Mr Harwood has to pay $1,800 a year for this, on top of the $700 for water he does receive from the Town of Southampton Water Authority. The monied migrants who help to swell the village's year-round 3,900 population by another 25,000 each summer would like a referendum on the water bills - except they would not be able to take part in it. Mr Harwood has said he may consider legal action to press his case if the tax situation does not change. His stand divides representatives in the area, which is just three hours away from Manhattan by road. "It is a grave injustice to take the money of summer residents and not give them full mem bership in the club, said Bill Hattrick, a permanent resident who is president of the Southampton Association, most of whose 700 members are part-timers. But Joseph Romanosky, the village mayor, said: "Permanent residents feel they can't drive around any more because of traffic and sometimes they can't even walk around because of the crowds of summer people. And now you are telling them that the summer people should have the right to vote? They don't know these people and they don't trust them." But if the permanent residents don't know many of the summer visitors then they are they are among the few people in the US who do not. The comedian Jerry Seinfeld is one of the most famous arrivals, having paid about $40m for a house formerly owned by Billy Joel, but others include many of America's most famous figures, including Steven Spielberg, Leonardo DiCaprio, and, just to give it a bit of edge, the rap figures Jay-Z and Sean "Puffy" Combs, both of whom have faced criminal charges relating to, respectively, assault and possession of firearms. Each year the Hamptons becomes more popular, raising the volume of grumbles from lifers about over-crowding. But some outsiders are prepared to make adjustments, of a sort. Jonathan Iseson, 42, a hedge fund manager, has just taken delivery of a new 48ft cruiser, docked at Sag Harbour yacht club. The last one was 55ft. "I got rid of the wife so I didn't need the space," he said. At home with Hollywood's big hitters Jerry Seinfeld Once the highest-paid man on television for his sitcom series, which finished two years ago. Since then he has devoted his time to getting married, buying Billy Joel's house for about $40m and hanging out, as they say Steven Spielberg The movie director is credited with starting the trend that gives the Hamptons its cache. He made his first foray 17 years ago and the rest of Hollywood followed, so the story goes. Bill and Hillary Clinton are frequent house guests Kelsey Grammer The Frasier star was said to have been so lonely in the house at Sagaponack that he took to walking along the beach introducing himself to people Sean "Puffy" Combs The rapper was fined $2,000 after last year's Fourth of July party got out of hand. He has taken his revenge on East Hampton by moving west to a bigger house priced at $3.9m Kim Basinger and her fellow actor and husband Alec Baldwin are renting a house during work on their farm Leonardo DiCaprio The Titanic star is sharing a house with his friend and rising star Tobey Maguire Sarah Jessica Parker is taking it easy with actor husband Matthew Broderick after completing work on the third series of Sex and the City

Bradley: "I don't watch TV. I used to watch EastEnders a lot, and MTV, but I don't get the time now. I haven't watched EastEnders for ages. Favourite character? I liked all of them. The people I think are good are Ali G - love him - and Richard Blackwood."

Jo: "I like Friends and Pet Rescue. That's it."

Jon: "I love EastEnders. Dot Cotton is my favourite, she's wicked. I used to love Ally McBeal - obviously, I'm a big fan of Calista Flockhart, she's absolutely beautiful, and I think it's the funniest show on TV. Favourite people? Vic and Bob, really funny. Hard to say who I don't like, because I haven't met anyone for longer than five minutes. So you see someone and it's "Hello! Goodbye!" I do like Chris Tarrant - Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? and Tarrant On TV. Oh, and I love Mrs Merton, and the Royle Family, but I haven't seen much of that_"

Paul: "Oh, I'll watch anything."

Rachel: "I do like EastEnders, Corrie, other soaps_ and I like our programme. I try to watch it when I'm at home or wherever. But if I miss it, I miss it. It was great working in LA, because we got to know it over three months. It's like England - same language, so you don't get homesick."

webTitle: Navy rocks the boat with effort to debunk Dunkirk 'myth' of little ships

fields.headline: Navy rocks the boat with effort to debunk Dunkirk 'myth' of little ships
fields.trailText: The Royal Navy found itself in controversial waters last night after launching an effort, 60 years after the event, to reclaim virtually all the credit for rescuing 338,000 British soldiers in the Dunkirk evacuation.
fields.body:
The Royal Navy found itself in controversial waters last night after launching an effort, 60 years after the event, to reclaim virtually all the credit for rescuing 338,000 British soldiers in the Dunkirk evacuation.

In a new book, an author from the navy's historical branch dismissed the popular "myth" that little ships crewed by civilians played a big role in saving troops stranded on the French coast.

But last night another writer, who has studied 100 of the small vessels, said the attempt to "airbrush civilians out of history" was grossly unfair. He called the figures on which it was based "absolutely ridiculous".

His attack came as nearly 70 surviving little ships gathered in Dover to sail to Dunkirk for this weekend's 60th anniversary celebrations.

In a new preface to the reissued RN staff history of the operation, Jock Gardner writes: "The popular view, although not entirely incorrect - has taken on the status of a myth.

"[It is] a myth because it conveys neither an accurate nor a balanced account of the real achievement. Clearly, from the angle of human interest, the mythical interpretation has an appeal. But now, some 60 years after the event, it is time for more factual material to become clearly visible."

Mr Gardner says figures in the book show that 230,446 soldiers were rescued from Dunkirk harbour - well over twice the 98,790 saved by little ships from the beaches, which were "very much a second choice". The figures were unsurprising because the harbour's capacity was much bigger than that of the beaches, where Royal Navy ships could not get close enough.

Moreover, the 500-600 mostly requisitioned civilian small ships which took part "were generally staffed by the Royal Navy and reservists rather than civilians".

David Knowles, whose book Escape from Catastrophe, is also published this week, said: "For anyone to claim that they took an accurate, detailed count of the soldiers they were loading at Dunkirk is absolute hooey".

Mr Knowles, who has interviewed scores of Dunkirk survivors, added: "We know from contemporary accounts that no satisfactory official record was possible. They were loading 2,000 people an hour.

"The whole place was in chaos. They had no time to count."

In Dover, Rob Stokes, an official of the Association of Dunkirk Little Ships, said: "The chaps on the beaches were standing up to their necks in water day and night waiting to be rescued.

"Without the little ships, they would not have come home. But Mr Gardner is absolutely right to say that most of these ships were manned by naval crews. I can't quarrel with that."

 The Evacuation from Dunkirk; Frank Cass (£45)

 Escape from Catastrophe; Knowles Publishing, Rochester, Kent ME1 2DU (£11.50), also available at WH Smith

fields.headline: See no evil
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Jamie McCallum
fields.trailText: Last night's TV: Can You Live Without... Television?/No Service Please, We're British
fields.body:
How we like to watch people suffer Can You Live Without... Television? (C4) was a bit like whipping the crutches away from some poor infirm war veteran at the top of a really big hill and filming their descent.

The Kenny family, who watched 250 hours of television a week, had all their home entertainment devices taken away (all £8,000 worth) and then the consequences were filmed. It wasn't pretty.

As Michelle, Sean, Sharna, Danielle and Laura bickered, sulked and played Connect 4 in an attempt not to miss Emmerdale or their PlayStations, the anatomy of their relationships was exposed, their emotions gently frayed until you felt it was only a matter of time until mum Michelle went bananas with a kitchen knife.

She did go bananas in the kitchen, but only when she decided to make Sunday dinner - and that wasn't pretty either. With dad Sean and daughter Laura away fishing - an excursion which neither of them enjoyed - and Danielle away to collect her Alzheimer's-afflicted grandma, this makes uncomfortable viewing.

That televisions, stereos, videos and computers are too often used as an anaesthetic against the hard pain of our everyday lives is not something you want to see on telly; it was like feeling the nerve in your tooth twinge halfway through getting a filling.

The Kennys survived though, and it genuinely seemed like Michelle had had an epiphany when she realised she could live without telly. It was heartwarming and a tiny bit chilling at the same time. Especially for a TV critic.

Coming soon: Can You Live Without... Your Wife?, Can You Live Without... Make-Up? and Can You Live Without... Your House? (I made that last one up, though expect it if the series is recommissioned).

Were Channel 5 the only station ever broadcast, it would be all too easy to live without TV. When the narrator of No Service Please, We're British (C5) said that Kim Winter was a witch inspector, the prospect of her travelling around hotels pricking the thumbs of the proprietors, checking for the mark of the Devil on chambermaids and looking for broomsticks raised its promising head. A supernatural drama shot in a vérité style with the look of a cheap documentary, perhaps the programme was The X-Files meets The Cops?

Alas, Winter was no witch inspector but a Which? inspector who travelled around hotels metaphorically pricking the thumbs of the proprietors, checking for the mark of the Devil on chambermaids and looking for broomsticks.

"They're everywhere... even in the capital!" the narrator shrieked in horror. Yes, even London with its 24-carat pavements has nasty hotels. Judging from the state of the rooms Winter stayed in, there were no broomsticks - or indeed any cleaning accoutrements - to be found, but plenty of nasty hoteliers and lackadaisical cleaners.

They didn't clean the rooms properly, they didn't change the sheets, they didn't provide a smoked salmon breakfast delivered to your room by Brad Pitt's hunkier brother... These hotels, the horrified narrator told us, were appalling. And these fly-by-night rascals had the cheek to charge a whole £25 a night for the displeasure of staying in one of their sweaty-walled rooms. Imagine the temerity!

The only remotely interesting bit was when Kim found a couple of bits of crisps under her bed. "I don't want to go any further," she snorted, but seeing as how she'd only just complained that all there was to eat in this hotel was biscuits, she might have sounded a bit more grateful.

No Service Please, We're British was a pointless programme which could have lasted five minutes had they got rid of the Tina Turner impersonator who was disgusted by the room he'd paid £30 for, and the unmarried couple who'd handed over some £40 to stay in a shabby hotel in Rhyl. (If you make a living out of pretending to be Ms Turner or you go to Rhyl to live in sin, you get all you deserve.)

While the programme-makers might think £30 is a lot of money - which it probably is if you're used to making programmes to Channel 5 budgets - the outrage of the narrator was just tiresome. The revelation that cheap hotels are scummy will have the nation in uproar, haranguing scheming hotel proprietors and encouraging a march on Downing Street to stop this evil trade. Or not.

fields.headline: Emap launches C4 web deal
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Emap, the magazine and radio group, yesterday announced a web-based joint venture with Channel 4, saying that the deal would set the pattern for a series of alliances with other partners.
fields.body:
Emap, the magazine and radio group, yesterday announced a web-based joint venture with Channel 4, saying that the deal would set the pattern for a series of alliances with other partners.

Kevin Hand, Emap's chief executive, said the business was unlikely to pursue a large scale merger with a new media company, effectively scotching speculation earlier this month of an impending deal with Yahoo! - at least an agreed one.

"We do not see a 'one size fits all' strategy," he said. "We prefer to do deals market by market and geography by geography. It's hard to imagine one umbrella partner. The Channel 4 deal is where we would want to go."

The agreement with Channel 4 will build a website combining content from both companies' youth brands, including Dawson Creek, Hollyoaks, Smash Hits, Match and J17. The business will make revenues from advertising and sponsorship, and could lead to joint ventures in other areas - including music - where the two companies overlap.

Emap announced plans in March to invest £250m developing an internet business over the next few years.

In its core magazine division most of Emap's recent invest ment has been ploughed into the roll-out of FHM as a global franchise.

Local versions of the best-selling men's magazine are now on sale in France, Australia, South Africa, Romania, the Phillipines and Singapore.

Sales of the first issue in the US in February reached 450,000, and the print run for its third edition featuring the world's 100 most beautiful women is 900,000. Mr Hand said the launches were a matter of judging what level of "laddishness" was acceptable in local markets.

FHM.com, the company added, was one of the few business to consumer websites actually making a profit although it declined to provide any numbers.

Heat, the weekly entertainment title which has been the company's most notable new title in the past year, is now selling more than 100,000 copies and Mr Hand said its future was looking more secure after a difficult launch.

Style magazine The Face, which was bought last year as part of the acquisition of Wagadon, is "back kicking ass again in a really big way," Mr Hand added.

Emap also disclosed plans to launch pay-television channels based on its London-based dance radio station, Kiss, FM and music magazine Q. The group recently set up a separate division which offers advertisers packages across the group's assets, and Mr Hand said the intention was to continue blurring the lines between its different media.

Emap reported a 14% increase in pre-tax profits to £184.3m for the year ending March 31 - the media group's eighth consecutive year of double-digit earnings growth.

Shares in the company, which reached £17.73 at the height of the internet mania, yesterday added 45p to close at £11.48. Analysts described the results as "solid and without suprises". The year-end dividend was lifted 10% to 18.3p.

The low point was the company's US division, which saw sluggish growth and advertisers turning their backs on its stable of motor magazines for the internet and dealer-support promotional activity.

Mr Hand said he intends Emap to play an active role in the consolidation of the radio market if, as expected, the government lifts ownership limits in the communications white paper. Emap also owns "easy listening" station Magic.

webTitle: Go north and get better value, students advised

fields.headline: Go north and get better value, students advised
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Students wanting to combine the best social life at university with achieving a good degree should avoid Oxbridge, according to a new guide.
fields.body:
Students wanting to combine the best social life at university with achieving a good degree should avoid Oxbridge, according to a new guide.

Good social life, as well as academic quality, is a bonus for northern universities, according to the Virgin Alternative Guide to British Universities 2001.

The guide highlights "added value" at certain universities that "are arguably offering better academic value than Oxford or Cambridge in certain subjects".

Each university was marked on five separate categories each with a highest possible mark of 20.

The guide, published on June 15, shows that Sheffield, Leeds, Manchester, Edinburgh, Glasgow and Birmingham score 20 out of 20 for their "student scene", with Oxford and Cambridge only achieving 12.

Although Cambridge scores highest for academic excellence, with 17.7, the northern universities only just lag behind, with Edinburgh's academic excellence at 15.5, Nottingham's at 16.1 and Oxford at 16.

Compiler Piers Dudgeon said: "The guide is trying to show that there is more to university than the academic element, although that is important too. It focuses on finding a university that has more than just the best teaching."
