fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Ziggy Stardust And The Spiders From Mars/Slacker/Total Recall/To Be Or Not To Be
fields.body:
Ziggy Stardust And The Spiders From Mars

(DA Pennebaker, 1983)

8pm, FilmFour

Before the model marriage, the internet albums and, indeed, Tin Machine, David Bowie had iconic status. Twenty-odd years on, this film of the last Ziggy Stardust gig reminds us why he inspired such devotion. Almost skeletally beautiful, clothed in, well, not very much, and made up like a geisha, he is a prodigious talent, moving between rock, cabaret and psychedelia with ease, aided by guitarist Mick Ronson, in split-to-the-navel jacket and masses of eyeshadow.

Slacker

(Richard Linklater, 1991)

10pm, FilmFour

The first part of fresh indie director Linklater's ramshackle trilogy, followed by Dazed And Confused and Suburbia. Slacker looks like a lot more than its $23,000-worth of alternative Austin, Texas life, wending its way round the city from one oddball scene to the next, crafting a patchwork of 100 or so strange-to-deranged characters: the result is sometimes puzzling, often riveting.

Total Recall

(Paul Verhoeven, 1990)

10pm, Sci-Fi

A spectacular mega-budget adventure adapted from Philip K Dick's mind-bending tale. fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Frontiers/Seven Days That Rocked The World
fields.body:
Peter Evans tries to get to grips with a real brane-buster in Frontiers (9.0pm, Radio 4). No, that's not a Guardian misprint. It's the name theoretical physicists have devised for an invisible wrapping which they think may enshroud our whole universe, and which would prevent us detecting the infinite fifth dimension beyond it. This fifth dimension could in turn contain the three further dimensions required to sustain the superstring theory of elemental matter.

Tessie O'Shea (pictured) participated in one of Stuart Maconie's Seven Days That Rocked The World (10.0pm, Radio 2). Tessie who? On February 7 1964 this long-forgotten British comedienne was one of the warm-up acts on Ed Sullivan's television show. The teenage US audience sat quietly through Tessie's jokes and some Swedish acrobats. Finally, the Beatles came on, and pandemonium reigned. The watching audience reached 73 million and the Fab Four's records regularly sold a million thereafter.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Snake in the grass
fields.body:
Wenlock Edge
The knot tightens and loosens at the same time. Coil over coil, endless, it moves in the dark, like thought. Each lithe flowing movement, the colour, smell, even the cool radiation pulsing from its presence speaks of one thought - "snake". Her head appears with its bright yellow V marking on the neck from the slow unraveling of her body at the entrance to the hole.

Following my slash-and-compost method of gardening, I'd hacked down a hedge bank last autumn and stacked the grass, nettles and twigs in a corner of the garden. Rediscovering this gem of a heap, which has been festering nicely all winter, I had wanted to incorporate it into the new compost heap. Although I've been looking out for grass snakes I haven't found one since moving here, until today. I love making rotting heaps but I'm always loathe to move them for fear of disturbing the creatures which make their homes there. Carefully dissecting this heap and discovering the grass snake is wonderful because it realises an ambition to provide a breeding place for snakes. It also tells me some thing about the ecological quality of the garden if it can support a population.

Judging by its size, this particular snake is an adult female. In her confined tunnel in the heap she seems huge and is perhaps two feet long. The breeding season for grass snakes is late April early May, so I assume she is in here preparing to lay eggs. If she has already laid I don't want to disturb the eggs because the embryos can easily be killed by turning them.

Grass snakes like our compost and muck heaps because they maintain a constant warm temperature for incubation and plenty of moisture to prevent desiccation. People and snakes, it would seem, were made for each other. What happened to our thinking about snakes that we changed from revering them as sacred to fearing them as evil? The ram-headed serpent was one of the most impressive and truly typical of the Celtic cult animals. A snake-handled vessel from Carlisle, and the statue of the river goddess from Ilkley holding them illustrate the reverence in which they were held in Celtic and proto-Celtic traditions.

fields.headline: Crash signalman weeps at inquiry
fields.standfirst: Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: A signalman wept yesterday as he described the fatal seconds of delay in which the Paddington rail disaster might have been averted.
fields.body:
A signalman wept yesterday as he described the fatal seconds of delay in which the Paddington rail disaster might have been averted.

David Allen admitted wait ing up to 25 seconds after the Thames train went through a red light because he expected the driver to realise his mistake and stop.

Only when it became clear the train was not stopping did Mr Allen change the signal for the London-bound Great Western express, the official inquiry was told yesterday.

The inquiry had previously heard that if the Thames train had begun emergency braking within 15 seconds of the alert reaching the signaller, the crash would not have happened.

Thirty-one people died in the disaster last October, including both drivers.

About 40 survivors and victims' families packed the public hearing yesterday as Mr Allen confessed: "There was a short period of time when I was expecting the driver to come on the phone and say to me that he had passed a signal at danger.

"Then he progressed further and I saw that we not only had a Spad [signal passed at danger] but that we had a train running away."

The only means to stop the Thames train then was to send the driver an emergency radio message "because he's entered the junction, and I can't stop him, he's gone to the point of no return," Mr Allen said.

His colleague James Hillman, who had hurried across the control room to help, sent the emergency stop alarm.

Mr Allen tried to change the points on the line to divert the Thames train out of the path of the express, but could not because the points were locked.

The signaller admitted his standing instructions were to stop a train's movements immediately once it had passed a signal at danger, but in his previous experience of "two or three" Spads, the trains had always stopped safely.

An independent report presented to the inquiry said Mr Allen's reaction time was not unreasonable, while counsel for his employers, Railtrack, said the company believed he had done his "best in difficult circumstances".

webTitle: Resisting the yen for a baby

fields.headline: Resisting the yen for a baby
fields.standfirst: Global population: special report
fields.trailText: Bandai, the Japanese toymaker, is offering employees £6,000 to have a third child in the latest in a series of increasingly desperate public and private moves to halt the country's alarming slowdown in the number of births.
fields.body:
Bandai, the Japanese toymaker, is offering employees £6,000 to have a third child in the latest in a series of increasingly desperate public and private moves to halt the country's alarming slowdown in the number of births.

From incentives of cars and cash to new laws on childcare and paternity leave, government officials and executives of the country's corporations are trying everything to reverse a trend that, if continued, will halve the population over the next 100 years.

Bandai, the toymaker behind the tamagotchi craze which swept the world three years ago, has decided to set an example by offering its workers a 1m yen reward for every baby they have after their second child.

Though they are not the first Japanese company to pay such a bonus, the amount is the largest ever offered. "We are hoping that this large sum will inspire our employees," a company spokesman said.

The scheme is still in its infancy and success is far from certain. So far, Bandai has failed to win over any of its 950 workers.

Similar schemes have made little impact. When the carmaker Daihatsu teamed up with the Ikeda city government in western Japan to offer a reward for a fourth child of £1,000 and free car rental for three years, the birthrate stubbornly refused to budge.

Nationwide, that rate has fallen sharply over the past 50 years. In 1950, the average Japanese woman gave birth to 3.65 children during her lifetime. By 1998, the figure had fallen to 1.38, far below the 2.08 needed to replenish the population. According to government estimates, the number of people in Japan will shrink from 126m this year to 105m by 2050.

With the world's longest life expectancy, Japan is also ageing at a record rate. In 20 years, one in four people will be over 64, which will mean fewer taxpaying workers and more benefit-drawing pensioners.

"It's a crisis," one welfare ministry official admitted. Almost every government ministry has set up its own commission or taskforce to address the problem, which will threaten productivity, pension schemes and the health system. Underlining the extreme measures that are being considered, the Keizai Douyukai business lobby has suggested that the government should do more to encourage illegitimate children.

Only 1% of children in Japan are born out of wedlock. This figure, once a source of immense pride, is now being blamed for one of the world's highest rates of abortion.

Politically, taking action is difficult. Apart from the odd outburst - one MP recently called for regional baby quotas - few lawmakers are willing to make a public stand. Memories are still strong of the pre-war militarist government's ban on abortion and its exhortation to women to have children for their country and the then godlike father-figure of the emperor.

Government measures have concentrated on improving childcare services, increasing paternity leave and launching publicity campaigns to encourage work-oriented fathers to take a more active role in child rearing. Parliament recently passed legislation that will double the number of children eligible for benefits.

Under the slogan "Children are the treasure of society", the education ministry plans to put more emphasis on child rearing in the curriculum. To ease the estimated 15m yen (£95,000) cost of putting a child through school - often cited as the main disincentive for having children - it will also boost grants for university students.

Critics say such moves miss the point, which is that Japanese women are educated to a higher standard than men and until they marry, they have a far higher disposable income.

"For women these days, marriage means lowering their living standards. The result is fewer weddings and fewer births," says Sumiko Iwao, a professor at Keio University.

Yayoi Ezaki, one of millions of mothers with a single child, agrees. "The main reason we don't want another child is because they cost so much. The money offered by Bandai is just a drop in the ocean.

"And it doesn't help to be told that we should have more children to look after the country's ageing population. The more I hear that, the less I want another another child. They are going to have such a tough life when they are older."

webTitle: Fatwa plan to kill Iranian president

fields.headline: Fatwa plan to kill Iranian president
fields.trailText: A plan to dispose of Iran's moderate president by clerically authorised murder has been foiled. The would-be assassin was a member of the presidential bodyguard and of the elite Revolutionary Guard who tried to convince senior clerics to issue an edict allowing him to kill President Mohammad Khatami.
fields.body:
A plan to dispose of Iran's moderate president by clerically authorised murder has been foiled. The would-be assassin was a member of the presidential bodyguard and of the elite Revolutionary Guard who tried to convince senior clerics to issue an edict allowing him to kill President Mohammad Khatami.

The plot was foiled by the son of an ayatollah, who called the authorities. It was the latest instance of an attempt to lend religious authority to political violence. Hardliners are increasingly asking traditionalist clerics to endorse murder plots against those regarded as enemies of Islam.

Eight men accused of the attempted assassination of a presidential aide, Saeed Hajjarian, on March 12 are believed to have received a fatwa from a hardline cleric in their religious centre in Shahr-e Rey, a town outside Tehran.

Three were acquitted, and five were convicted and sentenced to between three and 15 years in prison.

Residents of Shahr-e Rey say it is well known that murder plots are concocted in the town's main religious centre, where hundreds of members of the Islamic militia and Revolutionary Guard gather each week to hear hardline clerics preach.

Rogue agents in the intelligence ministry who confessed to murdering secular intellectuals in the late 90s are also believed to have sought fatwas from hardline clerics.

Ayatollah Sadeq Khalkhali, who became known as Iran's hanging judge after the Islamic revolution, said last year that plots to kill perceived enemies were hatched in the Shi'ite city of Qom at the Haqqani school, once the breeding ground of liberal-minded clerics, now a haven for hardliners studying to be theologians.

The loose coalition of hardline clerics and their extremist followers striving for more political power has become more apparent in the last few years.

"An alliance has always existed between conservative clerics and traditionalists in society, but it is more pronounced now," a senior cleric in Qom said.

Ayatollah Mohammad Taqi Mesbah-Yazdi, the leading ideologue of the right, routinely says that violence to uphold religious principles is legitimate.

According to sources close to the president and clerics in Qom, the would-be presidential assassin first contacted Ayatollah Hossein Nouri-Hamadani, who referred him to another cleric he said had higher standing.

When he met the second cleric, Ayatollah Mohammad Fazel-Lankaani, the cleric's son called the authorities.

"This was a self-sacrifice by the son. Now, he will risk having to face the right wing's wrath," a cleric in Qom said.

When President Khatami took power in May 1997 he brought his personal bodyguards from his native province, Yazd, and it is they who are directly in charge of his safety. His would-be assassin, presumed to be in jail, belonged to his second line of defence.

webTitle: Brother and sister lose bid to leave mother in the freezer

fields.headline: Brother and sister lose bid to leave mother in the freezer
fields.trailText: Given the cold shoulder by the French courts, a brother and sister who want to keep their dead mother in a glass-sided deep-freeze in their cellar said yesterday that they would take their case to the European Court of Human Rights.
fields.body:
Given the cold shoulder by the French courts, a brother and sister who want to keep their dead mother in a glass-sided deep-freeze in their cellar said yesterday that they would take their case to the European Court of Human Rights.

"We are suffering an injustice here," said Michel Leroy, 52, who with his sister Joelle, 50, has been fighting to have the body of their mother, Lise, interred in the basement of their house on the French Indian Ocean island of Réunion.

"French law is the toughest in the world in this domain," Mr Leroy said. "Yet all we want to do is return the love she gave us. For people like us, incapable of mourning their mother, this kind of interment would help us face up to the stress. Kept like that she would be dead - but somehow not completely. You could always hope for a scientific leap that would bring her back to life."

On Monday an appeal court in Bordeaux upheld the verdicts of two local lower courts, ruling that "the conservation of a body through freezing is not considered a legitimate method of treating a body in the eyes of the law". French legislation requires that a corpse be either buried or cremated.

"We have lost a battle, but we have not lost the war," said Mr Leroy, a philosophy teacher. "Until now, French justice has interpreted the law strictly. But with European integration, France will have to recognise that its attitude is exaggerated."

In their 20-page statement to the court, Mr and Ms Leroy pointed out that the ancient Egyptians and the Inuits also preserved their dead, and that more than 100 Americans have had their bodies - or parts of them - frozen through the American Cryonics Society.

"Why them and not us?" demanded Mr Leroy, whose mother died last July. He admitted, however, that his legal quest would have to be resolved rapidly. "At the moment, mother's body is refrigerated in the local morgue and the Réunion authorities claim she's a health risk," he said. "We have no time to lose."

fields.headline: Child hurt in Pokemon snatch
fields.trailText: A six-year-old boy suffered a fractured arm after he was pushed and kicked by another boy who was trying to steal his Pokemon cards, Humberside police said yesterday.
fields.body:
A six-year-old boy suffered a fractured arm after he was pushed and kicked by another boy who was trying to steal his Pokemon cards, Humberside police said yesterday.

A spokeswoman said the attacker, aged about nine, tried to grab the cards from the youngster, but failed.

Police were treating the incident in Hull, as attempted robbery.

The spokeswoman added: "The six-year-old boy was taken to Hull Royal infirmary, where it was found that he had sustained a fractured arm. He was not detained."

Police are appealing for information about the incident, which took place in the early evening of last Wednesday. The only description of the nine-year-old boy was that he had blond hair.

The Japanese cartoon series has sparked a craze among youngsters across the world.

Trading cards connected to the show can fetch hundreds of pounds and some schools have banned them from playgrounds to try to prevent bullying.
Press Association

fields.trailText:
Fame spurred teenage murder
Two Spanish girls told an investigating magistrate that they stabbed a 16-year-old friend to death because it was a new experience and would make them famous.
fields.body:
Fame spurred teenage murder
Two Spanish girls told an investigating magistrate that they stabbed a 16-year-old friend to death because it was a new experience and would make them famous.

The girls, aged 16 and 17, were arrested on Sunday in the southern town of San Fernando de Cadiz after the body of Clara Garcia was found with 18 stab wounds. They are being detained on murder charges.

El Pais newspaper said the police found at the girls' home horror stories and cuttings about a 16-year-old Spanish boy jailed for killing his parents and sister with a Samurai sword.
AP, Madrid

Bush march for freed pilots
Five Russian pilots freed by the Unita rebels in Angola have arrived in Zambia after walking for days through the bush.

The Zambian home affairs minister, Peter Machungwa, said they appeared to be in good shape.

The five, flying on contract for aid agencies delivering food to government-held towns, were shot down by Unita forces in May and June last year.
Reuters, Lusaka

Body recovered from town riot
The body of a 20-year-old was delivered to a South African police station yesterday after about 500 teenagers clashed with the police in Alexandra township, north of Johannesburg. The person was said to have been shot and killed during the violence but no further details were given.

The trouble began when teenagers marched to a shop in the township in search of a youth accused of a murder on Monday. Four police officers were wounded and a house was burned.
AP, Alexandra

webTitle: Help at hand on penalty shoot-outs

fields.headline: Help at hand on penalty shoot-outs
fields.trailText: A new sports science centre opening today could make it far less likely that the England football team loses to Germany on penalties.
fields.body:
A new sports science centre opening today could make it far less likely that the England football team loses to Germany on penalties.

The facility, based at Swansea University, aims to help footballers work out how to deceive goalkeepers.

The laboratory can also be used by competitors from a range of sports who want to perfect their techniques.

A project which will analyse how footballers can use their bodies to fool goalkeepers into diving the wrong way at penalties will be one of the first to benefit.

Simon Jenkins, director of sports science at Swansea, said the centre would film players in action with digital cameras and feed the results into a computer. It would enable performers to look at their techniques from every possible angle.

Dr Jenkins said: "The new facility will help bridge the gap between the mental and physical sides of sports."

The laboratory will be used by students of sports science and sports stars needing help.

fields.headline: Stuffed rare birds 'kept illegally'
fields.trailText: A wildlife photographer illegally kept dozens of shot and stuffed rare birds and then burned them to cover his tracks, Liverpool magistrates were told yesterday.
fields.body:
A wildlife photographer illegally kept dozens of shot and stuffed rare birds and then burned them to cover his tracks, Liverpool magistrates were told yesterday.

Dennis Green, 57, also had a collection of rare birds' eggs, including those of golden eagle and osprey, and police who raided his home in April last year found 99 stuffed wild birds, nine of which were seized, Damian Webb, prosecuting, said.

When police returned to Green's house in West Derby, Liverpool, three months later, all 90 remaining birds had been destroyed, he said. About two-thirds of the collection infringed the Wildlife and Countryside Act.

Green told officers he had burned his collection because he did not want them ending up in Liverpool museum. "But the prosecution say he destroyed the specimens because he didn't want police examining them," Mr Webb said.
Press Association The court was also told that Green tried to forge data cards on his rare egg collection so they would predate the 1954 Protection of Birds Act and therefore be lawful. "A lot of the cards refer to dates going back to the 1930s," said Mr Webb, "but the writing was in ballpoint pen _ [which] was not in common use in Europe until 1945 at least."

It was believed to be the first time forensic handwriting analysis has been used for eggshells.

Green denies eight counts of possessing wild birds' eggs, three counts of possessing dead wild birds and one count of possessing items capable of being used to commit an offence.

The trial continues today.

fields.headline: Infertility warning to men drivers
fields.trailText: Men who spend hours driving could be at increased risk of infertility, according to research published today.
fields.body:
Men who spend hours driving could be at increased risk of infertility, according to research published today.

French researchers have found that driving causes the temperature of the scrotum to rise, which can affect the formation of sperm.

Previous research has shown that men who drive for a living have a lower sperm count, more sperm abnormalities and that their partners take longer to conceive.

But scientists have not known why truckers and other professional drivers have more fertility problems.

The new research, published in the journal Human Reproduction, is the first to provide some of the answers.

Researchers in Toulouse attached skin thermometer probes to the scrotums of nine men who first walked in the open air and then drove for 160 minutes in a car. During the first 20 minutes of driving, the average scrotal temperature rose from 34.2C to 35.5C. In the next two hours, the temperature rose to 36.2C before stabilising.

The average temperature while driving was two degrees higher than when the men were walking.

Roger Mieusset, head of the research, said: "The increase in scrotal temperature could be one of the strongest pieces of evidence yet to explain why the partners of occupational car drivers take longer to conceive."
Press Association

webTitle: World needs nation states, says Hague

fields.headline: World needs nation states, says Hague
fields.trailText: William Hague last night moved to buck the integrationist trend in Europe when he argued that increasing globalisation made the survival of the nation state vital to freedom and prosperity.
fields.body:
William Hague last night moved to buck the integrationist trend in Europe when he argued that increasing globalisation made the survival of the nation state vital to freedom and prosperity.

On the day when a Whitehall survey suggested that Britain was starting to lose its attractions as the main EU destination for inward investment from the US and Japan, the Conservative leader mocked the concept that the nation state was dead.

"The very forces that are always cited as making the nation obsolete are in fact those that make it essential. In the age of the internet and of global free trade it is the small, flexible unit that will thrive," Mr Hague told a business audience in Israel.

Joining the eurozone would end Britain's freedom to set a free enterprise example in Europe, he said. But the Whitehall survey, which alarmed pro-euro ministers yesterday, said that the UK's share of inward investment slipped in 1999 from 28% to 24%, while France's rose from 12% to 18%.

Downing Street derided the figures and said that the Invest in Britain Bureau would show "a very very different picture" as still-confidential investments were made public.

Coincidentally yesterday the UK Independence party claimed a breakthrough at the expense of Mr Hague's Euro-sceptic strategy when Roger Knapman, a government whip under John Major, quit the Tories to join the hardline anti-European UKIP.

The former MP, who lost his Stroud seat at the 1997 general election, told a Westminster press conference he could no longer accept the "bogus premise" behind the Tory slogan about "being in Europe, not run by Europe" - not an option on offer, he claimed.

webTitle: Muslims step up attacks in Indonesia

fields.headline: Muslims step up attacks in Indonesia
fields.standfirst: Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: Hundreds of Muslim extremist fighters have attacked several predominantly Christian villages in eastern Indonesia's spice islands in the last two days, killing 50 people and injuring more than 200, the military said yesterday.
fields.body:
Hundreds of Muslim extremist fighters have attacked several predominantly Christian villages in eastern Indonesia's spice islands in the last two days, killing 50 people and injuring more than 200, the military said yesterday.

Lieutenant Colonel Sukarwo, the commander of Indonesian troops in the northern Moluccas, said up to 1,000 people armed with guns, grenades and swords attacked the villages of Makete and Duma in the Galela district on Halmahera island just before dawn on Monday.

"They came down from the hills and by sea in a coordinated assault," he said. "People were caught by surprise and many could do nothing. They were killed in their beds or hacked to pieces if they tried to defend themselves."

Others were burned alive when more than 150 buildings in the two villages were set alight. Some Christians fought back and the 44 dead included a handful of the raiders. A local church leader, Reverend Biso, said the death toll was 50.

On Thursday 35 died in a similar assault on Halmahera.

The regional military commander, Brigadier General Max Tamaela, said last night that the Muslims attacked several more villages in Galela yesterday. In Dokulamo at least seven people were killed, more than a dozen injured and many houses torched.

Local media quoted witnesses as saying that there appeared to be no concerted effort to hunt the attackers.

Brigadier General Tamaela has deployed hundreds of reinforcements in the district, issued a shoot-on-sight order and asked the navy to tighten their blockade of the northern Moluccas.

All the attacks are thought to have been coordinated by members of Laskar Jihad, a militant Islamic organisation based in Java that has infiltrated more than 2,000 fighters and arms into the Moluccas to intensify the holy war against the Christians.

"There are also reports that some army deserters might be involved," Col Sukarwo said. Dozens of soldiers and police officers have deserted during the inter-communal conflict, which has been going on for 18 months, to join one side or the other.

Some units have been accused of being partisan, with the police tending to side with the Christians and the army with the Muslims. At least 2,500 people have died in the fighting, including at least 120 since the Laskar Jihad force arrived three weeks ago.

Rev Biso said: "We are powerless to defend ourselves against such a force and as the military have not sent enough soldiers here we are at the mercy of the Laskar Jihad."

He reiterated a plea for UN intervention in the conflict, saying: "Unless international troops come here we will be wiped out. It is clear the military and the government are not going to defend us."

The Indonesian government has rejected such requests, saying that the crisis is an internal problem.

Muslim leaders have remained silent in the wake of the latest violence. The leader of Laskar Jihad, Jafar Umar Thalib, is rumoured to have close links with the former dictator Suharto, who was placed under house arrest on Monday to speed up a corruption investigation against him.

fields.headline: Skinny models 'send unhealthy message'
fields.standfirst:
Eating disorder warning as BMA urges media 'realism'

Comment: Jessica Cartner-Morley
fields.trailText: British doctors yesterday called on the media to use female models with more realistically proportioned bodies instead of "abnormally thin" women who contributed to the rise in the numbers of people suffering from eating disorders.
fields.body:
British doctors yesterday called on the media to use female models with more realistically proportioned bodies instead of "abnormally thin" women who contributed to the rise in the numbers of people suffering from eating disorders.

A report by the British Medical Association claimed that the promotion of rake-thin models such as Kate Moss and Jodie Kidd was creating a distorted body image which young women tried to imitate. It suggested that the media can trigger and perpetuate the disease.

"Female models are becoming thinner at a time when women are becoming heavier, and the gap between the ideal body shape and reality is wider than ever," said the report. "There is a need for a more realistic body shape to be shown on television and in fashion magazines."

The report, which says young women look at thin models and see themselves as fat in comparison, calls on broadcasters and magazine publishers to use a more realistic range of body images. It also suggests society should put more emphasis on better eating and health to increase awareness about the impact of poor nutrition and dieting on young women.

At a conference to launch Eating Disorders, Body Image and the Media, Vivienne Nathanson of the BMA said: "Let's see many different sizes and shapes reflected in the images of women we see in the different types of media. Let's play up the fact that it is not shape that matters. It is health that matters."

The report is published just weeks before Britain hosts a "thin summit" on June 21 to tackle the issue of the media and body image. An estimated 7m women and 1m men in Britain suffer from eating disorders. Anorexia affects up to 2% of British women aged between 15 and 30, and between six and 10 of every 100 patients die as a result of their illness.

The report concludes: "The media can boost self-esteem where it is providing examples of a variety of body shapes, roles and routes of achievement for young men and women. However, it often tends to portray a limited number of body shapes and messages linking external appearance with success."

After compiling two years' research, the BMA found that young women are now dieting at an increasingly earlier age and that this is an important precipitant factor in the development of eating disorders. The report points out that eating disorders are a mostly western phenomenon and that fewer Asian and black women apparently suffer from them. It says that in young men, perceived body image is "a crucial factor in the onset of the illness".

The report adds: "Advertising, in particular, may influence young people's perception of fashion and beauty and attitudes towards food. Young women may compare themselves to extremely thin models, working in the fashion industry or advertising products, and perceive themselves as fat in comparison, rather than healthy and attractive."

In 1998, a survey by the Bread for Life campaign, cited by the Eating Disorders Association, showed that 89% of women between 18 and 24 wanted more "average sized" models used in magazines.

Yesterday, however, the London-based Premier agency, which represents Naomi Campbell and Claudia Schiffer, said women who bought fashion magazines featuring thin models were as much to blame as their editors and the advertisers who used them. Agencies, advertisers and magazines were only responding to consumer demand.

"Advertisers, magazines and agencies supply the image that consumers want to see," said a spokesman. "Statistics have repeatedly shown that if you stick a beautiful skinny girl on the cover of a magazine you sell more copies.

"Agencies would say that we supply the women the advertisers, our clients, want. The clients would say that they are selling a product and responding to consumer demand. At the end of the day, it is a business and the fact is that these models sell the products.

Useful links:

 BMA report on eating disorders and the media
 Eating Disorders Association

fields.headline: Student rebels were 'frighteningly radical'
fields.standfirst:
Secret government report described young militants across western Europe in 1968 as 'looking for revolution as an aim in itself'

Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: A secret intelligence report drawn up to assess the threat from the May 1968 international student revolt warned the cabinet that a "shallow but destructive explosion" was to be expected in Britain "in the fairly near future".
fields.body:
A secret intelligence report drawn up to assess the threat from the May 1968 international student revolt warned the cabinet that a "shallow but destructive explosion" was to be expected in Britain "in the fairly near future".

British rebel student groups fuelled by nihilistic Marcusian philosophy were "frighteningly radical, badly lacking in theory, but dead-set on violence", according to the secret assessment for the cabinet's "anti-communism (home) official working group" chaired by Sir Burke Trend.

Whitehall files, released yesterday at the public record office, also show that the British government killed off, behind the scenes, a Council of Europe proposal at the peak of the 1968 riots to hold a Europe-wide summit between student leaders and the authorities. British officials were accusing their European counterparts of a "crisis of nerve" in the face of student unrest.

The report, drawn up by the Foreign Office's information research department, a shadowy anti-communist intelligence outfit, says the revolutionary student element in Britain was confined to small groups and individuals associated with the Radical Student Alliance, which was formed at the end of 1966 by Fergus Nicholson, student organiser of the British Communist party, a number of young communists, young liberals and a Trotskyist group which controlled the National Association of Labour Student Organisations.

Its purpose - in which it had little success - was said to be to wrest control from the moderates who had led the National Union of Students for many years. The RSA had been involved in the organisation of "most of the recent protest demonstrations at British universities".

The report says: "Under the influence of Trotskyists and Syndicalists, the RSA was concerned with the Vietnam Solidarity Campaign [another revolutionary Trotskyist organisation] in the violent demonstrations against the American embassy in March, and following the shooting of [Rudi] Dutschke in the demonstrations at the Germany embassy in April. It has regular contacts with the West German extreme leftwing Socialist Students League - which sent a strong arm delegation to Grosvenor Square."

The IRD report said that 100 members of the German SDS, led by Dutschke, had played a leading and organised part in the Grosvenor Square riot in front of the American embassy in London on March 17 1968. The German group were said to be the "acknowledged experts in methods of riot against the police and [they] send homemade Molotov cocktails and disciplined gangs to take part in militant demonstrations across Europe. Some of these activists are trained to attack police cordons in phalanx formation - a technique believed to have been evolved by Japanese student militants."

"It is generally known that Tariq Ali and David Robinson, secretary of the Vietnam Solidarity Campaign, which organised this demonstration, attended the international conference on Vietnam convened by the SDS in Berlin in February 1968, and there made contact with Dutschke, no doubt in order to make the necessary arrangements."

The report goes on to say that the VSC had links with the Trotskyist Fourth International, based in Paris, which had a network of contacts through which Trotskyist student militants kept in touch with each other. British student militants took part in riots in Bonn, Berlin and the revolt in the Sorbonne, Paris.

The IRD report also identified an influence from the American New Left in British student protesters saying many of them enjoyed "dollar remittances from home which makes them relatively prosperous in countries with devalued currencies". The report suggests the student movement was characterised by a disillusion with traditional ideologies and party politics - including communism.

"The militants look for revolution as an aim in itself. They turn to the exponents of revolution for their inspiration - Castro, Che Guevera, Mao and Ho Chi Minh - rather than to the ideologies which inspired their revolutions.

"If they have an ideological bible it consists of the work of Professor Herbert Marcuse, One-Dimensional Man. Marcuse is a 70 year old German Marxist professor ... His book has a simple theme: the complete rejection of the existing order ... The Marcusian philosophy is essentially destructive: it offers no clear model for a new order after the destruction of existing society. But young idealists who see a need for radical change, but no means to effect it, are ready to take first things first. The extent to which they are likely to carry this nihilistic philosophy into adult life will depend largely on the extent to which they can achieve satisfying careers when they leave university - hence the limited appeal of Marcusian philosophy to scientists."

Whitehall refused to be too alarmed by the prospects for student revolt in Britain and the broad mass of students reacted against the violence in Grosvenor Square. "There are seeds of trouble in the survival of Victorian ideas of student discipline, and in dissatisfaction with the level of student grants," the report said. The intelligence services regarded "the threat to the west presented by student protest" as a "potentially dangerous adjunct" to the communist subversion of west European morale and security.

But they also acknowledged the frustrations which gave rise to student protest in Britain were less acute than elsewhere and suggested more thought should be given to personal relations between university staff and students.

The report says: "Under the influence of Trotskyists and Syndicalists, the RSA was concerned with the Vietnam Solidarity Campaign [another revolutionary Trotskyist organisation] in the violent demonstrations against the American embassy in March, and following the shooting of [Rudi] Dutschke in the demonstrations at the Germany embassy in April. It has regular contacts with the West German extreme leftwing Socialist Students League - which sent a strong arm delegation to Grosvenor Square." The IRD report said that 100 members of the German SDS, led by Dutschke, had played a leading and organised part in the Grosvenor Square riot in front of the American embassy in London on March 17 1968. The German group were said to be the "acknowledged experts in methods of riot against the police and [they] send homemade Molotov cocktails and disciplined gangs to take part in militant demonstrations across Europe. Some of these activists are trained to attack police cordons in phalanx formation - a technique believed to have been evolved by Japanese student militants." "It is generally known that Tariq Ali and David Robinson, secretary of the Vietnam Solidarity Campaign, which organised this demonstration, attended the international conference on Vietnam convened by the SDS in Berlin in February 1968, and there made contact with Dutschke, no doubt in order to make the necessary arrangements." The report goes on to say that the VSC had links with the Trotskyist Fourth International, based in Paris, which had a network of contacts through which Trotskyist student militants kept in touch with each other. British student militants took part in riots in Bonn, Berlin and the revolt in the Sorbonne, Paris. The IRD report also identified an influence from the American New Left in British student protesters saying many of them enjoyed "dollar remittances from home which makes them relatively prosperous in countries with devalued currencies". The report suggests the student movement was characterised by a disillusion with traditional ideologies and party politics - including communism. "The militants look for revolution as an aim in itself. They turn to the exponents of revolution for their inspiration - Castro, Che Guevera, Mao and Ho Chi Minh - rather than to the ideologies which inspired their revolutions. "If they have an ideological bible it consists of the work of Professor Herbert Marcuse, One-Dimensional Man. Marcuse is a 70 year old German Marxist professor ... His book has a simple theme: the complete rejection of the existing order ... The Marcusian philosophy is essentially destructive: it offers no clear model for a new order after the destruction of existing society. But young idealists who see a need for radical change, but no means to effect it, are ready to take first things first. The extent to which they are likely to carry this nihilistic philosophy into adult life will depend largely on the extent to which they can achieve satisfying careers when they leave university - hence the limited appeal of Marcusian philosophy to scientists." Whitehall refused to be too alarmed by the prospects for student revolt in Britain and the broad mass of students reacted against the violence in Grosvenor Square. "There are seeds of trouble in the survival of Victorian ideas of student discipline, and in dissatisfaction with the level of student grants," the report said. The intelligence services regarded "the threat to the west presented by student protest" as a "potentially dangerous adjunct" to the communist subversion of west European morale and security. But they also acknowledged the frustrations which gave rise to student protest in Britain were less acute than elsewhere and suggested more thought should be given to personal relations between university staff and students.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
Say what you will about Neil Hamilton, he knows how to play his part. With no apparent intention of repaying any of the £2m he owes, Neil sustains the poverty-stricken image with verve and style . . . by going to Sainsbury's and buying not one, not two, not three but four cases of champagne! Admittedly the own-brand wine was half price at £5.99, but 48 bottles . . . it doesn't really fit the urchin boy in rags image, now does it? A furious Laura Osborne of Mottram St Andrew, who found Sainsbury's almost out of stock after Neil's raid, writes to the Wilmslow Express newspaper to ask: "Does the champagne lifestyle for the Hamilton's never stop?" It is a theme taken up with relish by Neil's chief creditor. "Up to his neck in debt, but still able to knock back the bubbly," says Mohamed Al Fayed. "At least he's down to non-vintage now - that must hurt. Who says there's no justice?" You do, actually, Mr Fayed. After all, you're the one whistling for £2m while Neil and Christine clink flutes.

Stupidest MP 2000 title favourite and defending champion David Winnick is in touch again, faxing extracts from Hansard recording his own priceless contributions to democracy concerning Sierra Leone (a country he sometimes mixes up with Sri Lanka). David's point is that the full text of a letter referred to here yesterday "would show that, when I consider it appropriate, I do vote against the government or abstain accordingly". No doubt, David, and when we get around to the Sycophantic MP 2000 contest (yes, Ben Bradshaw, your time will come) the fierce independence of your thinking will be taken into full account.

Meanwhile, a secondary competition to find the thickest member of the government is also being considered. Geoff Hoon is a highly fancied runner, and a peculiar piece of pre- election idiocy by him will be considered here tomorrow.

I am staggered by the conclusion to Eben Black's Sunday Times article about ill-feeling between weirdo chancellor Gordon Brown and colleagues, particularly my craic-loving friend O' Mandy Mandelson. "Relations between them are so poor that yesterday the chancellor's camp claimed Mandelson's supporters were behind a press report claiming Brown had parted from his girlfriend Sarah Macaulay," wrote Mr Black, referring to items written here last week. "Far from denying the allegation, Mandelson's allies found Brown's fears amusing." What, the idea that this column is controlled by O'Mandy ... they though that was funny? I see. As for the original source of the story, which I believe to be true despite denials, let me repeat that the source was as close to the weirdo as can be. (O'Mandy, is that OK? If not, I can do more tomorrow. MN)

It's intriguing to speculate how the latest memo from uncharlatan focus group expert Philip Gould reached the front pages. This document, which appears to warn that Mr Tony and the boys are not perceived as quite repressive enough to counter Mr Hague's witterings on race and asylum, can only have been sent to Number 10. And yet here are its contents published in detail, without a word of complaint from Downing Street. If you didn't know better, you might almost imagine that this was a ruse to prepare the ground for a lurch to the law and order right. We shall see, we shall see.

Mark Thomas rings to make a public apology to Robin Cook. Last week, Mark was rebuked by the Broadcasting Standard Council for being grossly rude about Cookie and his ethical foreign policy on Channel 4. But that was then. "It was only when I saw photographs of 14-year-olds in Sierra Leone supplied with British guns that I realised what an ethical foreign policy was all about," Mark says. "I'm now willing to apologise to Mr Cook for describing him as evil little corporate knob-polishing, hypocritical lying scum. Did you get all that? That's evil little ..."

webTitle: Government tapping of phone calls between UK and Ireland challenged

fields.headline: Government tapping of phone calls between UK and Ireland challenged
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The government is being taken to the European human rights court over allegations that the security and intelligence agencies have been engaged in the wholesale tapping of telephone conversations between Britain and Ireland.
fields.body:
The government is being taken to the European human rights court over allegations that the security and intelligence agencies have been engaged in the wholesale tapping of telephone conversations between Britain and Ireland.

It has refused to deny claims, first made last year, that it tapped the phones from a tower at Capenhurst in Cheshire.

The tower - described by the Ministry of Defence as an "electronic test facility" - intercepted phone calls carried by radio microwave between British Telecom relay stations at Gwaenysgor, Clywd, and Pale Heights, near Chester.

The stations carried Ireland's telecommunications links through Britain.

The government has never denied claims about the purpose of the Capenhurst tower which were first made by Channel 4 News in July last year.

Lawyers representing the Irish Council for Civil Liberties, Liberty, its British counterpart, and British Irish Rights Watch, claim the interceptions breached article 8 of the European human rights convention guaranteeing the right to privacy.

The Capenhurst tower, they said, had the capacity to intercept 10,000 simultaneous phone channels from Dublin to London and elsewhere. Tapped conversations included legally privileged material such as discussions between human rights groups and individuals who sought their assistance, they said.

They pointed to a section of the 1985 Interception of Communications Act which allows the security and intelligence agencies to seek warrants enabling them to tap conversations without referring to a specific target or address.

The act allows the home secretary to issue a warrant covering any information the agencies say they need to carry out their functions - so-called "certified" material - from "external communications".

However, they can only gather this material by intercepting other conversations and information passing through the communications link.

"The procedure ... by its nature requires all material, regardless of whether it falls within the scope of the purposes defined in the warrants or not, to be intercepted," Richard Clayton, counsel for the human rights groups, said in their submission to the European court.

He added: "The material is then examined after the event in order to discover whether it falls within the scope of the warrant." He said the 1985 act effectively allows interception for "any purpose".

The Capenhurst tower is redundant and up for sale and Ireland has a new fibre optic telecommunications system. Early this year, David Andrews, the former Irish foreign minister, said he accepted assurances from Robin Cook that Britain was not involved in indiscriminate or blanket tapping of Irish communications.

Minutes of an Irish security committee, released under the country's freedom of information act, concluded there was "no firm evidence available to the Irish authorities that commercial telecommunications traffic originating in or destined for this country has been intercepted in a systematic or extra-legal way".

However, members of the committee argued that interception technology in possession of many countries, including Britain, suggests that illegal bugging is going on.

The human rights groupsbringing the test case argue that indiscriminate bugging is being allowed by existing English law in contravention of the human rights convention.

John Wadham, director of Liberty, said yesterday that the loophole in the 1985 act will remain in the new regulation of investigatory powers bill which gives the security and intelligence agencies sweeping new bugging powers.

webTitle: Mr Bolkestein begins opening the mail

fields.headline: Mr Bolkestein begins opening the mail
fields.standfirst: News Analysis Europe's competition drive delivers tough challenge to Post Office
fields.trailText: News Analysis Europe's competition drive delivers tough challenge to Post Office
fields.body:
The chill wind of liberalisation is sweeping across Europe's postal sector. The Royal Mail's distinctive red post boxes may be the only choice on the street for now but it is only a matter of time before rivals get in on the act. Some 1.7m jobs across Europe are at stake in what is likely to be a bloody battle between modernisers and traditionalists. Yesterday, the opening salvoes were fired in Brussels.

Frits Bolkestein, the Dutchman with responsibility for regulating the £53bn sector, has drawn up proposals to open a further fifth of Europe's postal market to competition and reduce post office monopolies. Yesterday this plan won the backing of the European commission. The move has far-reaching implications for Europe's postal service, just 3% of which is classified as being open to competition.

It also marks the beginning of what many analysts believe is an inevitable process which will see postal services follow in the wake of the telecoms industry by succumbing to globalisation. A handful of big players is expected to emerge and the British post office hopes to be one of them. However, competition is fierce. Partial liberalisation may be hard enough for the Post Office to swallow but Mr Bolkestein reckons that things can only get tougher for monopoly providers.

"In the fullness of time I think the postal services will be completely open to competition. Trying to preserve the status quo is not a realistic option," he warned yesterday.

His plans still need to be approved by a notoriously fickle European Parliament as well as by EU trade ministers and there is likely to be vigorous lobbying on both sides of the debate. The Post Office said prices would rise for the consumer. "The commission's proposals would inevitably lead to higher prices for mail and they would dramatically hit investment in new technology aimed at improving customer quality of service. The commission are taking a leap of faith. They are going too far, too quickly. The proposals would eliminate the profit of Royal Mail. There would be no money for investment."

French opposition is certain to be fierce as the large public sector trade unions mobilise against what they perceive to be a threat to members' jobs. The plans may be watered down but some kind of market-opening legislation is likely to emerge from the process.

The drivers for change are hard to resist. The increasing popularity of email is forcing post offices to embrace the internet. The European commission's determination to give consumers in the 15-member EU exactly the same choices and services by harmonising legislation is also a factor. Greater competition and the breaking down of market barriers comprise the theme of the year.

The tiny segment of the European postal market which has already been opened to competition has attracted enormous interest. US groups Federal Express and UPS have already moved in on the £17bn parcel delivery market and are pleading to be allowed to do more.

Post offices across Europe are therefore busy transforming themselves into lean commercial operators and taking stakes in as many foreign operators as they can. The Post Office already owns German Parcel, the third-largest private carrier in Germany, and has joint-venture agreements with TNT Post Group and Singapore Post. This week it announced a joint venture with Swedish CityMail to deliver letters in Stockholm, Gothenburg and Malmo.

"The overriding ambition of the Post Office is to become a complete distribution company with global reach," it proclaims on its website. The Post Office is reckoned, however, to be a late arrival. Continental rivals such as Deutsche Post have already built up large power bases across Europe and Sweden's postal market has been completely liberalised for some time.

Change when it comes will also be painful and the Post Office trade unions have warned that as many as 50,000 of the Royal Mail's 200,000 jobs could be lost if the EC proposals are implemented. Mr Bolkestein says competition will create more jobs. "Any decrease in jobs in the public sector will be more than compensated for by new jobs in the private sector." The fact that Europe's postal sector is expanding at a rate of 2% to 3% per year, he adds, gives grounds for optimism.

Under the commission's proposals the delivery of letters weighing over 50 grams or costing two and a half times the rate of standard postage would be thrown open to competition. The threshold is 350 grams and the Post Office has already warned the commission not to reduce this below 150 grams. Its chief executive, John Roberts, believes the very concept of universal service and guaranteed delivery and collection of letters is threatened.

Again Mr Bolkestein disagrees: "Everybody agrees it [universal service] has to be preserved. Users, including those in remote areas will be protected."

The introduction of full competition in Sweden did not, he argues, affect universal service and in fact Sweden "has the highest quality postal service in the EU". National regulators can attach stringent conditions to any postal licences they award, and the concept of universal service is guaranteed in EU law. There is also a fund which operators can be forced to pay into in order to subsidise commercially unattractive services.

Mr Bolkestein believes he has all the answers.

webTitle: A Cambridge tutorial on the Laura Spence affair

fields.headline: A Cambridge tutorial on the Laura Spence affair
fields.trailText: By far the most cogent explanation of how private schools have increased their grip on Oxbridge admissions (Letters, May 30) since their post-war low point of 38% in the late 1960s has been provided by the prime minister's education adviser, Andrew Adonis (A Class Act: The Myth of Britain's Classless Society, 1997).
fields.body:
By far the most cogent explanation of how private schools have increased their grip on Oxbridge admissions (Letters, May 30) since their post-war low point of 38% in the late 1960s has been provided by the prime minister's education adviser, Andrew Adonis (A Class Act: The Myth of Britain's Classless Society, 1997).

Since the mid 1970s, as Adonis shows, the consumer power unleashed by the middle class flight from Labour's comprehensives led to the revitalisation of the moribund mass of private schools. These have now replaced Crosland's "fucking grammar schools" as the single main source of Oxbridge admissions. I do not advocate the return of selection in state schools; but simply point out the perverse consequences of retaining an unequal system that is segregated by wealth and income - that is, by class. According to Blair's adviser, "Universities are fashioned by the schools that supply them... Far from bringing the classes together, England's schools - private and state - are now a force for rigorous segregation".

I think I am now beginning to understand the third way. Does it involve approaching problems from the wrong end?
Dr Geoffrey Ingham
Faculty of Social and Political Sciences, Cambridge

 An admissions tutor admitted to me how impossible it is not to judge applicants according to how well he thought they would "fit in with the Cambridge scene". Others delight in complaining that the problems are all external: if only there were no public schools; if only the government gave enough funding to the education sector; if only we could break down the preconceptions of all those students who don't apply.

For all their goodwill, academics at my own institution seem unwilling to accept that they may have any degree of influence; or that they play any part whatsoever in perpetuating the social divisions that already exist within our education system. Perhaps this is the first preconception that should be broken down.
Tristan Jones
President, Cambridge University Students' Union

 A friend, from a private school, was rejected by Queens College, Cambridge in 1998. He is now at Yale. I am firmly egalitarian, but I do not believe that the government should be worrying about the privileged few, of whom Laura Spence is undoubtedly one. She, like my friend or I, is privileged by virtue of being intelligent. Whether she goes to Oxford or Harvard is irrelevant.

Gordon Brown should be trying to provide money for the thousands of underprivileged children who live below the poverty line, and trying to raise standards in state education (by raising both spending and tax). He should help those who don't have a chance in life, not those who have a choice between top universities. The government should be more interested in the effects of their policies than in their popularity.
Philip Woolfe
Peterhouse, Cambridge

fields.headline: The beer drinkers' friend
fields.trailText: I take issue with comments (Finance Notebook, May 26) about the sale of Whitbread's brewing interests to the Belgian company, Interbrew. Whitbread has no record as the traditional beer drinker's friend
fields.body:
I take issue with comments (Finance Notebook, May 26) about the sale of Whitbread's brewing interests to the Belgian company, Interbrew. Whitbread has no record as the traditional beer drinker's friend. In 1975 Whitbread operated at least 17 breweries around the country, several producing sometimes superb cask-conditioned beers. All have been axed except two, the Salmesbury megakeggery, and Castle Eden, saved by a management buy-out in 1998.

Interbrew, meanwhile, while it is perfectly happy to push out bland eurobrews such as Jupiler, and has closed a considerable number of formerly independent Belgian breweries itself, produces a range of "minority interest" beers in Belgium. Traditional British cask ale is probably safer in Interbrew's hands than in Whitbread's.
Martyn Cornell
Twickenham, Middlesex

 It is true that the big brewers are moving out; and taking their uninteresting and homogenous beer with them. fields.bodyText: I take issue with comments (Finance Notebook, May 26) about the sale of Whitbread's brewing interests to the Belgian company, Interbrew. Whitbread has no record as the traditional beer drinker's friend. In 1975 Whitbread operated at least 17 breweries around the country, several producing sometimes superb cask-conditioned beers. All have been axed except two, the Salmesbury megakeggery, and Castle Eden, saved by a management buy-out in 1998. Interbrew, meanwhile, while it is perfectly happy to push out bland eurobrews such as Jupiler, and has closed a considerable number of formerly independent Belgian breweries itself, produces a range of "minority interest" beers in Belgium. webTitle: Hizbullah success puts peace in jeopardy, says Arafat

fields.headline: Hizbullah success puts peace in jeopardy, says Arafat
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The sight of the mighty Israeli army retreating under fire from the Hizbullah guerrillas of south Lebanon exercises a powerful hold on the Palestinian imagination and could rebound on the peace process, Yasser Arafat has warned.
fields.body:
The sight of the mighty Israeli army retreating under fire from the Hizbullah guerrillas of south Lebanon exercises a powerful hold on the Palestinian imagination and could rebound on the peace process, Yasser Arafat has warned.

In a meeting in the West Bank town of Ramallah, the Palestinian leader confided to Israel's environment minister, Dalia Itzik, that his room for compromise in negotiations was shrinking because his people were galvanised by images of Israel's hasty exodus after 22 years of occupation, according to a report in the newspaper Ma'ariv yesterday.

"You have to understand what sort of pressure is being placed on me by the public," Mr Arafat was reported as saying. "My public perceives Hizbullah to be heroes who succeeded in getting the Israeli Defence Forces out of Lebanon and believe that this is the route we should take as well."

He added: "The pressure being applied on me is coming from every direction. The Palestinian people want to see results."

The Israeli and Palestinian authorities got a taste of that impatience earlier this month when the West Bank and Gaza exploded into the most serious unrest in four years.

More ominously, those tensions first erupted in February when the French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, was forced to flee Bir Zeit University under a hail of stones by protesters incensed that he had described the militia as "terrorists" during a state dinner in Jerusalem.

Since Israel's departure from south Lebanon last week, the Hizbullah guerrillas have been feted as victors. In the West Bank town of Hebron, protesters burned the Israeli flags, and invited the Lebanese guerrilla force to attack Tel Aviv.

Aside from the blow to Israeli prestige, Hizbullah's success puts Mr Arafat in an awkward position. The Hizbullah leader, Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah, has been exceedingly critical of his decision to negotiate with Israel. He told al-Jazeera television, the Qatar-based satellite network, that violence was the only effective way of getting Israel to give up occupied lands.

He also accused Mr Arafat of reducing the West Bank and Gaza to Israeli "buffer states" dedicated only to serving Israel's security interests.

Within the West Bank and Gaza, many now believe that images of a jubilant Hizbullah could raise tensions to breaking point. Most Palestinians are frustrated with the slow progress of negotiations with Israel.

There is also precious little to show for their willingness to give up their intifada - bar deepening poverty as a result of Israel shutting out thousands of Palestinian workers. In areas under Mr Arafat's control, there is growing anger at the corruption and incompetence of an administration which often flouts its own laws.

"In the last six years since Oslo it has become quite obvious that the harvest of the peace process has been a de facto apartheid which nobody could ever have dreamed of. It is a nightmare," said Raji Sourani, a prominent Gaza lawyer, and director of the Palestinian Centre for Human Rights. "So now people see that the peace process cannot deliver, and they are remembering the potential of what they did a few years ago - not with rifles, but with stones."

Opinion polls show that Palestinian support for armed struggle remains high at about 40%. However, support for the peace process remains steady at about 70%.

Khalil Shikaki, director of the Palestinian Centre for Policy and Research in Ramallah said: "A lot of people will believe that inflicting pain and suffering on the Israelis could be productive. However ... if there is progress in the peace process, the belief in violence may fade away."

He argues that many Palestinians may be heartened by the way the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, fulfilled his election promise to withdraw.

The most effective way to keep a lid on tensions in the West Bank and Gaza would be progress in negotiations.

Yesterday, Mr Arafat said negotiators would not be able to meet a June 23 deadline for producing a blueprint agreement for a final settlement.

"The peace process has stopped completely, in both the open track and in the secret track being held in Stockholm. We have reached an impasse," he said.

Palestinian National Authority

fields.headline: Pitched out
fields.trailText: Typical spring bank holiday weather forced us to give up on our camping holiday in East Anglia and come home early, In previous years the same trip has often been an endurance test.
fields.body:
Typical spring bank holiday weather forced us to give up on our camping holiday in East Anglia and come home early, In previous years the same trip has often been an endurance test.

At present we have two holidays in May, hard on the heels of Easter, followed by a three month gap before the next one. Would it not make sense to move this holiday to the end of June? I am sure the weather would be more reliable.
Eva Smith
Huddersfield eva.smith@lineone.net

fields.headline: Ulster needs opposition
fields.trailText: Peter Preston makes a prescient, and pressing, point about the role of the opposition in the Northern Ireland assembly (Peace first. Then normality, May 29) . The measure of any democracy is to be found not only in the quality and efficacy of the government, but also in the quality and efficacy of the opposition.
fields.body:
Peter Preston makes a prescient, and pressing, point about the role of the opposition in the Northern Ireland assembly (Peace first. Then normality, May 29) . The measure of any democracy is to be found not only in the quality and efficacy of the government, but also in the quality and efficacy of the opposition.

The Good Friday Agreement correctly establishes a system of government that may be characterised as institutionalised inclusion. This should certainly obtain in the transitional phase. It has costs, though, for the parties who take up office in the four party executive.

It means they can never again go to their respective electorates and suggest that they will be able to fully implement their personal party manifestos. (Though this may be no bad thing.)

Every party wish list will be tempered by at least two others, and the resultant programme of government will be at best a confluent compromise, at worst a confused collage.

This system of including al most all the parties in government also has potential costs for democracy.

We witnessed, in the pilot run of the executive, a congelation of power around the big two parties - the SDLP and the UUP - which saw, among other things, the abolition of a scrutiny committee on equality. Perhaps more worryingly, there were attempts to reduce the amount of Short money to be provided to parties in opposition.

The Agreement is silent on the nature of opposition voices in the assembly. Our past experience, as one of those small voices, has proved that we are now, more than ever, vital - to provide a constructive critique and challenge our permanent coalition government.

If Peter Preston's vision of "normal" politics is to have any chance of emerging, non-executive parties need to be able to function effectively. And that means they have to be properly resourced. There is nothing wrong with a coalition government, but when, as happened in January, the government cultivates clientalism without taking account of opposition voices, the quality of the democracy is diluted. We have come too far to accept second best now.

Kate Fearon
Northern Ireland Women's Coalition, Stormont, Belfast
kate.fearon@virgin.net

 Ronan Bennett (Brute force, May 27) argues "there is too much remembering and casting up of the past", and then proceeds to tar the Royal Ulster Constabulary with the brush of John Nixon's sectarian killings of the 1920s.

While the RUC have been guilty of corruption and human rights violations, officers have also shown immense bravery, particularly in protecting public security against terrorist attacks. Over 300 RUC officers have died in the "Troubles", many at the hands of Provisionals in attacks as bad as any perpetratd by Nixon.
Jon Moran
Bury, Lancs

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Our leader, The French take the reins, page 21, yesterday, implied that the French take over the presidency of the European Union "this week". In fact, the handover procedure starts on June 1 and the French take over from the Portuguese on July 1.
fields.body:
Our leader, The French take the reins, page 21, yesterday, implied that the French take over the presidency of the European Union "this week". In fact, the handover procedure starts on June 1 and the French take over from the Portuguese on July 1.

In a report headed Labour in turmoil over candidate selection, page 9, yesterday, we said that Judith Church won Dagenham in a 1994 byelection after the death of Joan [sic] Richardson. In fact Ms Church succeeded Bryan Gould. Jo Richardson was MP for Barking from 1974 until her death in 1994.

In our Media cover story about the new editor of the News of the World, Rebekah Wade, May 29, an over zealous spelling check changed the name of one of her friends, Judy Maguire, to Judy Mug gier; and in the same piece for the same reason Jean Ritchie appeared as Jean Russia. Apologies all round.

In a piece headed Final curtain for seaside variety, page 9, May 29, we made numerous references to Steve Hayler as the source of our information, calling him the author of a report "on cultural trends". So in a way he is, but what we meant to say was that his report appears in Cultural Trends (issue 34), a journal published by the Policy Studies Institute.

The photograph of the interior of the Congregation of Jacob Synagogue in Whitechapel, pages 12 and 13, G2 yesterday, was accidentally flipped, to the frustration of those who read Hebrew. Apologies.

In an article about university heads soon to depart we said that two were due to leave on April 31 2001. That would be a day after the month itself ended.

We gave the wrong telephone number for information about the exhibition Art in Sacred Places, at the end of an article on the arts pages, page 13, G2, yesterday. The correct number is 020-7690 4208.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Wanted: a grey leader
fields.trailText: Your leader (May 30) urges Age Concern, Help the Aged and Saga to unite to further the cause of pensioners. As a recently retired charity administrator with experience of dealing with all these organisations, I do not have the remotest hope that they will ever consider surrendering their individual identities - charities are notorious for guarding their independence.
fields.body:
Your leader (May 30) urges Age Concern, Help the Aged and Saga to unite to further the cause of pensioners. As a recently retired charity administrator with experience of dealing with all these organisations, I do not have the remotest hope that they will ever consider surrendering their individual identities - charities are notorious for guarding their independence.

What we need urgently is an altogether new organisation to advance the current assertion of grey power. Barbara Castle would have been the ideal person to summon a national convention to bring this about but, sadly, she has told me that, in her present state of health, she could not undertake this. Perhaps Professor Peter Townsend or Lord Young, or both, would consider taking on this role? If we miss this opportunity we will have only ourselves to blame when successive governments treat us as unwanted guests and throw crumbs at us from their table.
Steve Dey
Dousland, Devon

 There is already an alternative, which is a website with an email support group, where people can plan their campaigns: www.60-plus.co.uk
Janet Dixon
Bristol
Jan@60-plus.co.uk

 Over 2,000 participants at our recent Blackpool parliament called for a substantial increase to the state pension and the restoration of its link with average earnings as the only way to ensure that all older people share in the increasing prosperity of the nation.

We will continue to campaign for this.
Jack Jones
National Pensioners' Convention

fields.headline: A very minor triumph
fields.standfirst:
Most Scots spurned the Section 28 poll

More about section 28
fields.trailText: Brian Souter, the Perth transport tycoon, says he does not hate those with "homosexual lifestyles". Perhaps not, but a good number of his allies in fighting repeal of Section 28, as it is commonly known in Scotland, have outed themselves as intolerant bigots.
fields.body:
Brian Souter, the Perth transport tycoon, says he does not hate those with "homosexual lifestyles". Perhaps not, but a good number of his allies in fighting repeal of Section 28, as it is commonly known in Scotland, have outed themselves as intolerant bigots. The Scottish Daily Record, once a progressive newspaper, has wallowed in anti-gay prejudice. Cardinal Thomas Winning has abandoned one set of prejudices (against presbyterians) for the sake of another, in favour of holy heterosexualism.

Now, in Mr Souter's private poll, 1.1m Scottish residents have joined them as opponents of the mild reform proposed by the Scottish Labour-Liberal Democrat executive. Not all of these people are haters, but there are enough of them to dash the hope that devolution and the creation of a Scottish parliament would of themselves serve to renew and refresh a nation. In "modern" Scotland, it seems, illiberal views verging on the medieval are still widely held.

But Wendy Alexander and her cabinet colleagues (in the absence of the convalescing Donald Dewar) must stick to their guns. This free enterprise referendum is no more than a one-off, inconclusive poll. The don't knows (two thirds of those who were sent ballots abstained) hugely outnumber the know-alls. Adding abstainers and pro-repeal voters gets you to nearly three quarters of adult Scots. Yet even if the Souter poll were a reliable guide, here is an issue which touches on what Scotland is to become. Section 28 has never made much day-to-day-difference to the way children are educated, north or south. Its weight comes from the homophobic circumstances in which it was conceived and the prejudiced world view of those who oppose its repeal. Demolishing it clears space to build a more tolerant, freer country. Members of the Scottish parliament, yesterday labelled "isolated and extreme" by Mr Souter, must now speak for Scotland's future and press on at once with repeal.
