fields.headline: A chance for all talents
fields.standfirst: Class war? No, a mandate for opportunity
fields.trailText: John Prescott too is an Oxford man. One of his former tutors later recalled him as the incarnation of Jude the Obscure, with a tremendous appetite for learning, fiercely independent opinions, and a determination to crack the secret of knowledge.
fields.body:
John Prescott too is an Oxford man. One of his former tutors later recalled him as the incarnation of Jude the Obscure, with a tremendous appetite for learning, fiercely independent opinions, and a determination to crack the secret of knowledge. His essays - long, but not always grammatical- always had something urgent to say. And like all the best students he revelled in argument. His college, though, was not Magdalen, but Ruskin, which over the years picked up so many talented people who, like Mr Prescott, left school at 15 and went out to work. Raphael Samuel's model student moved on not to Balliol or Magdalen but to Hull.

Mr Prescott alluded briefly to Ruskin as he sought in a speech at Gillingham yesterday to make sense of the party's sudden excitement over Magdalen's rejection of the Tyneside schoolgirl, Laura Spence. On the facts of that decision, the Chancellor, Gordon Brown, whose outburst last week made her case headline news, was probably wrong: the students whom the college chose ahead of her were not the sons and daughters of privilege. But on the underlying issue he sought to dramatise - the persistent tendency in Britain for the privileged to outpace the less privileged - Mr Brown was entirely right. Of course there has been progress since John Prescott left school at 15. Of course the proportion of state school children getting to Oxbridge is edging up. And yet, as we noted on Saturday, private school products account for one third of students achieving three As at A level, but occupy half of all places at Oxbridge. Nor is this just about Oxbridge. Other universities of high academic achievement also suffer from this imbalance. And this kind of social injustice is by no means confined to the universities. The commanding heights of great institutions like the law and poli tics show much the same kind of bias, above all against women and ethnic minorities. fields.headline: Mahmoud el-Zou'bi
fields.standfirst: Politician brought low by Byzantine power struggle of Syrian politics
fields.trailText: A single gunshot to the head ended the life of Mahmoud el-Zou'bi, aged 62, and, until two months ago, Syria's prime minister for 13 years.
fields.body:
A single gunshot to the head ended the life of Mahmoud el-Zou'bi, aged 62, and, until two months ago, Syria's prime minister for 13 years. Official sources said he killed himself at home, as he was about to be charged with "economic irregularities and abuses".

Zou'bi had previously been considered a close ally of President Hafez el-Assad and a trustworthy steward of the Syrian economy. But in March, he and most of his cabinet were summarily sacked. Earlier this month, he was expelled from the ruling Ba'ath party and charged with "behaviour that seriously harmed the image of the state" - ironically, Zou'bi had replaced the previous prime minister, Abd el-Raoufel-Kasm, on precisely the same grounds. His assets were seized, and his sons were accused of corruption.

Initially something of a backroom manager in Syrian politics, Zou'bi gained prominence when the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 forced Syria to open up its economy. He communicated regularly with Arab neighbours, bargained with officials from the European Union, World Bank and Arab Fund for Economic Development, and sought to attract private investment through a major economic package in 1994, particularly targeted at wealthy Syrian expatriates.

That same year, the EU lifted its arms embargo on Syria. But no amount of soothing noises could persuade potential investors to risk losing all in the economy's bureaucratic morass. Roads were in a parlous state, private banks did not exist, possessing foreign currency was a crime and funds needed for schools and hospitals went to the military. Thousands fled Syria for jobs in Lebanon. By 1999, exports had dropped by 20% and agricultural production had halved.

Zou'bi was born in the village of Kherbit Gazaleh, near the Jordan border, and trained as an agronomist. He became information minister after the Ba'ath coup of 1966 swept into power hitherto neglected rural Sunni Muslims like himself. Yet he realised that the real masters of Syria were the Alawites, a minority sect despised by the urban Sunni elite. While Sunnis formally run most major ministries, Alawites dominate Syria's more important security network.

Zou'bi's fortunes improved after Assad's palace coup of 1970 and his "corrective revolution" of 1971. He became speaker of the people's assembly in the difficult years between 1981 and 1987. In 1982, security forces crushed a Sunni Muslim Brotherhood revolt in the city of Hama, at the cost of up to 15,000 lives. Then, in 1983, the president's younger brother, Rifaat, tried to stage a coup of his own.

Feelings were still raw in 1987, when Assad appointed Zou'bi as premier. His first task was to restore unity within the Ba'ath apparatus. In March 1967, two months before the six-day war, he had said: "There is no alternative for the Arabs but to liquidate Israel or be liquidated by her". And indeed, he played no obvious role in the peace negotiations with Israel after 1991.

Curiously, Zou'bi appeared to be gaining in stature just before he was axed. He negotiated with premiers, presidents and other senior figures from Iran, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Lebanon, Spain, the Emirates, Sudan, Cyprus and China. He championed ideas of an Arab common market, and opened the first Arab tourism conference in Damascus. A year before his dismissal, he launched an export bank and chaired the influential Ba'ath regional command.

He also helped end the years of mutual recrimination between Syria and Jordan that followed Amman's peace treaty with Israel in 1994. In April last year, he facilitated a historic first meeting between Jordan's new monarch, King Abdullah, and Bashar el-Assad, the Syrian president's son and heir apparent. In May, he dis cussed plans for a joint dam project on the Yarmouk river. In August, he chaired a joint economic committee in Amman.

When Muhammad Mustafa Miru replaced Zou'bi as Syria's premier, some wondered whether it was a sign that the country was softening its stance on talks with Israel. In fact, Zou'bi fell victim to a power struggle over who would succeed the ailing President Assad. Clearly, the leading aspirant, Bashar el-Assad, had engineered the purge. He publicly demanded "new blood", and Miru is his protege. He even recruited Zou'bi as a co-conspirator, by getting him to sack 10 directors of state institutions on grounds of corruption in December.

For all his faults, Zou'bi was diligent, pro-active and, in his own way, a dedicated patriot. His career and fate is a reminder of the fickleness and fragility of political power in Syria.

He is survived by his wife, two sons and a daughter.

Lawrence Joffe

webTitle: As red hand gang flies the flag, an unruffled Martin McGuinness goes back to schools

fields.headline: As red hand gang flies the flag, an unruffled Martin McGuinness goes back to schools
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The IRA's former chief of staff arrived back at operational headquarters in what was once enemy territory on Northern Ireland's staunchly pro-British Gold Coast yesterday to find that his old foes had been hard at work.
fields.body:
The IRA's former chief of staff arrived back at operational headquarters in what was once enemy territory on Northern Ireland's staunchly pro-British Gold Coast yesterday to find that his old foes had been hard at work.

Loyalists had scrambled up ladders overnight to unfurl the union flag, the red hand of Ulster, and the Ulster Volunteer Force's purple standard on the dozen street-lamps around Rathgale House, home to the Department of Education in Northern Ireland. They appeared to have starched the flags, so averting any danger of their hanging limply in the Co Down resort of Bangor.

A woman outside the perimeter fence, waiting for a bus, was the sole protester as Martin McGuinness, newly reinstalled, arrived in a battered Sinn Fein estate car to take up where he left off in February as minister for education. "Scumbag, McGuinness," she shouted, twice, but with only half a heart. He affected not to hear her as he addressed the media with honeyed sentiments.

Compliment

Mr McGuinness, 50, shrugged off the UVF's nocturnal activities. He used to be enraged when the RUC found out about funeral arrangements for republicans in his native Londonderry and turned up in force. He then realised that the deceased would see the police presence as some sort of tribute, and so, he chortled yesterday, he viewed the flags as a back-handed compliment.

Devolved government returned to Northern Ireland yesterday for the second time in seven months. There was less excitement than last December, except perhaps for the education minister.

Apart from Peter Robinson and Nigel Dodds of the Democratic Unionist party, ministers were back at work. They appeared determined to make the most of the last chance for the Good Friday agreement.

The DUP was due to decide last night whether it would take up its two ministerial portfolios, regional development and social development. Members were meeting to consider whether they might best pursue the party's avowed aim to destroy the two-year-old agreement by staying away. Under the rules, its places would then go to the Ulster Unionist party and the Alliance party.

It was clear yesterday that a tough time lay ahead. The first battle will be over the controversial flags issue, with the union flag due to fly over government buildings on Friday, Coronation Day. So tomorrow's first meeting of the 12-member power-sharing executive promises to be stormy.

Contrast

The rows over the policing bill continue. The SDLP is bemoaning a lack of access to Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, since a heated meeting a couple of weeks back, and senior Labour figures are promising amendments to effect Chris Patten's recommendations in full.

Mr McGuinness skipped happily out of the old Granada, a marked contrast to the plush chauffeur-driven Volvo in which a government press officer had earlier arrived. He flung his jacket over his back, adorned with green circular badge representing not some republican cause but an NSPCC campaign, and trumpeted: "It's great to be back."

As part of the IRA's terror campaign, which was to claim almost 1,800 lives, Mr McGuinness masterminded the bombings that devastated Londonderry, his home town, during the worst days of the Troubles. But yesterday he appeared to be interested only in building bridges.

Mr McGuinness spoke of the great challenges ahead, and how he wanted to work even with the DUP. He would keep extending the hand of friendship, he said, until its leading figures finally came to accept him. It was time to convince the doubters that politics worked.

Then it was a handshake and quick hello with Nigel Hamilton, his permanent secretary, just back from holiday. They had an excellent relationship during the short-lived previous executive, and Mr Hamilton made no repeat of his courteous gaffe last December when he had to be told: "It's Martin, not Minister."

There was then a scramble to the lifts of the 1960s office block, as he moved to his modest office on the seventh floor overlooking the corrugated iron roofs of the Balloo Road industrial estate.

Mr McGuinness, a father of four and grandfather, was like a gleeful child as resumed his position behind his desk, swinging on what he called his fancy chair. He looked even happier than he did last time round, and that was because, with the IRA decommissioning issue resolved, he could spend more time on getting down to wrestling with the 11-plus and crumbling buildings.

His department, with its £1.4bn budget, is second in spending terms to health, the fiefdom of his Sinn Fein colleague Bairbre de Brun, which has £1.9bn at its disposal each year. Together they are responsible for more than half the funds available to the executive.

In Mr McGuinness's four-month absence, his officials had had framed a colourful abstract painting of smiling faces and hung it behind his desk. The children of Templemore primary in Londonderry had given it to him, and he was delighted with his staff's gesture.

Unionists suspect that Mr McGuinness, twice jailed in the Irish Republic for IRA membership, might back away from the sentiments behind his best wishes to all ministers, including Messrs Robinson and Dodds. They are aware that the most persuasive arguments of anti-agreement unionists against a return to government were that it would mean that a former terrorist was back in charge of children's education.

They concede that he gave money to integrated education and unveiled a £72m funding package, giving a fair share to Protestant schools, but they were worried that his last move on the day before suspension was to set up a promotional body for Irish-medium education. They also complained about what they saw as his boast, during a primary school visit, of his life on the run.

Mr McGuinness's tenure last time prompted pupil demonstrations in several schools across Northern Ireland, though the suspicion was that hardline unionists had helped orchestrate them. He had asked some of them in for orange juice and tea, and they had had a good discussion.

Yesterday Mr McGuinness, in his most charming form, said: "There was an at tempt to whip up abuse from rejectionist unionists. This is natural and understandable given what we have all been through in the last 30 years. But people want to look to the future. There is a bright future ahead."

fields.headline: Britain cleans up its beaches
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's beaches and bathing areas have passed a landmark in cleanliness and won a record number of coveted blue flags.
fields.body:
Britain's beaches and bathing areas have passed a landmark in cleanliness and won a record number of coveted blue flags.

For the first time Britain has passed the point of 90% compliance with mandatory European cleanliness standards.

But 46 of the country's 541 beaches, including ones in Blackpool and Southport - two of the most popular holiday resorts - remain below par, according to the annual report by the European Commission, published in Brussels yesterday.

Overall, Britain gets good marks for steady improvements, producing an overall compliance figure of 91.5%, on the basis of data supplied to the commission by the environment agency.

Last year the number of British beaches failing minimum EU water standards also dropped steeply to 80 - 11% of those tested - from 115 in 1998.

According to the Tidy Britain Group, which awards the blue flags, Britain's new record of 57 award winners is up 16 on last year's total, leaving it ninth in the European league of clean beaches.

The commission findings place it lower, at 13th out of the 15 member states, slightly ahead of Finland and Sweden, at 84.5% compliance the worst offender.

According to the commission, below standard British beaches include Exmouth, Instow and Westward Ho in Devon, Bembridge, Isle of Wight, Southsea in Hampshire, Cleethorpes in Humberside, and South Shields, Tyne and Wear. Three out of four Blackpool beaches are also listed.

According to Tidy Britain, Britain's improvement was bettered only by Portugal, which has 24 more blue flags than last year. Of the British total, Wales made the most progress, doubling last year's total to 22 flags.

Scotland has also improved, with just one award winner in 1999 but three this year.

Twenty-four beaches in England made the grade, up one on last year. Northern Ireland has eight award-winning beaches, up two on last year.

webTitle: High-risk Down's mothers given all-clear by mistake

fields.headline: High-risk Down's mothers given all-clear by mistake
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Computer software faults have led to 154 pregnant women being wrongly told that they had a low risk of giving birth to a Down's syndrome baby, when in fact they were in the NHS high-risk category.
fields.body:
Computer software faults have led to 154 pregnant women being wrongly told that they had a low risk of giving birth to a Down's syndrome baby, when in fact they were in the NHS high-risk category.

Hospital blood tests on the women, mostly aged over 35, were misread for four months by computers at the Northern General hospital in Sheffield before the error was spotted.

An investigation has been launched into why it took a routine audit to uncover the mistake, which has affected women in the 18th to 35th weeks of pregnancy.

The hospital's NHS trust apologised yesterday and said terminations were still possible for some women likely to give birth to severely handicapped babies, even if they had passed the normal 24-week period.

All the women affected, who have been receiving antenatal care at Barnsley, Chesterfield, Doncaster, Grimsby, Rotherham, Scunthorpe, Sheffield and Worksop, have been contacted and offered further tests and clinical support.

John Watts, acting chief executive of the Northern General NHS trust, said: "This is a most unfortunate incident. It does not follow that the women concerned will give birth to a Down's syndrome baby, but they are at a higher risk of doing so."

It was made clear that the risk was still small. Nationally, 1.3 women per 1,000 in the high-risk category go on to have a Down's syndrome baby, a proportion that increases gradually with a mother's age.

The mistakes were made at the department of immunology, where the women were routinely blood-tested between the 14th and 18th weeks of pregnancy.

The hospital said yesterday that patients who had had the more rigorous testing by amniocentesis were not affected by the error.

Mr Watts said: "The correct information was punched in after the blood tests, but because of the software faults, the numbers being pushed out were very different. The inquiry will ensure we can put in place procedures to stop this happening again." The results will be made public.

The inquiry will be supervised by the Trent NHS regional director of public health, Lindsey Davies, and its results will be made public.

The Northern General's medical director, Colin Hardisty, said: "This only affects a small number of the people who were tested, but on behalf of the trust I would like to sincerely apologise to all the women and their families for whom this will have caused anxiety and concern. Our prime concern is to ensure these women are now seen speedily."

Debra Royston, 32, from Firth Park, Sheffield, said: "It's like a bomb has been dropped on us. I got a letter at 17 weeks saying I was low risk and we thought everything was OK. Now I have been told I am a high risk, with a one in 150 chance of the baby being born with Down's syndrome.

"The amniocentesis test is safer the earlier it is carried out. If I had the test now I risk losing a perfectly healthy baby."

She and her partner, Carl Bateley, have yet to decide whether to take the test, but are considering legal action against the hospital. Their baby is due in the autumn.

John Watts, acting chief executive of the Northern General NHS trust, said: "This is a most unfortunate incident. It does not follow that the women concerned will give birth to a Down's syndrome baby, but they are at a higher risk of doing so." It was made clear that the risk was still small. Nationally, 1.3 women per 1,000 in the high-risk category go on to have a Down's syndrome baby, a proportion that increases gradually with a mother's age. The mistakes were made at the department of immunology, where the women were routinely blood-tested between the 14th and 18th weeks of pregnancy. The hospital said yesterday that patients who had had the more rigorous testing by amniocentesis were not affected by the error. Mr Watts said: "The correct information was punched in after the blood tests, but because of the software faults, the numbers being pushed out were very different. The inquiry will be supervised by the Trent NHS regional director of public health, Lindsey Davies, and its results will be made public. The Northern General's medical director, Colin Hardisty, said: "This only affects a small number of the people who were tested, but on behalf of the trust I would like to sincerely apologise to all the women and their families for whom this will have caused anxiety and concern. Our prime concern is to ensure these women are now seen speedily." Debra Royston, 32, from Firth Park, Sheffield, said: "It's like a bomb has been dropped on us. fields.headline: Claud Morris
fields.standfirst: Behind-the-scenes mover for Middle East peace
fields.trailText: Claud Morris, who has died aged 80, was a tireless networker for peace in the Middle East.
fields.body:
Claud Morris, who has died aged 80, was a tireless networker for peace in the Middle East. Watching him work a huge reception was an awesome sight. He seemed to know everyone and had the ability to spot and engage the powerful rather like a heat-seeking missile. He could never understand why men of goodwill could not sit down together and debate rationally.

This was the culmination of more than 20 years' experience writing and publishing in the region. In 1989 he founded the Next Century Foundation to hold informal meetings between Arabs and Jews - long before the Madrid peace conference and the Oslo talks got going.

In 1991, he masterminded a meeting at Chatsworth House - the home of the Duke of Devonshire, then a member of the foundation's advisory board - which was attended by Israeli parliamentarians, Arab ministers and ambassadors, former British and Irish ministers and prominent members of the Jewish and Arab communities in Britain. More than 100 pol- icemen stalked the grounds in the cause of security.

After supper, Professor George Steiner elegantly traced the history of the Arab-Israeli conflict, and the duke put on display his letters and first editions of TE Lawrence. Three days later, the Madrid peace conference started, and Arab and Israeli foundation members were selected as negotiators, both there and, later, in Washington.

Morris had been an editor, Fleet Street columnist and publisher for most of his life, devoted to getting his views broadcast to the widest possible audience. But when it came to the foundation, he shunned publicity; partici- pants were guaranteed total secrecy, so sworn enemies could sit down together confident that nothing would leak to the press.

He was not without his critics. Yosef Yaakov wrote in the Jerusalem Post of the foundation's aim as "interesting western liberals, Arab moderates and Israeli doves to take part in its confidential peace-seeking discussions" and dismissed Morris as a pro-Arab lobbyist. Morris also fell out with Lord Mayhew, to whom he lost his publication, Middle East International - presumably for not being pro-Arab enough.

Sir David Gore-Booth, Britain's former ambassador to Saudi Arabia, was a longtime supporter and remembers Morris as a remarkable man. "There are far too few people who have a vision of how people should behave towards each other," he said. "He did his best to put them together."

Morris knew, and had interviewed, virtually every Arab leader, including King Faisal, President Numeiri of Sudan, Colonel Gadaffi of Libya and Sheik Zayed of Abu Dhabi.

He was born in Cornwall, left school at 13 and began writing immediately for the Cornishman. Later, as a Daily Mirror political writer in the 1950s, he became a close friend of Sir Stafford Cripps and Aneurin Bevan. In 1952, he left Fleet Street to set up his own independent paper, the South Wales Voice, a campaigning weekly which succeeded in getting pensions for miners increased by £1 a week. It closed after a mysterious fire burned out the press, after Morris had started printing a newspaper for a Palestinian group.

As a journalist-turned- proprietor, Morris's heart was always in storytelling. Even when he recalled past plots and business duplicity of long ago, he could always recall a relevant detail, drop a telling quote and tell a good anecdote. His house in Vincent Square, central London, was a hospitable salon for anyone interested in Middle East politics. The title of his book, The Last Inch, is taken from Solzhenitsyn's The First Circle - "the aim is not to finish the job quickly but to reach perfection".

Morris died after a series of strokes in the Cornish cottage in which he was born. His wife, Patricia, also a distinguished writer on the Arab world, was with him at the end. They had been married for more than 50 years, in a loving partnership underpinned by a deep religious faith. He is survived by two daughters, Ann and Margaret, five grandchildren and his son William, who is carrying on the work of the foundation.

Russell Twisk

webTitle: Glory days 63 years after the Hindenburg disaster

fields.headline: Glory days 63 years after the Hindenburg disaster
fields.standfirst: Germany invents a safer airship
fields.trailText: A company which plans to produce an airship with twice the volume of the ill-fated Zeppelin launched on the Frankfurt stock exchange yesterday.
fields.body:
A company which plans to produce an airship with twice the volume of the ill-fated Zeppelin launched on the Frankfurt stock exchange yesterday.

The launch went ahead despite red tape and technical problems which could prevent the new airship - which will fly freight around the world - from leaving the ground.

CargoLifter AG's airship, which is scheduled to be airborne by 2003, will be capable of lifting the equivalent of 10 fully loaded trucks. The German company, whose headquarters are on a former Soviet airfield outside Berlin, raised £75m from the launch.

CargoLifter's managing director, Carl von Gablenz, said yesterday that the planned airship amounted to a technical wonder that would put German engineering at the forefront of air transport innovation.

The stock market launch came 63 years after one of the original Zeppelins, the Hindenburg, burst into flames while landing in New Jersey and crashed, killing 36 passengers and crew. That tragedy ended the further development of airships as a serious form of commercial air transport.

CargoLifter plans to avoid the dangers inherent to the original Zeppelins by filling its airships with inert helium gas instead of highly flammable hydrogen. The company, which envisages a fleet of up to 200 craft, says its airships will have a range of some 6,000 miles, enabling them to cross the Atlantic.

The company believes the key to the airships' eventual success will be their ability to pick up and unload cargoes without touching down. It says that being able to fly heavy machinery around the world quickly and at minimum cost will solve a perennial problem.

A prototype has been constructed, but technical and bureaucratic problems may prevent them from taking off at all. Because of their size - each craft will be 260 metres long - CargoLifter is not certain that German or international air transport authorities will grant them permission to fly.

Wind resistance is another problem - the constructors have yet to prove that crew and cargo would not be exposed to serious risk in a real gale - and supply of helium could prove difficult.

German banks have warned that the project is a highly speculative investment, but Mr von Gablenz said yesterday that he was confident that every stumbling block would be overcome in time for the launch.

fields.headline: Raymond Hayes
fields.trailText: Visits to the Yorkshire archaeologist and photographer Raymond Hayes, who has died aged 90, were voyages of discovery, yielding new information on sites and anecdotes on people past, and present. In an amateur capacity, he directed archaeological work of all periods, usually working with a group of friends and minimal resources - and he published the results.
fields.body:
Visits to the Yorkshire archaeologist and photographer Raymond Hayes, who has died aged 90, were voyages of discovery, yielding new information on sites and anecdotes on people past, and present. In an amateur capacity, he directed archaeological work of all periods, usually working with a group of friends and minimal resources - and he published the results.

There were contributions to the History Of Rievaulx And District (1963), Wade's Causeway: A Roman Road In North-East Yorkshire (1964); and Rosedale Mines And Railway (1974). His 1988 monograph, North-East Yorkshire Studies, covered subjects of all periods, from Mesolithic flints to post-medieval pottery kilns. There were also two scholarly local histories, on Rosedale and Hutton-le-Hole.

Raymond worked with many leading archaeologists. His knowledge of his beloved north York moors allowed him to introduce Professor Geoffrey Dimbleby to sites that were crucial in the latter's pioneering analysis of pollen from archaeological sites.

As a skilled photographer, he assisted on many excavations from the mid-1930s. In 1947, he worked on the town-house site in Malton, and the photographs he took 11 years later of the excavations at the Roman town of Cataractonium (Catterick) now represent almost the only record of that work.

From the mid-1940s, he was associated with Malton museum. He assisted with its collections, undertook excavations and watching briefs, notably in Norton, where, with Sir Edward Whitley, he excavated Roman kilns of the 3rd century.

Raymond was born in York, the only son of a professional photographer who moved to Hutton-le-Hole on the north York moors. After attending the local village school, he was associated with the family photography business for more than two decades, until, during the second world war, he began to supplement his income by taking work as the Hutton postman. The contacts he built up gave him unrivalled access to regional sites, and the opportunity to pursue an interest in archaeology sparked at lectures by Wilfred Crosland and Philip Corder.

A founding member of the Helmsley Archaeological Society, he taught evening classes around the north York moors, and received many honours, including an MBE. In 1995, a collection of papers on the archaeology of north-east York shire, Moorland Monuments, honoured Raymond and his friend and collaborator, the late Don Spratt.

Raymond had a great generosity of spirit, freely assisting researchers and students. Innumerable publications have benefited from his photographs. His own published work comprises 90 monographs, articles and extended notes.

His archaeological and photographic archive is now housed at the Ryedale Folk museum, of which he was a founder.

Pete Wilson

fields.headline: Nicholas Clay
fields.standfirst: Swashbuckling actor who conquered theatre, film and television
fields.trailText: Nicholas Clay, who has died of cancer aged 53, was a superb Lancelot in John Boorman's film Excalibur (1981), a prominent player during Sir Laurence Olivier's golden Old Vic period in the 1970s, a television star, and an actor who loved teaching - and was good at it.
fields.body:
Nicholas Clay, who has died of cancer aged 53, was a superb Lancelot in John Boorman's film Excalibur (1981), a prominent player during Sir Laurence Olivier's golden Old Vic period in the 1970s, a television star, and an actor who loved teaching - and was good at it.

We first met in the early 1970s, at the Old Vic. Nick had named parts, I was "as cast". He was quite the most beautiful man I had ever seen, gallingly handsome and awesomely athletic. Olivier's company enjoyed hit after hit - and Nick was in most of them, notably Jumpers, The Misanthrope, Saturday, Sunday, Monday and Equus. After that, he went with The Misanthrope to Broadway.

His first film had been The Night Digger in 1971. A year later, he played Charles Darwin in The Darwin Adventure, and the decade ended with Zulu Dawn (1979). In the 1980s, he appeared in Lady Chatterley's Lover (1981), Evil Under The Sun (1982), Sleeping Beauty (1987), Lionheart (1987), and, of course, Excalibur. He wore a lot of armour - but that comes with heroic acting, and Nick did that with epic braggadocio. He could swash a buckle.

He also appeared in numerous television series. He was the Earl of Southampton in John Mortimer's William Shakespeare (1978) and starred in Virtual Murder, Picture Of Dorian Gray, The Three Musketeers and Gentlemen And Players, in which he shared top billing with Brian Protheroe. Nancy Banks Smith wrote: "Brian Protheroe looks as if he's been pressed between the leaves of a book. Nicholas Clay looks like he's been hit over the head by a brick." He loved quoting that. Self-deprecation was not a problem.

His stage work continued. There was a world tour of She Stoops To Conquer, and, at Chichester, he played in The Confederacy and A Month In The Country, opposite Dorothy Tutin.

Nick was born in Streatham, south London, to Rose and Bill Clay, a sergeant in the Royal Engineers. After a nomadic army childhood, the family settled in Kent. There is a clan of Clays in Kent - with no tradition of theatre or the performing arts. Dan Willis, a teacher at Upbury Manor school, kick-started Nick's love of theatre and he was soon performing with the Little Medway Theatre Club; he would later become its patron. But his defining moment was seeing Leo McKern in Peer Gynt at the Old Vic. The dye was cast. He worked as a hod carrier for two years to pay his way through the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art; in later years, he became an associate there, active in development and fundraising work.

Nick married Lorna Heilbron, a psychotherapist and actress, in 1980, and they had a daughter, Ella. After our Old Vic period, we had drifted apart for a bit. Our friendship rekindled and developed at about the time his second daughter, Madge, was born, 14 years ago. He and Lorna had been visiting Gillian Barge at her cottage at Sibton, in Suffolk; I was there as her partner.

He loved nature, and he loved that place. It suited his spiritual and practical sides. He was a very practical man, a collector of tools that he could use expertly. His favoured charity was the John Muir Trust For The Conservation Of Wild And Open Spaces.

Lately, Nick had been terrific as Ernest in Design For Living. It transferred from the Donmar Warehouse to the Gielgud theatre. Last year, he appeared in Max Gold's 50 Revolutions at the Whitehall. It was interesting, experimental stuff. He was a regular in Channel 4's Psychos, quite the most interesting drama series of last year. He was doing a lot of teaching at the Actors Centre and the Academy Of Live And Performing Arts.

Nicky faced his illness with enormous bravery, as I knew he would, without self-pity, sentimentality or "why me?" anger. He was open and candid about it, and thrilled when he heard that his old school was naming its new arts facility the Nicholas Clay Centre. He was a lovely man, and I am a better person for having known him.

At the end of Le Morte D'Arthur, Sir Ector Maris addresses the corpse of his friend and brother, Lancelot: "Thou were the courtliest knight that ever bare shield; and thou were the truest friend to thy lover that ever bestrode horse . . . and thou were the kindest man that ever strake with sword; and thou were the goodliest person ever came among the press of knights . . . Then there was weeping and dolour out of measure"

Nick is survived by Lorna, their two daughters and his mother, Rose.

Clive Merrison

Nicholas Anthony Phillip Clay, actor, born September 18 1946; died May 25 2000

webTitle: Ronaldo's fans get lost in cyberspace

fields.headline: Ronaldo's fans get lost in cyberspace
fields.trailText: The publishers of a new computer game starring the Brazilian football star Ronaldo tried yesterday to buy the Ronaldo internet site from a American computer programmer for £100,000.
fields.body:
The publishers of a new computer game starring the Brazilian football star Ronaldo tried yesterday to buy the Ronaldo internet site from a American computer programmer for £100,000.

Thousands of Ronaldo fans from around the world surf the www.ronaldo.com site every day only to discover that it is owned by a programmer, Ronaldo Nascimento.

Now Infogrames, the producers of a new Brazilian soccer PlayStation game, are trying to buy the domain name for the footballer.

It admitted that thousands of pounds in revenue are being lost through the confusion.

A spokesman said: "Anyone searching for information on Ronaldo, whether it is about the forthcoming PlayStation game or any other related merchandise, is automatically going to www.ronaldo.com."

He added: "If we don't secure the name in the next two weeks, we are going to have to spend considerably more on internet advertising than we would have done if we had owned www.ronaldo.com. We hope Mr Nascimento will take the offer seriously."

The spokesman said Infogrames has offered £100,000 to Mr Nascimento for the domain name. "We understand from him that he has held this name for his own business since 1996 and being that it is his first name, it is purely coincidental."

Mr Nascimento has no interest in football and lists as his interests computer games and Star Wars.

"Cybersquatters" have become a major problem on the information superhighway - they register the name of a website that mimics a well known brand or company name in a bid to sell the rights to the company when it wants to set up a website.

In March the owner of Harrods, Mohamed Al Fayed, won the rights to the website name dodialfayed.com after a United Nations trademark body ruled that Robert Boyd from Dayton, Ohio had no legitimate interest in owning his late son's name.

fields.bodyText: The publishers of a new computer game starring the Brazilian football star Ronaldo tried yesterday to buy the Ronaldo internet site from a American computer programmer for £100,000. Thousands of Ronaldo fans from around the world surf the www.ronaldo.com site every day only to discover that it is owned by a programmer, Ronaldo Nascimento. Now Infogrames, the producers of a new Brazilian soccer PlayStation game, are trying to buy the domain name for the footballer. It admitted that thousands of pounds in revenue are being lost through the confusion. A spokesman said: "Anyone searching for information on Ronaldo, whether it is about the forthcoming PlayStation game or any other related merchandise, is automatically going to www.ronaldo.com." He added: "If we don't secure the name in the next two weeks, we are going to have to spend considerably more on internet advertising than we would have done if we had owned www.ronaldo.com. We hope Mr Nascimento will take the offer seriously." The spokesman said Infogrames has offered £100,000 to Mr Nascimento for the domain name. "We understand from him that he has held this name for his own business since 1996 and being that it is his first name, it is purely coincidental." fields.headline: Purse strings
fields.standfirst: Are public institutions spending our money wisely? John Garrett on how treasury interference in the state audit undermines accountability
fields.trailText: Are public institutions spending our money wisely? John Garrett on how treasury interference in the state audit undermines accountability
fields.body:
The treasury has always had it in for our state audit body - formerly the Exchequer and Audit Department, now the National Audit Office (NAO), headed by the comptroller and auditor general.

Over the last 140 years, the treasury has sought to sideline state audit, render it ineffective, diminish it. From the 1940s to the 1980s, the treasury denied the constitutional status of the audit and effectively took control of it.

In all that time, neither parliament nor the Public Accounts Committee (PAC) raised a murmur of protest about this constitutional assault. It took a couple of outsiders to run a campaign for nearly two decades before the state audit was restored to parliament in 1984.

Now, I see, the treasury is up to its old tricks again, with the government resources and accounts bill, which transforms a number of functions currently audited by the NAO into PFI-type service providers which are not auditable by the NAO.

In a masterly comparative study of the state audit arrangements written by the late Dr EFL Normanton in 1966, it was pointed out that, in Britain, audit was more under the control of our finance ministry than in any other western country. The treasury nominated the comptroller and auditor general, usually from its own ranks. The treasury also determined the form of accounts to be audited, and the audit covered only half of public spending.

British auditors were the least qualified (school-leavers, as against graduates and post-graduates); their status and careers were at a level in the public service "unquestionably the lowest of any major country in the western world". Normanton's work prompted no interest in parliament whatsoever.

I got elected to parliament in 1974 and hammered away at the faults in our audit arrangements for the next two decades, exploiting my membership of the treasury select committee and the great reforming procedure committee of 1977-78. In the course of this campaign - of which I was the only member for 17 years, being joined in the last few years by Robert Sheldon, Joel Barnett, Edward du Cann and, fatefully, Norman St John Stevas - I did some historical research.

As part of Gladstone's reforms, the Public Accounts Committee was created in 1861 and the Exchequer and Audit Department, in 1866. The 1866 act said that every appropriation (that is, out-turn) account should be examined by the comptroller "on behalf of the House of Commons".

This legislation was referred to the PAC for its committee stage. During it, the comptroller suggested that the act should state that the audit should be conducted according to rules laid down by the House of Commons. The treasury official giving evidence said that was the intent, but that there really was no need to say so in the act.

In a debate on audit in 1903, the comptroller said his task was not only to certify the regularity of expenditure, but to comment on its merits (now forbidden by the legislation). "I am a parliamentary officer," he said. In debates and committee reports on the subject in 1912, 1916, 1921, 1932 and 1946, the status of the CAG, as an officer of parliament, was confirmed.

In 1976-77, I was a member of the expenditure committee and persuaded its general sub-committee to take up Normanton's strictures. In giving evidence to us, the comptroller of the day said: "I am, of course, totally independent, even of parliament." The treasury's observations on the committee report said the CAG "was not subject to directions from any quarter".

The expenditure committee recalled the comptroller for questioning; he now said that his status before the PAC "was that of a witness". Digging himself even deeper, he then wrote a memorandum to the committee saying that his department was "an important instrument of the treasury".

Even a supine parliament had to take notice of the treasury's blatant encroachment on its rights, and audit reform moved up the political agenda, became Labour party policy and was (mostly) achieved by Norman St John Stevas (Lord Fawsley) in his private members' bill, which made it into law in 1983.

I have written elsewhere (Whitehall: Does Parliament Work? Gollancz, 1992) of the establishment's skulduggery in trying to sink Stevas's bill. The chairmen of the nationalised industries, which were brought into the scope of audit, lobbied hard against it - and persuaded their trades unions to do the same.

I was asked to tea by the chancellor and invited to drop the matter because the Queen, who nominally appointed the CAG, would be annoyed. (Some years later, I let it be known that I was considering applying to be comptroller - on the grounds that I knew a great deal about state audit in Britain - as the position was about to be vacated. I was told that the prime minister, as head of the treasury, would not allow my appointment).

The act, however, was still not entirely what we reformers wanted: there were still significant areas of public spending not subject to its audit (for example, social housing, TECs). Its staff, though now mostly qualified or qualifying, do not have the higher degrees of the manager/engineers, accountant/social scientists of, for example, the US General Accounting Office.

Now the government resources and accounts bill has been brought before parliament. Ostensibly designed to put government accounting on an accrual (that is, commercial) basis, this bill will govern much of what the PAC/NAO does and, more important, does not do.

This bill does not allow the NAO statutory access to such new service providers as private contractors and voluntary bodies, which spend billions of public money - managing prisons, for example, and providing New Deal training. It does not allow the state audit of some 60 quangos (such as English Heritage) nor the 200 limited companies established by central government (for example, the student loans company) nor private/public partnerships.

Oddly, while the government insists, under the "best value" proposals, that the local government Audit Commission is to police the performance indicators or output measures of local councils, the NAO is forbidden to do the same for central government departments.

On January 20 this year, the PAC quizzed the chief secretary of the treasury, Andrew Smith, on these matters. "We have to be satisfied... that there was no costly duplication of effort, of scrutiny and audit," he said, urging the committee "not to accept that there was a conspiracy on the part of the people behind me somehow to deflect or obstruct the public interest in proper scrutiny". He went down, babbling.

All that MPs and the PAC need to remember is the great principle that parliament should have the right to audit the use made of every penny of public money voted by parliament. Simple, isn't it?

National Audit Office

HM Treasury

Public Accounts Committee

fields.headline: England 2 - 0 Ukraine
fields.standfirst:
Adams steals the Macca show
Richard Williams' analysis
Real McManaman fails to show
David Lacey on the final 22
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

England
Martyn, Southgate, Adams, Campbell, Beckham, Gerrard, Scholes, McManaman, P. Neville, Shearer, Fowler. Subs: Dyer, Keown, Ferdinand, Barry, Barmby, Phillips, Heskey, Wright.

Ukraine: Kernozenko, Luzhny, Dimitrulin, Vaschuk, Timoshchyuk, Popov, Kandaurov, Holokov, Husin, Shevchenko, Rebrov. Subs: Virt, Levytsky, Zubov, Morov, Mizin, Starostyak, Kovalov, Vorebey.

Referee: L Michel (Slovakia)

1 England kick-off and Beckham makes an early run at the Ukaraine defence as both teams get their legs into gear.
2 Ukraine break into the England half but Adams clears easily.
3 Shevchenko gets into the area but Campbell covers well before England with McManaman. The Real Madrid hero charges off through midfield and slides the ball through to Fowler but he is unable to control the ball.
8 Good work by Shevchenko hands Ukraine a good chance after Sol Campbell loses his man.
8 Oh so close! Scholes comes close after being played in by Fowler when his shot rebpounds of the left-hand post.
10 Shevchenko again the danger man as he skips into the England area with Campbell hot on his heels this time. Campbell maintains composure and burgles Shevchenko when the Ukrainian tries to be a little too fancy.
12 Shevchenko again as he makes space and forces Martyn to dive to his left.
14 Campbell breaks down the left but is hussled off the ball just outside the area. Ukraine clear and break; Rebrov picks up possession 25 yards out and sprays the ball wide to the right but England block well.
17 Ukraine win a corner, Kandaurov takes but England clear well. Shearer finds Beckham on the half-way line, and he in turn sprays the ball all of 40 yards out to the left for McManaman to deliver a poor shot.
24England finding it difficult to maintain any shape as Ukraine continue to show why they should be at Euro 2000/.
25 Scholes and McManaman exchange passes on the edge of the Ukraine area, before Scholes finds Beckham on the right. His cross is measured, but straight at Kernozenko.
29 Neville gets away on the left but his cross from deep is easy for Ukraine.
30 Rebrov looks the part as he hangs back in the Ukraine midfield. He passes to Dimitrulin on the left but his cross towards the advancing Shevchenko is covered well by Gerrard.
32 A superb ball by Adams on the half-way line finds Fowler running into the penalty area but 'keeper Kernozenko, on his first cap, shows great courage to charge out and win the ball.
35 Ukraine win a corner, Shevchenko takes for Popov to head down at the far post, straight at a defender.
38 Beckham shows great anticipation when he dispossesses Dimitrulin deep on the right. He moves up and crosses for one of three red shirts running into the area, but no-one meets the ball cleanly enough to matter.
43 Beckham comes close to finding McManaman with another looping pass across field, but Ukraine make up ground well.
44 England 1 - 0 Ukraine Joy! England win a corner, Shearer heads down, 'keeper Kernozenko makes a mess of things and Fowler pounces for a soft goal on the line.
45 England slow down the pace, keen not to go the way of last Saturday and concede right before the break. They don't. Half-time.

46 Substitution Heskey on for Fowler. Another Liverpool striker gets an interview as Ukraine kick-off the second half.
47 Shevchenko races onto a loose ball in the England area, gets away from Campbell again and shoots straight at Martyn on the near post.
49 Heskey shows early promise as he muscles his way into possession. England knock the ball around the edge of the area but fail to capitalise on the space.
51 Ukraine win a corner after Southgate tackles Shevchenko deep on the left to prevent a cross. Comes to nothing.
52 Gerrard does well to get inside the Ukraine area, spurns the chance for a one-two with Shearer and goes for the shot, but it is easy for Kernozenko.
59 Campbell charges up on the left and gets in a cross from the by-line but it is straight at the 'keeper.
64 Gerrard releases Heskey on the right; he runs into the area but his shot across goal goes wide of the far post.
66 England win a free-kick near the right touchline, Beckham takes, Adams gets up well for the header, Ukraine spoon it clear.
69 England 2 - 0 Ukraine Shearer wins a corner on the left, Beckham takes and very nearly puts it away first time. Kernozenko can only punch out and when the ball falls at Adams' feet, he fires into the far corner of the net.
74 Substitutions Barmby and Barry on for Neville and Scholes.
75 And almost a third. Barmby lights up the field immediately with a slide-rule pass that puts Heskey one on one with Kernozenko - Kernozenko comes off better when Heskey fails to miss him with his shot.
78 Rebrov and Shevchenko again combine to provide an opening; Rebrov's angled pass from the edge of the area clips a defender and runs just behind the unmarked Shevchenko.
81 Shevchenko blows a great chance for Ukraine to get back into the game. He covers half the field, loses the ball, gets it back straight away and then mis-kicks on the edge of the area.
83 Beckham has a crack from distance but the ball flies wide of the far post.
85 Barmby again the provider as he finds McManaman in space on the left of the Ukraine area. McManaman takes too much time and his shot is straight at the 'keeper's legs. England appear to have come alive in the last 10 minutes as many players get the jitters about that final 22.
88 England free-kick from out on the left. Beckham fires it into the area but Ukraine clear.
90 Shearer makes some space for himself and, perhaps hankering after the old days, spurns the assist and shoots... straight at the man in front of him. Ukraine have a late chance. Master of Ukrainian Ceremonies Rebrov picks up possession on the edge of the England area, passes right for the unmarked Shevchenko... offside. Full-time. England 2 - 0 Ukraine

fields.headline: Ukraine's striker for all seasons
fields.standfirst:
Andrei Shevchenko will tonight show Euro 2000 what it is missing, writes Richard Williams
McManaman rewarded with freedom to roam
fields.trailText: Andrei Shevchenko will tonight show Euro 2000 what it is missing, writes Richard Williams.
fields.body:
If the Wembley crowd can tear their eyes away from tonight's final battle for places in England's Euro 2000 squad, they will get a look at the tournament's most significant absentee, a pale marauder whose deadly brilliance made him this season's leading scorer in Serie A.

A year ago, when Andrei Shevchenko joined Milan from Dynamo Kiev, there was no shortage of predictions that the Ukrainian would be the new Marco van Basten, which is precisely the sort of claim that invites the displeasure of the gods. But, with 24 goals in the league, Shevchenko has amply fulfilled that promise.

As the eighth player in Milan's 100-year history to be Italy's leading goalscorer, he takes his place in an illustrious line including Gunnar Nordahl, Jose Altafini, Gianni Rivera and, of course, the great Van Basten himself, whose golden seasons, before his premature retirement, were 1989-90 and 1991-92. Shevchenko is also the first foreigner to win the honour in his debut season in Italy since Michel Platini at Juventus in 1982-83.

Not the least impressive aspect of Shevchenko's feat was the way he scored his goals. In open play six came from his right foot, five from his left and four from his head. One came from a free-kick and eight from penalties. His reliability, too, was exceptional; no other squad member equalled his 32 league appearances during the season.

There is a school of thought which holds that the players produced under the supervision of Valery Lobanovsky at Dynamo Kiev's football academy tend not to settle well when they take up employment abroad - as seems to be the case with Arsenal's Oleg Luzhny, who may also appear tonight. But Shevchenko's immediate success at San Siro constitutes a powerful rebuttal, dispelling the scepticism of those who doubted his ability to prosper when separated from Sergei Rebrov, his fellow Kiev striker.

Shevchenko was born 24 years ago in Yahotine, 70 miles from Kiev, the son of an NCO in the Red Army. Four years later the family moved to a suburb of Kiev and at 10 Andrei joined the Dynamo junior training scheme. A year later he and his schoolmates were evacuated to the Black Sea to avoid contamination from the Chernobyl disaster. At 16 he was a member of the first-team squad and he went on to win four national championships with the club, scoring 60 goals in 118 games. At 17 he made his debut in the European Cup, the competition in which he was to earn worldwide attention thanks to his goalscoring feats against Barcelona in 1998 and Real Madrid in 1999.

Halfway through the 1998-99 season he knew he would be leaving Lobanovsky and moving to Milan, whose president, Silvio Berlusconi, had agreed to pay Kiev a fee of £18m, with a five-year contract worth around £40,000 a week.

Adriano Galliani, Milan's general manager, predicted that "Sheva" would have no trouble settling in. "He's a player who is used to taking part in big games between great teams on the international stage," Galliano said on the eve of the player's home debut last September, "so we're not expecting him to have problems adjusting to the new lifestyle."

Unlike some imports, Shevchenko approached the challenge seriously on all levels. He began taking Italian lessons long before he left Kiev and now speaks it well enough to answer journalists' questions with reasonable fluency. "I can understand everything," he said recently, "but I'm still learning to speak."

At the end of his first season, his impressions of life in Serie A were virtually all positive. "I give Italy 10 out of 10," he told the Gazzetta dello Sport recently, "but not just for the football - for the friendliness, too." His particular friends are Demetrio Albertini, Alessandro Costacurta and Massimo Ambrosini, his room-mate. Tomorrow, he and Costacurta and Christian Panucci - who may soon return to Milan from Internazionale - are travelling to Los Angeles to watch the NBA finals. "Michael Jordan is my idol," Shevchenko says.

His parents live with him in an apartment in central Milan and the hardest part of the process of acclimatisation appears to have been the need to get into the habit of losing matches a bit more frequently.

"With Dynamo Kiev I got used to winning all the time," he said. Milan, who started the season as reigning champions, could finish the campaign no higher than third, despite his goals, although that still gives them automatic qualification for the Champions League for next season.

Until he got into his stride in the red-and-black shirt there were suggestions that his appetite for scoring sometimes took precedence over the need to bring other players into the game. But a player of his type, the successor to the great Kiev forwards Oleg Blokhin and Igor Belanov, will always be accused of egotism when chances are going begging. fields.bodyText: If the Wembley crowd can tear their eyes away from tonight's final battle for places in England's Euro 2000 squad, they will get a look at the tournament's most significant absentee, a pale marauder whose deadly brilliance made him this season's leading scorer in Serie A. A year ago, when Andrei Shevchenko joined Milan from Dynamo Kiev, there was no shortage of predictions that the Ukrainian would be the new Marco van Basten, which is precisely the sort of claim that invites the displeasure of the gods. But, with 24 goals in the league, Shevchenko has amply fulfilled that promise. As the eighth player in Milan's 100-year history to be Italy's leading goalscorer, he takes his place in an illustrious line including Gunnar Nordahl, Jose Altafini, Gianni Rivera and, of course, the great Van Basten himself, whose golden seasons, before his premature retirement, were 1989-90 and 1991-92. Shevchenko is also the first foreigner to win the honour in his debut season in Italy since Michel Platini at Juventus in 1982-83. Not the least impressive aspect of Shevchenko's feat was the way he scored his goals. In open play six came from his right foot, five from his left and four from his head. One came from a free-kick and eight from penalties. His reliability, too, was exceptional; no other squad member equalled his 32 league appearances during the season. There is a school of thought which holds that the players produced under the supervision of Valery Lobanovsky at Dynamo Kiev's football academy tend not to settle well when they take up employment abroad - as seems to be the case with Arsenal's Oleg Luzhny, who may also appear tonight. Shevchenko was born 24 years ago in Yahotine, 70 miles from Kiev, the son of an NCO in the Red Army. A year later he and his schoolmates were evacuated to the Black Sea to avoid contamination from the Chernobyl disaster. He began taking Italian lessons long before he left Kiev and now speaks it well enough to answer journalists' questions with reasonable fluency. "I can understand everything," he said recently, "but I'm still learning to speak." At the end of his first season, his impressions of life in Serie A were virtually all positive. webTitle: McManaman rewarded with freedom to roam

fields.headline: McManaman rewarded with freedom to roam
fields.standfirst:
Keegan gives Real Madrid midfielder a free role against Ukraine
Ukraine's striker for all seasons
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan has decided to give Steve McManaman a free role against Ukraine.
fields.body:
"Freedom!" cried William Wallace in Braveheart before he was decapitated. At Wembley tonight Kevin Keegan will give Steve McManaman his head in the friendly against Ukraine, trusting it will not be handed back on a critical platter.

The freedom of McManaman has become the focal point of England's last serious test before they begin Euro 2000 against Portugal in Eindhoven on Monday week.

The former Liverpool player will be asked to roam as effectively as he did for Real Madrid in the latter stages of the Champions League, and if he can reproduce his form of the final in Paris last Wednesday then Keegan will be entitled to believe that the inspiration so often lacking in England's performances since the last World Cup has been reborn.

"Steve McManaman will get the completely free role," Keegan announced yesterday. "I want him to have a go and do what he's been doing in the last six to eight weeks to the rest of Europe. I think he has earned that chance."

McManaman will not be given a specified role in tonight's line-up. According to Keegan it will be a case of "go where you want, do what you want. I think it takes away something from anybody like him, a free spirit, to stick him out wide on the left, although he could still do it there."

But what about the rest of the England team? Will they be sufficiently cute to bring out those qualities in McManaman so evident against Valencia at the Stade de France and, in the Champions League quarter-finals, Manchester United at Old Trafford? There is no Redondo in Keegan's side, nor is there a Michel Salgado, a Roberto Carlos or a Raul.

McManaman's definition of a free role, moreover, is more specific than that of the England coach. "I think I have suffered from the perception of people who think that all I do is play a free role when I certainly don't," he said.

"If the free role has ever come into existence it is in a three-man midfield where we have all worked very hard for each other. It's just that I have been the one who has pushed forward trying to find the gaps.

"You still have a job to do, still have your opponents to pick up. You can't afford to run here, there and everywhere."

Keegan, on reflection, concurred with this view. "No-body really gets a free role," he said. "It won't be a question of Steve going where he wants and the rest of the team getting the ball to him. But when he starts to run at people and use that tremendous energy he's got he frightens defenders.

"He can do it from wherever he wants against Ukraine. The team will not be built around Steve McManaman, but it will be built in a way where Steve McManaman can express himself."

To give McManaman a free rein, Keegan is expected to play three at the back and four across the middle with McManaman operating behind the two strikers, who look like being Alan Shearer and Robbie Fowler. Michael Owen, like Dennis Wise, will be rested.

Steven Gerrard will win his first full cap, playing alongside Paul Ince or Paul Scholes in central midfield, and Tony Adams will return to the defence unless Keegan feels he does not want to risk the Arsenal man suffering a recurrence of his back injury with the tournament so close.

Gareth Southgate could also return and an appearance by Gareth Barry at some stage should not be ruled out. Nigel Martyn, the second-choice goalkeeper, looks set to be given a run-out. Richard Wright can expect to play against Malta on Saturday.

Shortly after tonight's match Keegan will announce his squad of 22 for Euro 2000, having told the six players who will miss the cut the bad news after training today.

Four are likely to be David James, Rio Ferdinand, Ray Parlour and Jamie Redknapp. The other two will come from Andy Cole, Kevin Phillips, Robbie Fowler, Nick Barmby and Kieron Dyer.

webTitle: Redknapp and Parlour ruled out of Euro 2000

fields.headline: Redknapp and Parlour ruled out of Euro 2000
fields.trailText: Liverpool midfielder Jamie Redknapp's England injury jinx has struck yet again to ensure that he is ruled out of the Euro 2000 finals along with Ray Parlour.
fields.body:
Liverpool midfielder Jamie Redknapp's England injury jinx has struck yet again to ensure that he is ruled out of the Euro 2000 finals along with Ray Parlour.

Redknapp, who missed the last World Cup because of injury and also had his participation at Euro 96 curtailed due to ankle ligament damage, will not travel to the Euro 2000 tournament due to a knee problem.

The England coach said: "Sadly both players, having had a scan, will not be available for Euro 2000." The England coach also revealed that a knee injury was the cause of Parlour's withdrawal.
